SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; INTERCONNECTED POWER SYSTEMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MANITOBA; PEAK LOAD; RELIABILITY; CANADA; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130000* - Hydro Energy; 240100 - Power Systems- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: In many parts of the world, and particularly in North America, the development of remote renewable energy resources has resulted in an improved standard of clean living for the population and an enhanced quality of life. As each stage of development was accomplished in the planning of the reliability of the system, the authors looked at the possibilities of interconnecting with adjacent power systems. In the early 1950s, the interconnection of two power companies in Manitoba was accomplished, followed with a very low capacity interconnection with the Ontario Hydro Northwest region. The capacity of interconnections from Manitoba are in excess of 60 percent of the peak load of the Manitoba system and are expected to increase in the future. The authors want to generalize here by saying that the reliability of any system would be improved if it has interconnections of capacity equal to the connected load of the system as each new interconnection was added, the security of the system was improved. When the 500 kV interconnection was added, the security of the system was greatly enhanced.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Power Engineering Review (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Power Engineering Review (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: Reservoir systems analysis; Closing gap between theory and practice
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; WATER RESOURCES; RESOURCE MANAGEMENT; DECISION MAKING; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPTIMIZATION; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; ENGINEERING; MANAGEMENT; RESOURCES; 290400* - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Resources; 540310 - Environment, Aquatic- Basic Studies- (1990-); 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 990200 - Mathematics & Computers
DESCRIPTION: During the past three decades, the application of the systems approach to reservoir management and operations has been established as one of the most important advances made in the field of water resources engineering. a primary role of systems analysis is to provide an improved basis for decision making. It has been concluded that a gap still exists between research studies and the application of a systems approach in practice. The objective of this paper is to provide a short review of the mathematical models used in reservoir management and operations, to present conclusions reached by previous state-of-the-art reviews, and to provide two ideas for closing the gap between theory and practice. First, a simple simulation-optimization model for reservoir sizing has been presented as an example of systems approach respond to practical needs of water resources engineers. The second example illustrates the benefits of knowledge-based technology with regard to single-multipurpose reservoir analysis.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Water Resources Planning and Management; (United States); Journal Volume: 118:3
JOURNAL_NAME: Journal of Water Resources Planning and Management; (United States)

TITLE: Voltage regulators: Influencing generator system stability
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; START-UP; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; VOLTAGE REGULATORS; STABILITY; TUNING; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; POWER PLANTS; SIMULATION; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: One of the most valuable aspects of a hydropower plant to a utility system is its ability to come on line in a matter of minutes. Consequently, a hydroelectric generation must be able to provide fast transient performance regardless of load under any situation. To ensure this type of performance, it is important to understand the mechanics of the generator's voltage regulator so that stability adjustments can be properly attained. Various factors can cause generator instability. These include the characteristics of the voltage regulator, and the generator's field time constants as related to machine speed and size. For optimum performance, the generator's stability network needs to be tuned to match the field time constants of the machine. There are some basic steps in tuning the voltage regulator that should be followed during generator start up. In addition, computer modeling can be used to demonstrate the effect of more or less stability on generator performance.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:3

TITLE: Analyzing turbine bypass systems at hydro facilities
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FISHES; MORTALITY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; COLUMBIA RIVER BASIN; PREDATOR-PREY INTERACTIONS; SALMON; US CORPS OF ENGINEERS; ANADROMOUS FISHES; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; US DOD; US ORGANIZATIONS; VERTEBRATES; WATERSHEDS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: In the 1960s, biologists for several federal and state resource agencies investigated turbine mortality at US Army Corps of Engineers' hydroelectric projects along the Columbia River. Their findings suggested that turbine bypass systems would provide improved passage conditions for juvenile salmon. In response to these findings, the Corps installed bypass systems at many of its facilities. However, evaluations of salmon after the bypasses were installed indicated that these systems are not completely benign. The bypass system, guidance devices, and tailrace predation can cause variable levels of stress, injury, and mortality. When compared to a favorable turbine environment of deeply submerged runners and low head, certain bypass systems may even reduce survival in some cases. For example, preliminary results of a survival study conducted by biologists at the National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) from 1987 through 1990 at Bonneville Dam indicate bypassed juvenile chinook salmon have significantly lower survival rates than those passing through turbines. Consequently, comprehensive analyses of bypass components are necessary to ensure bypass passage improves survival, relative to turbine passage.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:3

TITLE: Identifying ways to repower hydro
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; MEETINGS; EFFICIENCY; ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RELIABILITY; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Hydropower, already supplying more than one-sixth of North America's electricity, has the greatest potential among all renewable resources -- including wing and solar power -- for making significant additional contributions to domestically produced renewable energy, according to participants at the North American Hydro Research and Development Forum held in Kansas City February 24-26, 1992. A group of more than 80 representatives from hydropower operation, environmental, research, and policy-oriented organizations participated in the meeting. The forum was sponsored by Hydro Review and underwritten by Pacific Gas and Electric Company and other organizations. The mission: develop comprehensive, prioritized recommendations for hydro research and development. Acknowledging that major challenges lie ahead to adapt existing plants and yet-to-be-developed facilities to new environmental criteria, forum participants shared the view that the challenges can be appropriately addressed through a process that emphasizes research and development. They agreed that the proven ability of hydropower to produce electrical energy in a reliable and low cost manner can be enhanced through R D activities. Forum participants identified more than 150 specific projects for increasing the efficiency of hydro plants, increasing reliability, decreasing maintenance costs, and responding to environmental issues -- making hydro even more valuable than it already is. Near-term benefits of identified research could provide hundreds of millions of dollars worth of social, environmental, and energy production pay-offs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:3

TITLE: Penstock water replaces hydraulic oil in spherical valve seals
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; VALVES; SEALS; HYDRAULIC FLUIDS; PENSTOCKS; WATER; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; FLOW REGULATORS; FLUIDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PIPES; POWER PLANTS; WORKING FLUIDS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The Public Service Co. of Colorado has designed a system that enables spherical valve seals at one of its hydroelectric plants to operate on penstock water, rather than oil. Workers implemented the system at the utility's Cabin Creek Pumped-Storage Project in response to environmental concerns expressed about oil leaks from spherical valves. The modification has proved reliable. Seal operation is also slightly faster than when operated with oil.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:3

TITLE: Transient excitation boosting at Grand Coulee Third Powerplant
AUTHORS: Osburn, G D; Lennon, Jr, C A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ELECTRICAL TRANSIENTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; BONNEVILLE POWER ADMINISTRATION; DESIGN; HVDC SYSTEMS; INSTALLATION; OPERATION; STABILITY; TESTING; WASHINGTON; DC SYSTEMS; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; FEDERAL REGION X; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; TRANSIENTS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; USA; VOLTAGE DROP; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes the design, installation, testing and operating experience of a transient excitation boosting system at Grand Coulee Third Powerplant on the Columbia River in Washington state. Test results are not included in this paper. Outages of the Pacific HVDC Intertie initiate interarea swings on parallel ac interties, threatening transient stability. The Bonneville Power Administration proposed the design and implementation of a transient excitation boosting (TEB) system at Grand Coulee as a partial solution to this stability problem. The TEB system was applied to the Third Powerplant's 600- and 700-MVA hydrogenerators. The fast-acting static excitation systems on these units are capable of providing the reactive power boost necessary to help stabilize the power system.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 7:2
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: Design and testing of a back-to-back starting system for pumped storage hydrogenerators at Mt. Elbert Powerplant
AUTHORS: Osburn, G D; Atwater, P L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; COLORADO; DESIGN; RELIABILITY; START-UP; TESTING; US BUREAU OF RECLAMATION; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; FEDERAL REGION VIII; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; US DOI; US ORGANIZATIONS; USA; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes the design and testing of a back-to-back starting system for pumped storage hydrogenerators at Mt. Elbert Powerplant in central Colorado. Marginal reliability of the existing static starting system adversely affected availability of the two 170,000-hp pumps. An alternate method of starting a unit in the pump mode was needed to increase plant availability and to provide interim starting capability for a planned static starter replacement. The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation research, design, maintenance, and operations forces worked together to design and test a back-to-back starting system that allows one unit, operating in generate mode, to synchronously start the other unit as a motor.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 7:2
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: Stochastic optimization of a hydro-thermal system including network constraints
AUTHORS: Gorenstin, B G; Campdonico, N M; Costa, J P; Pereira, M V.F.
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; POWER TRANSMISSION; OPTIMIZATION; ALGORITHMS; DYNAMIC PROGRAMMING; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; SCHEDULES; SIMULATION; WATER RESERVOIRS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; POWER; POWER PLANTS; PROGRAMMING; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SURFACE WATERS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 240200* - Power System Networks, Transmission & Distribution- (1990-); 130000 - Hydro Energy; 150000 - Geothermal Energy
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes a methodology for the optimal scheduling of hydrothermal systems taking into account multiple hydro reservoir characteristics, inflow stochasticity and transmission network represented by a linearized power flow model. The solution algorithm is based on stochastic dual dynamic programming, which decomposes the multi-stage stochastic problem into several one stage subproblems. Each subproblem corresponds to a linearized optimal power flow with additional constraints represented the hydro reservoir equations and a piecewise linear approximation of the expected future cost function. Each subproblem is solved by a customized network flow/Dual Simplex algorithm which takes advantage of the network characteristics of the hydro reservoirs and of the transmission system. The application of the methodology is illustrated in a case study with a Brazilian system comprising 44 hydroplants, 11 thermal plants, 463 buses and 834 circuits.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 7:2
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: A fast algorithm for power system optimization problems using an interior point method
AUTHORS: Ponnambalam, K; Quintana, V H; Vannelli, A
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; OPTIMIZATION; ALGORITHMS; EFFICIENCY; LINEAR PROGRAMMING; SCHEDULES; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; POWER PLANTS; PROGRAMMING; 240100* - Power Systems- (1990-); 130000 - Hydro Energy; 990200 - Mathematics & Computers
DESCRIPTION: Linear Programming (LP) is a widely used tool for solving many linear/non-linear power-system optimization problems. Variants of simplex-based methodologies are generally used to solve the underlying LP problems. In this paper an implementation of the newly developed Dual Affine (DA) algorithm (a variant of Karmarkar's interior point method) is described in detail and some computational results are presented. This algorithm is particularly suitable for problems with a large number of constraints, and is applicable to linear and nonlinear optimization problems. An application of the proposed optimization technique to hydro-scheduling is presented; the largest problem is comprised of 880 variable and 3680 constraints, and is solved over 9 times faster than an efficient simplex (MINOS) code.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 7:2
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: An opportunity for the White House. [Competitiveness in the non-federal hydropower industry]
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPETITION; LICENSING; COST; ECONOMIC IMPACT; ECONOMIC POLICY; ECONOMICS; LICENSE APPLICATIONS; TIME DELAY; US FERC; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 290201 - Energy Planning & Policy- Economics- (1992-); 299000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation
DESCRIPTION: This article examines the institutional barriers to economic development in the hydroelectric power industry. The topics discussed in the article include a review of the benefits and advantages to the US industrial competitiveness and economy of hydroelectric power, relicensing of existing hydroelectric power plants, costs related to relicensing, and areas for improvement of the licensing process.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:4

TITLE: Managing the risks of operating a hydro playground
AUTHORS: Bachman, G D; Blackburn, P C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LIABILITIES; RECREATIONAL AREAS; LEGAL ASPECTS; LICENSING REGULATIONS; US FERC; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; REGULATIONS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130800* - Hydro Energy- Health & Safety- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: An integral part of most hydro projects is some recreational opportunity for the public. As a result, plant owners need to be aware of and manage their exposure to recreational liability. This article discusses liability and the measures that hydro plant owners can take to reduce their risk.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:2

TITLE: Debunking the myths about fish mortality at hydro plants
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FISHES; MORTALITY; SURVIVAL CURVES; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; VERTEBRATES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Results of recent studies using an innovative fish recovery technique suggest that hydroturbines, in many cases, are viable exit routes for migratory and non-migratory fish. The technique involves tagging fish with a tiny latex balloon that is then injected with chemicals. The tagged fish are then released into the penstock of an operating turbine. The chemical contents in the bag react and inflate the tag shortly after passage. The tag then buoys the fish to the surface in the tailrace, where they are recovered within a few minutes. The recovered fish are then examined for injury and mortality. Tests have been conducted on juvenile American shad, salmon smolt, channel catfish, bluegill, and smallmouth bass. In the studies completed, only about 2% of fish have been mechanically injured (hit by the runner blade).
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:2

TITLE: Protecting modern hydro plant controls from electrical surges
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CONTROL SYSTEMS; SAFETY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SURGES; CONTROL; ELECTRIC CONTROLLERS; ELECTRIC GROUNDS; ELECTRICAL TRANSIENTS; LIGHTNING; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; ELECTRIC DISCHARGES; EQUIPMENT; POWER PLANTS; TRANSIENTS; VOLTAGE DROP; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Wiring and grounding a hydro plant in accordance with the National Electrical Code is not sufficient to prevent damage to the solid-state components found in PLC control systems. To properly protect these devices, plant owners must eliminate or minimize transient surge voltages and upgrade the electrical grounding system. This article describes designs for minimizing surge damage, especially emphasizing the interrelationship between surge protection and the grounding systems, and the effects of the higher frequencies that accompany transient surge voltages.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:2

TITLE: Storing hydroelectricity to meet peak-hour demand
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; POWER DEMAND; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; ECONOMICS; EFFICIENCY; ENERGY STORAGE; EPRI; PEAK LOAD; DEMAND; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; STORAGE; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: This paper reports on pumped storage plants which have become an effective way for some utility companies that derive power from hydroelectric facilities to economically store baseload energy during off-peak hours for use during peak hourly demands. According to the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) in Palo Alto, Calif., 36 of these plants provide approximately 20 gigawatts, or about 3 percent of U.S. generating capacity. During peak-demand periods, utilities are often stretched beyond their capacity to provide power and must therefore purchase it from neighboring utilities. Building new baseload power plants, typically nuclear or coal-fired facilities that run 24 hours per day seven days a week, is expensive, about $1500 per kilowatt, according to Robert Schainker, program manager for energy storage at the EPRI. Schainker the that building peaking plants at $400 per kilowatt, which run a few hours a day on gas or oil fuel, is less costly than building baseload plants. Operating them, however, is more expensive because peaking plants are less efficient that baseload plants.
RELATION: Journal Name: Mechanical Engineering; (United States); Journal Volume: 114:4

TITLE: Methods for measuring turbine efficiency
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ENERGY EFFICIENCY; MEASURING METHODS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; ACOUSTIC MEASUREMENTS; FLOW RATE; LIQUID FLOW; EFFICIENCY; EQUIPMENT; FLUID FLOW; MACHINERY; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: This article describes the most common methods used for measuring hydro turbine efficiency. These methods are the acoustic flowmeter method, the Gibson (pressure-time) method, pressure drop across a flow restriction, propeller-driven flowmeters, the volumetric method, Winter-Kennedy taps, and the thermodynamic method. A new computerized variation of the Gibson method is also described.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:2

TITLE: Guide on dam inspection performance revisited
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; INSPECTION; MONITORING; PERFORMANCE; RECOMMENDATIONS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: A good book stands the test of time - no matter when it was published, it is always relevant. Another measure of a book's worth is the number of times it is picked up and read. By these standards, the Electric Power Research Institute's Inspection and Performance Evaluation of Dams: A Guide for Managers, Engineers, and Operators, could be called a modern-day classic. Morrison-Knudsen Engineers, of San Francisco, prepared the 224-page guide, which was released in 1986 as part of an EPRI program to assist utilities in the design, operation, maintenance, and modernization of hydroelectric projects. EPRI's objective: to develop guidelines for inspecting utility dams and appurtenant structures, and for monitoring and evaluating dam performance. Although the publication turns six years old this fall, it continues to draw interest in hydro circles. Field reports indicate the guide still serves as a useful tool for project owners, managers, engineers, operators, and others.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:2

TITLE: Making the most of increased water flow: Expanding the Devil Canyon hydro plant
AUTHORS: DePuy, B E; Butler, R C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; EXPANSION; CAPITALIZED COST; COST; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; USA; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Amidst the longest California drought on record, work is proceeding to bring additional water to the southern part of the state. With extra water comes an opportunity for increasing hydro - one project is underway to add 160 MW of power to an existing 120-MW plant. The California State Department of Water Resources (DWR) completed the initial phase of its State Water Project 20 years ago. However, the state designed into the system provisions for future enlargement to meet anticipated increased water demands. Growth in southern California during the last ten years has been unprecedented. To meet demands for additional water supplies, in 1986 DWR and several of its water contractors signed water contract agreements to enlarge part of the California Aqueduct. This enlargement meant that increased flows would be available to the 120-MW Devil Canyon hydroelectric facility, the southernmost plant along the aqueduct. As a result, DWR is expanding Devil Canyon. The project expansion includes: enlargement of the powerhouse to allow room for two new units of 80 MW each; addition of a second penstock; and the addition of a second, larger afterbay. More than 15 primary contractors have worked on or are working on project contracts totaling more than $82.5 million. When water begins passing through the completed power plant in April 1992, Devil Canyon will be capable of producing an additional 160 MW of electricity.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:2

TITLE: Reinforcing the soundness of FERC's hydro licensing process
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING PROCEDURES; LEGAL ASPECTS; US FERC; OHIO VALLEY REGION; US DOI; US FWS; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: On January 10, 1992, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit upheld FERC licenses for 16 hydroelectric projects in the Upper Ohio River Valley. The licensing had been appealed in 1990 by the Department of Interior, several states, and two environmental organizations. This article reviews the Court's findings and its reasons for upholding FERC's granting of the licenses.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:2

TITLE: Evaluating relicense proposals at the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; US FERC; LICENSING PROCEDURES; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; RECREATIONAL AREAS; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; ECONOMICS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: This article describes the methods that FERC uses to evaluate the competing uses of a hydro facility, for evaluation of relicensing of hydro plants whose licenses expire at the end of 1993. Trade-offs between two competing resources such as fish and power are common in a relicense proceeding, but many projects present far more difficult choices. Often a single enhancement proposal, such as changing the operation of a project from peaking to run-of-the-river, affects several competing resources - a reservoir and instream fishery, reservoir recreation, and power. FERC staff is to use results of economic and environmental studies to choose among alternative uses of the water resource the option that gives the greatest benefit to the public and makes the best use of the existing waterway.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:2

TITLE: Gearing up for automatic geotechnical monitoring of civil structures
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; MONITORING; DATA ACQUISITION SYSTEMS; DESIGN; INSTALLATION; PENSTOCKS; EXTENSOMETERS; PIEZOMETRY; ROCKS; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; PIPES; PRESSURE MEASUREMENT; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130800 - Hydro Energy- Health & Safety- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Experience at Bath County Pumped Storage Station shows that using automated data acquisition systems with geotechnical instrumentation is beneficial. The trick is finding reliable equipment, installing it correctly, and setting up a database management system. This article describes the installation, design, and use of data acquisition equipment at the Bath County facility in Virginia.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:2

TITLE: Applying hydraulic transient analysis: The Grizzly Hydro Project
AUTHORS: Logan, T H; Stutsman, R D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; WATER HAMMER; CONTROL; PRESSURE CONTROL; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: No matter the size of the hydro plant, if it has a long waterway and will operate in peaking mode, the project designer needs to address the issue of hydraulic transients-known as water hammer-early in the design. This article describes the application of transient analysis to the design of a 20-MW hydro plant in California. In this case, a Howell Bunger valve was used as a pressure regulating valve to control transient pressures and speed rise.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:2

TITLE: Hydropower into the mainstream: A view from the Potomac
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; POLITICAL ASPECTS; REGULATIONS; NATIONAL GOVERNMENT; LEGISLATION; CLEAN WATER ACTS; NATIONAL ENERGY ACTS; US FERC; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; LAWS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POLLUTION LAWS; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: This article discusses the regulatory and political environment in Washington, D.C. as it affects the hydro power industry, and the actions of the National Hydropower Association in ensuring that regulators, politicians, and federal agencies understand the issues necessary to maintaining hydro power as a mainstream energy source for the U.S. Some of the issues discussed are the Clean Water Act reauthorization, the Endangered Species Act reauthorization, National Energy Strategy legislation, and trends in FERC regulation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:2

TITLE: Generating electricity along municipal water supply systems
AUTHORS: Busse, E J; Haag, T W; Coupe, L D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; MICRO-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; WATER UTILITIES; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; ECONOMICS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: In addition to providing water supply for municipalities, water mains can serve as conduits for small hydro plants. Examples of several such projects illustrate a practical, cost-effective way to meet growing electricity demands. A typical water supply system for a municipality consists of one or more reservoirs of water, a pipeline, and a water treatment plant. As the water flows from the reservoir down to the treatment plant, excess pressure develops. This pressure must be relieved before the water enters the water treatment station and water distribution mains along the city streets. Cities typically use pressure reducing valves to relieve this pressure. An alternative, though, is to convert the pressure to electricity by using small hydroturbines. The power generated by these small hydro units (typically ranging in size from 50 kW to 5 MW) can be used to meet a city's electricity load and/or supply power for water treatment operations. The idea of generating electricity from excess head along the water supply main is not new. However, the concept is viable only if it is cost-effective. Recent advances in the development and installation of mini and micro hydro units, as well as the availability of a wide range of turbines, have made the exploitation of this source of energy possible. The cities of Boulder, Colorado, and Wichita, Kansas, are operating small hydro plants as part of their water distribution system. And, the city of Sitka, Alaska, is building two hydro units along water supply lines that should begin operating in early 1993. These plants are a representative sampling from many municipalities throughout North America that are delivering water and generating electricity at the same time.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:2

TITLE: Engineering hydro's future
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; MARKET; PLANNING; COMPETITION; ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT; ECONOMICS; ELECTRIC POWER INDUSTRY; ENGINEERS; GEORGIA; GOODS AND SERVICES; PENNSYLVANIA; PUBLIC RELATIONS; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; SUSQUEHANNA RIVER; US FERC; VENEZUELA; VIRGINIA; WATER POLLUTION; WISCONSIN; ANIMALS; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; INDUSTRY; LATIN AMERICA; MAMMALS; MAN; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; PERSONNEL; POLLUTION; POWER PLANTS; PRIMATES; PROFESSIONAL PERSONNEL; RIVERS; SOUTH AMERICA; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; USA; VERTEBRATES; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: In this challenging hydropower market, hydropower engineering services are in high demand. The number of new hydropower projects entering the pipeline may have slowed in recent years but that does not mean work is not being done. Independent developers, utilities and municipalities are carrying out a considerable amount of hydropower activity. Whatever the work involves - preliminary planning, licensing and relicensing, environmental mitigation, plant rehabilitation or new-plant startup - engineering firms are finding a brisk market for their services. The complexity of the regulatory framework makes hydropower facility and other water resource work more important then ever. Executives of three engineering firms - Acres International, Harza Engineering and Black and Veatch - active in these areas discuss their views on the future of the hydropower engineering market.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:4

TITLE: Working with the FERC. [Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, Licensing of hydropower projects]
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSE APPLICATIONS; LICENSING; COOPERATION; ECONOMICS; INTERVENORS; LEGAL ASPECTS; TIME DELAY; US FERC; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations
DESCRIPTION: The FERC office of hydropower licensing is overburdened with license and relicense applications. Knowing how to work with the FERC can lighten the staff's load and expedite the process. While the policy debate intensifies over the proper balance between river protection and hydroelectric development, life goes on in the trenches of individual project review. Legislation on national energy policy, the Endangered Species Act, and the Clean Water Act all are important issues with long-term significance for the hydropower industry. Nevertheless, in the short term, applicants for license or relicense have real projects with which they wish to proceed. While they may feel frustrated by perceived injustices in the environmental review system, they must grin and bear it to expedite project development. To this end, project proponents need to establish effective working relationships with Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) staff members, which will facilitate smooth project review and avoid unnecessary delays. Which applicants, interveners, and resource agencies will be most effective in achieving their goals in the complex process of project review What is it FERC staff members are looking for when they dissect license applications What kinds of projects and submissions are processed most efficiently What is the secret to success in dealing with the FERC With the goal of identifying a pattern for effective working relations with the FERC, this article contains the answers to these questions asked of diverse parties involved with hydroelectric project review, including FERC staff, attorneys and consultants for license or relicense applicants and resource agencies.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:4

TITLE: Optimal design of run-of-river power plants
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; COMPUTER CODES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPTIMIZATION; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: In optimization of any hydro plant system, the analysis should make use of all information available, including a thorough study of streamflow and civil engineering and electromechanical cost effectiveness. For this purpose a general mathematical model is used for an overall design optimization of run-of-river power plants. The design criteria for such power plants are fundamentally based on some important and critical cost-effective parameters such as discharge design, penstock or tunnel diameter, turbine capacity, number of units and type of turbines. The optimization process consists of three main steps: (1) find the maximum yearly energy; (2) maximize the yearly benefits of all the maximized sets of power plants; and (3) select the most beneficial of the feasible sets of run-of-river power plants on the basis of a combination of the cited criteria. The computational analysis is based upon two major objective functions and a computer program which is developed for fast maximization and optimization of the generated equations.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resources Research; (United States); Journal Volume: 28:4

TITLE: Future tunnelling projects in Iceland
SUBJECT: 42 ENGINEERING; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; TUNNELING; COST ESTIMATION; PLANNING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ICELAND; ROADS; TUNNELS; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; EUROPE; ISLANDS; POWER PLANTS; UNDERGROUND FACILITIES; WESTERN EUROPE; 422000* - Engineering- Mining & Underground Engineering- (1980-); 130000 - Hydro Energy
DESCRIPTION: More than 300 km of hydro tunnels and 80-90 km of road tunnels could be excavated in Iceland before the year 2050. In order to complete this task, an average of 6-7 km of tunnel per year would have to be driven. This volume of tunnelling is estimated to cost more than $US1 billion, which could be divided as follows: (a) about 100 km of 3.5-m-wide diversion hydro tunnels (unsupported), for a total of $90 million; (b) approx. 100 km of 5-m-wide hydro tunnels (supported), for a total of $210 million; (c) about 100 km of 7.6-m-wide hydro tunnels (supported), for a total of $380 million; and (d) approx. 85 km of road tunnels with 25 m[sup 2] cross-section, for a total of $435 million. 5 refs., 5 figs., 4 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Tunnelling and Underground Space Technology; (United Kingdom); Journal Volume: 7:2
JOURNAL_NAME: Tunnelling and Underground Space Technology; (United Kingdom)

TITLE: Evaluation of HVDC cables for the St. Lawrence River crossing of Hydro-Quebec's 500-kV DC line. Part 3; Thermal behavior
AUTHORS: Chaaban, M; Leduc, J; Couderc, D; Trinh, N G; Belec, M
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC CABLES; TEMPERATURE EFFECTS; HVDC SYSTEMS; CONTROL; DESIGN; EVALUATION; FINITE ELEMENT METHOD; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; QUEBEC; RIVERS; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; TESTING; CABLES; CANADA; CONDUCTOR DEVICES; DC SYSTEMS; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; NORTH AMERICA; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 240301* - Power Transmission Lines & Cables- Power Cables- (1990-); 130700 - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: This paper presents the thermal analyses conducted during the different stages of Hydro-Quebec's St. Lawrence river crossing project. It reveals the important impact of the thermal studies on the choice of HVDC cable and the design of the installations. It also describes the numerous problems faced during the cable prototype and demonstration tests and the solutions obtained by numerical analysis using the finite-element method. These problems were related in part to the temperature controls of the cable and its accessories, and in particular to the control of the temperature gradient across the dielectric material at various locations along the test loop.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Delivery (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 7:2
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Power Delivery (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: Fixing hydro - The forgotten renewable
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ECONOMICS; REGULATIONS; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; US CORPS OF ENGINEERS; US FERC; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; ENERGY SOURCES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; US DOD; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Since the dawn of civilization, man has captured the energy potential of falling water, from the water wheels in the fertile crescent of ancient times to today's highly sophisticated conventional and pumped storage projects. As we approach the 21st century, electric energy captured from falling water provides 2.0 trillion kilowatt-hours (21.23 quadrillion Btu), roughly 20% of the world's electric energy. Of the 2.56 billion kilowatts of the world's installed electric generating capacity, hydropower accounts for 24%. Between 1980 and 1989, world generation of hydroelectric power rose from 1.7 trillion kWh to 2.0 trillion kWh. As of January 1, 1988, the US has 90.5 million kW of installed hydro capacity - 70.8 million kW of it under license by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission - with annual generation estimated at just under 300 billion kWh. Hydro's share, which not long ago comprised 13% of the nation's total capacity, now is just a 9% share. The US has the option to choose one or another path for hydro. If policy makers are willing to coast on a cushion of cheap natural gas, they will continue to shun hydro and put obstacles in its path. But if they come to regard hydro as an attractive resource - as they did only recently - economically and environmentally, they will encourage more balance in resource policies. Believing that interest in a balanced national resource portfolio will grow, the author reviews the past and suggests a possible future course of reasonable development for hydro. The article concludes with some suggested principles that will be needed if the appropriate balance is to be found.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electricity Journal; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:3

TITLE: Pumped storage in the Rockies
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; COLORADO; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; OFF-PEAK POWER; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC OPINION; PUBLIC RELATIONS; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; US BUREAU OF RECLAMATION; US FERC; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; FEDERAL REGION VIII; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; US DOE; US DOI; US ORGANIZATIONS; USA; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: This article examines the development of the Rocky Point pumped storage project near Gunnison, Colorado. The topics discussed in the article include the state-of-the-art pumped storage technology and a description of the project, permitting challenges in achieving four separate approvals to build the project, and addressing public concerns about the nature of the project.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 23:3

TITLE: Fisheries out of balance. [Fish mitigation costs for hydropower projects]
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; COLUMBIA RIVER; FISHERIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ECONOMICS; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; SALMON; US FERC; US FWS; ANADROMOUS FISHES; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; FISHES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; US DOE; US DOI; US ORGANIZATIONS; VERTEBRATES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 290300 - Energy Planning & Policy- Environment, Health, & Safety; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects

The author feels these costs are far out of proportion with the revenues from power sales. The topics discussed in the article include salmon recovery, a growing burden, instream flow, fish passage and screening, the need for power, and fisheries agencies' control.

TITLE: Using satellite data to increase accuracy of PMF calculations
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FLOODS; FORECASTING; SATELLITES; DATA ACQUISITION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS

TITLE: Analyzing hydraulic transients
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; TRANSIENTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DIAGRAMS; WATER HAMMER
DESCRIPTION: The operational mode of a hydroturbine determines hydraulic pressures and flows. The more starts and stops the turbine makes, the more pressure changes will occur. The faster the flow changes, the greater their magnitude. Analyses of hydraulic transients-known as waterhammer-should be part of preliminary engineering studies of any proposed hydro project that will operate as a peaking plant.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 11; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Mar 1992

TITLE: Technical requirements to connect parallel generators to the Ontario Hydro Distribution Electricity System
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ELECTRIC POWER; INDUCTION GENERATORS; ONTARIO; POWER; CANADA; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; 240200* - Power System Networks, Transmission & Distribution- (1990-); 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The demand for connecting small generators to the distribution system has increased considerably since 1986. Therefore, there is a need to summarize the technical requirements for generator connection. This paper highlights the technical requirements for connecting parallel generators to the Ontario Hydro Distribution Electricity System. It also discusses some applications to connect synchronous and induction generators to the DES.

SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; CONFIGURATION; CONTROL SYSTEMS; DESIGN; ELECTRIC GROUNDS; POWER SYSTEMS; SOUTH CAROLINA; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; EQUIPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NORTH AMERICA; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; USA; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: This paper reports on the site topography and arrangement of electrical equipment at Duke Power Company's Bad Creek Pumped Storage Project in Salem, SC which have made the project a challenge to design and construct. Although the electrical systems are similar in many respects to other power plants, the unique features of the main power system, auxiliary power systems, grounding, control systems and testing make it an interesting case study for the electrical designer.

TITLE: Retrofit of Traengslet Hydro Power Station
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; AUTOMATION; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; MODIFICATIONS; SWEDEN; CONTROL SYSTEMS; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; EQUIPMENT; EUROPE; ON-LINE CONTROL SYSTEMS; ON-LINE SYSTEMS; POWER PLANTS; SCANDINAVIA; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: An accident in Trangslet (Sweden) Power Station in the fall of 1982 resulted in among other things the flooding of the control equipment. Despite effective cleaning up after the flooding, the reliability was not adequate and new equipment needed to be procured. When assessing various options, STORA POWER came to the conclusion that a computerized control system, would be the best solution because of its capability to optimize the power production of the station. The paper describes the utility requirements for the distributed control system and experiences from implementation and operation. It also covers the control system philosophy and implemented functions.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 7:1

TITLE: Stochastic dual dynamic programming for seasonal scheduling in the Norwegian power system
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SCHEDULES; POWER SYSTEMS; ALGORITHMS; COMPUTERS; DYNAMIC PROGRAMMING; SEASONAL VARIATIONS; STOCHASTIC PROCESSES; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; POWER PLANTS; PROGRAMMING; VARIATIONS; 240100* - Power Systems- (1990-); 990200 - Mathematics & Computers; 130000 - Hydro Energy
DESCRIPTION: The recently published dual dynamic programming algorithm is applied to a part of the Norwegian power system. In this paper a procedure for obtaining a good start is presented, and other implementation details are discussed. The test shows that dual dynamic programming have reasonable computing times and can be a useful tool in stochastic scheduling in a hydro-dominated system like the Norwegian.

TITLE: Combining analytical models and Monte-Carlo techniques in probabilistic power system analysis
AUTHORS: Pereira, M Y.F.; Maceira, M E.P.; Oliveira, G C; Pinto, L M.V.G.
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PROBABILISTIC ESTIMATION; POWER SYSTEMS; COST; RELIABILITY; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; EVALUATION; MONTE CARLO METHOD; OPERATION; SIMULATION; POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; 240100* - Power Systems- (1990-); 130000 - Hydro Energy
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes a general framework for combining analytical models and Monte Carlo simulation. The basic idea is to use a simpler analytical model as an approximation to a more detailed model in a Monte Carlo simulation scheme. The simulation then deals with the residual, i.e. the difference between the result of the detailed model and of the approximation. In other words, the component of probabilistic indices which can be explained by the analytical model in factored out of the Monte Carlo sampling scheme, which then handles only the unexplained residuals. The proposed scheme is flexible and easy to implement, as no modification of existing analytical models is required. The approach is illustrated in case studies with utility-derived systems in several application areas: composite reliability evaluation, multi-area production costing, chronological production costing with ramping constraints, and operation of a multireservoir hydroelectric system.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 7:1
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: 1991 hydro highlights
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CANADA; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; START-UP; USA; ALASKA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; LOCAL GOVERNMENT; MANITOBA; NEW MEXICO; NEW YORK; NORTH CAROLINA; PUBLIC UTILITIES; QUEBEC; STATE GOVERNMENT; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: A review of hydroelectric projects that came on line in 1991 and a preview of plans for 1992 indicate action in all segments of the North American hydro industry. New projects range in size from a 7-kW unit built and operated by a farmer in Washington State to a 2,000-MW project that is part of an ongoing massive hydroelectric development in northern Canada. In the US, 22 new plants came on line in 14 states, contributing about 1,200 MW of capacity to the US electrical supply. In Canada, the presence of private power producers was more noticeable than ever before. Eight independent developers in three provinces brought plants on line, contributing nearly 35 MW of capacity. In addition, units at two large, utility-owned projects began generating power, a total of 1,532 MW. The development activity in 1991 indicates positive movement in all segments of the North American hydro industry. Owners of new projects can be grouped into three categories: utilities (both investor-owned and public); government entities (cities, counties, and states); and private developers (construction companies, industries, single-purpose development companies and entrepreneurs).
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:8

AUTHORS: Hunt, R T; Mohsberg, J A

TITLE: Planning for success. [Planning the New York State Dam hydroelectric project]
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; LICENSING; DAMS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; FISHERIES; MOHAWK RIVER; NEW YORK; PUBLIC RELATIONS; SCALE MODELS; SITE PREPARATION; WASHINGTON; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; FEDERAL REGION X; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; RIVERS; STREAMS; STRUCTURAL MODELS; SURFACE WATERS; USA; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects

TITLE: Hydropower and flood control trade-offs in a multireservoir system
AUTHORS: Braga, B P.F.; Barbosa, P S.F.
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FLOOD CONTROL; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; WATER RESERVOIRS; OPERATION; BRAZIL; REGULATIONS; CONTROL; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; LATIN AMERICA; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SOUTH AMERICA; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130400 - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations
DESCRIPTION: Hydropower generation and flood control are often presented as a classical case of conflicting objectives in water resources planning. Even though this is a well-known and accepted fact, very little has been done in the direction of quantification of these trade-offs in practical terms mainly considering multireservoir systems and different hydrologic scenarios. This article applies the Constraint Method to evaluate those trade-offs, taking as a case study the CESP (Sao Paulo Power Utility) multireservoir system of the Paranapanema Rive basin, located in southeast Brazil. This paper reveals what and how intense the trade-offs are between the conflicting objectives and serves as a guideline for CESP operational policy.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Sources; (United States); Journal Volume: 14:1

TITLE: Predicting the stress-strain state for the beds of heavy structures
AUTHORS: Ter-Martirosyan, Z G; Turaev, K S
SUBJECT: 42 ENGINEERING NOT INCLUDED IN OTHER CATEGORIES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 21 NUCLEAR POWER REACTORS AND ASSOCIATED PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; FOUNDATIONS; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; STRESSES; STRAINS; STRESS ANALYSIS; RHEOLOGY; CLAYS; SOILS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; STABILITY; WEIGHT
DESCRIPTION: During the construction and occupancy of heavy structures (nuclear power plants, hydroelectric power plants, etc.), which are built on a compressible bed, the need arises to predict their settlements and tilting. The solution of this problem requires a large volume of long-term experimental studies and calculation of the stress-strain state (SSS) of the bed. Successful solution of this problem is governed by both the correct selection of the geochemical model of the bed, and the accuracy with which the rheologic properties of the bed soils and the effectiveness of the adopted computational method are described. Studies conducted in recent years have shown that a rheologic model of the bed in the form of a layer of limited thickness is most optimal. Investigation of clayey soils suggests that a rheologic model where the deformations are logarithmically proportional with time is effective for predicting long-term deformations. A theoretical solution of the problem of predicting the SSS of a soil layer, which is inhomogeneous with respect to depth, under a local load with allowance for the rheologic properties of the soils is proposed below on the basis of these two premises, using Vlasov`s variational method, which ensures sufficient accuracy and practicality. 11 refs., 4 figs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Soil Mechanics and Foundation Engineering; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Jan 1992; TN: Translated from Osnovaniya, Fundamenty i Mekhanika Gruntov; No. 4, 21-24(Jul-Aug 1991)

SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MARKETING; PROCUREMENT; CONSTRUCTION; ENGINEERING; FINANCING; GOODS AND SERVICES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; LEGAL ASPECTS; MAINTENANCE; MANAGEMENT; OPERATION; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; REPAIR; SPILLWAY; TURBINES; WATER WHEELS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; POWER; POWER PLANTS; TURBOMACHINERY; WHEELS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects

TITLE: Regulating river flow
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FLOW RATE; ON-LINE CONTROL SYSTEMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; NORWAY; CONTROL SYSTEMS; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; ECONOMICS; EUROPE; ON-LINE SYSTEMS; POWER PLANTS; SCANDINAVIA; WESTERN EUROPE; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: A control strategy that precisely and continuously regulated water flow over the dam - releasing just enough water to meet the flow requirements downstream without any waste - can be quite valuable at a hydro project. At the Ulla-Forre project, the Norwegian Research Institute of Energy Supply (EFI) and the Norwegian Institute of Technology (NTH) developed an on-line controller to provide real-time control of river flow. By using the controller, the Norwegian State Power Board saved enough water to produce an extra $50,000 (US) worth of electricity a year at the Hylen power station. In 1989, the Ministry of Oil and Energy decided that the strict flow constraints, compared to relaxed constraints, were not contributing to improved environmental conditions, and thus dropped the minimum flow requirements. As a result, the power board discontinued use of the controller. The on-line controller designed for Ulla-Forre was a prototype. Using this version as a model, though, an on-line controller could be developed for any location to aid in meeting streamflow requirements and, at the same time, maximizing revenues. Depending on the complexity, the cost of developing an on-line controller begins at approximately $10,000.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:7

TITLE: Remedies for sediment buildup
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; DESIGN; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; SEDIMENTATION; MITIGATION; DRAWDOWN; ENGINEERING; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: An important issue in the design, construction, and operation of dams is reducing sedimentation in the reservoir to maintain maximum available water storage. Mitigative measures can be incorporated in dam design and reservoir operation to substantially reduce sediment entrapment, and to improve dissolved oxygen levels by releasing hypolimnetic waters (cold bottom waters) from the reservoir. These measures may also greatly reduce stream bed degradation downstream of the dam and consequent initiation of a new erosion cycle in the tributaries. The Illinois State Water Survey (a division of the Illinois Department of Energy and Natural Resources) investigated the advantages and disadvantages of various storage maintenance measures. In an economic analyses of the methods, the State Water Survey considered and compared the reduction in initial reservoir design storage capacity, cost of installation of sediment entrapment reduction measures, and cost of any dredging operations. The analysis indicates that the cost of incorporating sediment entrapment reduction measures in the design of a dam and reservoir can be justified by a decrease in capital and present worth costs due to the need for smaller initial storage capacity and an absence of dredging costs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:7

TITLE: Building in Canada's Coast Mountains: The challenging Kemano hydro project
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CANADA; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; EXPANSION; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; LEGAL ASPECTS; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: In the late 1940s, the government of British Columbia was looking for ways to develop industry in the northwestern region of the province. It encouraged Alcan Aluminium Limited to survey the vast water resources in the Pacific Northwest-including the Nechako River and Lake system-that could be harnessed to power aluminum smelters. Through its studies, Alcan determined that, indeed, the area had great hydroelectric potential. The company consequently decided to build an 816-MW hydro station at Kemano in the Kemano Valley and an aluminum smelter at Kitimat, 82 kilometers northwest of the valley. The hydro plant was one of the most advanced and difficult civil engineering projects of its time. To build the project, Alcan constructed a 97-meter-high dam that reversed the flow of the Nechako River and created the Nechako Reservoir, and then drilled and blasted a water tunnel and excavated a powerhouse deep inside Mount DuBose in the Coast Mountains. In 1989, Alcan launched an expansion of the underground hydro project. Although completion of the half-finished project has been delayed temporarily due to controversies over whether a federal environmental review is needed, the work represents a major engineering challenge and illustrates how man successfully conquered the handicaps of a remote location, harsh climate, and rugged terrain to build a massive hydro project.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:7

TITLE: Report documents O M at pumped-storage plants
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; EPRI; RECOMMENDATIONS; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; MAINTENANCE; OPERATION; CAVITATION; CIRCUIT BREAKERS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; VALVES; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT PROTECTION DEVICES; FLOW REGULATORS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MACHINERY; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The Electric Power Research Institute has published a report for planners, designers, owners, and operators of hydroelectric pumped-storage plants that records the operation and maintenance knowledge of 35 domestic and foreign pumped-storage projects. The report provides a comprehensive record of practices that have reduced forced outages and shortened scheduled repairs. As time passes and experienced staff retire at pumped-storage plants, many O M lessons are lost. To remedy that situation, EPRI commissioned Morrison-Knudsen Engineers Inc. to prepare a special report. The 348-page publication records the accumulated civil, geotechnical, mechanical, and electrical O M knowledge and experiences of pumped-storage plant staff. It also includes recommendations to planners and designers of future pumped-storage plants and concludes with descriptions of O M experiences reported by plant operators and utility representatives.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:7

TITLE: Strathcona hydro: Carrying on the dream
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; MICRO-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; DESIGN; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; ECONOMICS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: This article describes the design and construction of a small hydro plant at an outdoor education school in Vancouver Island, British Columbia. Most of the manual labor during construction was supplied by volunteers. Design information and financial data are given.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:7

TITLE: Personal computer accelerates dam analysis
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; DAMS; SAFETY ANALYSIS; STABILITY; PROGRAMMING; PERSONAL COMPUTERS; COMPUTERS; DIGITAL COMPUTERS; MICROCOMPUTERS; 130800* - Hydro Energy- Health & Safety- (1990-); 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 990200 - Mathematics & Computers
DESCRIPTION: Analyzing the stability of a dam can require several months of calculations - depending upon the number of dam cross sections and the variety of loadings that are studied. Monenco Consultants Limited, an engineering firm with its head office in Calgary, Alberta, has evaluated the safety of existing dams at more than 40 water resource developments in the last 20 years. Realizing the complexity of these evaluations, Monenco engineers were interested in developing techniques that would reduce the hours of professional time required for stability calculations, and therefore the cost to the dams owners. The firm eventually developed a microcomputer program for its engineers to use in the stability analysis of concrete gravity dams and two spread-sheets to use with the program for analyzing uplift and internal stresses. Using the computer programs cuts man-hours spent in analysis by about 75 percent and reduces the possibility of error in multiple calculations. Ultimately, the programs allow the engineer to spend more time in detailed analysis of a structure during a safety evaluation and less time performing tedious calculations.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:7

TITLE: Flood survival: Getting a hydro plant back on line
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FLOODS; REPAIR; CIRCUIT BREAKERS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; TRANSFORMERS; DISASTERS; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT PROTECTION DEVICES; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The Remmel Dam and Hydro Plant of Arkansas Power and Light Company was flooded on May 20, 1990. This article describes the teamwork and innovation that went into restoring the powerhouse in a short amount of time.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:7

TITLE: Verticality in hydroelectric machines
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ALIGNMENT; VERTICAL AXIS TURBINES; ROTORS; STATORS; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; WIND TURBINES; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Everyone who erects a vertical hydroelectric machine makes an effort to put the machine together so that its elements are vertical. A plumb line (or its optical equivalent) is a practical starting point for aligning the stationary parts of the machine - the generator stator, turbine case, and bearings. This does not mean, though, that the machine parts must be in near-perfect vertical orientation for the machine to perform well. Verticality is sometimes over-emphasized when procedures are undertaken to achieve good machine alignment. If the generator rotor, the connecting shaft, and the turbine runner are centered in stationary parts that are well-aligned along the same axis angle, this angle can depart from true vertical by a significant amount without ill effect. Mechanical balance does not often play a large part in determining how well a generator rotor is centered in the air gap. Magnetic forces are much more important. This is why it is desirable to maintain air gap variations around the machine to less than 5 percent from the average. However, this is sometimes difficult, especially if bearing clearances are large.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:7

TITLE: A [open quotes]green[close quotes] plan for pumped-storage projects
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; PLANNING; WETLANDS; REMEDIAL ACTION; FISHES; HABITAT; NAVIGATION; PUBLIC RELATIONS; RECREATIONAL AREAS; WATER QUALITY; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; ECOSYSTEMS; ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; VERTEBRATES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Environmental issues are expected to play a major role in the development of future pumped-storage projects. It's the responsibility of the project developer to proactively address and then mitigate for environmental effects. Consolidated Pumped Storage, Inc. (CPS), a subsidiary of Consolidated Hydro, Inc., has had recent experience addressing environmental issues at two proposed pumped-storage developments: the 1,500-MW Summit Pumped-Storage Hydroelectric Project in Ohio and the 600-MW River Mountain Pumped-Storage Project in Arkansas. Thus far in the licensing process, both projects have passed environmental scrutiny. Formulating an environmentally acceptable pumped-storage project is a complex process that requires the developer to: identify and document all possible environmental effects; communicate with and respond to resource agencies and the public; and propose measures to mitigate effects and to enhance existing resources. CPS's experience has been that money spent up front in carefully addressing environmental and community issues is a small price to pay for avoiding serious public opposition later on in the licensing process.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:7

TITLE: The new river conservationists
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ADVERSARIES; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; LICENSING; HUMAN FACTORS; INTEREST GROUPS; KENNEBEC RIVER; LAND OWNERSHIP; MAINE; PUBLIC OPINION; PUBLIC RELATIONS; REGULATIONS; WASHINGTON; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; FEDERAL REGION X; NORTH AMERICA; OWNERSHIP; POWER PLANTS; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; USA; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 290202 - Energy Planning & Policy- Sociology- (1992-); 299000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation
DESCRIPTION: This article examines how the efforts of environmental conservationists are affecting existing and future hydropower projects. The topics include relicensing case studies, the effects of the Electric Consumers Protection Act, the private property problem, the public trust doctrine, grass roots conservation organization, hydropower's place, and an industry strategy.

TITLE: The changing hydro market
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC POWER INDUSTRY; ECONOMICS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MARKETING; BUSINESS; CANADA; COMPUTER-AIDED DESIGN; EXPORTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RETROFITTING; SALES; TRADE; DESIGN; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; INDUSTRY; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; POWER PLANTS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: This article examines the increasingly competitive hydroelectric equipment market and the strategies being developed by participants to meet the environmental and economic challenges. The topics of the article include concentrating on uprating or rehabilitation of plants up for relicensing or becoming outdated, creating a niche in the market, the growth of the Canadian market, and the international market.
