TITLE: Seal rubs can cause shaft deflections
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; MECHANICAL SHAFTS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; SEALS; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; WEAR; EQUIPMENT; MACHINE PARTS; MACHINERY; SHAFTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Seals in hydroelectric machines should prevent the escape of oil and oil vapor from bearings and water from the turbine case along the rotating shaft of the turbine/generator set. However, in cases where seals are placed or move too close to the shaft, they may be responsible for unacceptable shaft runout. During runout, the shaft connecting the turbine to the generator moves laterally, subjecting bearings and structural supports to large pulsating forces. This can lead to a breakdown of lubricating oil film, which, in turn, can damage the shaft. No shaft rotates in a perfectly concentric manner. For that reason, all hydroelectric machines exhibit some degree of shaft runout. In cases where unacceptable levels of vibration occur, station and maintenance staff may consider such possible causes as mechanical unbalance, excessive bearing clearances, hydraulic effects, and electrical unbalance. Seals rubbing against the shaft, are also a cause of runout. Maintenance staff often can determine whether seal rub is the cause of shaft runout by observing machine performance. Such machines will make smooth cold starts but as the machine continues to operate, runout becomes more and more pronounced. This characteristic points to a seal rub as a likely cause of the vibration. When localized heat is generated by seals rubbing against a rotating shaft, the heat bends the shaft in the direction of the original runout. The seal rub that produced the temperature rise then worsens, producing additional heat and more deflection. This snowballing effect can continue until the seal rub becomes destructive.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:6

TITLE: A computer at the helm: Automating hydro plant controls
AUTHORS: Winship, R L; Clarke-Johnson, R C; DeVault, J E; Clifton, L M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; DESIGN; MICROCOMPUTERS; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; AUTOMATION; ALGORITHMS; EMERGENCY PLANS; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; COMPUTERS; CONTROL SYSTEMS; DIGITAL COMPUTERS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; ON-LINE CONTROL SYSTEMS; ON-LINE SYSTEMS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Small hydro developers range from investor-owned utilities to independent power producers to self-taught entrepreneurs. They all have one common goal, though: to maximize revenue by running the plants as efficiently as possible with minimal operation personnel. The way to reach this goal for many developers has been through automating plant controls. the need to minimize installation and operating costs at these plants initiated an acceptance of automated control in the early 1970s - and computerized control about a decade later - of portions of the power plant that previously required constant human attention or costly mechanical action. However, for plants not operated continuously or with unique requirements, such as prescribed flow rates for fish bypass, complete automation was virtually impossible - appropriate software packages did not exist and the cost of the components was unreasonable. In the last few years, though, advances in microprocessor design and application allowed diverse and previously separate plant functions to be integrated into one overall control system. Integrated computerized controls reduce initial installation costs and allow operators to maximize their effectiveness by operating and monitoring several plants concurrently via remote control. Specifically, using computerized controls can reduce plant engineering and custom software programming expenses - engineering and programming are already incorporated in the control package. The integration of sensing, control, protection, and display functions removes the need and expense of interfacing and installing individual components. Optimizing management of the available water and elmininating on-site operating personnel often results in increased plant revenue. Actual savings vary from plant to plant, depending on labor rates, generation capacity, and other requirements that might prevent elimination of on-site operators.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:6

TITLE: Water watch
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CAPACITY; STREAMS; FLOW RATE; USA; ATMOSPHERIC PRECIPITATIONS; DROUGHTS; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: In this issue of Water Watch, a summary of precipitation, drought, and streamflow conditions during the summer is presented. In addition, short-term streamflow forecasts (through October) for each region are given. For purposes of reporting, the US is divided into six regions. The data presented can be used to observe how weather conditions affected hydro generation in July.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:6

TITLE: Beaded epoxy applied to runner for cavitation repair
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CAVITATION; REPAIR; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; CERAMICS; EPOXIDES; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: This article describes the repair of cavitation in hydro turbines using a beaded epoxy. The epoxy contains ceramic beads and small ceramic particles. This epoxy facilitates repair by requiring only one step, as it can be used as both a filler and a coating.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:6

TITLE: Listening to your turbines
AUTHORS: Abbot, P A; Lowell, F C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CAVITATION; ACOUSTIC DETECTION; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; ACCELEROMETERS; EROSION; RECTIFIERS; ACOUSTIC MEASUREMENTS; CHARGED PARTICLE DETECTION; DETECTION; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; RADIATION DETECTION; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Cavitation is something hydro plant owners can't afford to ignore. A new technique using acoustic emissions can detect and monitor cavitation in its early stages, and thus serve as a guide for maintenance scheduling and operational changes. In the mid-1980s, the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) sponsored a feasibility study in which full-wave rectification spectral analysis was applied to two Kaplan turbines to process the sound emanating from cavitating blades. (In full-wave rectification spectral analysis, the system electronically manipulates the sound signal in order to bring out certain frequencies - in this case, those associated with cavitation. It is based on a phenomenon similar to the amplitude modulation in an AM radio signal, where a high frequency carrier wave is modulated by the lower frequencies of the sounds being broadcast). The study showed the approach to be a viable means of detecting the onset and severity of cavitation. The Institut de Recherche d'Hydro-Quebec (IREQ) also explored the potential of full-wave rectification spectral analysis in monitoring cavitation in hydroturbines in the mid-1980s. Its study, sponsored by the Canadian Electrical Association, focused on model and full-scale Francis turbines. The IREQ researchers confirmed the applicability of the method used in the EPRI study to large-scale Francis turbines.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:6

TITLE: EPRI releases report on project relicensing
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; EPRI; RECOMMENDATIONS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; COST; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; POWER PLANTS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations
DESCRIPTION: The Electric Power Research Institute is working to help utilities with hydroelectric projects successfully navigate the relicensing process as it exists following the Electric Consumers Protection Act of 1986. That act was designed to increase the overall net public benefit from water resources. EPRI sponsored and recently completed an analysis of new licenses for the 39 hydro projects relicensed by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission from 1984 through 1989. EPRI's objective for the analysis: provide utilities just beginning the relicensing process with insights and lessons learned from recent relicensing decisions. During a four-year period that runs through 1993, almost 200 relicense applications representing over 2,200 MW of capacity have been, or will be, filed with FERC. Utilities own and operate 70 percent of these projects. Richard Hunt Associates of Annapolis, Md., performed the review and analysis for EPRI and prepared an interim report, Lessons Learned in Hydro Relicensing (1984-1989) Trends, Costs, and Recommendations. EPRI plans for the 72-page report, released during the summer, to be updated periodically. Hunt Associates analysis of relicenses issued by FERC from 1984 through 1989 included 27 post-ECPA relicenses for 1987 through 1989. The relicenses were studied to document major issues of concern expressed by resource agencies and FERC. The contractor also documented special articles in the relicenses that required post-license actions and open-ended actions in which FERC reserved the right to make future changes throughout the life of the license.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:6

TITLE: Trouble-shooting bearing problems in large hydroturbine generators
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; BEARINGS; FAILURES; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; FORECASTING; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; JOURNAL BEARINGS; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: If hydro plant operators are aware of the signals that can alert them to potential harm to generator bearings and act promptly to investigate and evaluate any problems, failures should be averted. This article reviews two aspects of trouble-shooting: discovering and defining potential problems that might cause bearing failure; and pinpointing the cause of failures to prevent similar ones in the future.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:6

TITLE: Automating existing hydro stations: A cost-effective rehabilitation option
AUTHORS: Jarvis, D E; Bevivino, J P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; DESIGN; INSTALLATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; AUTOMATION; DATA ACQUISITION SYSTEMS; PERSONNEL; TRAINING; ANIMALS; CONTROL SYSTEMS; EDUCATION; MAMMALS; MAN; ON-LINE CONTROL SYSTEMS; ON-LINE SYSTEMS; POWER PLANTS; PRIMATES; VERTEBRATES; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The 135-MW Keokuk hydroelectric plant on the Mississippi River quietly generates power, operating much the same way as it has for the last 78 years. The 17 original Francis turbine units are in good working order, and the original generators, rewound in the 1940s and 1950s, are operating smoothly. Operating as it did originally, though, means the plant requires extensive human interaction. Operators must be on hand to manually perform all tasks required to start and stop the units. Although the plant's original mechanical governor control equipment is still operable and reliable, it has required more and more maintenance in the last several years. The Keokuk plant is typical of many of the existing hydroelectric facilities in North America-equipment in the plants, though decades old, provides adequate reliability, yet the control schemes are labor intensive. Faced with rising operation and maintenance costs in the mid-1980s, Union Electric Company, who owns and operates Keokuk, began exploring rehabilitation options that would make the plant more efficient. Initial feasibility studies indicated that, by automating the plant's control system, the utility could save hundreds of thousands of dollars each year in manpower costs and, at the same time, improve system monitoring and reduce energy costs. As a result, Union Electric has undertaken major automation projects at both its Keokuk and 60-year-old Osage hydro plants. Advances in electronics during the last five years have led to reliable, cost-effective control systems. By installing these systems, owners of aging hydro facilities can cut operation and maintenance expenses and improve the efficiency of the original generating equipment.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:6

TITLE: Responding to emergencies: This is only a test
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; FAILURES; FLOODS; SIMULATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; EMERGENCY PLANS; DISASTERS; POWER PLANTS; 130800* - Hydro Energy- Health & Safety- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: This article describes Highwater '89, a simulated dam failure exercise on the Columbia River. The exercise involved the simulated failure of several dams along the upper Columbia River caused by two earthquakes. This exercise represented the first time that a realistic, real-time simulation of a flood was used to test regulation and emergency response procedures involving several dam owners in a region of the country. Shortcomings in existing emergency response procedures were identified and are now being addressed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:6

TITLE: Using sound to divert fish from turbine intakes
AUTHORS: Loeffelman, P H; Hassel, J.H. van; Klinect, D A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; AVOIDANCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; SOUND WAVES; BEHAVIOR; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Experiments using underwater sound to deflect fish away from turbine intakes indicate that acoustical signals can potentially make hydroelectric projects more compatible with fish. Four years of development and field tests conducted by the American Electric Power Company, Inc. (AEP), Columbus, Ohio, demonstrated that synthesized low frequency sounds can divert warm and cold freshwater adult and juvenile fish. Test results indicate that underwater sound merits further exploration by the hydropower industry as a possible alternative to physically screening power plant intakes and other mitigation measures. The potential effect on the future of the industry is great, since project compatibility with fish is one constraint limiting development of new hydroelectric facilities, according to the US Department of Energy. In a patented process, AEP used sounds from fish such as chinook salmon, steelhead trout, striped bass, freshwater drum, largemouth bass, and gizzard shad to synthesize signals capable of stimulating fish in the most sensitive portion of their hearing range. The process can create either attracting or repelling sound signals - depending on how the user wants to behaviorally guide the fish. So far, AEP has refined its ability to create repelling sounds, and has customized these signals for single or multiple-target species. Although the hearing range of a few fish species has been determined previously in laboratory tests, the data is not comprehensive and doesn't include hearing ranges of many species at various life stages living near AEP's hydro plants.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:6

TITLE: Field tests with a prototype duplicate microprocessor based governor for a hydro turbine
AUTHORS: Li, Z; Ye, L; Wei, S; Malik, O P; Hope, G S; Hancock, G C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; DESIGN; IMPLEMENTATION; MICROPROCESSORS; COMPUTERS; CONTROL SYSTEMS; ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; MICROELECTRONIC CIRCUITS; ON-LINE CONTROL SYSTEMS; ON-LINE SYSTEMS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Field tests have been conducted with a prototype duplicate microprocessor-based governor for a hydro-turbine. The control strategy used in the governor determines the control parameters using an intelligent self-improvement procedure for no-load and loaded conditions. A brief description of the control strategy and implementation, and the results of the field tests are described in this paper.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 6:3
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: A state-space pressure and speed sensing governor for hydrogenerators
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; SPEED REGULATORS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; ELECTRICAL TRANSIENTS; NOISE; PRESSURE MEASUREMENT; SIMULATION; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TRANSIENTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; VOLTAGE DROP; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: This paper researches the use of the pressure signal for speed control of hydrogenerators. This is done by first analyzing and modelling the plant, assuming an isolated, resistive load. A set of governor gains, K{sub p}, K{sub l}, and K{sub D}, are then found which give an optimal response to a change in load level using speed feedback. With this response as a benchmark, various methods are analyzed and implemented, utilizing the pressure signal, to improve upon the response of the system. A state-space observer, is designed to attenuate noise on the pressure signal. Results show that an observer-based controller using all states as input, as compared to the PID controller, improves the transient response of hydrogenerators, is effective at filtering out the noise on the pressure signal, and is more robust to both steady-state pressure and plant parameter variations.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 6:3
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: Keeping dams safe in earthquake country
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SEISMIC EFFECTS; SAFETY; QUEBEC
DESCRIPTION: Although no dam has ever failed in Canada due to an earthquake, the provincial utility of Quebec-concerned about public safety-is evaluating how well its 500 dams can stand up to a big quake. This paper reviews Hydro-Quebec`s program for seismic safety evaluation. Their program includes several aspects: (1) A data communications network, (2) Inspection procedures, and (3) Dam evaluation guidelines. Application of their program after the Saguenay seismic event is discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1991

TITLE: Looking into the crystal ball: A new method for projecting plant costs
AUTHORS: Eckhoff, D W; Keaton, J R; Strassburger, A G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; MAINTENANCE; COST ESTIMATION
DESCRIPTION: By combining value engineering and risk analysis techniques, an owner of a hydroelectric project can identify an optimal operations and maintenance program for the future-and then decide if it`s worth the cost. This paper describes a systematic approach to discovering future costs and provides a case study that assesses the future maintenance/repair costs of a 10 MW facility on the Lower Provo River.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1991

TITLE: How safe are your gates?
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; CLOSURES; DESIGN; OPERATION; RELIABILITY
DESCRIPTION: Gates are critical pieces of equipment at most hydro plants. To maintain routine operation and ensure plant safety, they must operate reliably. Therefore, the primary considerations in gate design are reliability, safety, and dependable performance. Throughout the industry, gate designs are sometimes used that don`t meet strict reliability and safety standards. To ensure optimum performance, gate designers and plant owners need to be aware of, and follow, several design considerations. This paper is review of the several types of gates and their desirable characteristics.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1991

TITLE: Combining loss and cost objectives in daily hydro-thermal economic scheduling
AUTHORS: El-Hawary, M E; Ravindranath, K M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; FOSSIL-FUEL POWER PLANTS; COST; FUEL CONSUMPTION; PERFORMANCE TESTING; ELECTRIC POWER; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ITERATIVE METHODS; MULTIVARIATE ANALYSIS; PLANNING; POWER GENERATION; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY CONSUMPTION; ENERGY SOURCES; MATHEMATICS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; STATISTICS; TESTING; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 299000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation
DESCRIPTION: A formulation of optimal hydro-thermal power flow in electric power systems combining the minimum loss objective with the more conventional minimum fuel cost objective is considered. The implementation is based on a Newton's iterative procedure, with special initial guess and sparsity-based matrix manipulations to obtain improved convergence properties. The strategies are developed using three standard test systems. This paper discusses the question of assigning an equivalent cost to the loss objective component and compare results obtained using two proposed mechanisms. The first is based on results of conventional dispatch using Kron's loss formula and the second uses the bus incremental costs involved in the OPF solution. The effects of varying the relative weights assigned to each objective component on pertinent system variables such as active and reactive power generations as well as voltages are explored.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 6:3
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: Making friends for hydro: Providing recreational opportunities
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; PUBLIC RELATIONS; RECREATIONAL AREAS; MANAGEMENT; PUBLIC OPINION; POWER PLANTS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: One northeastern U.S. utility has been forming friendly ties with the public, offering recreation amenities at its hydro projects. As a result, the company has a strong base of public support as it enters relicensing.

TITLE: Hydropower: Making its mark in North America
AUTHORS: Barnes, M J; Eden, L; Vansant, C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CANADA; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; USA; OPERATING COST; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY; US BUREAU OF RECLAMATION; COST; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; US DOI; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: Hydro Review recently surveyed leaders in the hydro generation industry in Canada and the U.S. to discover what plans they have for their hydropower resources in the 1990s. They identified several activities and trends that point toward continued growth of hydro in North America. These trends are: producers are continuing major upgrade and rehabilitation work with schedules extending well into the next century; costs for continual, routine hydro operations and maintenance are stable; the overall cost of generating hydropower is low; plans for new hydro development in both the U.S. and Canada are ongoing.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:4

TITLE: Shedding light on hydroelectric thrust bearing problems
AUTHORS: Baudry, R A; Rielly, D H
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; BEARINGS; FAILURE MODE ANALYSIS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; HISTORICAL ASPECTS; SURFACE FINISHING; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; SYSTEM FAILURE ANALYSIS; SYSTEMS ANALYSIS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Why did thrust bearing failures, so rare in hydro plants built in the first decades of this century, increase greatly during and after World War II Engineers have found that modern manufacturing techniques created problems as well as solutions. Two primary reasons for failure are a too smooth surface finish, and an oil film force that causes the split runner in the thrust bearings to slip, which results in fretting.
