TITLE: A hydropower program reappears in the DOE budget
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; US DOE; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; IDAHO NATIONAL ENGINEERING LABORATORY; NATIONAL ENERGY ACTS; ORNL; SOLAR ENERGY RESEARCH INSTITUTE; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; LAWS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; US AEC; US ERDA; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The Department of Energy's (DOE) current budget includes a $1 million appropriation for hydropower research and development. And, the Bush administration is requesting another $1 million for DOE to continue work in hydro next year. These budgets represent the first significant federal hydro R D funding in several years. Many believe that President Bush's push for a national energy strategy - which stresses the importance of developing domestic, renewable energy sources - has revived interest in hydropower development at DOE. During a Congressional hearing earlier this year on Senate Bill 341 (the National Energy Security Act of 1991), Kevin Kelly of DOE's Office of Policy, Planning, and Analysis spoke to the advantages of hydro. He testified that in addition to offering a large and secure renwable energy resource that produces no atmospheric emissions or toxic wastes, hydropower provides utilities with the ability to respond quickly to variations in load demand with very low operating costs. The hydro studies being conducted by DOE are attempting to find ways to make better use of this valuable resource.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:4

TITLE: Estimated loss of juvenile salmonids to predation by northern squawfish, walleyes, and smallmouth bass in John Day Reservoir, Columbia River. [Oncorhynchus spp. ; Ptychocheilus oregonensis; Stizostedion vitreum; Micropterus dolomieu; O. tshawytscha]
AUTHORS: Rieman, B E; Beamesderfer, R C; Vigg, S; Poe, T P
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; COLUMBIA RIVER; PREDATOR-PREY INTERACTIONS; DAMS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; ANADROMOUS FISHES; ECOLOGY; FEEDING; MORTALITY; POPULATION DYNAMICS; WATER RESERVOIRS; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; FISHES; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; VERTEBRATES; 540310* - Environment, Aquatic- Basic Studies- (1990-); 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The authors estimated the loss of juvenile salmonids Oncorhynchus spp. to predation by northern squawfish Ptychocheilus oregonensis, walleyes Stizostedion vitreum, and smallmouth bass Micropterus dolomieu in John Day Reservoir during 1983-1986. Their estimates were based on measures of daily prey consumption, predator numbers, and numbers of juvenile salmonids entering the reservoir during the April-August period of migration. They estimated the mean annual loss was 2.7 million juvenile salmonids. Northern squawfish were responsible for 78% of the total loss; walleyes accounted for 13% and smallmouth bass for 9%. Twenty-one percent of the loss occurred in a small area immediately below McNary Dam at the head of John Day Reservoir. The authors estimated that the three predator species consumed 14% of all juvenile salmonids that entered the reservoir. Mortality changed by month and increased late in the migration season. Monthly mortality estimates ranged from 7% in June and 61% in August. Mortality from predation was highest for chinook salmon O. tshawytscha, which migrated in July and August. Despite uncertainties in the estimates, it is clear that predation by resident fish predators can easily account for previously explained mortality of out-migrating juvenile salmonids. Alteration of the Columbia River by dams and a decline in the number of salmonids could have increased the fraction of mortality caused by predation over what is was in the past.
RELATION: Journal Name: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society; (United States); Journal Volume: 120:4
JOURNAL_NAME: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society; (United States)

TITLE: Abundance and distribution of northern squawfish, walleyes, and smallmouth bass in John Day Reservoir, Columbia river. [Ptychocheilus oregonensis; Micropterus dolomieu; Stizostedion vitreum]
AUTHORS: Beamesderfer, R C; Rieman, B E
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; COLUMBIA RIVER; ECOLOGY; ANADROMOUS FISHES; DAMS; POPULATION DYNAMICS; PREDATOR-PREY INTERACTIONS; WATER RESERVOIRS; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; FISHES; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; VERTEBRATES; 540310* - Environment, Aquatic- Basic Studies- (1990-); 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The authors used mark-recapture and catch-per-unit effort data to estimate abundances and distributions of three potential predators on juvenile salmonids migrating through John Day Reservoir in 1984-1986. The northern squawfish Ptychocheilus oregonensis was the most abundant predator (estimated population: 85, 316), followed by smallmouth bass Micropterus dolomieu (34,954) and walleye Stizostedion vitreum (15,168). Because of uncertainty in sampling and assumption of the mark-recapture estimator, the combined abundance of these three predators could lie between 50,000 and 500,000. They believe, however, that bias is probably negative, and that any errors should result in conservative estimates. Northern squawfish were common reservoir-wide, but large concentrations occurred immediately below McNary Dam near the head of John Day Reservoir. Walleyes were largely restricted to the upper third of the reservoir, whereas the number of smallmouth bass increased progressively downriver. As judged by abundance and distribution, northern squawfish have by far the greatest potential for predation on juvenile salmonids. They also expect predation to be unevenly distributed in time and space as a result of variations in the number and distribution of predators.
RELATION: Journal Name: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society; (United States); Journal Volume: 120:4
JOURNAL_NAME: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society; (United States)

TITLE: Rates of consumption of juvenile salmonids and alternative prey fish by northern squawfish, walleyes, smallmouth bass, and channel catfish in John Day Reservoir, Columbia River. [Ptychocheilus oregonensis; Stizostedion vitreum; Micropterus dolomieu; Ictalurus punctatus; Oncorhynchus spp]
AUTHORS: Vigg, S; Poe, T P; Prendergast, L A; Hansel, H C
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; COLUMBIA RIVER; ECOLOGY; FISHES; PREDATOR-PREY INTERACTIONS; ANADROMOUS FISHES; FEEDING; POPULATION DYNAMICS; WASHINGTON; WATER RESERVOIRS; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; FEDERAL REGION X; NORTH AMERICA; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; USA; VERTEBRATES; 540310* - Environment, Aquatic- Basic Studies- (1990-); 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Adult northern squawfish Ptychocheilus oregonesis, walleyes Stizostedion vitreum, smallmouth bass Micropterus dolomieu, and channel catfish Ictalurus punctatus were sampled from four regions of John Day Reservoir from April to August 1983-1986 to quantify their consumption of 13 species of prey fish, particularly seaward-migrating juvenile Pacific salmon and steelhead (Oncorhynchus spp.). Consumption rates were estimated from field data on stomach contents and digestion rate relations determined in previous investigations. For each predator, consumption rates varied by reservoir area, month, time of day, and predator size or age. The greatest daily consumption of salmonids by northern squawfish and channel catfish occurred in the upper end of the reservoir below McNary Dam. Greatest daily predation by walleyes and smallmouth bass occurred in the middle and lower reservoir. Consumption rates of all predators were highest in July, concurrent with maximum temperature and abundance of juvenile salmonids. Feeding by the predators tended to peak after dawn and near midnight. Northern squawfish below McNary Dam exhibited this pattern, but fed mainly in the morning hours down-reservoir. The daily ration of total prey fish was highest for northern squawfish over 451 mm fork length, for walleyes 201-250 mm, for smallmouth bass 176-200 mm, and for channel catfish 401-450 mm. Averaged over all predator sizes and sampling months (April-August), the total daily ration (fish plus other prey) of smallmouth bass was about twice that of channel catfish, northern squawfish, and walleyes. However, northern squawfish was clearly the major predator on juvenile salmonids.
RELATION: Journal Name: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society; (United States); Journal Volume: 120:4
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ISSN 0002-8487; CODEN: TAFSA; TRN: 92-035479
JOURNAL_NAME: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society; (United States)

TITLE: Machined blocks ease job of separating generator rotor from Francis-type turbine
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; DECOUPLING; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ROTORS; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: The Bureau of Reclamation has designed a new method of separating the generator rotor from a hydraulic turbine. Before disassembly, workers measure the distance from the top of the discharge ring to the bottom of the turbine runner, at 10 to 12 locations around the discharge ring. Mechanics then machine steel blocks to the exact measurement for each location. Workers then use the generator's braking system to jack up the generator, and then set the steel blocks in place on the discharge ring. The generator is then lowered onto the jacking block, which supports the rotor. The turbine runner barely touches the steel blocks. The coupling bolts are then removed and the rotor lifted out. Since the elevation of the turbine runner is not significantly changed, reassembly is a matter of setting the rotor in place. This method has saved manhours of labor and has increased worker safety by decreasing workers' handling of heavy equipment.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:3

TITLE: Improving operating efficiency with more advanced generation control methods
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; EFFICIENCY; POWER GENERATION; CONTROL; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; EQUATIONS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; US BUREAU OF RECLAMATION; CONTROL SYSTEMS; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; ON-LINE CONTROL SYSTEMS; ON-LINE SYSTEMS; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; US DOI; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: A goal of most hydroelectric plant owners and operators is to produce as much energy as possible with the water that is available. By improving the power production efficiency of a plant, the turbine/generators can produce more electricity with the same amount of water. One way to achieve efficiency is by modifying operational methods, including generation control. Simply improving a plant's operational control scheme can result in as much as 6 percent gains in efficiency and additional energy production worth millions of dollars.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:3

TITLE: Gapping the miles with hydro conferencing
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MAINTENANCE; OPERATION; PERSONNEL; COMMUNICATIONS; OPERATING COST; TELEPHONES; ANIMALS; COST; MAMMALS; MAN; POWER PLANTS; PRIMATES; VERTEBRATES; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Montana Power Company uses teleconferencing to maintain communications among its operations and maintenance personnel. Once a week, the staff meets by teleconference to discuss operation and maintenance plans, staff schedules, and other operational matters at the company's 14 hydro projects. In five years of operation, teleconferencing has improved plant scheduling, avoided operating problems, and reduced operating costs. In addition, it has made possible the creation of a team approach to operations and maintenance.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:3

TITLE: Hydro update: Obstacles to capacity development
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; COURTS; LAWSUITS; STATE GOVERNMENT; US CLEAN WATER ACT; US FERC; LAWS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POLLUTION LAWS; POWER PLANTS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 299000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: This article examines some examples of licensing obstacles that can thwart development of hydroelectric capacity. Topics discussed include incremental capacity, licensing preferences, state-imposed conditions, Federal Energy Regulatory Commission vs. state agency authority scope, Clean Water Act scope and influence of state fish and wildlife agencies in license requirements.
RELATION: Journal Name: Public Utilities Fortnightly; (United States); Journal Volume: 127:11

TITLE: Water watch
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ATMOSPHERIC PRECIPITATIONS; FORECASTING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; CAPACITY; STREAMS; FLOW RATE; DROUGHTS; SOILS; USA; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: This issue of [open quotes]Water Watch[close quotes] focuses on soil moisture conditions across the country as of the first of April. In addition, the department describes streamflow conditions across the US forecast for April through July. The information presented is based on data from the US Geological Survey, the National Weather Service, and the Soil Conservation Service. For purposes of providing this information, the US is divided into six regions. The Hydropower Generation Report can be used to observe how weather conditions affected hydro generation in March.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:3

TITLE: Evaluating effects of proposed instream flow releases for hydroelectric projects
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; FLOW RATE; LICENSING REGULATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; RECREATIONAL AREAS; US FERC; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; REGULATIONS; SIMULATION; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: An issue often associated with hydro project relicensing is that of minimum instream flow -- and whether licensees should provide or increase releases from the project to protect and enhance downstream aquatic habitat. Changes in instream flow requirements can affect energy production, water supply, and recreational opportunities at a project. Therefore, licensees should thoroughly evaluate alternative flow release regimes proposed during relicensing. One hydro project owner in Texas recently used a computer model to evaluate the effects of various instream flow release regimes proposed during the course of relicensing. The computer program allowed the licensee to analyze the effects of each alternative release regime and then bring those effects to the attention of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC). As a result, the project's new license (relicense) established a flow release regime that benefits downstream fish and wildlife without causing intolerable harm to other purposes of the project. Traditionally, hydro project owners and resource agencies have used the IFIM methodology to study how changes in instream flow affect habitat. Now, several hydro engineering firms are developing specialized computer programs such as the one for Morris Sheppard Dam to determine effects on reservoir levels and yield and hydroelectric generation, instead of focusing only on habitat effects.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:3

TITLE: Reacting to the National Energy Strategy
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; NATIONAL ENERGY PLANS; NATIONAL GOVERNMENT; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; LICENSING REGULATIONS; US FERC; US NATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY ACT; US PUBLIC UTILITY REGULATORY POLICIES ACT; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY POLICY; ENERGY SOURCES; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; LAWS; NATIONAL ENERGY ACTS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER; REGULATIONS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 293000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Policy, Legislation, & Regulation
DESCRIPTION: In February, 1991, the Bush administration unveiled its National Energy Strategy (NES). The NES contains elements relating to hydropower which could be beneficial to the industry. The major elements of the NES relating to hydropower are presented, along with reaction to the strategy by six industry leaders.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:3

TITLE: Minimizing losses from an earthen dam breach
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; SYSTEM FAILURE ANALYSIS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SAFETY ANALYSIS; FAILURES; FLOOD CONTROL; CONTROL; POWER PLANTS; SYSTEMS ANALYSIS; 130800* - Hydro Energy- Health & Safety- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The prospect of a dam breach is universally feared by dam owners. In many cases, a failure would lead to water rising many feet above the 100-yr flood plain downstream, with the likelihood of life and property losses. The state of Illinois has identified four important parameters involved in dam breach. By recognizing and analyzing the roles played by these parameters at a specific dam site, engineers can do a better job of designing and constructing a new earthen dam, or rehabilitating and then operating and maintaining an existing structure to reduce the magnitude of flooding and the resulting losses in case of a dam breach.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:3

TITLE: Predicting and prioritizing maintenance for concrete structures
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CONCRETES; NONDESTRUCTIVE TESTING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MAINTENANCE; CALCIUM CARBONATES; ELECTRIC CONDUCTIVITY; ELECTRIC POTENTIAL; ELECTROCHEMICAL CORROSION; MECHANICAL IMPEDANCE; REPAIR; STEELS; TASK SCHEDULING; ULTRASONIC TESTING; ACOUSTIC TESTING; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; ALLOYS; BUILDING MATERIALS; CALCIUM COMPOUNDS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBONATES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CORROSION; DATA PROCESSING; ELECTRICAL PROPERTIES; IMPEDANCE; IRON ALLOYS; IRON BASE ALLOYS; MATERIALS; MATERIALS TESTING; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; POWER PLANTS; PROCESSING; TESTING; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Using nondestructive testing of concrete structures to predict maintenance needs can help schedule maintenance work in advance and prevent unexpected shutdowns. Nondestructive testing methods are described and development of a testing program is discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:3

TITLE: Long-term views on hydro O M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MAINTENANCE; OPERATION; CONCRETES; DAMS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; LICENSING REGULATIONS; OPERATING COST; PROGRAM MANAGEMENT; BUILDING MATERIALS; COST; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; MANAGEMENT; MATERIALS; POWER PLANTS; REGULATIONS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Like the proverbial iceberg, at least 90 percent of the effort, costs, and headaches of owning a hydroelectric plant is usually hidden from view in the unglamorous, but essential, category of operations and maintenance (O M). While the processing of planning, designing, and constructing a plant may command more attention and excitement, and the economic benefits of ownership may be more satisfying, the day-in, day-out work of O M is a key component in the long-term success of a hydro plant. With project lives of between 50 and 100 years, running a hydro plant can be an extremely long-lived venture requiring an equally long-term approach to O M. Hydro O M experts in the US and Canada generally agree that successful O M requires a long-term view. Representatives of government agencies, investor-owned utilities, and private non-utility hydro owners contacted for this article all share similar perspectives, experiences, and methods for dealing with O M problems.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:3

TITLE: Hydropower licensing authority struggles
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; FISHERIES; LAND USE; US FERC; WASHINGTON; WILD ANIMALS; ANIMALS; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; FEDERAL REGION X; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; USA; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 299000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: This article examines the issues facing licensing and relicensing of hydropower plants in the face of increasing environmental concern for fisheries and wildlife habitat. Topics discussed include significant adverse effects, Federal Energy Regulatory Commission authority, Washington state hydro project, application of the Federal Power Act, revision of hydro license procedures, mandatory fishways, and National Energy Strategy.
RELATION: Journal Name: Public Utilities Fortnightly; (United States); Journal Volume: 127:11

TITLE: Geothermal electric power generation in Iceland for the proposed Iceland/United Kingdom HVDC power link
AUTHORS: Hammons, T J; Palmason, G; Thorhallsson, S
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; POWER GENERATION; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; COST; ELECTRIC POWER; EVALUATION; HVDC SYSTEMS; ICELAND; INDUSTRY; POWER TRANSMISSION; SITE CHARACTERIZATION; UNITED KINGDOM; DC SYSTEMS; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; EUROPE; ISLANDS; POWER; POWER SYSTEMS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 150800* - Geothermal Power Plants; 150100 - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability; 150500 - Geothermal Energy- Economics, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The paper reviews geothermal electric power potential in Iceland which could economically be developed to supplement hydro power for the proposed HVDC Power Link to the United Kingdom, and power intensive industries in Iceland, which are envisaged for development at this time. Technically harnessable energy for electricity generation taking account of geothermal resources down to an assumed base depth, temperature distribution in the crust, probable geothermal recovery factor, and accessibility of the field, has been assessed. Nineteen known high-temperature fields and 9 probable fields have been identified. Technically harnessable geo-heat for various areas is indicated. Data on high temperature fields suitable for geothermal electric power generation, and on harnessable energy for electric power generation within volcanic zones, is stated, and overall assessments are made. The paper then reviews how the potential might be developed, discussing preference of possible sites, and cost of the developments at todays prices. Cost of geothermal electric power generation with comparative costs for hydro generation are given. Possible transmission system developments to feed the power to the proposed HVDC Link converter stations are also discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 6:2
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: Soviet Union's Energy Situation
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 21 SPECIFIC NUCLEAR REACTORS AND ASSOCIATED PLANTS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 03 NATURAL GAS; 02 PETROLEUM; USSR; ENERGY POLICY; ENERGY SOURCES; AGING; AVAILABILITY; CHERNOBYLSK-4 REACTOR; COAL; CONSTRUCTION; ENERGY CONSERVATION; ENERGY CONSUMPTION; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; EXPORTS; FOREIGN POLICY; FOSSIL-FUEL POWER PLANTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; LABOR RELATIONS; MAINTENANCE; MANAGEMENT; MINING; NATURAL GAS; NUCLEAR POWER; PETROLEUM; POWER GENERATION; PUBLIC OPINION; REACTOR ACCIDENTS; REACTOR SAFETY; REPAIR; RESERVES; SIBERIA; SUPPLY AND DEMAND; TRANSPORT; URANIUM; VOLGA RIVER; WWER TYPE REACTORS; ACCIDENTS; ACTINIDES; ASIA; CARBONACEOUS MATERIALS; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ELEMENTS; ENRICHED URANIUM REACTORS; EUROPE; FLUIDS; FOSSIL FUELS; FUEL GAS; FUELS; GAS FUELS; GASES; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; GRAPHITE MODERATED REACTORS; LWGR TYPE REACTORS; MATERIALS; METALS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; POWER REACTORS; PWR TYPE REACTORS; REACTORS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; RIVERS; SAFETY; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; THERMAL REACTORS; TRADE; WATER COOLED REACTORS; WATER MODERATED REACTORS; 290200* - Energy Planning & Policy- Economics & Sociology; 293000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Policy, Legislation, & Regulation; 210800 - Nuclear Power Plants- Economics; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 200600 - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects- (1990-); 030200 - Natural Gas- Reserves, Geology, & Exploration; 020200 - Petroleum- Reserves, Geology, & Exploration
DESCRIPTION: The Soviet Union is a country of vast sources of energy supply including oil, natural gas, coal, uranium, and hydropower, all of which are used in varying degrees to supply its energy needs. In spite of this wealth of resources, the Soviet Union has difficulty meeting its demand for energy. Opinions on the situation vary, from those who claim the country is in the midst of an energy crisis to those who argue that distribution is the only difficulty. But in any event, the unfortunate fact is that in some areas of the country, energy needs exceed its availability. Until recently, soviet energy policy concentrated on supply. With the release of its 1983 Energy Program however, the Soviet Union acknowledged the necessity of a fundamental shift in energy policy from the supply side to the demand side in order to curb energy consumption.
RELATION: Journal Name: Nuexco. Monthy report to the Nuclear Industry; (United States); Journal Volume: 273
JOURNAL_NAME: Nuexco. Monthy report to the Nuclear Industry; (United States)

TITLE: Heuristic operating policies for reservoir system simulation
AUTHORS: Johnson, S A; Stedinger, J R; Staschus, K
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; WATER RESERVOIRS; RESOURCE MANAGEMENT; CAPACITY; DESORPTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPERATION; OPTIMIZATION; SIMULATION; STORAGE; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; MANAGEMENT; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: Reservoir system simulation models are widely used to determine a system's firm water yield, average yield, or hydropower capacity. Most such models use guidelines to define the system's operating policy. Alternatively, optimization can be used within the simulation to identify a reasonable operating strategy. In this paper a theoretical justification is provided for several heuristic operating guidelines, including the widely used space rule. The guidelines are expressed as a mathematical objective function and combined with constraints on system operation to yield one-period optimization models improved the simulated operation of the Central Valley Project in California over the critical period of record and provided reasonable policies for other hydrologic scenarios.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resources Research; (United States); Journal Volume: 27:5

TITLE: FERC's position: Embankment protection for increasing spillway capacity
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; SAFETY; EMBANKMENTS; EROSION; US FERC; REGULATIONS; BUILDING MATERIALS; CEMENTS; FLOODS; FLUID FLOW; DISASTERS; MATERIALS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) has maintained for some time that finding the means to protect an embankment from failure due to overtopping would represent an important advance in the dam safety and an economic point of view. As a result, FERC's Division of Dam Safety and Inspections has maintained a keen interest in the recent advances and ongoing research in embankment protection. The foremost mission of FERC's dam safety program is to provide for the general public's safety downstream of dams at hydroelectric projects under FERC jurisdiction. To accomplish this mission, some older dams have had to be modified to meet present-day engineering criteria, particularly with respect to stability and spillway capacity. While dam modifications to ensure the public safety are mandatory, it has always been FERC's policy to allow licensees to pursue the most cost-effective means of modification. However, the traditional approach to meeting FERC's requirement has been to expand or construct structural concrete spillways. Increasing the spillway capacity of a project is often a very expensive repair. On the other hand, using innovative methods of protecting embankments against overtopping is much less expensive and thus can represent tremendous savings for project licensees. Of the 2,200 dams under FERC's jurisdiction, approximately 700 are major embankment structures. Clearly, a cost-effective means to upgrade these dams, where necessary, would have an important effect on the dam safety community.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:2

TITLE: Protecting embankment dams with concrete block systems
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; SAFETY; EMBANKMENTS; EROSION; BUILDING MATERIALS; CONCRETE BLOCKS; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; FLOODS; FLUID FLOW; DISASTERS; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; ECONOMICS; MATERIALS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Dam owners are frequently confronted with the costly and difficult task of retrofitting existing embankment dams and associated outlet works to accommodate current estimates of the probable maximum flood (PMF). Searching for a cost-effective retrofit, engineers have recently considered placing a protective overlay on the embankment and allowing limited overtopping. This armoring of the embankment protects against damaging and potentially catastrophic erosion caused by steep-slope, high-velocity flow. Embankment armoring is an alternative to the more costly and time-consuming methods of enlarging flood control spillways, raising embankments, or extending outlet control structures. Structural (reinforced) concrete and, more recently, roller-compacted concrete traditionally have been used for embankment armoring to achieve the desired level of performance and stability. However, articulated concrete block revetments (a series of individual blocks placed together to form an overlay) now offer another viable armoring option. An articulated concrete block revetment may be the method that can achieve the desired level of stability for the least cost. Advantages of the method are its low cost compared to conventional protection techniques and its applicability to a wide range of hydraulic conditions.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:2

TITLE: Embankment dams: Methods of protection during overtopping
AUTHORS: Frizell, K H; Mefford, B W; Dodge, R A; Vermeyen, T B
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; SAFETY; EMBANKMENTS; EROSION; US BUREAU OF RECLAMATION; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; BUILDING MATERIALS; CEMENTS; FLOODS; FLUID FLOW; HIGH-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; US FERC; DISASTERS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MATERIALS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; US DOE; US DOI; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: As a result of ongoing research, information on the performance of several types of materials to use to protect embankments from erosion due to overtopping floods is available. Dam owners can use this performance data to select a reliable overtopping protection system for their dams. Some block-type revetment systems have proven reliable for protecting low embankments subjected to small overtopping heads, and many embankment dams have been protected with either soil cement or roller compacted concrete (RCC). Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) recently approved the use of RCC for protection of the embankment dam at Southern California Edison's Bishop Creek [number sign]2 hydroelectric plant. As a result of FERC's acceptance of RCC for overtopping protection to add spillway capacity, the utility saved $500,000. Protective systems for high embankment structures currently favor using RCC or slip-formed stepped or smooth concrete deck overlays. Reclamation's near-prototype research program, continuing for the next four years, will extend the present data base for low embankment dams while providing information on scale effects of aeration and dynamic forces associated with high embankment dam protection schemes. This research should provide the confidence needed to apply overtopping protection to high head embankment dams.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:2

TITLE: Assessing economic and emissions effects: What hydro does for your generation system
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; AIR POLLUTION; CARBON DIOXIDE; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; FOSSIL-FUEL POWER PLANTS; MONTE CARLO METHOD; NITROGEN OXIDES; SULFUR DIOXIDE; CALCULATION METHODS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; ECONOMICS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POLLUTION; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SIMULATION; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; SULFUR OXIDES; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The environmental effects of hydropower have come under increased scrutiny since the passage of the Electric Consumer's Protection Act (ECPA) in 1986. Until recently, methods used to quantify hydro's effects on the environment have been limited to evaluating effects on fish and wildlife. The methods also have examined the project in isolation from the remainder of the power system. However, because of the recent development of sophisticated computerized analytical tools, hydro's environmental and economic effects within the context of an entire power system can now be determined and quantified. With access to this kind of information, policy makers should be able to make better, more fully informed decisions about hydro's value to a generation system. They can then establish operating criteria for hydro facilities that recognize these values. Several new computerized analytical tools can accurately simulate operation of entire utility systems, and even regional grids, and thus provide information regarding not only effects on fish and wildlife, but overall economic and environmental effects of hydro projects within the system. These computer models typically can provide statistics on operating costs, marginal costs, unit production levels, and emissions levels.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:2

TITLE: Recreation and hydropower: A partnership deserving attention
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RECREATIONAL AREAS; PLANNING; WATER RESERVOIRS; LICENSING PROCEDURES; LICENSING REGULATIONS; PUBLIC OPINION; PUBLIC RELATIONS; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; POWER PLANTS; REGULATIONS; SURFACE WATERS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Recreation is an important consideration in hydroelectric project planning and licensing from both the regulatory and public relations perspectives. During licensing and relicensing, an applicant is required to address recreation issues, and may need to provide recreational opportunities as part of the hydro project. The developer or owner with a thorough understanding of recreational uses and opportunities at a project is in a better position to meet these requirements, and thus to ensure a balance between hydropower production and use of the non-power resources at the site. Addressing recreational issues is also a good way to gain public support for a project. Many people correlate the value of hydro projects with recreation opportunities at the site. Therefore, when recreation issues are treated as a meaningful part of project planning, there is an opportunity to develop public support. In order for applicants to select appropriate recreation plans and demonstrate equal consideration for power production and non-power values, a comprehensive planning approach that begins early in the licensing process is needed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:2

TITLE: Hydropower engineering handbook: A review
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; OPERATION; ECONOMICS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; FINANCING; HYDRAULIC EQUIPMENT; RECOMMENDATIONS; REVIEWS; DOCUMENT TYPES; EQUIPMENT; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: This article is a review of a handbook developed out of a four-day course on hydropower development presented by the books editors. The book is designed to provide a short explanation of a particular phenomenon, some design and operational guidelines, and references to other more specific publications. The book also addresses environment impacts of hydropower facilities.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:4

TITLE: Changing hydro policy
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LEGISLATION; HEARINGS; REGULATIONS; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; US CLEAN WATER ACT; US FERC; US NATIONAL ENERGY PLAN; DOCUMENT TYPES; ENERGY POLICY; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; LAWS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POLLUTION LAWS; POWER PLANTS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 293000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Policy, Legislation, & Regulation
DESCRIPTION: This article reviews current legislation and licensing reform affecting the hydropower industry. The topics are the role of hydropower, streamlining regulation, water quality, and exemptions for small hydropower projects. The provisions for hydropower make up one portion of the legislation introduced as the National Energy Security Act of 1991 and the National Energy Strategy.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:4

TITLE: Diverting water at dams during construction of hydro plants
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; OUTLET STRUCTURES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; SHUTDOWN; BARGES; LOS ALAMOS; PUMPS; US CORPS OF ENGINEERS; WATER QUALITY; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NEW MEXICO; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; URBAN AREAS; US DOD; US ORGANIZATIONS; USA; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) estimates that hydropower could contribute another 24,000 MW of electricity to the US power supply by building new plants at existing dams. (Conventional hydro currently contributes about 71,800 MW of electricity.) When installing a plant at an existing dam, it is often feasible to connect the plant to the existing outlet works of the dam. To do this, however, typically requires a temporary shutdown of the outlet works during construction. Since most dam owners are required to discharge a minimum flow of water through the outlet works to meet water quality standards, some type of temporary diversion scheme is essential. The Incorporated County of Los Alamos, New Mexico, was recently faced with this situation when constructing a hydroelectric project at an existing US Army Corps of Engineers' dam. The county hired Tudor Engineering Company in Oakland, California, to perform the design for the hydro project, including a water diversion system that temporarily conveyed reservoir discharges over the dam to the river downstream. The diversion was necessary so modifications could be made to the outlet works of the dam where the county was building its 13-MW plant. This system, comprised of pumps mounted on a floating barge in the reservoir, allowed the Corps of Engineers to maintain required instream flows while the outlet works were being modified.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:2

TITLE: Correcting mechanical unbalance in hydroelectric machines
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; CORRECTIONS; BEARINGS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MAINTENANCE; MECHANICAL SHAFTS; EQUIPMENT; MACHINE PARTS; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; SHAFTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Mechanical unbalance is one of several causes of high vibration or excessive shaft runout in hydroelectric machines. Shaft runout, in which the shaft connecting the turbine and the generator moves laterally, can subject bearings and structural supports to large pulsating forces. This can lead to a breakdown of a lubricating oil film, which can cause damage to bearings and the shaft. From the practical standpoint of the owner or operator of a hydro machine, unbalance does not often present a difficult problem to solve. However, solutions do require an understanding of the causes of unbalance. Mechanical unbalance possesses a reliable characteristic that distinguishes it from other causes of shaft runout (for a discussion of monitoring for shaft runout see the Machine Dynamics Notebook in Hydro Review's February 1991 issue). The frequency of the runout or vibration is generally once per revolution of the rotating parts. When total vibration is observed with another dominant frequency, some other cause is at work. Quite often when a vibration problem is investigated on a hydroelectric machine, there will be more than one cause. The contribution of any mechanical unbalance can be readily seen on a spectral plot. Even though the unbalance component of the total vibration may be relatively minor, it is sometimes desirable to reduce it by balancing so that the vibration from other causes becomes more tolerable. This may be done because unbalance is frequently seen as [open quotes]easier to fix[close quotes] than other causes, such as magnetic unbalance. In some cases, an intentional unbalance can be added that will counteract other undesired effects and result in a smoother running machine.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:2

TITLE: The 4 times 6 network; Upgrade of a major 500kV substation
AUTHORS: Page, R; Nishikawara, K; Stromotich, F
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER SUBSTATIONS; RELIABILITY; CAPITALIZED COST; CIRCUIT BREAKERS; COST; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT PROTECTION DEVICES; POWER PLANTS; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 240200 - Power System Networks, Transmission & Distribution- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes a study to enhance the reliability of BC Hydro's Ingledow 500 kV substation. It employs truth tables and frequency and duration analysis. The study included double-breaker double-bus and 4 {times} 6 arrangements, and 4 {times} 6 was recommended for its cost and reliability advantages.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Delivery (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA); Journal Volume: 6:2
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Power Delivery (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA)

TITLE: Gas turbines, hydro continue strong in new utility plant mix
SUBJECT: 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 42 ENGINEERING; FLUIDIZED BED BOILERS; CIRCULATING SYSTEMS; GAS TURBINES; PERFORMANCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LIGNITE; FLUIDIZED-BED COMBUSTION; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; COAL-FIRED GAS TURBINES; CONSTRUCTION; EFFICIENCY; GAS TURBINE POWER PLANTS; OFF-PEAK ENERGY STORAGE; PLANNING; PUMPED STORAGE; SOUTH CAROLINA; TEXAS; BOILERS; BROWN COAL; CARBONACEOUS MATERIALS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; COAL; COMBUSTION; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY STORAGE; EQUIPMENT; FEDERAL REGION VI; FOSSIL FUELS; FUELS; MACHINERY; MATERIALS; NORTH AMERICA; OXIDATION; POWER PLANTS; STORAGE; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; USA; 200102* - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Power Cycles; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 014000 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- Combustion; 421000 - Engineering- Combustion Systems
DESCRIPTION: This paper reports that the emphasis in utility power plant construction has shifted from the traditional large coal and nuclear power plants to gas turbines, which have the advantages of shorter construction lead times and quicker start-up. The latter feature makes them an easy choice for peaking power. The nuclear plant construction pipeline emptied with the completion of Comanche Peak and Seabrook. Construction of hydroelectric power stations continues, however, both at new locations and existing sites. The new Bad Creek pumped storage unit in South Carolina will generate more than 532 MW, and new capacity at the old Lewiston site in Maine will add 27 MW for Central Maine Power.
RELATION: Journal Name: Power Engineering; (United States); Journal Volume: 95:4

TITLE: Are we coming full circle. [regulatory constraints to development]
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING PROCEDURES; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT; CLEAN WATER ACTS; CONSUMER PROTECTION; ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY; LICENSING REGULATIONS; US ENERGY SECURITY ACT; US FERC; US PUBLIC UTILITY REGULATORY POLICIES ACT; WATER QUALITY; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; LAWS; NATIONAL ENERGY ACTS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POLLUTION LAWS; POWER PLANTS; REGULATIONS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations
DESCRIPTION: A decade ago, the US was seeing a renewed interest in hydropower. But as interest in hydro grew, so did public concerns. The result: regulations that complicate the development climate. Recent events, though, offer hope for streamlining regulation and once again expediting development of hydroelectric power.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:2

TITLE: Water watch. [streamflow conditions in US and hydropower generation]
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; CAPACITY; PRODUCTION; WATER; AVAILABILITY; TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY; US BUREAU OF RECLAMATION; US CORPS OF ENGINEERS; USA; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; US DOD; US DOI; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: This issue of [open quotes]Water Watch[close quotes] describes streamflow conditions across the US for January and February. In addition, the department focuses on the availability of water from April through July along rivers in the US. The information presented is based on data from the US Geological Survey, the National Weather Service, and the Soil Conservation Service. Handar has then collected and analyzed these data. For purposes of providing this information, the US is divided into six regions as indicated on the accompanying figure and table. The data presented in the Hydropower Generation Report can be used to observe how past streamflow conditions affected hydro generation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:2

TITLE: Distribution and stability of potential salmonid spawning gravels in steep boulder-bed streams of the eastern Sierra Nevada. [Salmo trutta; Oncorhynchus mykiss]
AUTHORS: Kondolf, G M; Cada, G F; Sale, M J; Felando, T
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ANADROMOUS FISHES; REPRODUCTION; STREAMS; ECOLOGY; ABUNDANCE; HABITAT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; MOUNTAINS; POPULATION DYNAMICS; SITE SELECTION; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; FISHES; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SURFACE WATERS; VERTEBRATES; 540310* - Environment, Aquatic- Basic Studies- (1990-); 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Interest in small hydroelectric development (< 5 MW) has recently focused attention on steep streams and the resident trout populations they contain. High-gradient boulder-bed streams have been the sites of relatively few studies of salmonid spawning habitat, although they have geomorphic and hydraulic characteristics - and therefore gravel distributions - that are quite different from the more commonly described lower-gradient channels. The authors documented gravel distribution in seven high-gradient stream reaches in the eastern Sierra Nevada. Gravels occurred only in locations characterized by relatively low shear stress; they formed small pockets in sites of low divergence and larger deposits upstream of natural hydraulic controls. In 1986 (a wet year), all tracer gravels placed in gravel pockets at nine sites on four streams were completely swept away, and substantial scour, fill, and other channel changes occurred at many sites. In 1987 (a dry year), tracer gravels and the channel cross sections were generally stable. Periodic mobility of gravel may explain why brown trout Salmo trutta are more abundant than rainbow trout Oncorhychus mykiss in the study reaches, where high flows occur every May and June during snowmelt. Brown trout are fall spawners, and their fry emerge long before the high snowmelt flows, whereas rainbow trout are spring spawners whose eggs are in the gravel, and thus vulnerable to scour, during snowmelt flows.
RELATION: Journal Name: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society; (United States); Journal Volume: 120:2
JOURNAL_NAME: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society; (United States)

TITLE: Digital simulation of an impulse turbine; The Bradley Lake project
AUTHORS: Wozniak, L; Collier, F; Foster, J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; TURBINES; STABILITY; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; DISTURBANCES; DYNAMIC LOADS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; SIMULATION; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: This paper discusses a digital simulation and stability study of the Bradley Lake hydroelectric project. The basic system consists of two 45-MW, multiple-jet impulse turbines supplied by a three mile conduit. A digital governor is utilized. Once produced, the simulation is used to investigate the stability of the system. The system was found to be locally stable, but unstable to large perturbations. Due to economic constraints in plant design, the response of the system to load acceptance is poor.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA); Journal Volume: 6:1
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA)

TITLE: A new computer method to optimize turbine design and runner replacement
AUTHORS: Goede, E; Cuenod, R; Grunder, R; Pestalozzi, J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FLUID FLOW; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; COMPUTER-AIDED DESIGN; COMPUTER GRAPHICS; NUMERICAL ANALYSIS; PERFORMANCE TESTING; PREDICTION EQUATIONS; DESIGN; EQUATIONS; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; MATHEMATICS; SIMULATION; TESTING; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: When a designer's ideas for the design or rehabilitation of a hydraulic turbine are tested before the actual machine is manufactured, operating characteristics can be improved. A variety of techniques exist to perform this preliminary design testing. In recent years, great progress has been made in the area of numerical simulation of physical phenomena. Sulzer Escher Wyss has been successfully using the computer method of numerical flow simulation to test designers' ideas. The method calculates the fluid flow in a hydraulic turbomachine, effectively simulating the hydraulic performance of a turbine before it is manufactured. The authors have used flow analysis as a theoretical tool -- a numerical test stand -- to aid in the first cut of turbomachinery design and rehabilitation. This way, only the fine tuning must be made in physical tests. This approach provides a fast and cost-effective layout procedure for machine components. However, the reliability of such a numerical test greatly depends on the quality of the method used, as well as on its proper use in terms of correct boundary conditions and accurate interpretation of the results. To aid in interpretation of the data from the flow analysis, the authors have developed a procedure to compress data from the flow calculations and present them in the form of sophisticated computer graphics. In this way, the design engineer can visualize the main relationships, which will aid him or her in making sound decisions regarding the turbine layout procedure. Ultimately, the method has helped optimize the design and rehabilitation of hydraulic machines, while reducing overall time and expense.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:1

TITLE: Overcoming anti-hydro policies in the Ohio River Basin
AUTHORS: Kissel, P C; Robbins, A I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; NATIONAL GOVERNMENT; ENERGY POLICY; LICENSING REGULATIONS; OHIO RIVER; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; FISHERIES; FLOOD CONTROL; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; US CORPS OF ENGINEERS; US DOE; US DOI; US FERC; US FWS; CONTROL; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER; REGULATIONS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; US DOD; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: This article focuses on the need to develop a national energy policy, with hydroelectric power playing a greater role. As an example of the consequences of a lack of a cohesive policy, the authors use the regulatory battles taking place over the development of hydroelectric power in the Ohio River Basin. Sixteen potential plants could provide 1,560 gigawatts of power and have been granted licenses, but the Department of the Interior appealed the license authorization. A slew of demands by other regulatory agencies are also hampering development.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:1

TITLE: Water watch
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; CAPACITY; STREAMS; FLOW RATE; USA; FLOODS; FORECASTING; SNOW; TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY; US BUREAU OF RECLAMATION; US CORPS OF ENGINEERS; ATMOSPHERIC PRECIPITATIONS; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; DISASTERS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SURFACE WATERS; US DOD; US DOI; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: The Hydropower Generation Report provides generation figures for the largest hydropower producers in each of six regions in the US. The report compares, for each month, the amount of hydroelectricity generated (in thousands of megawatt-hours) by each producers in the last two years to the ten-year average for that month. This database is used to figure long-term generation averages and percent of averages. The producers regularly provide current generation data to update the database. This issue of [open quotes]Water Watch[close quotes] focuses on winter snow conditions across the US as of mid-January. In addition, the department provides an outlook of spring flood potential. The information presented is based on data from the US Geological Survey, the National Weather Service, and the Soil Conservation Service.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:1

TITLE: Spiral case embedment: Sharing experiences
AUTHORS: Fazalare, R W; Hayes, S J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; COVERINGS; INSTALLATION; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; COATINGS; CONCRETES; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; PRESSURIZATION; BUILDING MATERIALS; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; ECONOMICS; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; MATERIALS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: One decision hydro project designers and developers make when building a new facility is what method to use to embed the turbine spiral case in the powerhouse concrete. The type of technique chosen often is based on the long-standing practice or individual preference of the plant owner. However, according to a recent industry survey, any method can be used successfully if proper design and installation procedures are followed. Although pressurized embedment has been the prominent method in the past, especially in the US, the bare deflated casing method is gaining popularity throughout the world because it can reduce cost and construction time. This method has been the primary technique used with apparent success in Japan and Scandinavia.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:1

TITLE: Fish monitoring: Getting a complete picture
AUTHORS: Kuehl, E S; Johnson, G E; Olson, F W
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FISHES; SAMPLING; SURVEYS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; LICENSING PROCEDURES; ACOUSTICS; OHIO RIVER; POPULATION DENSITY; SURVIVAL CURVES; TELEMETRY; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; COMMUNICATIONS; DATA TRANSMISSION; POWER PLANTS; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; VERTEBRATES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: During licensing or relicensing procedures, resource agencies often recommend that hydroelectric project owners monitor fish passage at the site of the power plant. By using multiple sampling techniques, an owner can made a comprehensive assessment of the fish population surrounding a site and determine how the project affects these fish. This approach was recently used at a hydro project in southern Ohio along the Ohio River. Recognizing that each commonly used biological sampling method has strengths and weaknesses, the plant owner, its consultants, and agency representatives decided on a strategy that employed four techniques to study the effects of the project on fish. Combining various monitoring methods provided complementary sampling of fish distributions and behavior in the river and at the dam. In this study, hydroacoustic techniques allowed extensive sampling over time and space. When complemented with species composition information from net sampling, hydroacoustic techniques produced useful information on fish population and entrainment. Radiotelemetry was used to estimate minimum survival rates of fish passing through a dam gate and turbine unit. In combination, the use of hydroacoustics, netting, electrofishing, and radio telemetry provided a complete picture of the fish population at Greenup Dam over three seasons, and facilitated an accurate assessment of the project's effects on fish.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:1

TITLE: Evaluating hydro relicensing alternatives
AUTHORS: Birk, J R; Sullivan, C W; Rice, J S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING PROCEDURES; EVALUATION; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; DECISION TREE ANALYSIS; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; EPRI; SENSITIVITY ANALYSIS; US FERC; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; ECONOMICS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 130400 - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations
DESCRIPTION: The relicensing of 300 hydroelectric plants in the 1990s involves a total capacity of about 4,000 MW -- a $10 billion value. Applicants are likely to face strong opposition to their plans from resource agencies and environmental groups. Extreme differences in agendas decrease the likelihood that [open quotes]win-win[close quotes] situations will transpire easily; trade-offs and compromises will be a reality. However, opposing parties may find a common framework for discussion in a methodology recently developed by the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI). The methodology evaluates the effects of relicensing alternatives on power and non-power values. Properly implemented, the methodology will help the plant owner determine: (1) the preferred relicensing alternative from a public perspective; (2) the power and non-power value components of each alternative; (3) the important (as well as unimportant) areas of uncertainty in power and non-power values; and (4) the value of gathering additional information to resolve uncertainties.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:1

TITLE: Focusing attention on turbine rehabilitation
AUTHORS: Froehlich, D R; Veatch, J A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; RETROFITTING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONTRACT MANAGEMENT; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; PROGRAM MANAGEMENT; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; ECONOMICS; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; MANAGEMENT; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Plant modernization is not a new issue for the hydropower industry. Utilities and federal power suppliers in North America have been performing major overhauls and plant life extension programs for many years. However, several recent developments have caused the industry to refocus its attention on the advantages of rehabilitating older hydro plants. And, plant owners are finding that turbine rehabilitation is one of the most cost-effective options to increase plant value while extending plant life. Achieving the potential improvements and benefits of turbine rehabilitation, however, is not necessarily guaranteed. Management and control of the engineering decision process is needed to ensure that the desired unit performance and output are met.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:1

TITLE: Water-activated foam used to seal leaks at Texas dam
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; REPAIR; LEAKS; PLASTIC FOAMS; SEALING MATERIALS; COLLOIDS; DISPERSIONS; FOAMS; MATERIALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC POLYMERS; POLYMERS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Water activated foam is used to seal leaks in a construction joint in the dam. The joint leaks because of incomplete bonding of old and new concrete used during two separate phases of construction. Pipes are inserted above the seam to divert water from the seam, and pressurized foam is pumped into the pipes to seal the seam. Since the first application of the foam five years ago, it has performed well. Over 600 feet of leaks have been sealed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:1

TITLE: The High Line Canal project: Working out the bugs
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CONTRACT MANAGEMENT; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; DESIGN; CALIFORNIA; CONTRACTORS; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; ECONOMICS; MANAGEMENT; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; PROGRAM MANAGEMENT; USA; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: This article describes the experience of Santa Clara in building a hydro plant using the design/build approach. In this approach, the developer hires one contractor, who is responsible for both design and construction of the plant. The municipality believes it saved millions of dollars using this approach, but did encounter some problems on start-up. Some of these problems possibly could have been avoided by having an independent engineering review of the contractor's design before proceeding with construction.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:1

TITLE: Hydro turbine rehab benefits from modeling
AUTHORS: Froehlich, D R; Veatch, J A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; AGING; DESIGN; REPAIR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MAINTENANCE; COST; MODIFICATIONS; PLANNING; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The turbine aging process, while seemingly imperceptible, inevitably results in reduced turbine efficiency and capacity. The primary causes of these reductions are runner hydraulic profile changes during weld repairs, surface finish deterioration from cavitation, and runner seal clearance increases due to wear. Many aging turbines require more frequent repairs due to runner cavitation, and wicket gate mechanism, shaft seal, and guide bearing wear. In many instances turbine component repair can be performed in-place. On older units, runner seals, wicket gate bearings, and wicket gate end seals can be repaired only when the turbine is disassembled. Since the significant cost to disassemble and overhaul units must be offset by future maintenance savings and generation increases, turbine rehabilitation is often postponed as owners consider other alternatives. Rehabilitation is a general term used to describe a wide range of turbine reconditioning and design alternatives. Turbine rehabilitation can include a major overhaul of components, runner replacement, and component modifications. Deteriorated runners can be replaced with either a new identical runner or a new modern design having increased efficiency and capacity. The comparative turbine performance of an original, existing, and a modern runner design are shown in this paper. Component overhauls can extend turbine life and restore original efficiency and capacity to existing units. However, the overhaul of existing components cannot increase plant capacity and generation above the as-new values. As a result, owners of aging plants are considering the benefits of replacing existing turbines with modern, more efficient, higher capacity turbines, or expanding the sites. Where expansion is not feasible, hydroelectric power plant owners are finding that turbine rehabilitation is the most cost-effective method to increase plant value and life.
RELATION: Journal Name: Power Engineering; (United States); Journal Volume: 95:1

TITLE: The effect of electrical array reconfiguration on the performance of a PV-powered volumetric water pump
SUBJECT: 14 SOLAR ENERGY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC MOTORS; PERFORMANCE; PHOTOVOLTAIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; OPTIMIZATION; PERMANENT MAGNETS; SOLAR WATER PUMPS; EQUIPMENT; MAGNETS; MOTORS; POWER PLANTS; PUMPS; SOLAR EQUIPMENT; SOLAR POWER PLANTS; WATER PUMPS; 140600* - Solar Energy- Photovoltaic Power Systems; 130700 - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: This paper presents a technique to improve the performance of a photovoltaic (PV) powered permanent magnet dc motor coupled to a screw-type volumetric water pump. The method uses a solid state Electrical Array Reconfiguration Controller (EARC), which senses the radiation as low, medium or high. accordingly, the controller chooses one favorable set of I-V characteristics for starting and another favorable set of I-V characteristics for steady state operation. This is done by switching the solar panels, depending upon the starting current requirements and the irradiance level, from a parallel to series-parallel to series connection. This produces sufficient staring current especially at low and medium radiation levels, which considerably improves the pump's performance, particularly in the early morning, late evening and cloudy days, providing valuable extra pumping hours for the user.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 5:4
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: Electrical upgrades for a 1909 vintage hydro station
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPTIMIZATION; DESIGN; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; INFORMATION SYSTEMS; EQUIPMENT; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130700 - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: This paper is intended to provide information useful to individuals who are involved in upgrades of old hydroelectric stations. This paper provides information on the electrical upgrades approach taken older stations. Equipment replaced, reasons for replacement, and the design of new equipment are discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 5:4; Journal Issue: 4
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: Fish and hydroelectricity; Engineering a better coexistence
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; DESIGN; FISHES; MIGRATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY; DAMS; US FERC; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; VERTEBRATES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 130400 - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: This paper reports on the problems that hydroelectric plants have regarding fish populations. The utilities that operate these plants are finding that accommodating migrating fish presents unique engineering challenges, not the least of which involves designing and building systems to protect fish species whose migratory behavior remains something of a mystery. Where such systems cannot be built, the status of hydroelectric dams may be in doubt, as is now the case with several dams in the United States. A further twist in some regions in the possibility that certain migratory fish will be declared threatened or endangered-a development that could wreak havoc on the hydroelectric energy supply in those regions.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Spectrum (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 27:12
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Spectrum (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: Optimization of hydropower plant integration in water supply system
AUTHORS: Afshar, A; Jemaa, F B; Marino, M A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPTIMIZATION; POWER SYSTEMS; DYNAMIC PROGRAMMING; CAPACITY; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; PLANNING; TURBINES; ENERGY SYSTEMS; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; PROGRAMMING; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 240100 - Power Systems- (1990-); 240700 - Power Transmission & Distribution- Economic, Industrial & Business Aspects- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: An optimization model is presented for determining the optimal design capacities of a water delivery system integrating small hydropower plants. A discrete distance model of the transmission pipeline is solved by employing dynamic programming. The model determines the proper allocation of available pressure head to various potential hydropower sites along the supply main and determines the optimal pipe diameter. The practical value of the model is demonstrated in an example for a supply system to serve four towns. The solution of the model gives the set of turbine capacities, pipe diameters, head allocation resulting in maximum net benefit for a given quantity of available water and demand, and the expected net benefits.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Water Resources Planning and Management; (USA); Journal Volume: 116:5
JOURNAL_NAME: Journal of Water Resources Planning and Management; (USA)

TITLE: A graphical approach to hydrogenerator governor tuning
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; CONTROL SYSTEMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; GRAPHS; OPERATION; PARAMETRIC ANALYSIS; ROTORS; STABILITY; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 299000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation; 240100 - Power Systems- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: A number of published works deal with governor tuning for speed control of hydrogenerators. This work is based on the hypothesis that some system parameters are not known at the design stage. It develops a graph which can be used to predict optimum proportional and integral gains based on four parameters: the time constants of the water column and of the rotor inertia and the self-regulation constants of the turbine and of the loading grid. The pole cancellation method of design is used and the results are posed in an easy-to-use format not requiring the solution of systems of equations. Information on stability limits and comparisons with other work are included.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA); Journal Volume: 5:3
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA)

TITLE: Safety goals for high-hazard dams: Are dams too safe
AUTHORS: Lave, L B; Resendiz-Carrillo, D; McMichael, F C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; DAMS; SAFETY; COST; FLOOD CONTROL; INSPECTION; RETROFITTING; CONTROL; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 299000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation
DESCRIPTION: The 1977 National Dam Inspection Program determined that many high-hazard dams in the US were incapable of passing a probable maximum flood (PMF). Retrofitting these dams was estimated to cost at least $10 billion. Since the PMF is revised upward periodically, retrofit is a continual issue. But surviving a PMF is a more stringent safety criterion than preventing other sources of dam failure; in addition, it is more stringent than safety criteria for other structures with respect to wind, earthquakes, or storm surges. This higher safety goal has large social costs. The authors propose an alternative safety goal, separating property damage from possible loss of lives. For a proposed dam whose failure could cause large loss of life or property damage, a careful evaluation should be done as to whether the dam should be built. For dams that impose smaller hazards, property damage should be handled by an analysis based on expected values of annualized benefits and costs. An adjustment for scale could be used if the property damage were extremely large. Danger to lives should be handled by establishing programs to warn and evacuate people. The authors' proposal should (1) lead to less injury and death, (2) use society's limited resources more efficiently, and (3) put the determination of safety goals on a more scientific and sensible basis.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resources Research; (United States); Journal Volume: 26:7

TITLE: A centrifugal pump used as a turbine
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CENTRIFUGAL PUMPS; PERFORMANCE; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; DESIGN; ALTERNATORS; ECONOMICS; EFFICIENCY; FLOW RATE; FLOWSHEETS; OPERATION; POWER GENERATION; DIAGRAMS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; PUMPS; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Due to the high cost of putting up conventional turbines for micro-hydropower installations, Inversin (1986) mentioned the use of pumps being run in reverse to function as turbines. Typical performance characteristics of a centrifugal pump running as a turbine are shown in a figure. Pump/turbine maximum efficiencies tend to occur over a wide range of capacity. This study is concerned with the use of non-conventional hydro equipment, locally and readily available for small rural electricity applications. Here, the operation of a small centrifugal pump, used as a turbine and coupled with a conventional car alternator, was investigated. The article reveals a method for evaluating not only this but other small generating systems for appropriateness to the conditions of the site.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sunworld; (USA); Journal Volume: 14:2

TITLE: Thermal effects
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 63 RADIATION, THERMAL, AND OTHER ENVIRON. POLLUTANT EFFECTS ON LIVING ORGS. AND BIOL. MAT.; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; HABITAT; REVIEWS; TEMPERATURE EFFECTS; DOCUMENT TYPES; POWER PLANTS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 560200 - Thermal Effects
DESCRIPTION: An overview is presented of the temperature effects on aquatic organisms in lakes and streams. Attention is focused on the development, activity, distribution, and growth of these organisms. The effect of temperature on oxygen metabolism is also reviewed. Other topics of discussion include the following: thermal tolerance; thermal preference; temperature and other stresses; and biochemical reaction studies.
RELATION: Journal Name: Research Journal of the Water Pollution Control Federation; (United States); Journal Volume: 62:4

TITLE: Field tests and operation of a duplicate multiprocessor-based governor for water turbine and its further development
AUTHORS: Ye, L; Wei, S; Li, Z; Malik, O P; Hope, G S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; ARRAY PROCESSORS; TECHNOLOGY IMPACTS; CHINA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; ON-LINE MEASUREMENT SYSTEMS; ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE; AUTOMATION; COMPUTER CODES; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; FIELD TESTS; PLANNING; ASIA; CONTROL SYSTEMS; MACHINERY; ON-LINE SYSTEMS; POWER PLANTS; TESTING; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 990200 - Mathematics & Computers; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: A duplicate microprocessor-based governor (D{mu}PG) contains 2 redundant processing modules. A research prototype has been transferred to an industrial product. This paper gives the details of the hardware and software and the field test results. The paper also gives an evaluation of the financial benefits with examples from the 11 D{mu}PGs operating at seven different hydro-power plants in China. A proposal is presented for a new D{mu}PG with a control strategy based on intelligent self-improvement.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA); Journal Volume: 5:2
