TITLE: Decision-making process on the Danube and the Platte
AUTHORS: Bleed, A; Nachtnebel, H P; Bogardi, I; Supalla, R J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; AUSTRIA; RESOURCE MANAGEMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; DECISION MAKING; IRRIGATION; RECOMMENDATIONS; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; EUROPE; MANAGEMENT; POWER PLANTS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Two case studies highlighting the institutional arrangements and decision-making processes used to attempt to allocate water on large scale river systems in two countries are presented. In both cases the implementation of river plans has been blocked by conflicts between those who wish to use water for irrigation, hydropower, or municipal purposes and those who wish to maintain instream flows for fish and wildlife. To date conflict has blocked the implementation of a large hydropower scheme on the Danube River, downstream from Vienna, Austria, and the construction of municipal and agricultural projects, as well as the relicensing of an existing hydropower facility on the Platte River in Nebraska. Analysis of the decision-making processes and institutional settings of both cases led to the identification of problem areas and development of recommendations that would support the achievement of compromise solutions for management.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resources Bulletin; (United States); Journal Volume: 26:3

TITLE: Interface requirements of a large hydroelectric power plant with its regional load dispatch office
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HIGH-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LOAD MANAGEMENT; REAL TIME SYSTEMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MANAGEMENT; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 990200 - Mathematics & Computers; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes the real-time interface requirements of a large hydroelectric power plant with its regional load dispatch office (LDO).

JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA)

TITLE: Second order hydraulic turbine models for multimachine stability studies
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; TRANSFER FUNCTIONS; INTERCONNECTED POWER SYSTEMS; STABILITY; CALCULATION METHODS; ELECTROMECHANICS; PERFORMANCE TESTING; ENERGY SYSTEMS; FUNCTIONS; MACHINERY; MECHANICS; POWER SYSTEMS; TESTING; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: This paper presents an approximation of the exact hydraulic turbine transfer function particularly suitable for stability calculations in a multimachine power system. This approximation is made with a second order transfer function, the coefficients of which are estimated so that it resembles as closely as possible the dynamics of the actual hydraulic turbine in the frequency range of the electromechanical oscillations between the synchronous machines of the system. The method is applied to a realistic multimachine model of the Hellenic interconnected system and the improvement in accuracy over the traditional first order hydro turbine model is found to be significant.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA); Journal Volume: 5:2
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA)

TITLE: Improved generator temperature monitoring for hydroelectric powerplants
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 42 ENGINEERING; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TEMPERATURE MONITORING; AUTOMATION; DATA ACQUISITION SYSTEMS; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; VARIATIONS; MONITORING; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 420400 - Engineering- Heat Transfer & Fluid Flow; 990200 - Mathematics & Computers
DESCRIPTION: The problem of monitoring the temperatures of hydroelectric generators and pumps has existed since the first machines were built. The past methods of collecting, archiving, and analyzing these data have been primarily manual processes with humans taking recordings on paper from analog meters. The operator would determine if the temperatures were out of range as he collected the data. Variations included automated data collection with output on paper for operator analysis and storage. This paper describes a fully automated temperature monitoring system which collects, archives, and analyzes the data for the operator, as well as generates any report defined by the operator.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA); Journal Volume: 5:2; Journal Issue: 2
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA)

TITLE: Usable hydro capacity and electric utility production simulation and reliability calculations
AUTHORS: Staschus, K; Bell, A; Cashman, E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RELIABILITY; ENERGY MODELS; PEAK LOAD; SIMULATION; POWER PLANTS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Hydroelectric plants are modeled in equivalent load duration curve (ELDC) based production simulation and reliability models in two ways: through peakshaving and by dispatching the hydro plants against the ELDC. This paper compares the two methods with respect to the implied usability of the hydro capacity. Tests results indicate that the peakshaving approach is more appropriate, according to this comparison criterion.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA); Journal Volume: 5:2
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA)

TITLE: An efficient algorithm for optimal reservoir utilization in probabilistic production costing
AUTHORS: Conejo, A J; Caramanis, M C; Bloom, J A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; ALGORITHMS; COST; POWER GENERATION; PROBABILISTIC ESTIMATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 990200 - Mathematics & Computers
DESCRIPTION: This paper presents an efficient and accurate algorithm which determines optimal storage reservoir utilization (pumped hydro) in probabilistic production costing models with multiple storage, thermal and limited energy units. The algorithm exploits the special nature of the production cost function, which is piecewise linear with respect to the reservoir utilization levels. It achieves the same accuracy as previously developed, less efficient, approaches which require multiple production costing calculations. The proposed algorithm is also more efficient as well as more accurate than heuristic reservoir utilization algorithms which are prone to inaccuracies when multiple storage units are considered.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA); Journal Volume: 5:2
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA)

TITLE: An innovative approach to generation scheduling in large-scale hydro-thermal power systems with fuel constrained units
AUTHORS: Tong, S K; Shahidehpour, S M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; CONSTRAINTS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY DEMAND; FUEL CONSUMPTION; LOAD MANAGEMENT; DEMAND; ECONOMICS; ENERGY CONSUMPTION; MANAGEMENT; POWER; POWER PLANTS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: This paper proposes a new methodology for the short-term unit commitment. Thermal, fuel constrained and hydro units have been modeled in the formulation of the problem, and restrictions on fuel and water utilizations as well as the limits on the storage levels of reservoirs are included. In this regard, the proposed method incorporates the following special features. First, a set of upper bounds is added to limit the excess in the spinning reserves at different periods during the search for a feasible suboptimal solution. Second, a revised economic dispatch algorithm is introduced in the final stage of the method. This algorithm identifies unnecessarily committed units in the generation schedule of a large power network, and provides the solution for the economic allocation of the system demand among the committed units.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA); Journal Volume: 5:2
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA)

TITLE: Streamlining hydro licensing
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; CONSTRAINTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; HISTORICAL ASPECTS; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; NATIONAL ENERGY PLAN; NEW HAMPSHIRE; OPERATION; OWNERSHIP; PUBLIC RELATIONS; PUBLIC UTILITY REGULATORY POLICIES ACT; SALMON; SIZE; US DOE; US FERC; WATERSHEDS; ANADROMOUS FISHES; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; ENERGY POLICY; FEDERAL REGION I; FISHES; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; LAWS; NATIONAL ENERGY ACT; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; US ORGANIZATIONS; USA; VERTEBRATES; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The U.S. Department of Energy's proposed National Energy Strategy includes an initiative to streamline the licensing of hydroelectric sites. If past efforts are an indicator, the job will not be easy. In 1978, a FERC regulatory process more compatible with large utility projects than small, independently owned projects, was chief among the perceived obstacles to hydropower development. Thus, is section 405 of the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act, Congress specifically directed FERC to streamline its licensing procedures for small hydroelectric projects (1,500 kW or less) at existing dams. The FERC interpreted Congressional intent very broadly and extended its streamlining efforts to projects as large as 5 MW. By 1980, the FERC had established regulations exempting certain projects from the burdens of licensing on a case by case basis, as well as entire categories of small projects with obviously limited environmental impact. Times have changed since 1978, and there is no question that the process of licensing and operating hydroelectric projects has become anything but streamlined. The case of the proposed Livermore Falls project in central New Hampshire, which has dragged on since 1982, is examined.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (USA); Journal Volume: 20:4

TITLE: Real-time control of a system of large hydropower reservoirs
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATIONS RESEARCH; WATER REQUIREMENTS; WATER SUPPLY; WATER RESERVOIRS; HYDROLOGY; ALGORITHMS; DECISION MAKING; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; RESOURCE MANAGEMENT; RIVERS; RUNOFF; STOCHASTIC PROCESSES; VENEZUELA; WATERSHEDS; DEMAND; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; ENGINEERING; ENVIRONMENTAL TRANSPORT; LATIN AMERICA; MANAGEMENT; MASS TRANSFER; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; POWER PLANTS; SOUTH AMERICA; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 580000 - Geosciences; 540350 - Environment, Aquatic- Site Resource & Use Studies- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes a real-time optimal control approach for operating a system of large hydropower reservoirs. The operating objective is to track specified power output targets, subject to a variety of physical constraints. The constraints describe the hydrologic behavior of the tributary watershed and the dynamics of the reservoir system. The decision variables are monthly average releases from each of the system reservoirs. These releases are derived in real time, as functions of available measurements of reservoir storage and tributary inflow. Inflow and measurement uncertainty are explicitly included in the state and measurement equations. The stochastic operations problem is first formulated in general terms and then simplified to allow the use of classical linear-quadratic stochastic control concepts. The solution to the simplified control problem is implemented by combining a linear deterministic control law with a linear estimation algorithm. The resulting stochastic controller is applied to a two-reservoir system in the Caroni River basin of Venezuela. Preliminary tests indicate that the controller performs well in this application, even when some of its underlying assumptions are violated.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resources Research; (United States); Journal Volume: 26:4

TITLE: A program for calculating audible noise levels around power substations
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 63 RADIATION, THERMAL, AND OTHER ENVIRON. POLLUTANT EFFECTS ON LIVING ORGS. AND BIOL. MAT.; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTER CODES; NOISE; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; POWER SUBSTATIONS; SITE SELECTION; QUEBEC; DESIGN; PERSONAL COMPUTERS; CANADA; COMPUTERS; DIGITAL COMPUTERS; MICROCOMPUTERS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 560400 - Other Environmental Pollutant Effects; 990200 - Mathematics & Computers
DESCRIPTION: In order to minimize the impact of power substations on environmental noise, different approaches may be taken. As a basis for evaluating different approaches, one needs to predict the noise levels around a substation as accurately as possible before committing additional equipment. Since an accurate assessment of the noise levels must consider all propagation paths the sound waves take to travel from source to receivers (reflections on barriers and ground, diffraction around barriers, transmission through barriers, etc.), a PC computer program best performs all the calculation chores. This article describes such a computer program. It is available on PC to help the substation designer estimate the contours of noise levels resulting from a selected substation layout.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Computer Applications and Power; (USA); Journal Volume: 3:2

TITLE: HVDC line brings Canadian hydropower to New England
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; POWER TRANSMISSION; DESIGN; ECONOMICS; RELIABILITY; ELECTRIC POWER; ELECTRIC POWER INDUSTRY; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; HVDC SYSTEMS; DC SYSTEMS; ENERGY SYSTEMS; INDUSTRY; POWER; POWER SYSTEMS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 240202 - Power System Networks, Transmission & Distribution- DC Systems- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Hydro generating units totaling 2,000 MW of capacity, part of the 10,300-MW LaGrande complex on James Bay, Quebec (Fig 1), are now linked over high-voltage dc lines to a converter terminal close to Boston, Mass. Testing of the ac/dc converter terminals this spring and summer will complete years of negotiations and construction. The negotiations were successfully culminated as the technologies needed for dc bulk-power transmission were refined and several technical concerns solved.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electrical World; (United States); Journal Volume: 204:3

TITLE: The miniboom in pumped storage
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; COLORADO; GEORGIA; NEW JERSEY; OHIO; DESIGN; CAPACITY; CONSTRUCTION; CONTAINMENT; ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT; ECONOMICS; ENGINEERING; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; LICENSING; LOAD MANAGEMENT; MODULAR STRUCTURES; OWNERSHIP; PEAK LOAD; PLANNING; SIZE; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; US FERC; WATER RESOURCES; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; FEDERAL REGION II; FEDERAL REGION IV; FEDERAL REGION IX; FEDERAL REGION V; FEDERAL REGION VIII; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MANAGEMENT; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; RESOURCES; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; USA; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: A growing need b electric utilities for peaking capacity combined with their reluctance to invest in major new power plants has triggered significant interest in the independent development of pumped storage hydroelectric facilities. Moreover, several developers have added a new twist to a well-established technology by formulating self-contained projects that avoid using natural water courses and thus minimize challenges over environmental impacts. Most prospective pumped storage projects are still in the early formulative stages. Four projects, however, have advanced to the point of having their applications for license under review by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC), while one other project has recently resumed construction after a lengthy delay. If successfully completed, these five projects would add a minimum of 5,300 MW of energy storage capacity by the mid-to-late 1990s. The paper describes the following projects: the 760 MW Rocky Mountain project near Rome, Georgia; the 1500 MW Summit Energy Storage Project neat Akron, Ohio; 200 MW Mt. Hope project in Rockaway Township, New Jersey; 100 MW Rocky Point project neat Colorado Springs, Colorado; and a 100 MW project in Redding, California. Several projects still on the drawing board are briefly described. Also discussed is the technology of the self-contained pumped storage approach.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 20:3

TITLE: Automation of hydroelectric power plants
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; OPERATION; PNEUMATICS; REMOTE CONTROL; SAFETY; CONTROL; CONTROL SYSTEMS; FLUID MECHANICS; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes how the author's company has been automating its hydroelectric generating plants. The early automations were achieved with a relay-type supervisory control system, relay logic, dc tachometer, and a pneumatic gate-position controller. While this system allowed the units to be started and stopped from a remote location, they were operated at an output that was preset by the pneumatic control at the generating site. The supervisory control system at the site provided such information as unit status, generator breaker status, and a binary coded decimal (BCD) value of the pond level. The generating units are started by energizing an on-site relay that sets the pneumatic gate controller to a preset value above the synchronous speed of the hydroelectric generator. The pneumatic controller then opens the water-wheel wicket gates to the preset startup position. As the hydroelectric generator starts to turn, the machine-mounted dc tachometer produces a voltage. At a dc voltage equivalent to synchronous speed, the generator main breaker closes, and a contact from the main breaker starts a field-delay timer. Within a few seconds, the field breaker closes. Once the cycle is complete, a relay changes the pneumatic setpoint to a preset operating point of about 8/10 wicket gate opening.
RELATION: Journal Name: Tappi; (USA); Journal Volume: 73:3

TITLE: Analysis of grid connected induction generators driven by hydro/wind turbines under realistic system constraints
AUTHORS: urthy, S S; Jha, C S; Rao, P S.N.
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 17 WIND ENERGY; 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; PERFORMANCE; INDUCTION GENERATORS; WIND TURBINES; CAPACITORS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; GRIDS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; ELECTRODES; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; SIMULATION; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 170602 - Wind Energy Engineering- Turbine Design & Operation; 240100 - Power Systems- (1990-); 299000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation
DESCRIPTION: Results of an investigation dealing with the behavior of grid connected induction generators (GCIG) driven by typical prime movers such as mini-hydro/wind turbines are presented. Certain practical operational problems of such systems are identified. Analytical techniques are developed to study the behavior of such systems. The system consists of the induction generator (IG) feeding a 11 kV grid through a step up transformer and a transmission line. Terminal capacitors to compensate for the lagging VAR are included in the study. Computer simulation is carried out to predict the system performance at the given input power from the turbine. Effects of variations in grid voltage, frequency, input power and terminal capacitance on the machine and system performance are studied. Analysis of self excitation conditions on disconnection of supply has been carried out. Behavior of a 200 kW hydel system and 55/11 kW 22 kW wind driven system corresponding to actual field conditions are presented and discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA); Journal Volume: 5:1
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA)

TITLE: Optimal sizing of projects in a hydro-based power system
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; COST; ECONOMICS; FORECASTING; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPTIMIZATION; SIZE; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 990200 - Mathematics & Computers
DESCRIPTION: This paper deals with the problem of obtaining the optimal design of hydroelectric power systems with respect to determining each project's optimal size or capacity. The problem of sizing projects is analyzed from a theoretical and economical standpoint and a mathematical model is presented to reflect on project sizing in the general framework of expanding a purely hydroelectric system. The interaction between sizing and sequencing decisions is also discussed. The results offer design rules to choose the optimal size and marginal cost for individual projects, and show the interdependence of scaling and sequencing decisions. These rules are in summary such, that it is optimal to make the current marginal cost (CMC) of each new project equal to the discounted weighted average of the long term marginal unit cost (MRMC) for all future projects.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA); Journal Volume: 5:1
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA)

TITLE: North American turbine companies
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; MANUFACTURERS; DESIGN; ECONOMICS; ENGINEERING; HISTORICAL ASPECTS; MARKET; MARKETERS; PUMPS; RETROFITTING; SERVICE SECTOR; SIZE; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; TURBOGENERATORS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBOMACHINERY; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 130700 - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Although the number of North American-owned hydro turbine companies has declined considerably from the past, those active in today's market are surviving by finding the right niche. Two companies which stand out in particular because of their commitment to North American-based technology and design in the medium and large-scale turbine market are American Hydro Corporation, of York, Pennsylvania and Hydro West Group Inc. of Bellevue, Washington. Other North American turbine companies - such as Niagara Turbine Systems, Flygt Corp., Byron Jackson Products and Canyon Industries - have carved out a niche in the small turbine market. All six companies and their main products are described.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 20:3

TITLE: Hydroelectric power and America's energy future
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PERMITS; SITE SELECTION; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; NATIONAL ENERGY PLAN; SITE SURVEYS; US FERC; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; ENERGY POLICY; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 296000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: This article discusses the debate over the merit of hydroelectric power and the part it will play in providing energy in America in the future. The environmental impact, reliability, efficiency, and regulation of hydroelectric projects are discussed with examples and references to other publications. FERC application of existing regulations in the licensing and relicensing process is also discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Public Utilities Fortnightly; (United States); Journal Volume: 125:3

TITLE: Shifting strategies
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC POWER INDUSTRY; ECONOMICS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRAINTS; DIVERSIFICATION; ECONOMIC IMPACT; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; JOINT VENTURES; OWNERSHIP; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; REGULATIONS; SIZE; US FERC; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; INDUSTRY; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Three years ago, top management of key development companies reported that the hydroelectric industry had reached a different level of maturity and that a shakeout was underway. Follow-up interviews with many of the same managers show the extent of that shake-out and that companies are developing new strategies for the coming years. As was the case in 1987, declining power purchase rates and an increasingly complicated regulatory environment continue to affect the strategy of the independent hydroelectric industry. However, today the impact of these and other factors is being felt in new and different ways. Many of the same companies that were devoting their attention to going public and acquiring operating stations three of four years ago are now shifting their strategies. Virtually all of the companies investigated indicated an unwillingness to undertake anything but larger projects. For some this has spawned a new-found interest in pumped storage hydroelectric facilities, and in one instance it meant full divestiture of all hydroelectric interests in order to focus on other alternative fuels. Regardless, there is a consensus that large scale projects are necessary to support the sophisticated corporate infrastructures required to shoulder the burdens of increasingly stringent FERC regulation and enforcement and utility bidding systems.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 20:2

TITLE: Simulation and field tests of the black start of a large coal-fired generating station utilizing small remote hydro generation
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; BLACKOUTS; REMEDIAL ACTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; REMOTE CONTROL; POWER SYSTEMS; PLANNING; COAL; COAL-FIRED GAS TURBINES; COMBUSTION; FIELD TESTS; FOSSIL-FUEL POWER PLANTS; GAS TURBINE POWER PLANTS; SIMULATION; CARBONACEOUS MATERIALS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CONTROL; ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY SYSTEMS; FOSSIL FUELS; FUELS; GAS TURBINES; MACHINERY; MATERIALS; OXIDATION; POWER PLANTS; TESTING; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 240100* - Power Systems- (1990-); 014000 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- Combustion; 130700 - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: The ability to rapidly recover from a major, region-wide blackout is a significant concern of electric utility engineers and operators. Even though such blackouts are rare occurrences, it is prudent and necessary for an electric utility to prepare for such events and to develop plans for recovering from them. This paper describes a method which utilizes remote hydro generation to restart a major coal-fired generating station. Previous work on restoration techniques and the use of combustion turbines to blackstart a generating station has been documented. This paper documents a comprehensive black start project. It includes considerations for a black start project, details of an analytical study, identification of critical factors, development and implementation of an actual black start test, comparison of field tests with the simulation results, and the required system modifications identified during the project.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA); Journal Volume: 5:1
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA)

TITLE: A new generation scheduling program at Ontario Hydro
AUTHORS: Habibollahzadeh, H; Frances, D; Sui, D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTER NETWORKS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; POWER GENERATION; PROGRAMMING; CONTROL SYSTEMS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 990200 - Mathematics & Computers
DESCRIPTION: The new daily generation scheduling model for the Ontario Hydro system is presented in this paper. The model is capable of considering the thermal and hydraulic systems together with system reserve requirement and transmission losses. The hydraulic system is considered in a detailed formulation which is capable of handling river couplings in a complete manner. This is a major weakness in the peak shaving technique used since early 1970s. A special network programming technique has been used to solve the problem. This method has proved to be very efficient from a computational point of view. Test results from application of the new technique is presented and compared to the peak shaving method. The user has estimated 1.4 million dollars per year of savings from the new computer package.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA); Journal Volume: 5:1
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA)

TITLE: New runners to boost peak output at Niagara Falls
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; WATER CURRENT POWER GENERATORS; RETROFITTING; COMPUTER-AIDED DESIGN; LAKE ERIE; NEW YORK; NIAGARA RIVER; DESIGN; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; FEDERAL REGION II; GREAT LAKES; LAKES; MACHINERY; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; TURBOMACHINERY; USA; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Retrofitted Francis turbines will improve the value of power generated from Niagara Falls by increasing the peak output of the hydroturbine units at the Robert Moses hydroelectric plant. The computer-designed runners are expected to add 330 MW to the peak capacity of the 28-yr-old plant and significantly increase the efficiency at high flow rates. Next year, the first new runner will be retrofit to the highly instrumented Unit 4. If the retrofit unit meets it increased-performance expectations, the other 12 units will be upgraded between 1993 and 1998. The work is part of an overall expansion of the Niagara Power Project designed to made better use of the power value of Niagara river water, within the constraints of a treaty with Canada and the scenic value of the falls. These constraints, together with varying flows and heads, introduced enormous complexities into the selection and design of the new runners. The alterations being made to Unit 4, in addition to replacing the turbine runner, include modifying the draft tube-liners, increasing the wicket-gate stroke, replacing the turbine discharge ring (to accommodate longer blades), making various electrical modifications to the generator, and replacing the transformer. But the key to the retrofit is the computer-designed runner. Charles Grose, senior project manager, New York Power Authority, White Plains, NY, emphasizes that such computer design techniques were not available a few years ago; neither were the computer-controlled machining techniques necessary to manufacture the new runners. Other aspects of the upgrading that were analyzed include runner stability, resonance, shaft torsional stress, and runaway speed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electrical World; (United States); Journal Volume: 204:1

TITLE: Unique nature of hydroplant complicates design
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; RETROFITTING; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; LAKE ERIE; NEW YORK; NIAGARA RIVER; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; FEDERAL REGION II; GREAT LAKES; LAKES; NORTH AMERICA; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; USA; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: This article describes the unique nature of the Niagara Power Project as it affected upgrading of the Robert Moses powerplant and operation of the powerplant and pumped storage facility. To be taken into account are the variable flow of the Niagara River, treaties regarding division of river flow between Canada and USA and maintenance of river flow over the falls, and the level of Lake Erie.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electrical World; (United States); Journal Volume: 204:1

TITLE: Turbine competition sharpens
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TURBOGENERATORS; MARKET; COMPETITION; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; EUROPE; FORECASTING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; JAPAN; MARKETERS; MARKETING RESEARCH; RETROFITTING; TURBINES; USA; ASIA; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; MACHINERY; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The shrinking market for new hydropower turbines worldwide is accelerating consolidation in the industry. In large part, the consolidation in the industry is a European phenomena. Old-line U.S. companies have largely abandoned the hydro turbine market. The major vendors are now European- and Japanese-based. With the increasing integration of the European Economic Community, the incentive for European companies is toward the international market. To compete successfully, European firms are restructuring as big diversified participants, capable of offering a broad array of hydropower related services to projects of widely varying sizes. Featured in the list of services are the furnishing of the full range of turbine types and sizes, turbine governors, gates and valves, penstocks and bifurcations, and engineering and installation. In the future, the industry will undoubtedly be dominated by fewer and bigger competitors whose survival will require a careful definition of specific, exploitable markets. Most observers see the market as segmented in three parts: The market for new large turbines (runner diameters greater than three meters), the market for new small and mini turbines, and the rehabilitation market.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 20:1

TITLE: Optimization of value of CVP's hydropower production
AUTHORS: Tejada-Guibert, J A; Stedinger, J R; Staschus, K
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; CALIFORNIA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PERFORMANCE TESTING; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; NONLINEAR PROGRAMMING; OPTIMIZATION; PRODUCTIVITY; FEDERAL REGION IX; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; PROGRAMMING; TESTING; USA; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 990200 - Mathematics & Computers
DESCRIPTION: CVPOP is a nonlinear programming model for the optimization of the multi-month operation of the hydropower system of the California Central Valley Project (CVP). CVPOP includes the dependence of energy values within each month of the capacity factor of the generating unit, avoiding the simplification of assuming constant monthly or yearly values as is common in other models. The model also includes contractual energy and capacity constraints which are nonlinear because of the powerplants' variable head performance curves (capability in MW and energy production rate in kWh per unit release versus reservoir storage). An example illustrates the difference between the values of the energy generated with operations schedules obtained using different objective functions.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Water Resources Planning and Management; (USA); Journal Volume: 116:1
JOURNAL_NAME: Journal of Water Resources Planning and Management; (USA)

TITLE: Incorporating daily flood control objectives into a monthly stochastic dynamic programming model for a hydroelectric complex
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; BRITISH COLUMBIA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DAMS; FLOOD CONTROL; POWER GENERATION; ENERGY ANALYSIS; ENERGY POLICY; FLOODS; FLOW MODELS; LAKES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MONTHLY VARIATIONS; OPERATING COST; RIVERS; STOCHASTIC PROCESSES; WATER RESERVOIRS; CANADA; CONTROL; COST; DISASTERS; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; VARIATIONS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: A monthly stochastic dynamic programing model was recently developed and implemented at British Columbia (B.C.) Hydro to provide decision support for short-term energy exports and, if necessary, for flood control on the Peace River in northern British Columbia. The model established the marginal cost of supplying energy from the B.C. Hydro system, as well as a monthly operating policy for the G.M. Shrum and Peace Canyon hydroelectric plants and the Williston Lake storage reservoir. A simulation model capable of following the operating policy then determines the probability of refilling Williston Lake and possible spill rates and volumes. Reservoir inflows are input to both models in daily and monthly formats. The results indicate that flood control can be accommodated without sacrificing significant export revenue.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resources Research; (USA); Journal Volume: 26:1

TITLE: Economic reservoir design and storage conservation by reduced sedimentation
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; SITE CHARACTERIZATION; STORAGE FACILITIES; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; COST; DESIGN; EROSION; HYDROLOGY; ILLINOIS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; WATERSHEDS; ECONOMICS; ENGINEERING; FEDERAL REGION V; NORTH AMERICA; USA; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: A mathematical model has been developed for estimating the design storage capacity of a reservoir by using the expected water demand, storage loss due to sedimentation, and physical and hydrological characteristics of the watershed. Suitable mitigative measures can be incorporated in dam design and reservoir operation to substantially reduce sediment entrapment in the reservoir, and to improve dissolved oxygen levels by releasing hypolimnetic waters from the reservoir. These measures may also greatly reduce streambed degradation downstream of the dam and consequent initiation of a new erosion cycle in the tributaries. Economic analyses for different storage-maintenance measures (such as undersluices and flushing pipes) have been investigated in terms of reduction in initial reservoir design storage, cost of installing measures, and cost of any dredging operations. These analyses are performed for a site in Illinois for several water-demand levels and useful lives of the reservoir.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Water Resources Planning and Management; (USA); Journal Volume: 116:1
JOURNAL_NAME: Journal of Water Resources Planning and Management; (USA)

TITLE: Low-head hydropower impacts on steam dissolved oxygen
AUTHORS: Thene, J R; Stefan, H G; Daniil, E I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; OXYGEN; ECOLOGICAL CONCENTRATION; AERATION; DAMS; DISSOLVED GASES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; STREAMS; ELEMENTS; FLUIDS; GASES; NONMETALS; POWER PLANTS; SOLUTES; SURFACE WATERS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: A method to evaluate the effect of hydropower development on downstream dissolved oxygen (DO) is presented for a low head dam. Water, previously aerated during release over spillways and under gates, is diverted through the hydropower facility without further aeration. The oxygen transfer that occurs as a result of air entrainment at the various release points of a dam is measured. Oxygen transfer efficiencies are calculated and incorporated into an oxygen transfer model to predict average release DO concentrations. This model is used to systematically determine the effect of hydropower operation on downstream DO. Operational alternatives are investigated and a simple operational guide is developed to mitigate the effects of hydropower operation. Combinations of reduced generation and optimal releases from the dam allow the hydropower facility to operate within DO standards.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resources Bulletin; (United States); Journal Volume: 25:6

TITLE: Multicriterion analysis of hydropower operation
AUTHORS: Duckstein, L; Hobbs, B F; Tecle, A; Nachnebel, H P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PERFORMANCE TESTING; MONTE CARLO METHOD; OPERATION; PRODUCTIVITY; SIMULATION; POWER PLANTS; TESTING; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Two examples are presented to show how multicriterion decision-making (MCDM) techniques can help hydropower engineers mitigate the environmental and social effects of hydropower development and operation. A brief introduction and overview of MCDM is presented, consisting of an 11-step process that starts with problem definition and ends with implementation. A typology of MCDM is provided, dividing the techniques into three groups: outranking, distance-based, and value- or utility-based typed. The operation of the Upper Isar River project in Bavaria is analyzed by means of a value technique and an out-ranking technique called multicriterion Q-analysis. Fourteen criteria are considered in that study, including power production, habitat quality for four groups of species, aesthetics, several recreation indices, minimum flows, and phosphorus loadings. The case study of the Erlauf River Division in Austria is evaluated using a distance-based technique, called composite programming, combined with Monte Carlo simulation. An outcome of that study is that the facility's owners have increased the minimum instream flow in order to protect ecological values.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Energy Engineering; (USA); Journal Volume: 115:3

TITLE: Short-term hydro-thermal dispatch detailed model and solutions
AUTHORS: Luo, G X; Habibollahzadeh, H; Semlyen, A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; ENERGY MODELS; RESERVOIR ROCK; VARIATIONS; COMPUTER CALCULATIONS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; ITERATIVE METHODS; LOAD ANALYSIS; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; OPTIMIZATION; SECURITY; ENERGY SYSTEMS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 990200 - Mathematics & Computers; 290100 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Analysis & Modeling; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The short-term hydro-thermal dispatch approach of this paper has the capability of taking into account the following effects: coupling of cascaded multichained reservoirs, water time delays, reservoir head variations, Load Flow and other constraints due to security and environmental considerations. The problem is decomposed into a hydro and a thermal subproblem which are then solved iteratively. An effective adjustment is proposed to take into account the nonlinear relation between the two subproblems to speed up the convergence of the iterative process. In this adjustment, as well as in solving the thermal subproblem, equations of coordination and optimal power flow are combined for better computational efficiency. Numerical examples are included to demonstrate the advantages of the new approach.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems; (USA); Journal Volume: 4:4

TITLE: Creative mitigation
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MITIGATION; BUSINESS; DAMS; ECONOMICS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; HABITAT; LICENSING; REGULATIONS; SALMON; US FWS; ANADROMOUS FISHES; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; FISHES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; US DOI; US ORGANIZATIONS; VERTEBRATES; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: On May 9, 1989, in front of a small but enthusiastic group composed of residents of Columbia Falls, Maine, Downeast fisherman and a crew of Bangor Hydro-Electric employees removed some of the wooden sections of the Columbia Falls dam. The dam is located at the mouth of the Pleasant River on the Maine seacoast, only thirty miles from the border between Maine and New Brunswick, Canada. In so doing, they provided unobstructed access by Atlantic salmon to crucial upstream aquatic habitat for the first time since the day was constructed in 1981. At the same time they made possible the efficient operation of a 13 MW hydroelectric facility some 75 miles inland at West Enfield, Maine, on the Penobscot River. This article describes the creative strategies used by Bangor Pacific Hydro Associated to satisfy environmental mitigation requirements at West Enfield, Maine.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (USA); Journal Volume: 19:8

TITLE: Conflict analysis and management alternative for the Manayunk Canal
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; PENNSYLVANIA; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; MANAGEMENT; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; ECONOMICS; FEDERAL REGION III; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; USA; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 299000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation
DESCRIPTION: The solution of a water resource allocation problem by an alternative social arrangement is presented. Classical Austrian economic theory and the new resources economics provide both theoretical and practical evidence to support the development of well-defined, private property rights to the water resource in question. A conflict analysis demonstrates that management of the Manayunk Canal by a firm would reconcile existing confrontations through compromise use of the water resource. Benefit and cost calculations show that a compromise among industrial and recreational interests, currently competing in the political arena, would increase social benefits.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resources Bulletin; (United States); Journal Volume: 25:5

TITLE: Penstock productivity improved
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MAINTENANCE; CLEANING; COST; PIPES; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The Strawberry Water Users Association recently realized a significant increase in output on their hydroelectric plant near Spanish Fork, Utah. The plant's output was declining steadily and the problem was determined to be caused by build-up in its 11,000 foot long, 18 inch diameter penstock. After considering replacing the penstock or using hydro-blasting, the association decided that the pipe could be cleaned internally with flexible foam pits. Following the cleaning operation, the plant's output increased 22 percent to 345 kW. The new output level represents an increase in the association's annual income from the sale of electricity of $32,850 -enough to cover the costs of the equipment and contractor costs in approximately one year. The association plans to maintain maximum production by pumping an 18 inch pig down the line each year.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (USA); Journal Volume: 19:7

TITLE: Alternative methods of energy recovery for the mining industry
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 32 ENERGY CONSERVATION, CONSUMPTION, AND UTILIZATION; TURBOGENERATORS; DESIGN; UNDERGROUND MINING; COOLING SYSTEMS; WATER; ENERGY RECOVERY; AIR CONDITIONING; ECONOMICS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY CONVERSION; FLOW RATE; GOLD; POTENTIAL ENERGY; SILVER; WORKING CONDITIONS; CONVERSION; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ELEMENTS; ENERGY; ENERGY SYSTEMS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; METALS; MINING; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POWER; RECOVERY; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 012033 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- Underground Mining- Mine Environment- (1987-); 290300 - Energy Planning & Policy- Environment, Health, & Safety; 320304 - Energy Conservation, Consumption, & Utilization- Industrial & Agricultural Processes- Waste Heat Recovery & Utilization
DESCRIPTION: When mining for certain precious metals (such as gold and silver), it is sometimes necessary to excavate to great depths (> 3000 m) below the surface, where the environment is hot and humid. Refrigeration plants are needed to produce a healthy working environment. These plants require large volumes of cooling water to be brought into and taken out of these mines. By converting the potential energy of the incoming water to electricity rather than to heat, the water stays colder. This results in cooler mine temperatures, and less need for off-site power. The objective of the project reported was to demonstrate the technical and economic viability of energy recovery from the incoming cooling water used in the refrigeration systems. The economic, operational, and logistic constraints imposed by a mining operation, where ore production, not power production, is the primary concern, were addressed. The final design was an impulse turbine-generator machine rated at 300-kW output at 90:00820 m head and 40 l/s flow rate.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Industry Applications (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA); Journal Volume: 25:5
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Industry Applications (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (USA)

TITLE: Refining hydropower
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; DAMS; EFFICIENCY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MARKET; OPERATION; SPILLWAY; TURBINES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; MACHINERY; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130400 - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations
DESCRIPTION: Hydropower has been in commercial use since at least the industrial revolution and is typically viewed as a mature technology rather than one on the cutting edge of technological progress. However, this belies the fact that innovation in the field is constantly going on. A number of professionals in the hydropower field were surveyed and asked to identify the significant advances in hydroelectric technology. The developments and refinements described by these experts can be divided into three different types: (1) refinements made possible by technological advances in other fields which, in hydroelectric applications, can have rather radical effects; (2) improvements made possible by the development and commercial availability for hydroelectric applications of new materials; and (3) changes and developments brought on by the scarcity of high quality hydro sites and the associated need to harness very low head sites (as low as nine feet) and small capacity sites. Some examples of the new refinements in the hydropower field are presented.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (USA); Journal Volume: 19:7

TITLE: Variable structure and time-varying parameter control for hydroelectric generating unit
AUTHORS: Luqing, Y; Shouping, W; Haibo, X; Malik, O P; Hope, G S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONTROL SYSTEMS; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; PARAMETRIC ANALYSIS; STABILITY; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The plant structure and parameters of the governing system of an hydroelectric generating unit are variable. Therefore, a variable structure and time-varying parameter control is desirable. A variable structure control strategy relative to the variable plant structure and output variation is developed, and a non-linear compensation approach is proposed and analysed. Moreover, for a certain plant structure but with variable parameters a time varying parameter control approach is developed, and its stability is analysed and proved. Simulation results show the effectiveness of the proposed control strategy applied to an hydroelectric generating unit.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; (USA); Journal Volume: 4:3

TITLE: Optimal PID gain schedule for hydrogenerators
AUTHORS: Orelind, G; Wozniak, L; Medanic, J; Whittemore, T
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; DESIGN; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DIGITAL SYSTEMS; GAIN; PERFORMANCE TESTING; AMPLIFICATION; CONTROL SYSTEMS; POWER PLANTS; TESTING; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes the development and testing of a digital gain switching governor for hydrogenerators. Optimal gains were found at different load points by minimizing a quadratic performance criterion prior to controller operating. During operation, the gain sets are switched in depending on the gate position and speed error magnitude. With gain switching operating, the digital governor was shown to have a substantial reduction of noise on the command signal and up to 42% faster responses to power requests. Non-linear control strategies enabled the digital governor to have a 2.5% to 2% reduction in speed overshoot on startups, and an 8% to 1% reduction in undershoot on load rejections as compared to the analog.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; (USA); Journal Volume: 4:3

TITLE: Output error identification of hydrogenerator conduit dynamics
AUTHORS: Vogt, M A; Wozniak, L; Whittemore, T R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PARAMETRIC ANALYSIS; DYNAMICS; SENSITIVITY ANALYSIS; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Two output error model reference adaptive identifiers are considered for estimating the parameters in a reduced order gate position to pressure model for the hydrogenerator. This information may later be useful in an adaptive controller. Gradient and sensitivity functions identifiers are discussed for the hydroelectric application and connections are made between their structural differences and relative performance. Simulations are presented to support the conclusion that the latter algorithm is more robust, having better disturbance rejection and less plant model mismatch sensitivity. For identification from recorded plant data from step gate inputs, the other algorithm even fails to converge. A method for checking the estimated parameters is developed by relating the coefficients in the reduced order model to head, an externally measurable parameter.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; (USA); Journal Volume: 4:3

TITLE: Feasibility of Iceland/United Kingdom HVDC submarine cable link
AUTHORS: Hammons, T J; Olsen, A; Gudnundsson, T
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC POWER INDUSTRY; MARKET; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INVESTMENT; ICELAND; UNITED KINGDOM; ELECTRIC CABLES; ENERGY SOURCES; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; FORECASTING; FOSSIL-FUEL POWER PLANTS; HVDC SYSTEMS; INVERTERS; NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS; OVERHEAD POWER TRANSMISSION; RECTIFIERS; UNDERWATER OPERATIONS; CABLES; CONDUCTOR DEVICES; DC SYSTEMS; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; ENERGY SYSTEMS; EQUIPMENT; EUROPE; INDUSTRY; ISLANDS; NUCLEAR FACILITIES; POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; POWER TRANSMISSION; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; WESTERN EUROPE; 296000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 200300 - Electric Power Engineering- Power Transmission & Distribution- (-1989); 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The paper addresses (i) market considerations including forecasts for the development of electricity supply in the United Kingdom with cost of electricity from new plant, (ii) investments for the development of hydro resources in Iceland, supply of submarine cables, overhead transmission lines and rectifier/inverter plant, (iii) marine environment, installation of cables and cable repair, (iv) rectifier/inverter station equipment, (v) HVDC overhead transmission lines and (vi) overall availability of the link. It is shown that (a) there should be no major difficulties in the manufacture and laying of submarine cables of length and type necessary for the Link, (b) availability of the connection should be at least equal to that of new coal or nuclear plant, and (c) cost of energy delivered would be competitive with that from new coal or nuclear power stations. The first 500MW of Icelandic Hydro Power could be available at inverter stations in the South of England in seven to ten years after a decision is made to proceed with the project, 1500MW could be supplied before the year 2010, about 2000MW could be developed by 2010 -- 2015. Tap-in of up to 1000MW of surplus power from Scottish power stations during the early years of the development would facilitate electrical power export of up to 2000MW from Scotland to the South of England by the turn of the century.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; (USA); Journal Volume: 4:3

TITLE: An experimental study of the performance of the counter-rotating wave energy conversion turbine
AUTHORS: McCormick, M E; Surko, S W
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ROTARY SEPARATOR TURBINES; PERFORMANCE TESTING; WAVE ENERGY CONVERTERS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; PNEUMATIC MOTORS; WATER; DATA; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; MACHINERY; MOTORS; NUMERICAL DATA; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; TESTING; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Results of an experimental study of a counter-rotating turbine operating on a pneumatic wave energy conversion system are presented. The vertical capture chamber of the water column of the system has a down-facing water intake. An electrical generator (d-c) is coupled to the turbine by a ten-gear-ratio drive train. Tests of the pneumatic wave energy conversion system were conducted with the mouth at two depths in order to vary the natural oscillating frequency of the water column. The maximum electrical power output of the system was approximately 90 W in the monochromatic waves. This value corresponds to at 36-percent efficiency based on the incident wave power in a wave crest width equal to the diameter of the capture chamber. The theoretical maximum efficiency of such a system has been shown to be 50 percent by several investigators.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Energy Resources Technology; (USA); Journal Volume: 111:3

TITLE: Application of operations research in automatic generation control of hydropower plants
AUTHORS: Wang, D; Wu, Y; Zhou, C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; AUTOMATION; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; DYNAMICS; ECONOMICS; LOAD ANALYSIS; PROGRAMMING; REAL TIME SYSTEMS; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; SAFETY; CONTROL SYSTEMS; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 990220 - Computers, Computerized Models, & Computer Programs- (1987-1989); 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Automatic generation control (AGC) of hydropower plants includes determination of the optimal number of operating units and which units ought to operate, economic dispatching of load among generators and load-frequency control (LFC). AGC must satisfy not only the economic requirements but also the safety requirements. The latter is very important for real-time control. Direct use of dynamic programming suffers from serious disadvantages, such as difficulty in considering the safety requirements, long time of calculation, large required computer memory, etc. This paper presents a new approach to solve the problem stage by stage, using in each stage different method of operations research (OR) : dynamic programming, 0-1 integer programming, principle of equal incremental. The new algorithm has been used in several hydropower plants, and good results have been achieved. This paper briefly describes the realization of AGC in the Left Powerhouse of Gezhouba Hydropower Plant. This algorithm is suitable for real-time AGC.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; (USA); Journal Volume: 4:3

TITLE: An investigation of the accuracy and the characteristics of the Peak-Shaving Method applied to production cost calculations
AUTHORS: Wu, R N; Lee, T H; Hill, E F
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CAPACITY; LOAD MANAGEMENT; PLANNING; COST; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; EQUATIONS; EXPORTS; IMPORTS; LICENSING; PEAK LOAD; POWER GENERATION; MANAGEMENT; POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 130400 - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations
DESCRIPTION: The Peak-Shaving Method (PSM) has been applied in many well-known commercial software packages for hydrothermal scheduling to minimize the system production cost. These packages are frequently applied by government agencies and utilities for rate hearings, energy import/export licensing, generation capacity expansion planning, and hourly production scheduling for a weekly system operation planning, etc. The accuracy and the characteristics of the PSM however have not yet been carefully investigated. This work presents an extensive study of the PSM. A wide range of load factors and hydro ratio systems have been tested and compared with the results of the rigorous Coordination-Equation Method (CEM). It has been found that the PSM always scheduled more water in the high load period than the CEM. The PSM, therefore, is more likely to swing the hydro plants and may thus avoid frequent on/off operation of thermal units.
RESEARCH_ORG: National Taiwan Univ., Taipei (Taiwan); New Brunswick Electric Power Commission, Fredericton, NB (Canada); New Brunswick Univ., Fredericton, NB (Canada)
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:3

TITLE: Optimal long-term unit commitment in large scale systems including fuel constrained thermal and pumped-storage hydro
AUTHORS: Aoki, K; Itoh, M; Satoh, T; Nara, K; Kanezashi, M
SUBJECT: 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; ECONOMICS; ALGORITHMS; CONSTRAINTS; LAGRANGE EQUATIONS; LIQUEFIED NATURAL GAS; LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GASES; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; ENERGY SOURCES; EQUATIONS; FLUIDS; FOSSIL FUELS; FUEL GAS; FUELS; GAS FUELS; GASES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LIQUEFIED GASES; LIQUIDS; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; NATURAL GAS; NATURAL GAS LIQUIDS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; POWER PLANTS; 200107* - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Off-Peak Energy Storage- (1980-); 200106 - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Economics; 250300 - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989); 130700 - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: This paper is concerned with a method for solving a long-term unit commitment problem in a large scale power system, which consists of three types of units; (i) usual thermal, (ii) fuel constrained thermal and (iii) pumped-storage hydro. In such a system, a long-term scheduling over one week to one month must be determined, because the LNG/LPG fuel is assigned to the fuel constrained unit at weekly or monthly intervals from contractual restrictions and also because the operation cycle of the pumped-storage unit is one week from economical reasons. The subgradient method using the Lagrangian relaxation for a daily unit commitment is not suitable to the long-term problem, since the convergence property to the dual maximum is not so good. In order to overcome this defect, the authors develop a new algorithm based on the variable metric method for dual maximization.
RESEARCH_ORG: Hiroshima Univ. (Japan). Faculty of Engineering; Aichi Inst. of Tech., Yachigusa, Yagusa-cho, Toyota (Japan)
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:3

TITLE: Reliability evaluation of sub-transmission networks with capacity and energy-limited hydraulic generation
AUTHORS: Fong, C C; Grigg, C H
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LOAD MANAGEMENT; POWER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEMS; RELIABILITY; ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OUTAGES; PEAK LOAD; MACHINERY; MANAGEMENT; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 200104 - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Components; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 990230 - Mathematics & Mathematical Models- (1987-1989); 130700 - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes an analytical tool for evaluating the reliability of sub-transmission/distribution systems which have local hydraulic generation. The local generation is normally used for peaking purposes. It has energy limitation, and is limited in capacity such that it may only be able to partially alleviate transmission overload. The model includes outage phenomena such as generation scheduled outages, transmission individual forced outages, and transmission scheduled outages. The overload relief operations include hydraulic generation dispatch and load transfer. Daily variation of power flow is modeled also.
RESEARCH_ORG: Ontario Hydro, Toronto, ON (Canada); Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, Terre Haute, IN (US)
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:3

TITLE: A nonlinear programming approach to optimal static generation expansion planning
AUTHORS: Ramos, A; Perez-Arriaga, I J; Bogas, J
SUBJECT: 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; COMPUTER CODES; M CODES; POWER GENERATION; PLANNING; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; CAPITALIZED COST; CALCULATION METHODS; CONSTRAINTS; ENERGY DEMAND; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; OPTIMIZATION; PROGRAMMING; COST; DEMAND; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 200104* - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Components; 130700 - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 200107 - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Off-Peak Energy Storage- (1980-); 990220 - Computers, Computerized Models, & Computer Programs- (1987-1989)
DESCRIPTION: This paper shows how a standard nonlinear programming approach can be applied to solve a sophisticated version of the static optimal mix problem in generation planning. The solution of the static mix problem can provide useful insights if the underlying model is able to capture the relevant features of the actual system. The model presented in this paper considers technical minima of thermal capacity, detailed operation models of storage-hydro and pumped-hydro units, a realistic model of capital costs for hydro plants, operating reserve and minimum demand constraints, and also capacity already in existence. The model formulation is in a format that can be directly handled by the well-known MINOS code and can be efficiently solved.
RESEARCH_ORG: Instituto De Investigacion Tecnologica, Universidad Pontificia Comillas, Albert Aguilera, 23, 28015 Madrid (ES)
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:3

TITLE: Computer configuration for Ontario Hydro's new Energy Management System
AUTHORS: Barrie, D; Hill, D S; Yuen, A
SUBJECT: 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; COMPUTER CODES; RELIABILITY; ENERGY MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS; DESIGN; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTER ARCHITECTURE; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; ONTARIO; PERFORMANCE; STANDARDS; CANADA; CONTROL SYSTEMS; ENERGY SYSTEMS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; 200104* - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Components; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 990220 - Computers, Computerized Models, & Computer Programs- (1987-1989)
DESCRIPTION: In 1985, Ontario Hydro decided to build a new System Control Centre and install a new Energy Management System. This decision was primarily due to obsolescence, space restrictions and other site considerations rather than dissatisfaction with the existing Energy Management System. Indeed, the existing Energy Management System had several features (eg, the suite of custom-developed application programs) which were considered so valuable to the System Operators that they should be retained in the new Energy Management System. Nevertheless, because new hardware was being installed, it provided an opportunity to review the standards of performance demanded of the Energy Management System and technological advances that could be utilized to best effect.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:3

TITLE: Reliability assessment of generation systems containing multiple hydro plant using simulation techniques
SUBJECT: 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; RELIABILITY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PERFORMANCE TESTING; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MONTE CARLO METHOD; POWER PLANTS; SIMULATION; TESTING; 200104* - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Components; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The studies reported in this paper describe models and evaluation techniques based on Monte Carlo simulation for the reliability assessment of mixed hydro-thermal generation systems. In particular it considers the effects that system operating and water management policies have on the reliability indices. These effects are described and discussed using the basic IEEE Reliability Test System (RTS) extended by additional hydro plant data. The outcome of these studies is an improved understanding of the effects that operational policies have on the behavior of mixed hydro-thermal systems and, in particular, an improved knowledge of the response of the RTS.
RESEARCH_ORG: Manchester Univ. (UK). Inst. of Science and Technology; Institute de Investigacion Tecnologica, Madrid (ES)
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:3

TITLE: New control center for EPM in Medellin, Columbia
AUTHORS: Gomez, H C; Zadeh, K N; Meyer, R C
SUBJECT: 32 ENERGY CONSERVATION, CONSUMPTION, AND UTILIZATION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; COLOMBIA; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; ENERGY SUPPLIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LOAD MANAGEMENT; LATIN AMERICA; MANAGEMENT; POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; SOUTH AMERICA; 320603* - Energy Conservation, Consumption, & Utilization- Municipalities & Community Systems- Public Utilities- (1980-); 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: The municipal electric utility of Empresas Publicas de Medellin (EPM) in Medellin, Colombia, has completed the installation and testing of their new control center. These facilities, which include all the functions expected from a modern control center, were implemented through carefully monitored and executed project stages, which are described in this article. EPM generates and transmits 1400 MW of exclusively hydroelectric energy to their service territory of the city of Medellin and nine neighboring cities and 77 smaller cities. The EPM system load ranges from 400 MW to 1200 MW.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Computer Applications in Power; (USA); Journal Volume: 2:3

TITLE: Design features of the Murray Hydroelectric Project
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; ARKANSAS RIVER; ENGINEERING; POWER PLANTS; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The Murray Hydroelectric Project is a two unit, 39 MW total rated capacity, run-of-the river facility. It is located on the Arkansas River, just outside the limits of the City of North Little Rock. The project is being developed at the existing Murray Lock and Dam No. 7, which is operated by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers for flood control and navigation. During average flow conditions, flows up to the discharge capacity of the two units will be discharged through the hydro plant. Flows above plant capacity will be discharged through the gated spillway at the previously existing dam. The new hydroelectric generating station is wholly owned by the City of North Little Rock. It is designed for both manned and unmanned (SCADA) control. This paper describes the basic design of the project, with emphasis on the electrical features.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Electronics; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:2

TITLE: Design features of the Bad Creek pumped storage project generators motors
AUTHORS: McLaren, D G; Herrin, R C; Wright, R H
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; CANADA; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; CALIFORNIA; COOLING SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC MOTORS; PERFORMANCE TESTING; ENERGY SYSTEMS; FEDERAL REGION IX; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MOTORS; NORTH AMERICA; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; TESTING; USA; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 200107 - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Off-Peak Energy Storage- (1980-)
DESCRIPTION: This paper provides a description of the four pumped-storage generator/motors supplied to Duke Power Company by General Electric Canada Inc. for the Bad Creek project. Descriptions are provided for the general unit construction, the cooling system, the thrust bearing and the structural design. The most unique design aspect of these units is the arrangement of the forced fan ventilation system which uses twenty motor driven fans to direct air in very controlled paths. This ventilation system was a result of prototype laboratory tests and recent experience at the Balsam Meadow Pumped Storage Plant of Southern California Edison.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Electronics; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:2

TITLE: Optimal sequencing of development for hydropower stations in cascade
AUTHORS: Wan, Y; Huang,; Marino, M A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 14 SOLAR ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; CHINA; POWER SYSTEMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DYNAMIC PROGRAMMING; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; MANY-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPERATION; OPTIMIZATION; PLANNING; SIMULATION; SPACE-TIME; ASIA; ENERGY SYSTEMS; POWER PLANTS; PROGRAMMING; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 140502 - Solar Energy Conversion- Thermonic & Thermoelectric conversion; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 990200 - Mathematics & Computers
DESCRIPTION: The sequencing problem for hydropower station development is a multidimensional problem involving space-time decisions. In this paper, a mathematical model that uses a combination of dynamic programming and mixed-integer programming is developed, and an efficient algorithm for its use in optimal sequencing problems is presented. This model is applied to the preliminary planning of hydropower stations on the Wujiang River in the southwestern region of China, and the results are described.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Water Resources Planning and Management; (USA); Journal Volume: 115:3
JOURNAL_NAME: Journal of Water Resources Planning and Management; (USA)

TITLE: Evaluation of unit connected, variable speed, hydropower station for HVDC power transmission
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; COMPUTER CALCULATIONS; ECONOMICS; EFFICIENCY; ELECTRICAL TRANSIENTS; ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS; HARMONICS; HVDC SYSTEMS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; ROTORS; SIMULATION; DC SYSTEMS; ENERGY SYSTEMS; MACHINERY; OSCILLATIONS; POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; TRANSIENTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; VOLTAGE DROP; 200302* - Power Transmission & Distribution- DC Systems- (1989-); 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130700 - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: The paper describes an economic alternative to the conventional design of a hydro power station which feeds power into a hvdc transmission line. A methodology is developed to operate hydraulic turbines under variable speed to maximize the turbine efficiency taking the loading and water head conditions into account. A 10x100 MW unit connected hydro power station is analyzed. A 500 MW unit connection scheme which represents one pole of the above station is simulated in time domain using Electro-Magnetic Transient Program (EMTDC). The harmonic currents flowing in stator and rotor circuits of the generator are computed and its derating factors at 60 Hz and 70 Hz operation are evaluated. Economic evaluation has been performed for 10x100 MW hydrostation for both conventional and unit connection configurations. Savings achieved by adopting unit connection scheme are presented.
RESEARCH_ORG: Univ. of Manitoba, Winnipeg (CA); Univ. of Western Ontario, London (CA)
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:2

TITLE: Hydrothermal optimal power flow based on a combined linear and nonlinear programming methodology
AUTHORS: Habibollahzadeh, H; Luo, G X; Semlyen, A
