SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; OPTIMIZATION; POWER TRANSMISSION; DESIGN; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; LINEAR PROGRAMMING; NONLINEAR PROGRAMMING; ENERGY SYSTEMS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; MACHINERY; PROGRAMMING; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130700 - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: The paper considers a new formulation of Optimal Power Flow (OPF) that makes it eminently suitable for accurate incremental modeling. Zoutendijk's method of feasible directions for solving the nonlinear programming problems is adapted for the solution of the OPF. Hydraulic modeling of systems with considerable share of hydraulic generation is also considered. The method is very efficient as it is designed to exploit the special structure of the problem.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:2

TITLE: River basin projects in Africa
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; AFRICA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; RESOURCES; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 290300 - Energy Planning & Policy- Environment, Health, & Safety
DESCRIPTION: While developers seek hydroelectric power to boost national economies, conservationists press for preservation of the natural resources and habitats on which riverside communities depend. Each side's arguments, the possible compromises, as well as the likeliest solutions are presented. The developers emphasize that urban-industrial development and food self-sufficiency in Africa require the construction of large dams. The conservationists emphasize the negative environmental and socioeconomic effects that have accompanied dam construction to date. Rhetoric on both sides is escalating; river basin authorities and their supporters are making unrealistic claims of benefits in their efforts to secure funding, while the criticism of conservationists, though it has proven to be important as a corrective measure, places disproportionate emphasis on costs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Environment; (United States); Journal Volume: 31:2

TITLE: Optimum diversion plan for hydropower scheme
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PLANNING; TAIWAN; WATER; AVAILABILITY; ECONOMICS; NONLINEAR PROGRAMMING; OPTIMIZATION; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; ASIA; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; ISLANDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POWER PLANTS; PROGRAMMING; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 290400 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Resources
DESCRIPTION: An overall study has been made to develop an optimum water resources utilization plan in the Cho Shui River Basin in Taiwan, the Republic of China (ROC). This paper represents a part of this overall study. It focuses on the optimum diversion plan and preliminary design of diversion amounts, tunnel sizes and capacities of power plants. Two diversion schemes, scheme I and scheme II, are identified and evaluated based on economic criteria. The optimization procedure of the present study consists of two phases: the first phase deals with the separate optimization of each subsystem consisting of diversions and power plants; the second phase deals with the economic evaluation of the combined subsystems. The optimum capacities of diversions and power plants in each scheme are determined successfully by using Rosenbrock's technique of nonlinear programming.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Wat. Res. Plan. Mngmt.; (United States); Journal Volume: 115:2
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Wat. Res. Plan. Mngmt.; (United States)

TITLE: Capacity expansion model for hydrothermal power systems
AUTHORS: Matsumoto, J; Fahlbusch, F E; Stiffler, P E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; CAPACITY; ENERGY DEMAND; FEEDBACK; LAGRANGE EQUATIONS; NETWORK ANALYSIS; PERFORMANCE; POWER TRANSMISSION; DEMAND; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; POWER PLANTS; SIMULATION; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 990220 - Computers, Computerized Models, & Computer Programs- (1987-1989)
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes a computer model that can be used to analyze long-term capacity expansion strategies for power generation systems consisting of hydrothermal plants and transmission networks. The objective is to determine the optimum capacity expansion schedule that minimizes the present worth of capacity cost and operating cost, subject to meeting peak power demand and energy demand. The problem is formulated as a large scale mixed-integer program and solved by Lagrangean relaxation decomposing into two-level hierarchy. At the top level is the capacity problem, where the capacity expansion decisions are made. At the second level is the operating problem, where the operational decisions on power generation and transmission are made. The feedback information is conveyed by the Lagrange multiplier.
RESEARCH_ORG: Texas Water Development Board, Austin, TX (USA); Morrison-Knudsen Engineers, Inc., San Francisco, CA (USA)
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Wat. Res. Plan. Mngmt.; (United States); Journal Volume: 115:2
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Wat. Res. Plan. Mngmt.; (United States)

TITLE: Avoided costs
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 21 SPECIFIC NUCLEAR REACTORS AND ASSOCIATED PLANTS; ECONOMICS; CALCULATION METHODS; FUELS; COST ESTIMATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PLANNING; NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; ONTARIO; ELECTRICITY; EMISSION; ENERGY DEMAND; ENERGY POLICY; ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY; POWER SYSTEMS; REGULATIONS; THEORETICAL DATA; CANADA; DATA; DEMAND; ENERGY SYSTEMS; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; INFORMATION; NORTH AMERICA; NUCLEAR FACILITIES; NUMERICAL DATA; POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 130400 - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 210700 - Nuclear Power Plants- Regulation & Licensing; 210800 - Nuclear Power Plants- Economics
DESCRIPTION: Controversies that surround the calculation of avoided costs in many parts of the U.S. are alive and well in Canada too. Ontario Hydro regularly estimates avoided costs primarily for use in evaluating some design, operating, planning and domestic marketing alternatives. Avoided costs reflect the expected cost of increased of decreased use of existing facilities or the expected cost of delaying or advancing additional resources. Avoided costs are estimated to be about 2 cents/kW.h (in $1988) to the mid 1990s. Costs increase to 3 to 4 cents/kW.h towards the late 90s (in $1988) as the nuclear construction program is completed and acid gas emission regulations become more costly to meet. Future avoided costs projections change from time to time because they are sensitive to projections of electricity demand and fuel costs and to the timing and cost of resource expansion plans. As in many other jurisdictions, regulatory and policy making bodies in Ontario and developers of cogeneration and small hydro are interested in calculations of avoided costs. This paper explains how Ontario Hydro calculates avoided costs. The paper includes a brief review of various methods proposed for calculating avoided costs. The discussion then refers to the theoretical basis for the methods used and lists in detail the assumptions used by Ontario Hydro.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:1

TITLE: A persistent error in cost-benefit analysis; The case of the Three Gorges dam in China
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CHINA; DAMS; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; ERRORS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; ASIA; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The history of cost-benefit analysis is closely intertwined with the history of hydro megaprojects. The U.S. Flood Control Act of 1936 and the Green Book of 1950 are frequently cited as the seminal documents in the discipline, and many of the key academic studies in the field are focused explicitly on the analysis of large hydroelectric dams. The extensive literature on cost-benefit analysis has illuminated several fundamental issues, such as the discounting of costs and benefits, the evaluation of multipurpose projects, the difference between financial and economic prices, and the treatment of externalities (environmental effects). It seems fair to say that, at a conceptual level, the authors now understand these issues much better than they did half a century ago when the Flood Control Act was passed, though, of course, at a practical level the implementation of these insights can still pose major headaches.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Systems and Policy; (USA); Journal Volume: 13:2

TITLE: Minimum loss power flow in hydro thermal electric power systems based on Kron's loss formula
AUTHORS: Ravindranath, K M; El-Hawary, M E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPTIMIZATION; CALCULATION METHODS; ITERATIVE METHODS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; POWER LOSSES; ENERGY LOSSES; LOSSES; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 990230 - Mathematics & Mathematical Models- (1987-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The authors discuss the formulation of the optimal minimum loss hydro-thermal power flow problem in electric power systems on the basis of Kron's loss formula as the objective function. Results of computational experience with a Newton's iterative implementation using two standard test systems. The conclusion is that it is extremely important to have an accurate loss model representation due to the potential errors as well as slow and difficult convergence behavior of the process.
RESEARCH_ORG: Technical Univ. of Nova Scotia, Nova Scotia (CA)
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. Mach. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: 16:3

TITLE: Measurement of harmonic currents and evaluation of the dc filter performance of the New England - Hydro-Quebec Phase I HVDC Project
AUTHORS: Garrity, T F; Hassan, I D; Donahue, J A
SUBJECT: 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC CURRENTS; HARMONICS; ELECTRIC FILTERS; PERFORMANCE TESTING; HVDC SYSTEMS; QUEBEC; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; POWER TRANSMISSION LINES; CANADA; CURRENTS; DC SYSTEMS; ENERGY SYSTEMS; FILTERS; NORTH AMERICA; OSCILLATIONS; POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; TESTING; 200101* - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Cooling & Heat Transfer Equipment & Systems; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Measurements of harmonic currents in the New England-Hydro-Quebec Phase I HVDC Project de transmission line are presented in this paper. Measurements were conducted to determine the cause of increased telephone interference and to evaluate the dc filter performance. The measurements revealed unexpected high levels of 3-pulse harmonic currents in the dc pole conductors. The cause is attributed to imbalances within the 6-pulse bridges caused by the converter transformer and valve stray capacitances to ground. The conventional model of the converter power circuit used as the basis for the dc filter design does not reproduce the measured 3-pulse harmonics. Modification to this model is required to account for the effect of the converter transformer and valve stray capacitances to ground.
RESEARCH_ORG: Ebasco Services Inc., New York, NY (US); New England Power Service Co., Westborough, MA (US)
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Del.; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:1

TITLE: A digital governor for hydrogenerators
AUTHORS: Murphy, L D; Wozniak, L; Whittemore, T A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; ALGORITHMS; ANALOG SYSTEMS; DIGITAL SYSTEMS; MICROPROCESSORS; OPERATION; COMPUTERS; CONTROL SYSTEMS; ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; MICROELECTRONIC CIRCUITS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 990220 - Computers, Computerized Models, & Computer Programs- (1987-1989)
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes the development and testing of a microcomputer-based digital governor for hydrogenators. The digital governor was shown to approximate the control function of existing analog controllers. This task was performed as a first step to future work intended to utilize the versatility of microcomputers in effecting more sophisticated control algorithms to improve hydrosystem operation.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Electronics; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:4

TITLE: Waved core lamination techniques on large and bulb hydroelectric machinery
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; EQUIPMENT PROTECTION DEVICES; DAMAGE; DEFORMATION; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ELECTRIC MOTORS; SPRINGS; STATORS; THERMAL EXPANSION; THERMAL STRESSES; EXPANSION; MACHINE PARTS; MOTORS; POWER PLANTS; STRESSES; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Stator core lamination of large hydroelectric generators and motors and especially bulb type machines are often exposed to heat expansion forces causing severe damages. The temperature difference between the warm core lamination and the relatively colder stator frame, creates both radial and tangential stresses in these components. The consequence of these stresses depends on the axial prestressing of lamination and the internal design of the core. An overriding of some critical combination of these stresses may result in buckling of lamination, fracture of core tensioning and supporting components or cracks in the stator frame. The present waved lamination technique reduces the tangential and radial spring constant of core and prevents the damages. The research performed through theoretical and experimental methods, indicates a fundamental change in the behavior of core. The waved lamination was successfully used in a large number of machines, providing the reliability and wide application range of the method.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Electronics; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:4

TITLE: Hydro project updates
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; CALIFORNIA; CAPACITY; CONSTRAINTS; DENMARK; DESIGN; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY; FEDERAL REGION X; FISHES; IDAHO; IRELAND; MASSACHUSETTS; NORWAY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; RHODE ISLAND; TAIWAN; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; ASIA; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; EUROPE; FEDERAL REGION I; FEDERAL REGION IX; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; ISLANDS; NORTH AMERICA; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SCANDINAVIA; USA; VERTEBRATES; WESTERN EUROPE; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 299000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: While they keep their eye on future relicensing activities, developers of hydroelectric facilities are proceeding with finishing their backlog of projects. Following is an update on the Gem State project near Idaho Falls, Idaho; the Tupperware facility along the Blackstone River between Rhode Island and Massachusetts; the Byllesby project of North American Hydro; and the Mington Pumped Storage project in central Taiwan. In addition a proposal to prohibit hydroelectric development in the north west along streams where salmon, steelhead, or wild non-seagoing fish are present is reviewed. Developments in Ireland, Norway, and Denmark are discussed. Problems with the Rio Bravo plant in California are described.
RELATION: Journal Name: Alternative Sources of Energy; (USA)

TITLE: Real-time monitoring, optimization and control of a hydroelectric generation complex
AUTHORS: Naccarino, J; Cheung, R; Briggs, W; Mayur, N
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CHILE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ELECTRIC POWER; PLANNING; OPTIMIZATION; REAL TIME SYSTEMS; ALGORITHMS; C CODES; CONTROL SYSTEMS; DESIGN; FIELD TESTS; FORECASTING; LINEAR PROGRAMMING; COMPUTER CODES; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; LATIN AMERICA; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; POWER; POWER PLANTS; PROGRAMMING; SOUTH AMERICA; TESTING; 296000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes the design, implementation, field installation and testing of the new control system developed for the COLBUN/MACHICURA hydro-generation complex in Chile. This control system features state-of-the-art production planning functions (Reservoir Inflow Forecasting and Generation Scheduling), generation control functions (Regulation Adjustment and Generator Setpoint Control), and hydraulic monitoring and control functions, plus a complete set of SCADA functions. All the optimization algorithms have been formulated based on a unified methodology using Linear Programming, which provides a high level of effectiveness and cohesiveness among all the applications functions, and makes this unique package one of the most advanced control systems for hydro-generation facilities in operation today.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:4

TITLE: Prediction of power system generator self-excitation using pattern recognition
AUTHORS: Mohamed, E A; Swift, G W
SUBJECT: 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; OVERVOLTAGE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; AC SYSTEMS; MANITOBA; ALGORITHMS; DESIGN; FORECASTING; OPTIMIZATION; PATTERN RECOGNITION; SECURITY; CANADA; ENERGY SYSTEMS; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; 200104* - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Components; 200301 - Power Transmission & Distribution- AC Systems, EHV & UHV- (-1989); 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: Power system generators may experience self excitation overvoltages due to certain contingencies. In an attempt to derive a new self-excitation (SE) preventive scheme, a prediction system based on pattern recognition techniques is described in this paper. Several design approaches are explained. A hyperplane discriminant is used to define the predictor surface. An algorithm is developed to reduce the number of telemetered channels required and hence the complexity of the prediction system structure. Moreover, a fast corrective algorithm designed to provide security improvement action is explained. The studied system is the Manitoba Hydro northern ac collector system where SE is the operating problem of concern. The results obtained prove the effectiveness of the proposed prediction scheme.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:4

TITLE: What's your hydro project worth
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MARKET; COST; ECONOMICS; EVALUATION; PRICING REGULATIONS; POWER PLANTS; REGULATIONS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 290200 - Energy Planning & Policy- Economics & Sociology
DESCRIPTION: Developers and bankers are reluctant to expand their hydroelectric holdings without a firm assessment of the market value of the hydroelectric assets securing their loans. Competent appraisers are essential to the industry; however, few appraisers have sufficient hydroelectric knowledge and expertise to prepare a competent and cost effective value determination of a hydroelectric station. The sales comparison technique used by most appraisers should be supplemented with the income capitalization technique for determination of value. By capitalizing the value of the project's income stream at an acceptable yield rate or rate of return, it establishes project value on the basis of what the market considers to be feasible.
RELATION: Journal Name: Alternative Sources of Energy; (USA)

TITLE: Optimizing turbine efficiency using index testing
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TURBINE BLADES; OPTIMIZATION; COLUMBIA RIVER; DATA ACQUISITION SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; PERFORMANCE TESTING; POWER PLANTS; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; TESTING; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Index testing is especially valuable for turbines that use a mechanical linkage and a cam to set the blade angle for various gate positions. A key element in the process is a computerized data acquisition system. Periodic testing can also detect changes in the characteristics of the turbines. The blade control linkages and blade trunnion bushing can become worm, and welding done to repair cavitation damage to the blades may alter their profile. As these changes occur, the original set of cams becomes less efficient. Index testing was performed at two hydroelectric plants on the Columbia River in central Washington, one at the Wanapum Dam and the other at the Priest Rapids Dam. Each of these facilities has 10 turbine generators. The combined annual production for the two plants is more than 9.9E9 kilowatt hours.
RESEARCH_ORG: Grant County Public Utility District, Ephrata, WA (US)
RELATION: Journal Name: Mech. Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 110:10

TITLE: Installation of hydro-Quebec's distribution feeder automation system
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; AUTOMATION; POWER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEMS; CIRCUIT BREAKERS; COMPUTER CODES; QUEBEC; ECONOMICS; ELECTRIC POWER; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; EQUIPMENT PROTECTION DEVICES; INSTALLATION; PILOT PLANTS; REMOTE CONTROL; CANADA; CONTROL; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; FUNCTIONAL MODELS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 200104 - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Components; 200300 - Electric Power Engineering- Power Transmission & Distribution- (-1989); 200106 - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Economics
DESCRIPTION: Electric power distribution involves three different levels of operation: substations, feeder and customer meters. Many substations at Hydro-Quebec have reached a high degree of sophistication in automation these days and the next logical step for improving the distribution is to automate the feeder networks and, then, the household end. Most feeder interrupting devices are static and call for line crews to open and close switches manually in order to locate and isolate faults and restore power to customers. Traditional feeder maintenance service is no longer adequate because, as the distribution network becomes more and more complex due to expansion, customers have to face longer outages. This paper discusses a pilot project involving feeder automation at Hydro-Quebec which was installed in November 1984 and commissioned in February 1985. All the work from the design of the remote terminal unit, the operating software for the master station and the communication protocol to the production follow-up of 40 RTUs and field installation was completely performed by Hydro-Quebec and its research institute, IREQ, in Varennes.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Del.; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:4

TITLE: Environmental effects of the high dam at Aswan
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; EGYPTIAN ARAB REPUBLIC; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; NILE RIVER; DAMS; AFRICA; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; POWER PLANTS; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: No single resource development project has aroused more controversy than the high dam that stores the flow of the Nile River above the first cataract at Aswan. It is praised as the mainstay of the Egyptian economy and vilified as an environmental catastrophe. Twenty-one years after its completion there has been sufficient time to permit a first approximation of what is known about the dam's environmental effects and how they compare to what was anticipated when engineers and politicians decided to undertake the massive project. Although the evidence from post-audit study over the past decade is far from complete, there is enough to warrant general observations on direct economic impacts and to suggest several possible lessons of importance to scientists engaged in predicting and tracing environmental linkages from major water projects.
RELATION: Journal Name: Environment; (United States); Journal Volume: 30:7

TITLE: Optimal short term operation of a purely hydroelectric system
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; PERFORMANCE; POWER GENERATION; OPTIMIZATION; ALGORITHMS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; LINEAR PROGRAMMING; LOAD MANAGEMENT; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; WATER RESERVOIRS; CONTROL SYSTEMS; MANAGEMENT; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; POWER PLANTS; PROGRAMMING; SIMULATION; SURFACE WATERS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 990220 - Computers, Computerized Models, & Computer Programs- (1987-1989); 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: The short term production scheduling problem for a purely hydroelectric system can be simplified so that power production and water can be managed separately. This approximation is possible, when plants have large daily reservoirs with fixed or controllable heads. The model described in this paper, optimizes the hourly power production of a system of hydroplants, by minimizing losses in turbines and waterways, while maintaining production of meat load. The problem is inherently of the mixed integer nonlinear type, but an algorithm has been developed to solve it in 2 stages by Linear Programming (LP). The model has been tested with data from an existing purely hydroelectric system (The Icelandic Power system being the model system). Results indicate considerable savings in water usage from large seasonal reservoirs. These results also indicate feasibility to install the model in a control center computer when conditions are similar to the model system.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:3

TITLE: A contribution to the midterm scheduling of large scale hydrothermal power systems
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTER CODES; OPTIMIZATION; ALGORITHMS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; COMPUTERS; NETWORK ANALYSIS; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; POWER PLANTS; SIMULATION; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 990220 - Computers, Computerized Models, & Computer Programs- (1987-1989)
DESCRIPTION: This paper is concerned with optimal midterm scheduling of large power systems with predominance of hydroelectric generation. Modelling leads to the problem of minimizing a nonlinear piecewise differentiable function of flows in a network. A suitable algorithm is presented. A case study considers midterm scheduling for a large Brazilian hydroelectric system. An optimization-simulation strategy that attains a good suboptimal solution with saving in computer requirements is also presented.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:3

TITLE: Dynamic voltage control by remote voltage regulation for pumped storage plants
AUTHORS: Dehdashti, A S; Luini, J F; Peng, Z
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; POWER SYSTEMS; PERFORMANCE; PLANNING; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; ON-LINE CONTROL SYSTEMS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; FIELD TESTS; NETWORK ANALYSIS; OVERVOLTAGE; VOLTAGE REGULATORS; CONTROL SYSTEMS; ENERGY SYSTEMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ON-LINE SYSTEMS; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; SIMULATION; TESTING; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 250300 - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989); 990220 - Computers, Computerized Models, & Computer Programs- (1987-1989); 290100 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Analysis & Modeling
DESCRIPTION: This paper presents a new application in dynamic voltage control based on an older method of voltage regulation. The resulting method is suitable for adoption inn multi-unit pumped storage plants. Inherent operation characteristics of pumped storage plants in the pumping mode can created visible load rejection overvoltages on the transmission and the nearby distribution networks and cause customer complaints. This paper proposes a method in which the on-line units' excitation system impedance compensators are utilized to reduce the magnitude of these overvoltages. This paper presents the theoretical background, computer simulation results, and the field test results at the Pacific Gas and Electric Company's Helms Pumped Storage Plant. This paper should be of interest in the areas of power system planning as well as power system operation.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:3

TITLE: Control variable adjustment in load flows
AUTHORS: Maria, G A; Yuen, A H; Findlay, J A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LOAD MANAGEMENT; COMPUTER CALCULATIONS; ONTARIO; ITERATIVE METHODS; LINEAR PROGRAMMING; NEWTON METHOD; CANADA; MANAGEMENT; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; PROGRAMMING; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: A linear programming type approach is used to adjust all adjustable load flow variables to respect specified constraints. The technique is applicable to the Newton coupled and decoupled as well as the fast decoupled load flows. The coordinated adjustment of all adjustable variables improves the convergence of the load flow iterations with minimal increase in the computation required by each iteration. No change to the structure (Newton) (or structure and values (fast decoupled)) of the Jacobian result when constrained variables violate their limits. The variable set remains the same throughout all of the iterations. This algorithm was implemented in the Ontario Hydro energy management system. Test results who a considerable reduction in the number of iterations and computation saving when major adjustments to the adjustable variables are required.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:3

TITLE: High water, hot dispute
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; ATTITUDES; DAMS; NEW YORK; FEDERAL REGION II; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; USA; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Rising 200 feet above the Genesee River, the Mt. Morris Dam is capable of turning a New York gorge known as the Grand Canyon of the East into a muddy lake. But the dam seldom holds much water. Its sole purpose is to restrain yearly floodwaters - or so conservationists thought until recently. Angered to learn that the federal government considers the dam site a good place to generate hydropower, a local group called the Letchworth Preservation Alliance has mobilized to protect the gorge from further incursions.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sierra; (United States); Journal Volume: 73:4

TITLE: Letting the rivers flow
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ANADROMOUS FISHES; HABITAT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; COLUMBIA RIVER BASIN; FISHERIES; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; MIGRATION; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; FISHES; POWER PLANTS; VERTEBRATES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: By 1980, 35 percent of the anadromous-fish habitat in the Columbia River basin was gone, and the salmon run had been reduced to a million. Then Congress stepped in. In 1980 it passed the Pacific Northwest Electric Power Planning and Conservation Act, which included a provision to stop and reverse fisheries depletion. This year the Northwest Power Planning Council may take a dramatic step toward meeting that goal. The council has proposed a protected areas program that would ban new hydroelectric dams on more than 40,000 miles of streams in the Pacific Northwest. As a result, at least 200 potential hydro projects could be scrapped.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sierra; (United States); Journal Volume: 73:4

TITLE: Highlights of the GURI hydroelectric plant computer control system
AUTHORS: Dal Monte, R; Banakar, H; Hoffman, R; Lebeau, M; Schroeder, R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; VENEZUELA; AUTOMATION; CLOSED-LOOP CONTROL; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; MAINTENANCE; PROGRAM MANAGEMENT; REACTOR MONITORING SYSTEMS; TRAINING; CONTROL; CONTROL SYSTEMS; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; LATIN AMERICA; MANAGEMENT; POWER PLANTS; SIMULATION; SOUTH AMERICA; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The GURI power plant on the Caroni river in Venezuela has 20 generating units with a total capacity of 10,000 MW, the largest currently operating in the world. The GURI Computer Control System (GCS) provides for comprehensive operation management of the entire power plant and the adjacent switchyards. This article describes some highlights of the functions of the state-of-the-art system. The topics considered include the operating modes of the remote terminal units (RTUs), automatic start/stop of generating units, RTU closed-loop control, automatic generation and voltage control, unit commitment, operator training stimulator, and maintenance management.
RESEARCH_ORG: Computer Control and Communication Section of Harza Engineering Co., Chicago, IL (US)
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Comput. Applicat. Power; (United States); Journal Volume: 1:3

TITLE: Forty years of operation of the hydraulic structures of the Shirokovo hydroelectric station
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; USSR; BUILDING MATERIALS; CIVIL ENGINEERING; CONSTRUCTION; DAMS; DEFORMATION; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; FOUNDATIONS; HISTORICAL ASPECTS; MAINTENANCE; RELIABILITY; REPAIR; SLOPE STABILITY; SPILLWAY; URALS; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; ENGINEERING; EUROPE; GEOLOGY; MATERIALS; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MOUNTAINS; POWER PLANTS; STABILITY; SUPPORTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The Shirokovo hydroelectric station is located on the Kos'va river and has been operating since 1948. The hydrostation was constructed during the Second World War with a shortage of metal, cement, and construction machines. The designs of the structures were made lightweight with the minimum consumption of construction materials without considerable safety factors with respect to strength and stability. Nevertheless, these structures have already been operating for a long time under the harsh climatic conditions of the mountainous region of the Northern Urals, on a river with an unstable water regime under conditions of frequent strats of the unit for covering peak loads. This paper describes the design, construction, and operating history of the station along with maintenance and reinforcement regimes undertaken to ensure its reliability.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:1; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnich. Stroitel'stov; 22: No. 1, 47-50(Jan 1988)

TITLE: Uplift pressure of water in a system of cracks of eccentrically compressed reinforced-concrete elements
AUTHORS: Kogan, E A; Mgalobelov, Yu B
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CONCRETE BLOCKS; PRESSURE EFFECTS; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; REINFORCED CONCRETE; CRACKS; COMPRESSION; DIAGRAMS; FRACTURE PROPERTIES; HYDRAULICS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MECHANICAL TESTS; PERMEABILITY; PRESSURE DROP; STATIC LOADS; STRESS ANALYSIS; STRESSES; TEST FACILITIES; BUILDING MATERIALS; CONCRETES; FLUID MECHANICS; MATERIALS; MATERIALS TESTING; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; MECHANICS; REINFORCED MATERIALS; TESTING; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The water uplift pressure in a system of cracks of compressed reinforced concrete was both theoretically and experimentally investigated under conditions of eccentric compression. In the tensioned zone equal to the depth of the cracks observed in the experiments a rectangular water pressure diagram was at first established, but after several days due to losses of pressure as a consequence of seepage along partially clogged cracks, the pressure diagram became less rectangular, and pore water pressure equal to 30-50% of the pressure head occurred in the compressed zone. The measured values of the increments of stresses in the reinforcement in sections along the extreme cracks from the effect of a water pressure of 5-8 gauge atm were close to the calculated values of such increments.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:1; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnich. Stroitel'stov; 22: No. 1, 56-60(Jan 1988)

TITLE: Concerning the technology of constructing pumped-storage stations of a new design
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; SHAFTS; EMPLACEMENT; UNDERGROUND FACILITIES; BUILDING CODES; CONTROL; EXCAVATION; MATERIALS HANDLING EQUIPMENT; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; SUBSURFACE STRUCTURES; EQUIPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MACHINE PARTS; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The technological methods of sinking underground structures under the effect of their own weight recommended by the building code and those traditionally used (and also the recommendations on eliminating tilting and sticking) do not provide the normal occurrence of the sinking process and do not preclude the possibility of failures. Reliable control of the process of sinking drop shafts can be accomplished by using a jack-cable system with simultaneous control of the stress-strain state of the drop shaft. Construction of deep underground structures should be carried out in two and more stages using these systems.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:1; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnich. Stroitel'stov; 22: No. 1, 51-53(Jan 1988)

TITLE: Concrete dam on the Bratsk hydroelectric station
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; AGING; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CIVIL ENGINEERING; CONCRETES; DEFORMATION; DRAINAGE; FOUNDATIONS; GROUTING; IN-SERVICE INSPECTION; LEACHING; MAINTENANCE; PRESSURE EFFECTS; REPAIR; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; ROCKS; SLOPE STABILITY; SPILLWAY; TEMPERATURE EFFECTS; ASIA; BUILDING MATERIALS; DISSOLUTION; EASTERN EUROPE; ENGINEERING; EUROPE; INSPECTION; MATERIALS; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; POWER PLANTS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; STABILITY; SUPPORTS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The Bratsk concrete dam was designed and constructed with a sufficient degree of reliability. Settlement of the dam together with the powerhouse developed uniformly under the entire foundation. Two irreversible processes causing aging of the dam have been established by operating observations: leaching of the concrete and decompression of the contact zone of the foundation near the upstream face of the powerhouse sections. The decompression is due to the fact that the powerhouse sections are lighter than the spillway sections. At the present level this process can only be slowed by the combined use of grouting and drainage unloading.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:1; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnich. Stroitel'stov; 22: No. 1, 40-46(Jan 1988)

TITLE: Experience in using the water resources of the Novosibirsk reservoir
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; WATER RESERVOIRS; WATER USE; ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT; FLOOD CONTROL; IRRIGATION; MANAGEMENT; ORGANIZING; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; RIVERS; SHORTAGES; WATER REQUIREMENTS; WATER RESOURCES; WATER SUPPLY; WATER UTILITIES; ASIA; CONTROL; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; RESOURCES; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 290400 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Resources
DESCRIPTION: With the creation of the Novosibirsk hydrodevelopment a water-management complex was formed on its basis, which unites water users and water consumers such as hydropower, water transport, irrigation, municipal services, agriculture, forestry, and fishery. During the 30-year operation of the hydrodevelopment changes have occurred in the natural conditions on the stretch of the Ob river adjacent to the development which was the cause of the occurrence of a considerable shortage of water resources in years with a low runoff of the river. To increase the effectiveness of using water resources of the Novosibirsk reservoir, organizational and technical measures on providing the normal activities of the water-management complex under conditions of a water resource shortage have partially been and will be carried out in the near future.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:1; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnich. Stroitel'stov; 22: No. 1, 18-22(Jan 1988)

TITLE: Selection and investigation of supports of the underground generator hall of the Rogun hydroelectric station
AUTHORS: Zolotov, O N; Ilyushin, V F; Mostkov, V M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ROOFS; SUPPORTS; TURBOGENERATORS; UNDERGROUND FACILITIES; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ANCHORS; CIVIL ENGINEERING; COMPRESSION STRENGTH; CONSTRUCTION; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; CRANES; DEFORMATION; DESIGN; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; EXCAVATION; FLEXIBILITY; REINFORCED CONCRETE; STRESS ANALYSIS; STRESSES; TECTONICS; ASIA; BUILDING MATERIALS; CONCRETES; EASTERN EUROPE; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ENGINEERING; EQUIPMENT; EUROPE; GEOLOGY; MATERIALS; MATERIALS HANDLING EQUIPMENT; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; POWER PLANTS; REINFORCED MATERIALS; TENSILE PROPERTIES; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes the selection, design, and construction of a yielding support for the arch of the generator hall of the Rogun hydroelectric station which provides reliable roof support under conditions of large tectonic stresses. Compared with more technologically efficient rigid structures, the proposed structure makes it possible to obtain a technical-economic effect due to a reduction of the volume of works on rock excavation and underground reinforced concrete because of an allowed reduction in the thickness of the arch.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:1; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnich. Stroitel'stov; 22: No. 1, 11-15(Jan 1988)

TITLE: A reliability cost-benefit analysis for HVDC transmission expansion planning
AUTHORS: Kuruganty, P R.S.; Woodford, D A
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HVDC SYSTEMS; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; OUTAGES; RELIABILITY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DATA ACQUISITION; DEMONSTRATION PROGRAMS; INFORMATION NEEDS; PLANNING; SEASONAL VARIATIONS; STATISTICS; THYRISTORS; DC SYSTEMS; ENERGY SYSTEMS; MATHEMATICS; POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES; VARIATIONS; 200302* - Power Transmission & Distribution- DC Systems- (1989-); 296002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Transmission & Distribution- (-1989); 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: A major portion of Manitoba Hydro's generation is located in the North on the Nelson River. The lower Nelson River generation is brought into the load centre in Southern Manitoba through an HVDC transmission system consisting of two bipoles, the first rated at 1680 MW at the rectifier and the second at 2000 MW. This paper presents the methodology used in arriving at the optimum Bipole 3 size using a reliability cost-benefit analysis. The analysis considers the forced outages of the generation and transmission systems using system outage statistics. The generator and valve group maintenance and the reduction in capability of thyristor valve groups during the summer season were also incorporated in the analysis. The load model used in the study was based on system data for the period 1980-1984. The criterion used in choosing the Bipole 3 size is to optimize the present worth value of the annual energy curtailment due to the HVDC system forced outages and the incremental installation cost of the transmission as the capacity of Bipole 3 is increased. The optimum Bipole 3 size based on the study is 2200 MW. This value is significantly lower than that based on a pole spare criterion used in the earlier development of the HVDC system. Finally, the need for validation of the outage data in evaluating future HVDC projects and the need for data collection and classification is indicated.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Del.; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:3

TITLE: Strength of thawed and frozen soils of dam cores under conditions of triaxial independent loading by tension and compression
AUTHORS: Vasil'ev, I M; Sinyakov, L N; Mel'nikov, V A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; BUILDING MATERIALS; TEMPERATURE EFFECTS; DAMS; MATERIALS TESTING; SOILS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; COMPRESSION STRENGTH; DEFORMATION; FRACTURE PROPERTIES; FREEZING; MECHANICAL TESTS; PRESSURE EFFECTS; SAMPLING; STRAINS; STRESS ANALYSIS; STRESSES; TENSILE PROPERTIES; THAWING; THERMAL CYCLING; THERMAL TESTING; MATERIALS; NONDESTRUCTIVE TESTING; TESTING; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: A method is proposed to solve the problem of tension cracking of dam cores which includes testing soil samples in thawed and frozen states, calculating the stress-strain state of the dam, determining the extent and spatial orientation of tension cracks, and establishing the extent of open cracks. The results of such investigations are given for evaluating cracking on the crests of the cores of two dams: one being constructed under northern conditions with a height of 132 m and one being planned for construction in the southern region of the country with a height of 330 m. The method can be used when solving problems of stability, investigating the failure possibility of deformable foundations by tension, and determining pressure on a structure.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:1; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnich. Stroitel'stov; 22: No. 1, 25-29(Jan 1988)

TITLE: Experience in constructing the gravity arch dam of the Sayano-Shushenskoe hydroelectric station
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; BINDERS; CIVIL ENGINEERING; CONCRETE BLOCKS; CONCRETES; COST; DESIGN; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; FLY ASH; FOUNDATIONS; MOUNTAINS; POWER GENERATION; PROGRAM MANAGEMENT; RELIABILITY; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; START-UP; WASTE PRODUCT UTILIZATION; WATER RESERVOIRS; AEROSOL WASTES; ASHES; ASIA; BUILDING MATERIALS; EASTERN EUROPE; ENGINEERING; EUROPE; GEOLOGY; MANAGEMENT; MATERIALS; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; POWER PLANTS; RESIDUES; SUPPORTS; SURFACE WATERS; WASTES; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: The gravity arch dam of the Sayano-Shushenskoe hydroelectric station has a construction height of 242.5 m, base width of 107.2 m, crest length of 1066 m, maximum head 220 m, and a volume of concrete of 8,500,000 m/sup 3/. This paper reviews the construction and materials technology involved in building the dam and the practice of staged start-up during construction at incomplete heads. The designers and builders were able to markedly reduce reinforcement of the dam without detriment to its reliability. It was also possible to almost completely eliminate imported rubble to make from gravel concrete all structural elements. Fly ash from a central heating and power plant was used as a binder in the final construction stages. Many aspects concerning possible improvement of the design of the dam, its economy, reliability, and improvement of the scheme of construction became clear during construction while conducting and analyzing on-site observations. These aspects are discussed in detail.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:1; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnich. Stroitel'stov; 22: No. 1, 8-11(Jan 1988)

TITLE: Seismic loads on the foundations of hydraulic structures during strong earthquakes
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; SEISMIC EFFECTS; EARTHQUAKES; DATA PROCESSING; FOUNDATIONS; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; SEISMIC DETECTION; SEISMICITY; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; SPECTRA; ASIA; DETECTION; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; GEOLOGY; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; POWER PLANTS; PROCESSING; SEISMIC EVENTS; SUPPORTS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: Records of earthquakes with an intensity of 3-5 were recorded at the same observation point on a rock foundation near the Chirkey dam were examined. The data of the horizontal and vertical components of the seismic oscillations were analyzed. The seismometric data were processed manually and according to the Spectrum program on a BESM-4 computer. The spectra obtained with computer processing of the accelerograms indicate that the maximum intensities of oscillations for the horizontal and vertical components lie in the same interval of frequencies between 2 and 9 Hz, but that for the horizontal component the maximum at 0.2 Hz is absent and the entire spectrum is somewhat shifted into the high-frequency region.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:1; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnich. Stroitel'stov; 22: No. 1, 22-25(Jan 1988)

TITLE: Activities of the twenty-second congress of the international association for hydraulic research
AUTHORS: Kartelev, B G; Karelin, V Ya; Zolotov, L A; Dmitriev, N Yu
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; HYDRAULICS; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY; EROSION; FLOOD CONTROL; INLAND WATERWAYS; INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; LAKES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MEETINGS; RIVERS; SOIL CONSERVATION; TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER; TURBULENCE; WATER POLLUTION; WATER QUALITY; WATER RESERVOIRS; WATER RESOURCES; CONTROL; FLUID MECHANICS; MECHANICS; POLLUTION; RESOURCE CONSERVATION; RESOURCES; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 290400 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Resources; 520200 - Environment, Aquatic- Chemicals Monitoring & Transport- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The Twenty-Second Congress of the International Association for Hydraulic Research was comprised of four sessions and four seminars. About 700 specialists from 47 countries participated in the work of the congress. This paper gives a breakdown of the various delegations attending the congress, reviews the contents of the sessions and seminars, discusses the process of information transfer between the delegations, and describes the political and administrative developments that took place, including the election of a new president and council. Session topics included turbulence in hydraulics, river hydraulics, marine hydraulics, and problems of hydraulics in environmental protection.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:1; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnich. Stroitel'stov; 22: No. 1, 61-62(Jan 1988)

TITLE: Hydraulic resistances and sediment discharge in the case of bed ripples
AUTHORS: Pletneva, E V; Bodanov, A Zh
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; INLAND WATERWAYS; HYDRAULIC CONDUCTIVITY; SEDIMENT-WATER INTERFACES; FLOW MODELS; SEDIMENTS; HYDRAULIC TRANSPORT; WATER RESERVOIRS; EROSION; FROUDE NUMBER; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; HYDROLOGY; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; REYNOLDS NUMBER; ROUGHNESS; ENGINEERING; INTERFACES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE PROPERTIES; SURFACE WATERS; TRANSPORT; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: This analysis of hydraulic resistance proceeded from the fact that the key issues of the problem of hydraulic resistance are the relationship of roughness and the resistance coefficient and the relation between hydraulic resistance and sediment discharge. The relation between resistance and bed roughness was realized by the Froude number. Experiments were conducted in a flume closed into a circulating system which automated the delivery of sediments. The difference between a ripple and a dune bed was seen to consist not only in the shape and size of the bed formations but also in the character of sediment transport. A parameter comprised of the Froude and Reynolds numbers was proposed. Its relation to sediment discharge led to recommendations useful for compiling schemes for flushing the lower pools of structures.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:1; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnich. Stroitel'stov; 22: No. 1, 36-39(Jan 1988)

TITLE: Consideration of meteorological factors when calculating large canals
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; INLAND WATERWAYS; METEOROLOGY; AIR-WATER INTERACTIONS; BERNOULLI LAW; EMBANKMENTS; ENERGY LOSSES; ENERGY TRANSFER; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; FLOW MODELS; FLOW RATE; HYDRAULIC CONDUCTIVITY; HYDRAULICS; SHEAR; SLOPE STABILITY; STRESSES; UNSTEADY FLOW; VISCOUS FLOW; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FLUID FLOW; FLUID MECHANICS; LOSSES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MECHANICS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; STABILITY; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The effect of meteorological factors on the dynamics of open-channel flows is taken into account, as a rule, when studying unsteady fluid flows. In shallow-water equations for unsteady flow in open channels the meteorological factors are included as normal and shear stresses on the free surface. The use of dynamic shallow-water equations makes it possible to obtain diverse information about the effect of the atmosphere on the structure of the open-channel flow. The approach presented in this article, based on the equation of balance of mechanical energy and ultimately on the Bernoulli equation, does not permit obtaining detailed information about the interaction of meteorological and hydraulic factors. It permits obtaining mainly simple estimates which can establish when the effect of meteorological factors on the hydraulic characteristics of the flows in canals should be taken into consideration.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:1; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnich. Stroitel'stov; 22: No. 1, 33-36(Jan 1988)

TITLE: Improvement of the method of calculating the strength of reinforced-concrete elements on the basis of inclined sections
AUTHORS: Zalesov, A S; Nikolaev, V B; Rubin, O D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; DAMS; BUILDING CODES; REINFORCED CONCRETE; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; ACCURACY; BENDING; CALCULATION METHODS; CONCRETE BLOCKS; FLEXURAL STRENGTH; FORECASTING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INCLINATION; RELIABILITY; TENSILE PROPERTIES; BUILDING MATERIALS; CONCRETES; MATERIALS; POWER PLANTS; REINFORCED MATERIALS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 360603 - Materials- Properties
DESCRIPTION: Modifications to building code SNiP 2.03.01-84 and SNiP II-56-77 paragraph 3.25 are recommended for unifying and making more accurate the method of calculating and forecasting the strength of reinforced-concrete elements on the basis of inclined sections. The proposed changes provide an increase of reliability and cost effectiveness of hydraulic structures. Calculations by the proposed method show a better agreement with experimental data than calculations by each separate SNiP 2.03.01-84 and SNiP II-56-77; the method requires further development to take into account all the phenomena reflecting the resistance of reinforced-concrete elements to the effect of a combination of external loads and bending moments.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:12; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No. 12, 39-42(Dec 1987)

TITLE: Interpretation of the results of shear tests of sands
AUTHORS: Ivanov, I P; Ivanikova, N P; Zavodchikova, M B
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; BUILDING MATERIALS; MECHANICAL TESTS; DAMS; SLOPE STABILITY; SAND; SHEAR PROPERTIES; COMPRESSION STRENGTH; DEFORMATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INTERNAL FRICTION; MOISTURE; PARTICLE SIZE; POROSITY; STRESS ANALYSIS; STRESSES; WATER SATURATION; FRICTION; MATERIALS; MATERIALS TESTING; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; POWER PLANTS; SATURATION; SIZE; STABILITY; TESTING; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 360603 - Materials- Properties
DESCRIPTION: This paper investigates the main factors which determine the shear strength of sands and assesses such properties as the angle of internal friction, density, porosity, saturation, moisture content, residual strength, stress-strain state, and vertical and horizontal deformation for their contributions to the shear strength. Issue is taken with the conclusion of an earlier study that the density has no effect on the angle of internal friction. It is concluded that the bearing capacity of sands should be calculated with consideration of the effect of their density.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:12; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No. 12, 37-39(Dec 1987)

TITLE: Damming of the Vilyui river channel at the construction site of the Vilyui III hydroelectric station
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; RIVERS; FLOW BLOCKAGE; SIBERIA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CIVIL ENGINEERING; DESIGN; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; EROSION; EXPLOSIVE FRACTURING; FLOW RATE; HYDRODYNAMICS; LEVELS; OUTLET STRUCTURES; WATER CURRENTS; WATER RESERVOIRS; ASIA; COMMINUTION; CURRENTS; EASTERN EUROPE; ENGINEERING; EUROPE; FLUID MECHANICS; FRACTURING; GEOLOGY; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; USSR; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: Damming of the Vilyui River by dumping a bank from local earth materials without the use of outsizes at a discharge up to 400 m/sup 3//sec became possible owing to the large capacity of the diversion channel and good provisions of diversion at the final stage of damming. The maximum surface current velocities during the period of damming were 3.0-3.6 m/sec, the discharge varied from 372 to 403 m/sup 3//sec, and the final difference of levels between the upper and lower pools of the damming site was 0.7 m.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:12; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No. 12, 19-23(Dec 1987)

TITLE: Hydraulic tests of the spillway of the Zeya hydroelectric station
AUTHORS: Boyarskii, V M; Vasilevskii, V V; Ginzburg, M V; Kozodoi, N F; Shvainshtein, A M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CONCRETES; MATERIALS TESTING; SPILLWAY; HYDRAULICS; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CAVITATION; CONSTRUCTION; DAMAGE; DAMS; EROSION; FROST TESTS; INSPECTION; OUTLET STRUCTURES; PRESTRESSED CONCRETE; RELIABILITY; TEMPERATURE EFFECTS; WEAR RESISTANCE; ASIA; BUILDING MATERIALS; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; FLUID MECHANICS; MATERIALS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; NONDESTRUCTIVE TESTING; POWER PLANTS; TESTING; THERMAL TESTING; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: Material tests for evaluating the resistance of construction concretes to hydraulic forces were conducted for the spillway of the Zeya hydroelectric station. Grades of concrete were used in accordance with the conditions of cavitation and frost resistance. Damage of the concrete surface of four types were found upon inspection during and after conducting the tests: spalling off of the concrete, dents from the impact of logs, pits formed on the surface of the in situ concrete, and cavitation of the concrete surface. The provision of a good quality of cavitation-resistant hydrotechnical concrete in absorbing formwork free of asperites created a sufficiently reliable counteraction to cavitation erosion for dams with a head up to 100 m.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:12; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No. 12, 33-37(Dec 1987)

TITLE: Industrial design of an earth overflow dam
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; DAMS; DESIGN; BUILDING MATERIALS; CIVIL ENGINEERING; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; CONSTRUCTION; FLOW REGULATORS; FOUNDATIONS; HYDRODYNAMICS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OUTLET STRUCTURES; REINFORCED CONCRETE; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; SLOPE STABILITY; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; SOILS; SPILLWAY; USSR; WATER RESERVOIRS; WATER SUPPLY; WATER USE; WAVE FORCES; ASIA; CONCRETES; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; EASTERN EUROPE; ENGINEERING; EQUIPMENT; EUROPE; FLUID MECHANICS; MATERIALS; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; REINFORCED MATERIALS; STABILITY; SUPPORTS; SURFACE WATERS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 290400 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Resources
DESCRIPTION: As a result of theoretical and experimental investigations of earth overflow dams of various types and purpose conducted by the author in the past ten years, methods of calculating the stability of protective structures of riprap, reinforcement meshes, gabions, and in situ and precast reinforced concrete were substantiated; the limits of economic applicability of various types of revetments and structures were determined; and new efficient designs of dams and revetments allowing the overflow of water with large discharge intensities were proposed. An earth overflow dam with the downstream slope protected by a precast reinforced-concrete revetment was determined to be the most effective design-technological solution. Both the entire dam or a part of it can be made overflow. The design has been realized on a number of experimental water-management objects which are reviewed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:12; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No. 12, 15-18(Dec 1987)

TITLE: Ways to create and improve high-parameter hydraulic drives for hydraulic structures
AUTHORS: Martenson, V Ya; Kaplan, I Kh; Ser'ga, V D; Kholodov, A A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; HYDRAULIC EQUIPMENT; CYLINDERS; DESIGN; FABRICATION; INSTALLATION; OPERATION; OPTIMIZATION; OUTLET STRUCTURES; PERFORMANCE TESTING; PISTONS; RELIABILITY; REVIEWS; DOCUMENT TYPES; EQUIPMENT; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; POWER PLANTS; TESTING; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Methods are reviewed for improving the design, manufacture, installation, and operation of hydraulic drives for hydraulic structures for the purpose of increasing the plant readiness of hydraulic cylinders and reducing the installation, startup, and adjustment work at hydraulic structures. A set of devices for operating hydraulic drives is reviewed which will make it possible to increase their operating reliability and improve the working conditions. Work is reviewed on the unification of hydraulic drives with the goal of creating economical layouts of modern hydraulic structures. The manufacture of a stepping hydraulic drive with a short-stroke cylinder as a single mechanism for operating gates and for various installation purposes is discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:12; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No. 12, 12-15(Dec 1987)

TITLE: Current trends in the development of pumped-storage stations in the world
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; DESIGN; ENERGY EFFICIENCY; ENERGY POLICY; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY; GLOBAL ASPECTS; INTERCONNECTED POWER SYSTEMS; LOAD MANAGEMENT; PUMP TURBINES; REVIEWS; TURBOGENERATORS; UNDERGROUND FACILITIES; WATER RESERVOIRS; DOCUMENT TYPES; EFFICIENCY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ENERGY SYSTEMS; GEOLOGY; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MACHINERY; MANAGEMENT; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; SURFACE WATERS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 290500 - Energy Planning & Policy- Research, Development, Demonstration, & Commercialization
DESCRIPTION: In the development of pumped-storage stations it is possible to distinguish the following main progressive trends which provide a decrease of unit expenditures, increase of their efficiency in power systems, and reduction of the adverse impact on the environment: development of higher heads and increase of capacity with simultaneous design improvement; underground or semiunderground powerhouses and underground lower and upper reservoirs; incorporation of pumped-storage stations into hybrid power complexes; flexible use of local topographic, engineering-geological, and other conditions; and provision of greater maneuverability of the units and their greater operating time. This paper describes international research and development efforts aimed at fulfilling these trends.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:12; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No. 12, 42-47(Dec 1987)

TITLE: Seepage strength of gypsinate foundations of hydraulic structures
AUTHORS: Terletskaya, M N; Metonidze, N V
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; FOUNDATIONS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; GYPSUM; PERMEABILITY; SOILS; DEFORMATION; EROSION; GROUTING; HYDRAULIC CONDUCTIVITY; LEACHING; POROSITY; SERVICE LIFE; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; CALCIUM COMPOUNDS; CALCIUM SULFATES; DISSOLUTION; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MINERALS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; SULFATE MINERALS; SULFATES; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; SUPPORTS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: Methods are discussed for determining the seepage strength of gypsinate soil foundations of hydraulic structures. When designing hydraulic structures it is necessary to calculate also the casual piping strength of soils. Conditions under which the casual strength can be calculated are evaluated. A calculation will determine the need for implementing cutoff measures in the case when the duration of occurrence of deformations obtained is less than the designed service life of the structure.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:12; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No. 12, 18-19(Dec 1987)

TITLE: A new method for stochastic production simulation in generation system with multiple hydro units
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LOAD MANAGEMENT; CHINA; ECONOMICS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ENERGY ACCOUNTING; LOAD ANALYSIS; OUTAGES; STOCHASTIC PROCESSES; ACCOUNTING; ASIA; ENERGY ANALYSIS; MANAGEMENT; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes a new method of calculating loss of load probability, expected energy generation and production cost for units in a generating system with multiple hydro units. The method uses the equivalent load duration curve (ELDC) obtained by convolving the distributions of the original load and the forced outage power loss of all generators. Hydro units are scheduled on the ELDC according to their assigned energy and available capacity. Then the deconvolution procedure is performed to obtain a load duration curve for an equivalent system without hydro units. The expected energy of the thermal units is achieved by convolving the generating units in an economic merit order of loading.
RESEARCH_ORG: Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua Univ., Beijing (CN)
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Energy Conver.; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:2

TITLE: Experience and prospects of using vibrating rollers in hydrotechnical construction
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; MATERIALS HANDLING EQUIPMENT; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; ROCKS; COMPACTING; SOILS; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; ENERGY EFFICIENCY; FIELD TESTS; MANUFACTURERS; PERFORMANCE; PERFORMANCE TESTING; SOIL MECHANICS; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; EFFICIENCY; EQUIPMENT; EUROPE; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; TESTING; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: It has been confirmed by investigations conducted in the USSR and by the practice of hydrotechnical construction that with mass placement of earth materials by the method of their layer-by-layer dumping, heavy vibrating rollers are the most effective compacting machines. It is possible to obtain a higher density degree with fewer number of passes using vibrating rollers compared with static rollers. Industrial production of and designs for various vibrating rollers for hydrotechnical construction from the USSR and several other countries were compared and assessed. Modern electronic instruments and computer technology are beginning to be incorporated into compacting equipment with the final product being the production of a self-regulating vibrating roller.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:11; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No. 11, 33-37(Nov 1987)

TITLE: Improvement of the method of calculating safe distances in underwater explosions
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; BLAST EFFECTS; CALCULATION METHODS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; UNDERWATER EXPLOSIONS; SAFETY ENGINEERING; CHEMICAL EXPLOSIVES; CONSTRUCTION; DETONATION WAVES; DISTANCE; EXPLOSIVE FRACTURING; PRESSURE EFFECTS; SPECIFICATIONS; COMMINUTION; ENGINEERING; EXPLOSIONS; EXPLOSIVES; FRACTURING; GEOLOGY; POWER PLANTS; SHOCK WAVES; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: One factor affecting water safety when conducting underwater explosions is correctly determining the safe distance as a function of the charge mass and type of explosive used. A method was examined which with an accuracy sufficient for practical use permits determining numerical values for the empirical coefficients characterizing the rate of change in the pressure relative to the distance covered by the detonation wave for arbitrary initial conditions, including with the use of industrial explosives. The method was based on a generalization and analysis of available data on individual types of explosives and establishment of new regularities characterizing the interrelation of the coefficients as parameters of a single physical process. This method made it possible to determine the coefficients and the safe distance under various initial blasting conditions which helps simplify engineering calculations and increase their reliability.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:11; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No. 11, 37-39(Nov 1987)

TITLE: Creation of high-head mechanical equipment of large-capacity outlets
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; OUTLET STRUCTURES; REVIEWS; USSR; HIGH-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CAVITATION; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; DESIGN; HOISTS; HYDRAULIC CONTROL DEVICES; HYDRAULIC EQUIPMENT; HYDRODYNAMICS; LINERS; PERFORMANCE; PRESSURE EFFECTS; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; SPILLWAY; TUNNELS; WEAR RESISTANCE; ASIA; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; DOCUMENT TYPES; EASTERN EUROPE; ENGINEERING; EQUIPMENT; EUROPE; FLUID MECHANICS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MATERIALS HANDLING EQUIPMENT; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; UNDERGROUND FACILITIES; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Data are given on the parameters of newly created complexes of hydromechanical equipment which, with respect to design load, reliability, and operating run considerably broaden the technical possibilities of builders in harnessing the hydropower potential of large rivers and constructing high-head hydro developments. Geometric forms of conduits and gates were created which could provide separation of the flow from the embedded parts and a free space formed along the perimeter of the flow to provide reliable aeration sufficient for creating a water-air mixture for reducing or eliminating cavitation erosion and damage to conduit linings. A new type of stepping hydraulic drive was created with lifting capacity and working stroke of moving the gate. A general list of the new structural elements and components of hydromechanical equipment was tabulated for high-head outlet structures for several Soviet hydro developments.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:11; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No. 11, 43-47(Nov 1987)

TITLE: Water requirement of concrete mixes
AUTHORS: Bugaeva, N K; Deryugin, L M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; 32 ENERGY CONSERVATION, CONSUMPTION, AND UTILIZATION; CONCRETES; WATER REQUIREMENTS; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; BINDERS; COMPRESSION STRENGTH; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MATERIALS TESTING; MIXTURES; MOISTURE; PARTICLE SIZE; ROCKS; SAND; SPENT LIQUORS; WASTE PRODUCT UTILIZATION; BUILDING MATERIALS; DISPERSIONS; INDUSTRIAL WASTES; LIQUID WASTES; MATERIALS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; POWER PLANTS; SIZE; TESTING; WASTES; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 360603 - Materials- Properties; 320305 - Energy Conservation, Consumption, & Utilization- Industrial & Agricultural Processes- Industrial Waste Management
DESCRIPTION: An experimental check was conducted to determine the water requirement of concrete mixes used in hydroelectric station construction. Sand and gravel obtained by sorting the sand-gravel mix of the Oznachennoe quarry and Portland cement and Portland blast-furnace cement of the Krasnoyarsk cement plant were used for the mixes. The quality of the gravel fractions corresponded to the requirements of the standard. An admixture of sulfite-yeast waste liquor was introduced into all mixes. The fluidity of the concrete was adjusted to prescribed values by the addition of water and was measured immediately after preparation. The dependence of the compressive strength on the water/cement ratio was determined. The relation between the amount of water and the amount of cement was determined to be nonlinear.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:11; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No. 11, 52-53(Nov 1987)

TITLE: Hydroelectric station dams and methods of constructing them (review of 1980-1986 patents)
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; BUILDING MATERIALS; CIVIL ENGINEERING; DESIGN; ENERGY CONSERVATION; ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY; HYDRAULICS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MATERIALS HANDLING EQUIPMENT; OPTIMIZATION; PATENTS; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; RESOURCE CONSERVATION; REVIEWS; SPILLWAY; DOCUMENT TYPES; ENGINEERING; EQUIPMENT; FLUID MECHANICS; MATERIALS; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Some of the more promising directions in the area of hydraulic engineering were analyzed on the basis of patents covering the past 5 or 6 years. Particular attention was devoted to studying the dams of hydroelectric stations, particularly dams with energy dissipators in the lower pool and methods of constructing them with optimal efficiency, no adverse effects on ecology, increasing the level of mechanization and reducing material consumption. As an example a method of transporting building materials used for constructing a concrete structure having an inclined surface and underwater parts was presented.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:11; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No. 11, 49-51(Nov 1987)

TITLE: Grout curtain in the foundation of the earth dam of the Maina hydroelectric station
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; FOUNDATIONS; GROUTING; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; BENTONITE; CIVIL ENGINEERING; DESIGN; DRILLING; DRILLING RIGS; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; PERMEABILITY; PLUGGING; PORTLAND CEMENT; SLOPE STABILITY; SLURRIES; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; SOILS; ASIA; BUILDING MATERIALS; CEMENTS; CLAYS; DISPERSIONS; EASTERN EUROPE; ENGINEERING; EUROPE; GEOLOGY; MATERIALS; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MIXTURES; POWER PLANTS; STABILITY; SUPPORTS; SUSPENSIONS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: A grout curtain was embedded 1-3 m into the bedrocks (shales) to provide stability of the fill and natural alluvial soils in the foundation of the Maina hydro dam. Experiments showed high permeability of the alluvial soils, so a combined method of grouting consisting of packerless, packer, and with a moving pipe made it possible to reduce the cost of the curtain by 30% versus the contract design in which only the packer method of grouting was specified. Bentonite-cement and bentonite slurries containing bentonite clay powder and Portland cement M400 were used for the grouting operations. The results of control tests showed a high density of the grout curtain with permeability coefficient within limits up to 0.5-1.0 m/day.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:11; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No. 11, 39-42(Nov 1987)

TITLE: Prevention of reverse rotation of a pumping unit
AUTHORS: Dadazhanov, A; Aliev, A Sh; Saidakhmedov, A V
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; WATER PUMPS; EQUIPMENT PROTECTION DEVICES; BRAKES; DIRECT CURRENT; ELECTRIC MOTORS; HYDRAULICS; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; PIPELINES; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; RECTIFIERS; ROTATION; SAFETY ENGINEERING; SHUTDOWNS; START-UP; STRESS RELAXATION; WATER HAMMER; CURRENTS; ELECTRIC CURRENTS; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; ENGINEERING; EQUIPMENT; FLUID MECHANICS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MACHINE PARTS; MECHANICS; MOTION; MOTORS; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; PUMPS; RELAXATION; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: A method and equipment were developed for preventing reverse rotation and runaway in the electrical pumps of large pumping stations under conditions of negative head and the resulting vibration and damage to bearings and structures. The method of electrical braking by delivering to the stator and rotor windings a direct current at the time of the change in the direction of rotation of the rotor is used for preventing reverse rotation. The braking device for automatic maintenance of the pumping unit shaft at zero rotational velocity has a simple electrical circuit and uses standard rectifiers.
