The use of the device makes it possible to reduce the tangential forces and radial stresses of the rotor and the dynamic loads on elements of the pipeline and structural elements of the pumping station building.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:11; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No. 11, 47-48(Nov 1987)

TITLE: Combined construction method
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; ROCKS; EXCAVATION; SOILS; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CIVIL ENGINEERING; CRUSHING; DIESEL FUELS; EARTHMOVING EQUIPMENT; ENERGY CONSERVATION; HYDRAULIC EQUIPMENT; HYDRAULIC TRANSPORT; MATERIALS HANDLING EQUIPMENT; PLANNING; SLURRY PIPELINES; SORTING; ASIA; COMMINUTION; EASTERN EUROPE; ENGINEERING; EQUIPMENT; EUROPE; FREIGHT PIPELINES; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; PIPELINES; POWER PLANTS; TRANSPORT; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Combining soil excavation by the dry-excavation method and structure placement by the hydraulic method makes it possible to expand hydraulic use under conditions of excavating heavy soils such as gravel, pebbles, and boulders. The combined method also makes it possible to transport soil to individual sections by the dry method and to include a sorting complex and crushing devices in the technological chain. Examples of using the combined method were cited and problems of slurry preparation were also examined. It was found that some of these problems could be solved with the use of sluice feeders or rock chutes with hydraulic unloading.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:10; Other Information: Translated from Gidroteknich. Stroitel'stvo; 21: No. 10, 38-39(Oct 1987)

TITLE: Increase of the effectiveness of hydropower construction exemplified by the blast-fill dams of the Kambarata hydroelectric stations
AUTHORS: Korchevskii, V F; Burshtein, M F; Petrov, G N
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; ROCKS; EXPLOSIVE FRACTURING; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; BLAST EFFECTS; CHEMICAL EXPLOSIVES; CIVIL ENGINEERING; COST ESTIMATION; DESIGN; ENERGY CONSERVATION; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; LABOR; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPTIMIZATION; PERMEABILITY; PLANNING; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; ROCK MECHANICS; SEISMIC EFFECTS; WATER RESERVOIRS; ASIA; COMMINUTION; EASTERN EUROPE; ENGINEERING; EUROPE; EXPLOSIVES; FRACTURING; GEOLOGY; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: Plans for the future development of the hydropower industry require constructing dams with greater height (100-300 m). Experimental blasting was conducted on site. Theoretical and experimental investigations and calculations were developed for models and technology of blasting, regularities of geotechnical formation and seepage and piping properties of blast-fill dams, methods of reducing permeability and design and calculation, as well as energy-saving optimization of the profile and problems of blasting seismic action. The results of the investigations made it possible to recommend a variant of the hydro development layouts with homogeneous blast-fill dams and determined configuration and volume of the blast-collapsed rock mass providing the creation of a slide dam.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:10; Other Information: Translated from Gidroteknich. Stroitel'stvo; 21: No. 10, 33-38(Oct 1987)

TITLE: Recreational use of the reservoirs of hydroelectric and pumped-storage stations
AUTHORS: Kukushkin, V A; Skladnev, M F; Fedorov, M P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 22 GENERAL STUDIES OF NUCLEAR REACTORS; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; WATER USE; RECREATIONAL AREAS; ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT; WATER RESERVOIRS; COST ESTIMATION; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; LAND USE; MICROCLIMATES; NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS; PAYBACK PERIOD; PLANNING; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; REGIONAL ANALYSIS; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; CLIMATES; ENGINEERING; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; NUCLEAR FACILITIES; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 130601 - Hydro Energy- Land Use & Aesthetics- (-1991 ); 220501 - Nuclear Reactor Technology- Environmental Aspects- Siting; 290400 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Resources
DESCRIPTION: Planning reservoir recreation areas located in various natural and climatic zones requires climatophysiological analyses. Economic load on a reservoir was evaluated and an assessment of the total effect of recreation on changes in the state of a reservoir was made. It was concluded that part of any project should be devoted to developing natural, hydrological, sanitary-hygienic, engineering-technical and economic proposals of recreational measures, evaluating their positive and negative consequences, and estimating not only costs but also the payback period and effectiveness from the recreational development.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:10; Other Information: Translated from Gidroteknich. Stroitel'stvo; 21: No. 10, 23-25(Oct 1987)

TITLE: Enlargement of concrete blocks of arch dams with allowance of the formation of radial thermal cracks
AUTHORS: Verbetskii, G P; Chogovadze, G I; Daneliya, A I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CONCRETE BLOCKS; STRESS RELAXATION; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; CIVIL ENGINEERING; CONCRETES; CONTROL; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; CRACK PROPAGATION; CRACKS; FRACTURE PROPERTIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PRESSURE EFFECTS; TEMPERATURE EFFECTS; THERMAL STRESSES; BUILDING MATERIALS; ENGINEERING; MATERIALS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; POWER PLANTS; RELAXATION; STRESSES; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: Considerable acceleration of the construction of arch dams with the use of highly productive continuous concreting mechanisms is possible with enlargement of the blocks and allowance of the formation of thermal radial cracks in them. A theoretical analysis and the results of on-site observations show that under the effect of the hydrostatic head of water, radial joints and cracks in compressed zones of an arch dam close and the dam in these zones works as a solid dam. Thermal cracking in concrete blocks of arch dams enlarged in plan should be controlled by making radial notches to concentrate tensile stresses providing the formation of radial cracks at prescribed places and through the usual methods of thermal regulation. The block size along the face of an arch dam is then no longer limited by the condition of crack resistance but is determined by the rate of concreting. The technical and economic effects from concreting arch dams are cited.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:10; Other Information: Translated from Gidroteknich. Stroitel'stvo; 21: No. 10, 49-51(Oct 1987)

TITLE: Method of predicting the characteristics of a rock mass in hydrotechnical construction
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; BUILDING MATERIALS; ROCKS; MATERIALS TESTING; SOILS; CALCULATION METHODS; CIVIL ENGINEERING; COMPRESSION STRENGTH; DENSITY; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; FORECASTING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; MOISTURE; PARTICLE SIZE; PERMEABILITY; SHEAR PROPERTIES; SLOPE STABILITY; STRAINS; STRESS ANALYSIS; STRESSES; ENGINEERING; GEOLOGY; MATERIALS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; POWER PLANTS; SIZE; STABILITY; TESTING; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: A method for predicting the physical and mechanical properties of the earth materials and their dependence on the placement density, moisture content, and stress-strain state is described. The method is based on the results of experimental investigations of coarse-fragmental soils conducted with the use of large testing equipment and supplemented by engineering-geological data on the properties of a rock mass from various rocks. The method calculates the average particle-size distribution of a rock mass, its density in air-dry and water-saturated states, and its permeability coefficients, compression and shear strength, and makes it possible to predict rock mass behavior when designing rockfill and earth-rock dams when there is minimum information about the properties of the rock in the deposit.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:10; Other Information: Translated from Gidroteknich. Stroitel'stvo; 21: No. 10, 45-48(Oct 1987)

TITLE: Reduction of local scour at wing dams of bridge crossings
AUTHORS: Kurganovich, A A; Klimov, O N
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; BRIDGES; DESIGN; DAMS; EROSION; INHIBITION; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CIVIL ENGINEERING; CONSTRUCTION; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; FLOW MODELS; FLOW RATE; FLOW REGULATORS; HYDRODYNAMICS; RIVERS; VORTEX FLOW; WAVE FORCES; ASIA; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; EASTERN EUROPE; ENGINEERING; EQUIPMENT; EUROPE; FLUID FLOW; FLUID MECHANICS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Wing dams and bridge piers are subjected to damage by floods and local scour is the main threatening factor during passage of high waters. Local scour develops as a result of transverse circulation. A method was proposed for constructing rigid guide ribs on wing dams of bridge crossings, and generalized to calculate the parameters for dams of any type, with the effect of reducing local scour by 1.5 times. The size of the ribbed box made it possible to reduce construction labor by at least 8 times. A method was also developed for calculating structures reducing erosion at concave banks and structures increasing the intensity of transverse circulation for the purpose of controlling sediment deposits.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:10; Other Information: Translated from Gidroteknich. Stroitel'stvo; 21: No. 10, 29-33(Oct 1987)

TITLE: Prevention of the destruction of the stilling basin of the Sayano-Shushenskoe hydroelectric station
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; DESIGN; SPILLWAY; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; WATER RESERVOIRS; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; CIVIL ENGINEERING; ENERGY TRANSFER; FLOOD CONTROL; FLOW MODELS; HYDRODYNAMICS; OPTIMIZATION; WAVE FORCES; ASIA; CONTROL; EASTERN EUROPE; ENGINEERING; EUROPE; FLUID MECHANICS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: New spillway designs at the Sayano-Shushenskoe hydrostation were proposed which can be incorporated into the existing spillways. Characteristics of classical operating schemes of joining pools were investigated. Methods were assessed for optimizing regimes on the ski jumps and calculations of the energy exchange between flow phases to reduce water spray into the atmosphere and increase the accuracy of calculating the distance of the jet deflection were recommended. Site-specific recommendations for metal as a construction material for the different elements of the spillway--longitudinal partitions, deflecting slabs, ski jumps, and turns--were also made. It was determined that the proposed reconstruction of the spillways of the Sayano-Shushenskoe hydrostation can be accomplished with insignificant expenditures in the period between floods.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:10; Other Information: Translated from Gidroteknich. Stroitel'stvo; 21: No. 10, 43-45(Oct 1987)

TITLE: Consideration of changes in the local climate in the region of the reservoir and lower pool of hydroelectric stations
AUTHORS: Rastorguev, V I; Roshchina, I M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; WATER RESERVOIRS; MICROCLIMATES; DESERTS; ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY; ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY; HUMIDITY; HYDROLOGY; LAND USE; METEOROLOGY; MOUNTAINS; REVIEWS; RIVERS; SPECIFIC HEAT; SURFACE AREA; TEMPERATURE EFFECTS; USSR; ARID LANDS; ASIA; CLIMATES; DOCUMENT TYPES; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE PROPERTIES; SURFACE WATERS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 290400 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Resources
DESCRIPTION: The positive and negative effects of large hydroelectric power plant reservoirs located in various physiographic zones of the Soviet Union on the local climate were characterized. These effects occur due to an increase in the volume of the water mass having a greater heat capacity and an increase of the area of the water surface compared with the river in an unregulated state. Comparisons were drawn between reservoirs in mountainous and plain territories and in northern and southern zones of the country. Warming and humidity trends along with extensions of frost-free periods into the colder seasons were assessed. The creation of large reservoirs in the southern zone of the Asian part of the country was determined to make the desert and steppe territories suitable for animal habitation. The impact of favorable climatic conditions on recreational development was also assessed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:10; Other Information: Translated from Gidroteknich. Stroitel'stvo; 21: No. 10, 16-17(Oct 1987)

TITLE: Investigation of the ice regime of a stretch of the Daugava river under regulated conditions
AUTHORS: Karnovich, V N; Tregub, G A; Balagurov, B F; Tveritnev, V P; Pastors, A A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FLOOD CONTROL; ICE; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; RIVERS; FLOW BLOCKAGE; USSR; DRAINAGE; FLOODS; HEAT TRANSFER; HYDROLOGY; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; METEOROLOGY; REGRESSION ANALYSIS; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; SEASONAL VARIATIONS; ASIA; CONTROL; DISASTERS; EASTERN EUROPE; ENERGY TRANSFER; ENGINEERING; EUROPE; MATHEMATICS; POWER PLANTS; STATISTICS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; VARIATIONS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The rise of water levels of the Daugava River caused by ice dams and jams was determined mainly by the volume of shuga and ice accumulating on the jam-hazardous stretch and depended on the water discharges in the river. It was shown that with the construction of the Daugavpils hydrostation the maximum volume of shuga and ice decreases in the jam-hazardous stretch by 50% and that the height of the maximum rises of the levels caused by dams and jams will not exceed 6.8 m under conditions of normal operation. This means that Daugavpils hydrostation flooding of the territory as a result of water level rise due to ice jams will not occur in its lower pool. To control ice dams and jams a bypass could be constructed for draining water and for lowering the water levels caused by ice dams and jams.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:10; Other Information: Translated from Gidroteknich. Stroitel'stvo; 21: No. 10, 26-29(Oct 1987)

TITLE: Engineering protection of reservoirs of hydropower developments from flooding and subirrigation
AUTHORS: Vasil'ev, Yu S; Khrisanov, N I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 22 GENERAL STUDIES OF NUCLEAR REACTORS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FLOOD CONTROL; WATER RESERVOIRS; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; ALGORITHMS; BULGARIA; CANADA; ECUADOR; EMBANKMENTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY; GROUND WATER; HUNGARY; HYDROLOGY; IRRIGATION; LAND USE; NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS; RESOURCE CONSERVATION; RIVERS; ROMANIA; SUBSURFACE ENVIRONMENTS; USSR; WATER USE; ASIA; CONTROL; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; EASTERN EUROPE; ENGINEERING; EUROPE; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; LATIN AMERICA; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; NORTH AMERICA; NUCLEAR FACILITIES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POWER PLANTS; SOUTH AMERICA; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; WATER; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 220500 - Nuclear Reactor Technology- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Examples are given of current hydropower construction with the creation of systems of embanking lands for protecting them from flooding and subirrigation. The examples are drawn from hydropower developments in Canada, Ecuador, Hungary, Bulgaria, Romania, and the Soviet Union, and include tidal and nuclear plants as well. An analysis of the specific land-use intensity of different power stations showed that at present there is a tendency toward a reduction of the difference of this index for hydroelectric stations, on the one hand, and thermal power stations (nuclear power stations) on the other. For protection and conservation of lands and improvement of the ecological state of streams, reservoirs, and the lower pools of hydro developments, calculation methods (algorithms and programs) have been developed for optimizing the parameters of the embankment systems.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:10; Other Information: Translated from Gidroteknich. Stroitel'stvo; 21: No. 10, 21-23(Oct 1987)

TITLE: Hydropower planning in Developing Countries
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; COMPUTER CODES; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; DECISION MAKING; FORECASTING; PLANNING; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SIMULATION; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 990220 - Computers, Computerized Models, & Computer Programs- (1987-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The 1960's and 1970's saw the development in the U.S. and Europe of a number of useful mathematical planning tools for electric power systems. Utilization of these tools in practical application, however, appears more significant in some of the developing countries than in the industrialized countries where they originated. It is not uncommon to find electric power utilities in third world countries that are using and indeed developing state of the art planning techniques in long-range generation planning. This is particularly so for systems with large amounts of existing and/or potential hydroelectric power. Despite the approximations that are necessary, these techniques furnish planners and decision makers with valuable insights on the range of possible long-term consequences of near-term decisions. This paper highlights several computer models that have been found useful in long-range planning in nations with high hydro potential.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Energy Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 114:1

TITLE: Redevelopment of an abandoned small hydro project
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; WASTE PROCESSING PLANTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; WATER TREATMENT PLANTS; ABANDONED SITES; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; LICENSING; OPERATION; PLANNING; PROGRAM MANAGEMENT; RETROFITTING; SURPLUS POWER; WASTE WATER; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS; LIQUID WASTES; MANAGEMENT; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; WASTES; WATER; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130400 - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: There were innumerable small hydroelectric power plants constructed at the beginning of the twentieth century. Many have since been abandoned, with the advent of large central-station power plants. Craggy Dam on the French Broad River in North Carolina, built in 1904, is one of these abandoned plants. The owner of the property commissioned an engineer to evaluate the site for possible redevelopment for hydroelectric power purposes. This paper describes the planning, feasibility, licensing, construction, and operation, with the associated problems that were encountered during project development. The powerhouse, with induction generators, exceeds its rating and is connected by a one-half-mile concrete-pole power line to the owners' wastewater treatment plant, where project power is utilized. Surplus power, about one third of the project's total output, is sold to the local electric utility.
RESEARCH_ORG: Hydro Consultant to Hendon Engrg. Assoc., Inc., P.O. Box 20348, Birmingham, AL (US)
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Energy Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 114:1

TITLE: A separable linear algorithm for hydropower optimization
AUTHORS: Ellis, J H; ReVelle, C S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ALGORITHMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPTIMIZATION; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: A deterministic, separable, linear algorithm is presented for maximizing aggregate hydropower production. The method is iterative and amenable to solution using standard LP software. The utility of the technique is demonstrated using several test applications involving a hypothetical single-purpose hydropower reservoir and a monthly increment 20-year flow record from the Gunpowder River in Maryland. The separable linearized forms solved quickly using MPSX on a variety of IBM hardware: 3090-400 VF, 3084 QX, dual processor 4381-3, and an AT/370 personal computer. For comparison purposes, the original nonlinear nonseparable version of the model was also solved using MINOS. This yielded a value of aggregate hydropower marginally higher than that using MPSX. The separable, linearized methodology proved to be a useful and an efficient means of generating good starting points for MINOS. The use of these warm starts effected substantial reductions in MINOS execution times.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resources Bulletin; (USA); Journal Volume: 24:2

TITLE: Speed loop cancellation governor for hydrogenerators - Part I: Development
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONTROL SYSTEMS; SPEED REGULATORS; DAMPING; DYNAMICS; MAINTENANCE; NONLINEAR PROGRAMMING; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; PROGRAMMING; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130700 - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Speed control governors for hydrogenerators utilize a proportional-integral (PI) control with constant gains. Given the nonlinear characteristics of the installations, the result is compromised speed and power transients for step load changes. The PI control is not able to provide a responsive power response while maintaining the desired speed transient. This paper discusses the development of a control strategy that essentially neutralizes the speed dynamics in order to achieve improved power tracking. Employing this technique results in up to a fifty percent reduction in the magnitude of offspeed. The power transient is also more responsive as demonstrated by a twenty percent decrease in the settling time while maintaining acceptable damping and overshoot.
RESEARCH_ORG: Dept. of General Engineering, Univ. of Illinois (US)
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Electronics; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:1

TITLE: Subsynchronous resonance phenomena considering skin effects in solid iron rotor turbo-generators
AUTHORS: Lee, E U; Ooi, B T
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; TURBOGENERATORS; PERFORMANCE TESTING; CALCULATION METHODS; IRON; ROTORS; STABILITY; SYSTEMS ANALYSIS; THREE-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ELEMENTS; METALS; TESTING; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 990230 - Mathematics & Mathematical Models- (1987-1989)
DESCRIPTION: This paper addresses the question of how the skin effects of the eddy current in the rotor of synchronous generator influence the induction generation modes and the torsional interaction modes of the subsynchronous resonance (SSR) phenomena. The 3-D magnetic diffusion equation is solved in a round solid iron rotor to provide data for comparison and discussion purposes. The paper examines the problem of representing skin depth, which is frequency dependent, in the time domain stability analysis base on x = (A) x.
RESEARCH_ORG: Dept. of Electrical Eng., Chung-Nam National Univ., 300-31 Daejeon (KR)
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Electronics; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:1

TITLE: Relationship between stator core buckling, core losses, vibration and local over-temperatures
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TURBOGENERATORS; BUCKLING; HIGH TEMPERATURE; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; CALCULATION METHODS; HOT SPOTS; MAGNETIC FLUX; MEASURING METHODS; PERFORMANCE TESTING; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; POWER PLANTS; TESTING; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 360103 - Metals & Alloys- Mechanical Properties
DESCRIPTION: Measurements on a hydrogenerator stator core during core test with higher than normal magnetic flux and extended test time provided the base for a study of interaction between buckling, local heat generation, hot spots and vibration. The mechanism of buckling is analyzed. Curves were developed showing how the buckling influences the temperature at the bottom of the slot and between the stator coils. There is clear evidence that the core does not behave as a homogeneous structure. The upper and lower halves of the core may vibrate independently of each other, with different node numbers. The node number may be an odd number, contrary to the accepted theory. The magnitude and position of buckling does not seem to have any influence on the distribution of vibration nodes.
RESEARCH_ORG: Siemens Energy and Automation Inc., Bradenton, FL (US)
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Electronics; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:1

TITLE: Determination of negative-sequence resistance of turbo-generators from rated-frequency standstill tests
AUTHORS: Neidhoefer, G J; Subbarao, V S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; TURBOGENERATORS; PERFORMANCE TESTING; CALCULATION METHODS; SYSTEMS ANALYSIS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; TESTING; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 990230 - Mathematics & Mathematical Models- (1987-1989)
DESCRIPTION: On the basis of standstill tests with applied rated-frequency voltage, a method is presented for determining the negative-sequence resistance of turbo-generators, which is properly obtainable only from rotational tests, in a simpler but fairly accurate manner. Systematic analysis and comparison of standstill and rotational test results, for a large number of turbo-generators in the range of 30 to 1300 MVA and having various damper systems, shows that the ratio of negative-sequence resistance to mean subtransient resistance varies in a narrow range of +-10% around 0.85. This corresponds to an increase of about 1.5 to 1.85 times in the equivalent rotor resistance when the frequency is doubled, in contrast to the figure of ..sqrt..2 quoted in the literature. Additional verification is obtained from frequency-response tests on one of the machines investigated.
RESEARCH_ORG: BBC Brown, Boveri and Co. Ltd., Baden (CH)
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Electronics; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:1

TITLE: Load-level-sensitive governor gains for speed control of hydrogenerators
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; SPEED REGULATORS; SYSTEMS ANALYSIS; TURBOGENERATORS; CALCULATION METHODS; COMPUTER CALCULATIONS; DIGITAL FILTERS; DYNAMIC LOADS; SPECTRAL DENSITY; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; CONTROL SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; EQUIPMENT; FUNCTIONS; POWER PLANTS; SIMULATION; SPECTRAL FUNCTIONS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130700 - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 990220 - Computers, Computerized Models, & Computer Programs- (1987-1989); 990230 - Mathematics & Mathematical Models- (1987-1989)
DESCRIPTION: This work discusses the application of load-level-sensitive gains to proportional-plus-integral speed control of hydrogenerators. Appropriate root configuration gain functions of wicket gate position are derived for isolated resistive loads. Computer programs are used to calculate these gains from model turbine data and system parameters. Root locus tuning is used to determine appropriate gains for infinite bus loads. Simulations are presented which compare the use of constant gains to the use of these variable gains for isolated resistive and infinite bus loads. Additional resistive load simulations show the effect of a one-second digital filter on the gain functions. Results indicate that the variable gain responses resemble 0.707 damping at each load level. Sample speed-transient comparisons between variable and constant gains show decreases of up to 45% in speed peak overshoot and 80% in power settling time. Load and pressure time-responses are included.
RESEARCH_ORG: Dept. of General Engineering, Univ. of Illinois, Urbana, IL (US)
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Electronics; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:1

TITLE: Economic-emission load dispatch through goal programming techniques
AUTHORS: Nanda, J; Kothari, D F; Lingamurthy, K S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; TURBOGENERATORS; ALGORITHMS; ECONOMICS; EMISSION; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; LINEAR PROGRAMMING; NONLINEAR PROGRAMMING; POLLUTION CONTROL; POWER GENERATION; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; CONTROL; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; PROGRAMMING; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 990220 - Computers, Computerized Models, & Computer Programs- (1987-1989); 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 500200 - Environment, Atmospheric- Chemicals Monitoring & Transport- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Operating at absolute minimum cost can no longer be the only criterion for dispatching electric power due to increasing concern over the environmental considerations. The economic-emission load dispatch (EELD) problem which accounts for minimization of both cost and emission is a multiple, conflicting objective function problem. Goal programming techniques are most suitable for such type of problems. In this paper, the economic-emission load dispatch problem is solved through linear and non-linear goal programming algorithms. The application and validity of the proposed algorithms are demonstrated for a sample system having six generators.
RESEARCH_ORG: Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi 110 016 (IN)
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Electronics; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:1

TITLE: Automatic generation control for hydro systems
AUTHORS: Kusic, G L; Sutterfield, J A; Caprez, A R; Haneline, J L; Bergman, B R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; AUTOMATION; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; ON-LINE CONTROL SYSTEMS; ON-LINE MEASUREMENT SYSTEMS; POWER GENERATION; TURBOGENERATORS; DIGITAL COMPUTERS; TELEMETRY; COMMUNICATIONS; COMPUTERS; CONTROL SYSTEMS; DATA TRANSMISSION; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ON-LINE SYSTEMS; POWER PLANTS; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 990220 - Computers, Computerized Models, & Computer Programs- (1987-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Modern Automatic Generation Control (AGC) is implemented with digital computers that periodically sample tie line real power flows, line frequency, and generator power outputs. These analog signals are usually measured to second periodically and combined with desired interchange to obtain the Area Control Error (ACE). The ACE digital quantity is allocated to regulating hydro turbines and transmitted via telemetry to the remote terminal untis (RTU). The RTUs convert the raise/lower megawatts (MW) into timed relay contact closures to the governor which result in wicket gate open/close movement to change the generator output power. The output power of each generator is monitored by the digital AGC which closes a feedback loop around the governor-turbine-generator to assure the desired power level is attained. This paper describes the feedback loop design, which is essentially a sampled-data control. Additional feedback loops due to the ACE and load regulation are also analyzed. A method is presented for allocating water usage between reservoirs on a generator command-time basis. The theoretical designs are verified by on-line measurements presented in the paper.
RESEARCH_ORG: Advanced Control Systems, Inc., Atlanta, GA (US)
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Electronics; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:1

TITLE: Developing a mini-hydro plant in the remote Canadian North
AUTHORS: Turner, A B; Simpson, R J; Guilland, C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CANADA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; COST; DESIGN; IMPLEMENTATION; CONSTRAINTS; DIESEL FUELS; WOOD; ENERGY SOURCES; NORTH AMERICA; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The paper describes the implementation of a 1150 kW Mini-Hydro generation plant at Wemindji, a remote community in Northern Canada. A number of studies and investigations of the overall costs of energy to the community led to the choice of a mixed energy supply system consisting of mini-hydro, diesel and firewood. The 1150 kW mini-hydro powerplant constitutes the main element in this energy supply. Details are given of the design and implementation of the mini-hydro power facility and its related equipment, with descriptions of constraints that were overcome from the conception through to commissioning an initial operation.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Electronics; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:1

TITLE: A frequency domain method for tuning hydro governors
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; DESIGN; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SYSTEMS ANALYSIS; TURBINES; PENSTOCKS; MACHINERY; PIPES; POWER PLANTS; SIMULATION; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 990230 - Mathematics & Mathematical Models- (1987-1989); 130700 - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: A frequency domain method to determine the optimum values for the parameters of a PID governor is presented. The method readily handles detailed models of turbine-penstock gate dynamics and other system components. The main advantages of the method are that it is computationally simple, does not involve any iterations and that the designer can pre-specify a speed response for load rejection.
RESEARCH_ORG: Univ. of Illinois at Chicago, Chicago, IL (US)
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Electronics; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:1

TITLE: Speed loop cancellation governor for hydrogenerators - Part II: Application
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SPEED REGULATORS; TURBOGENERATORS; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; OPTIMIZATION; PERFORMANCE TESTING; REAL TIME SYSTEMS; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; CONTROL SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; EQUIPMENT; POWER PLANTS; SIMULATION; TESTING; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130700 - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 990220 - Computers, Computerized Models, & Computer Programs- (1987-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The essential dynamics for a hydrogenerator supplying a large grid may be represented by two control loops: the first for power and the second for speed. Part One of this work develops a governor design intended to neutralize the speed loop's destabilizing effects while tuning for improved load tracking. This paper considers the practical implementation of such a controller by computer. An approximate system is used to develop analytical expressions for the control parameters. These parameters are functions of load level throughout the operating range and may be computed in real time. The effectiveness of the approximate-system-derived control is verified by simulation. Computed transients are indistinguishable from transients for the optimally tuned control.
RESEARCH_ORG: Dept. of General Engineering, Univ. of Illinois (US)
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Electronics; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:1

TITLE: Application and testing of a fiber optic communication system at Grand Coulee
AUTHORS: Osburn, G D; Arnold, R G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; COLUMBIA RIVER; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DATA TRANSMISSION SYSTEMS; FIBER OPTICS; DESIGN; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; BUREAU OF RECLAMATION; TEST FACILITIES; USA; CONTROL SYSTEMS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; US DOI; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 990300 - Information Handling; 990230 - Mathematics & Mathematical Models- (1987-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation (USBR) operates the world's largest, fully operational hydroelectric facility at Grand Coulee Dam located on the Columbia River in eastern Washington state. Data transmitted for control, protection, and communication between this facility's Third Powerplant and 500-kv switchyard are essential for the safe and efficient operation of the Bureau's equipment and the integrity of the connected power systems. To accomplish the reliable, high speed transmission of such data over the relatively long distance between these two locations having unequal ground potential rise (GPR) a fiber optic communication system was installed, tested, and placed into service. The paper discusses the rationale for applying fiber optic technology in this application with emphasis on the related design considerations important in control and protection of this large hydroelectric facility. Brief summaries of hardware used and installation considerations are given. Fundamentals and principles of fiber optic system design are not intended or covered. Discussion of factory and unique field testing, including electromagnetic interference (EMI) induced transient influence and timing tests, is included. Operating experience and projected future use are summarized.
RESEARCH_ORG: U.S. Bureau of Reclamation, Engineering and Research Center, Denver, CO (US)
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Energy Conver.; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:1

TITLE: Efficient methods for optimal scheduling of fixed head hydrothermal power systems
AUTHORS: Zaghlool, M F; Trutt, F C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPTIMIZATION; PERFORMANCE TESTING; CONSTRAINTS; ITERATIVE METHODS; JACOBIAN FUNCTION; LEAST SQUARE FIT; LINEAR PROGRAMMING; MATRICES; ENERGY SYSTEMS; FUNCTIONS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; MAXIMUM-LIKELIHOOD FIT; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; PROGRAMMING; TESTING; 130000* - Hydro Energy; 990230 - Mathematics & Mathematical Models- (1987-1989)
DESCRIPTION: This paper highlights a simple, very reliable and effective approach, employing matrix factorization, to the solution of hydrothermal dispatch problems. The salient feature of the solution method is calculating the LU factors corresponding to a permutation of the rows of the Jacobian matrix (Lagrange matrix) at each iteration. The economic operation of hydrothermal systems is further reformulated as a linearly constrained least-squares problem leading to another iterative technique which needs much less computer storage for cases when the hydro plant performance curve is modelled by a linear function. Results for sample systems are worked out in order to demonstrate the superiority of the proposed techniques.
RESEARCH_ORG: Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Pennsylvania State Univ., University Park, PA (US)
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:1

TITLE: Effects of variable discharge schemes on dissolved oxygen at a hydroelectric station
AUTHORS: Mathur, D; McClellan, E S; Haney, S A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; RIVERS; WATER QUALITY; DISSOLVED GASES; OXYGEN; STATISTICAL MODELS; VARIATIONS; ELEMENTS; ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY; FLUIDS; GASES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; NONMETALS; POWER PLANTS; SOLUTES; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 540320 - Environment, Aquatic- Chemicals Monitoring & Transport- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The effects of variable discharges during the summer on the dissolved oxygen (DO) content and water temperature upstream and downstream of the Conowingo Hydroelectric Power Station were investigated. The DO dynamics are controlled primarily by meteorological factors that are independent of the mode of hydrostation operation. DO stratification occurred during the summer in Conowingo Pond, but thermal stratification was not observed. The magnitude and duration of off-speak discharges including a run-of-the-river operation did not affect DO stratification in Conowingo Pond; little vertical mixing occurred. However, strong winds and/or high river flows temporarily destroyed DO stratification. The run-of-the-river operation of off-peak continuous discharge schemes did not provide better DO conditions downstream of the hydrostation than the peaking operation with intermittent off-speak releases. A statistical model predicted that a DO of 5 ppm occurrs 0.6 miles downstream of the powerhouse when the natural river flow is consistently greater than 15,000 cfs and water temperature is less than 80{degree}F. A mean daily DO of at least 4 ppm was predicted to occur over 80 percent of the time during the 92-day summer period. Farther downstream (1.3 miles from the powerhouse) a mean daily DO of at least 4 ppm was predicted to occurr 90 percent of the time in summer.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resources Bulletin; (USA); Journal Volume: 24:1

TITLE: Transient stability analysis of stressed power systems using the energy function method
AUTHORS: Vittal, V; Rajagopal, S; Fouad, A A; El-Kady, M A; Vaahedi, E; Carvalho, V F
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DYNAMIC LOADS; ELECTRICAL TRANSIENTS; PERFORMANCE TESTING; SYSTEMS ANALYSIS; ONTARIO; ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; CALCULATION METHODS; EVALUATION; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; CANADA; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; TESTING; TRANSIENTS; VOLTAGE DROP; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 290100 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Analysis & Modeling
DESCRIPTION: This paper outlines the nature and characteristics of the transient response of a large stressed power network. Transient stability analysis of such a system by the transient energy function (TEF) method requires overcoming a number of analytical and numerical problems. These issues are identified and solution to them are proposed. The procedure developed is tested on two realistic power networks derived from a large power flow base case of the Ontario Hydro system. Results of the tests compare well with time simulation and accurately predict the complex dynamic behavior.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:1

TITLE: Hydro enters calmer waters
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PERMIT APPLICATIONS; CAPACITY; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; US FERC; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: According to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission's (FERC) Qualifying Facilities Report, only 38 filings-for projects with a combined capacity of 87 MW - for QF status were made with the agency in 1987 (through the third quarter). This is about the same as the level of QF filings made in 1982 and is only a fraction of the 260 fillings, for projects with a combined generating capacity of 1773 MW, made in 1986. From 1980 through the third quarter 1987, 639 applications for QF status for projects having a combined capacity of over 3144 MW, were made with the FERC. The decline in QF does not mean that activity in the industry is coming to an end, by any means. This article describes some of the more recent projects to be announced or of facilities to come on-line recently.
RELATION: Journal Name: Alternative Sources Energy; (United States)

TITLE: New environment requirements of ECPA
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; CONSUMER PROTECTION; LEGISLATION; ELECTRIC POWER; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; LICENSING; REGULATIONS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 293000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Policy, Legislation, & Regulation
DESCRIPTION: On October 16, 1986, President Reagan signed into law the so-called Electric Consumers Protection Act of 1986 (ECPA). ECPA incorporates significant amendments to Part I of the Federal Power Act (FPA) regarding the issuance of licenses for hydroelectric projects. The ostensible purpose of ECPA is to provide greater protection for energy consumers. Unfortunately, ECPA has little to do with protecting consumers of electricity. To the contrary, it may actually be detrimental to a larger number of consumers than it helps, because it will make the development of hydroelectric power, an economically efficient and environmentally sound source of energy, more complex, more time-consuming, and more expensive. Briefly states, Congress in ECPA directs the Federal Energy Regulatory Commissions (FERC) when issuing licenses, to give an upgraded level of consideration to energy conservation, fish and wildlife protection, recreational opportunities,and environmental quality.
RESEARCH_ORG: Baller, Hammelt, Williams, and Kissel, Washington, DC (USA)
RELATION: Journal Name: Alternative Sources Energy; (United States)

TITLE: The hydro-thermal optimal power flow problem in rectangular coordinates
AUTHORS: Ravindranath, K M; El-Hawary, M E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTER CALCULATIONS; NEWTON METHOD; ALGORITHMS; CARTESIAN COORDINATES; CONSTRAINTS; EQUATIONS; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; OPTIMIZATION; COORDINATES; ITERATIVE METHODS; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 990200 - Mathematics & Computers
DESCRIPTION: This paper considers the formulation and computational solution of the optimal power flow problem in hydro-thermal electric system. The problem is formulated using the cartesian coordinate form of the power flow equations. Here the hydro generation is energy limited. As a result, a dynamic optimization problem involving the daily scheduling of the system is encountered. This dynamic optimal power flow problem requires the solution of a large scale set of non-linear simultaneous equations. In this paper, Newton's method is used to solve the problem. Due to the large scale nature of the problem, the authors have exploited the sparsity of the Jacobian and developed three different versions of the algorithms and implementation of these versions have been detailed in this paper. In all cases, the algorithm has been successfully tested with six standard IEEE test systems varying in size from 5 bus to 118 bus. Computational results and the CPU times required by all of the methods are given. Results are compared with the results obtained by the earlier version using polar form for load flow constraints and it is shown that the sparse implementation using rectangular coordinates offers superior computational speed.
RESEARCH_ORG: Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Technical Univ. of Nova Scotia, P.O. Box 1000, Halifax, Nova Scotia B3J 2X4 (CA)
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. Mach. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: 14:5

TITLE: A novel approach for limit cycle analysis of an interconnected hydrothermal power system
SUBJECT: 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; INTERCONNECTED POWER SYSTEMS; CONTROL SYSTEMS; ALGORITHMS; AUTOMATION; EVALUATION; GRAPHS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; POWER GENERATION; STABILITY; THERMAL CYCLING; ENERGY SYSTEMS; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; 200105* - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Heat Utilization; 130700 - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: A novel approach which can predict limit cycle oscillations of arbitrary control systems containing multiple nonlinearities is presented. First a widely convergent algorithm for finding a limit cycle is presented. Then an efficient and systematic graphical approach is delineated for plotting the limit cycle loci on the parameter plane of interest. The attractive merits of this approach lie in its generality, simplicity, and ability to give a more complete picture about the parameter influence on the limit cycle. Besides, incorporating with the proposed method, a quasi-static criterion is also derived for checking the stability of a limit cycle with little additional efforts. Finally, the proposed method is applied to the limit cycle analysis of an interconnected hydrothermal power system to investigate the effects of parameter changes on limit cycles.
RESEARCH_ORG: National Tsing Hua Univ., Hsinchu (TW); National Taiwan Institute of Technology, Taipei (TW)
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. Mach. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: 14:3; Journal Issue: 3-4

TITLE: Application of an on-line air gap monitor for hydroelectric generator protection and problem diagnosis
AUTHORS: Talas, P; Toom, P O; Franklin, D E; Palylyk, R A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; MONITORS; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DATA ACQUISITION SYSTEMS; MONITORING; SYSTEM FAILURE ANALYSIS; BRITISH COLUMBIA; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; FIBER OPTICS; ON-LINE SYSTEMS; OPTICAL SYSTEMS; ROTORS; STATORS; CANADA; CONTROL SYSTEMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; SYSTEMS ANALYSIS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 990220 - Computers, Computerized Models, & Computer Programs- (1987-1989)
DESCRIPTION: This paper presents the application of a new hydroelectric generator air gap measurement system. It is a continuous on-line system using optical triangulation, fiber-optics, a microprocessor-based monitor, specially developed instrumentation and power supplies. This system is non-invasive, insensitive to EMI and has 0.2% accuracy over a range of 2 to 40 mm. The paper presents air gap data obtained from B.C. Hydro's Mica Creek Unit G2 (457 MVA) during March 1986. Readings were taken from stator-to-rotor and from rotor-to-stator to determine the unit's characteristics prior to rotor rim shrink modifications. This data assisted in determining the individual contributions of the rotor and the stator to the generator's behavior and provides a comparison for post-modification testing.
RESEARCH_ORG: B.C. Hydro and Power Authority, Vancouver, British Columbia (CA)
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Electronics; (United States); Journal Volume: EC-2:4

TITLE: Optimization-based methods for operations scheduling
AUTHORS: Cohen, A I; Sherkat, V R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; LOAD MANAGEMENT; ON-LINE SYSTEMS; OPERATION; OPTIMIZATION; PLANNING; POWER GENERATION; POWER SYSTEMS; SCHEDULES; CONTROL SYSTEMS; ENERGY SYSTEMS; MANAGEMENT; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 990220 - Computers, Computerized Models, & Computer Programs- (1987-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The operations scheduling problem in electric power systems is to determine which generating units should be on-line and available for generation at each hour and the associated nominal generation or dispatch. This paper describes the scope of the operations scheduling problem, presents mathematical formulations to the problem, and surveys recent advances in optimization-based solution methods. It is mainly concerned with the shorter term aspects of the problem where the time horizon is of the order of a week. The unit commitment, short-term hydro scheduling, and hydro-thermal coordination problems as well as solution methods are emphasized.
RESEARCH_ORG: Systems Control, Inc., Palo Alto, CA (US)
RELATION: Journal Name: Proc. IEEE; (United States); Journal Volume: 75:12

TITLE: Optimizing fluctuating flows
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; FLOW RATE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DATA ANALYSIS; DECISION MAKING; GRAPHS; UNSTEADY FLOW; FLUID FLOW; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: A standard, high-speed turbine with good peak efficiency is perfectly suitable for constant water flows. However, at sites with fluctuating flows, a strong case can be made that subdivided Cross-Flow Turbine offers better rentability due to higher annual energy production, lower purchase price and installation cost. The most important criteria of a site is the existing water flow data. The regional office provides data of each gaging station, from which a flow duration curve can be plotted. This graph will show the expected annual flow and how the water flow is affected monthly or daily for each of the pertaining hydro sites. The flow-duration curve also reveals the consistency of the water flow and the difference between minimum and maximum flow. Knowledge of the flow characteristics is a prerequisite in determining the right turbine system to optimize utilization of the available resource. In this regard, it's important to remember that water turbines are essentially differentiated by turbines with high or low specific speeds, called high- or low-speed runners.
RELATION: Journal Name: Alternative Sources Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 95

TITLE: Hydro's new redevelopment market
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; MARKET; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MODIFICATIONS; ELECTRIC POWER INDUSTRY; ENGINEERING; LICENSING; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; INDUSTRY; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: The market for new hydro development is in a state of stagnation. Manufacturers are encountering fierce competition as developers complete work on their backlog of projects. Engineering firms, however, have found a market within a market. They are busy planning the redevelopment of the nation's aging hydro facilities. Relicensing requirements couldn't have come along at a better time. ASE contacted the American Public Power Association, the Bureau of Reclamation, and the Army Corps. of Engineers to find out what their upgrade/rehab plans are. Also, comments from some of the engineering firm representatives are included.
RELATION: Journal Name: Alternative Sources Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 95

TITLE: Manufacturers look beyond relicensing
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; ELECTRIC POWER INDUSTRY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; MANUFACTURERS; MODIFICATIONS; LICENSING; EQUIPMENT; INDUSTRY; POWER PLANTS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: As has been documented in recent issues of ASE magazine, the next five years will feature intense activity in hydropower relicensing activity, as developers compete for a rash of licenses due to expire and environmental groups push for mitigation of perceived damages to the environment. The early states of this new chapter in hydro development will create a lot of work for legal staffs, consulting engineers and environmental specialists, but the equipment suppliers and contractors will have to wait until the relicense awards are made by the FERC before receiving new business. From the equipment supplier's point of view, and especially the turbine manufacturer's point of view, the current relicensing program is a minor perturbation in the on-going process of repairing and replacing old plants. However, it would appear that the improvement and replacement of obsolescent plants may soon be accelerated considerably by the level of competition and external pressures to make efficient use of resources.
RELATION: Journal Name: Alternative Sources Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 95

TITLE: Engineering theory of slide processes in the design of earth dams on a soft ground foundation
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; CIVIL ENGINEERING; LANDSLIDES; SLOPE STABILITY; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; FOUNDATIONS; RECOMMENDATIONS; ROCK MECHANICS; ROCKS; SAFETY STANDARDS; SHEAR PROPERTIES; SITE SURVEYS; SOIL MECHANICS; SOILS; STATIC LOADS; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; ENGINEERING; EUROPE; GEOLOGY; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; STABILITY; STANDARDS; SUPPORTS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: This paper discusses the slope stability and landslide propensity of several hydroelectric plant earth dams throughout the Soviet Union from the standpoint of slide theory and compares the research of several Soviet institutions into this problem with existing standards and recommendations on dam stability and reliability. The comparisons are made for earth dams having a soft ground foundation under static loading conditions. Applicable properties are discussed for a wide range of soils and rocks including clays, loams, sands, alluvials, and soft and hard gravels. Seismic effects are not discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:5; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; No. 5, 18-22(May 1987)

TITLE: Monitoring of the seepage regime of earth structures
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; LEAKS; MONITORING; SAND; PERMEABILITY; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CIVIL ENGINEERING; DRAINAGE; FLOW RATE; HYDRAULIC CONDUCTIVITY; HYDRAULICS; PRESSURE EFFECTS; PRESSURE MEASUREMENT; RELIABILITY; SEASONAL VARIATIONS; TEMPERATURE EFFECTS; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; WATER; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; ENGINEERING; EUROPE; FLUID MECHANICS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MECHANICS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POWER PLANTS; VARIATIONS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: This article reports on the seepage regime of the earth dams of the Dneprodzerzhinsk hydroelectric power plant and on the methods employed in the continuous monitoring and inspection of the seepage. The dams are composed of sand with various concrete slab reinforcements at critical areas and riprap and other ground cover used where erosion might be problematic. The main stabilization of the seepage behavior of the dams occurred during the first year after reservoir fill. It was measured according to pressure and temperature. An increase in seepage in the summer is explained by the effect of temperature on the permeability and hydraulic conductivity of the dam material. This increase was found not to affect reliability.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:5; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; No. 5, 42-44(May 1987)

TITLE: Methods of determining the particle-size distribution of coarse soils used in construction
AUTHORS: Pakhomov, O A; Kopatilov, V I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 32 ENERGY CONSERVATION, CONSUMPTION, AND UTILIZATION; DAMS; BUILDING MATERIALS; CONSTRUCTION; ROCKS; PARTICLE SIZE; SORTING; SOILS; WASTE PRODUCT UTILIZATION; CALCULATION METHODS; CRUSHING; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MEASURING METHODS; POROSITY; ROCK MECHANICS; SOIL MECHANICS; STATISTICS; TAILINGS; COMMINUTION; GEOLOGY; MATERIALS; MATHEMATICS; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; SIZE; SOLID WASTES; WASTES; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 320305 - Energy Conservation, Consumption, & Utilization- Industrial & Agricultural Processes- Industrial Waste Management
DESCRIPTION: This article reviews statistical geological calculation and measuring methods for determining and selecting rock and soil rubble particle size for the construction of hydroelectric power earth and rockfill dams. The methods are comparatively assessed in a sample examination of mine tailing particle size distribution. Blast-derived and crushed rock is also examined.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:5; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; No. 5, 29-31(May 1987)

TITLE: Ways to reduce the cost and time of constructing earth dams
AUTHORS: Savchenkov, N G; Kolesnichenko, A I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; CIVIL ENGINEERING; CONSTRUCTION; COST; SAFETY ENGINEERING; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPLEX TERRAIN; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; FOUNDATIONS; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; IRRIGATION; ROCK MECHANICS; ROCKS; SITE SURVEYS; SLOPE STABILITY; SOIL MECHANICS; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; SOILS; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; ENGINEERING; EUROPE; GEOLOGIC FRACTURES; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; GEOLOGY; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; STABILITY; SUPPORTS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: Using the site of the Rogun hydroelectric power plant as a case study, this article describes methods for reducing construction time and cost for dams composed of rock-soil composites and built in complex and difficult terrain. The specifications for the finished Rogun dam and a comprehensive geological description of the canyon are given. Engineering considerations, including the design of tunnels and intake structures, the availability and mechanics of the materials used, facilities for their conveyance from the quarries to the dam site, and preparation of the canyon walls, are described in detail.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:5; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; No. 5, 14-18(May 1987)

TITLE: Sediment transport in a curved channel
AUTHORS: Altunin, V S; Larinova, L V; Martinkus, A T; Novikova, N M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LAND RECLAMATION; SOIL CONSERVATION; INLAND WATERWAYS; EROSION; SEDIMENTS; FLOW MODELS; HYDRODYNAMICS; SOILS; CIVIL ENGINEERING; ENTRAINMENT; FLOW RATE; LIQUID FLOW; OPTIMIZATION; PARAMETRIC ANALYSIS; SEDIMENTATION; USSR; WATER; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; ENGINEERING; EUROPE; FLUID FLOW; FLUID MECHANICS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MECHANICS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POWER PLANTS; RESOURCE CONSERVATION; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 510500 - Environment, Terrestrial- Site Resource & Use Studies- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The authors construct mathematical and experimental flow models to describe the hydrodynamic behavior of sediments eroding into hydroelectric plant waterways for purposes of arriving at sediment reclamation scenarios as well as optimizing waterway design parameters for the minimization of erosion. The models simulate both straight and curved waterways and also allow the determination of the cross-sectional design.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:5; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; No. 5, 37-40(May 1987)

TITLE: Combined diversion and service tunnel spillway of the Tashkumyr hydroelectric station
AUTHORS: Ilyushin, V F; Kurakina, E V; Reznikova, S P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; INTAKE STRUCTURES; CONSTRUCTION; DESIGN; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; SPILLWAY; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CIVIL ENGINEERING; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; DAMS; HYDRAULICS; PARAMETRIC ANALYSIS; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; RIVERS; SEISMIC EFFECTS; SITE SURVEYS; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; TECTONICS; TUNNELS; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; ENGINEERING; EUROPE; FLUID MECHANICS; GEOLOGY; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; UNDERGROUND FACILITIES; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: This article describes the design and construction of a combined diversion tunnel-service spillway at the Tashkumyr hydroelectric plant on the Naryn River which during construction served as a diversion tunnel and during operation serves as a spillway. The combined function of the structure made possible a savings of about four million rubles. Gate and tower intake design for the diversion tunnels was influenced by the layout of the Rogun hydroelectric plant. Seismic and tectonic evaluations of this kind of construction are given for different geological conditions at possible Soviet sites. Extensive illustrations are included.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:5; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; No. 5, 31-36(May 1987)

TITLE: Stress-strain state, seepage strength, stability, and optimization of earth dams
AUTHORS: Rasskazov, L N; Nedriga, V P; Mozhevitinov, A L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; CIVIL ENGINEERING; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; LEAKS; SLOPE STABILITY; STRESS ANALYSIS; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTER-AIDED DESIGN; CONSTRUCTION; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; FOUNDATIONS; HEIGHT; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPTIMIZATION; PERMEABILITY; RELIABILITY; SOIL MECHANICS; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; SOILS; STRAINS; STRESSES; ASIA; DIMENSIONS; EASTERN EUROPE; ENGINEERING; EUROPE; GEOLOGY; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; SIMULATION; STABILITY; SUPPORTS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: Computer simulation and design scenarios incorporating the stress-strain state, seepage strength, slope stability, and optimization procedures for earth dams intended for Soviet hydroelectric development are described. Stress distribution and soil permeability considerations are used to determine height and thickness parameters. Two-dimensional and three-dimensional simulations are assessed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:5; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; No. 5, 25-28(May 1987)

TITLE: Increase of the effectiveness of safety control of hydraulic structures under pressure
AUTHORS: Tsarev, A I; Blinov, I F; Enikeev, F G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; INSPECTION; PRESSURE EFFECTS; RELIABILITY; SAFETY ENGINEERING; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CIVIL ENGINEERING; CONCRETES; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; ROCK MECHANICS; ROCKS; SAFETY STANDARDS; SLOPE STABILITY; SOIL MECHANICS; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; SOILS; STATISTICAL MODELS; STRESS ANALYSIS; STRESSES; ASIA; BUILDING MATERIALS; EASTERN EUROPE; ENGINEERING; EUROPE; MATERIALS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; STABILITY; STANDARDS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology

Failure probability rates are taken into account. Inspection standards are established which enable the determination and effect of stresses and displacements resulting from age.
