TITLE: Problems of quality control in constructing earth dams
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; QUALITY CONTROL; SAFETY ENGINEERING; COMPACTING; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; EXCAVATION; GEOLOGIC SURVEYS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INSPECTION; SLOPE STABILITY; SOIL MECHANICS; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; SOILS; STANDARDS; CONTROL; ENGINEERING; GEOLOGY; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; STABILITY; SURVEYS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: This paper discusses the inadequacy of current criteria for the quality control of high earth dams and proposes new criteria, based on engineering geology and safety engineering considerations as well as soil standards and inspection during site preparation and soil emplacement and compaction, for ensuring the reliability and longevity of these dams in hydroelectric power generation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:5; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; No. 5, 9-14(May 1987)

TITLE: New method for qualitative simulations of water resources systems. 2. Applications
AUTHORS: Antunes, M P; Seixas, M J; Camara, A S; Pinheiro, M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 02 PETROLEUM; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; WATER RESOURCES; MANAGEMENT; SIMULATION; ACCIDENTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OIL SPILLS; POWER PLANTS; RESOURCES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 020900 - Petroleum- Environmental Aspects; 520500 - Environment, Aquatic- Site Resource & Use Studies- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: SLIN (Simulacao Linguistica) is a new method for qualitative dynamic simulation. As was presented previously, SLIN relies upon a categorical representation of variables which are manipulated by logical rules. Two applications to water resources systems are included to illustrate SLIN's potential usefulness: the environmental impact evaluation of a hydropower plant and the assessment of oil dispersion in the sea after a tanker wreck.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 23:11

TITLE: On the application of functional analysis to the optimization of the production of hydroelectric power
AUTHORS: Christensen, G S; Soliman, S A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTER CALCULATIONS; PRODUCTION; FORECASTING; OPTIMIZATION; PLANNING; POWER GENERATION; RIVERS; WATER RESERVOIRS; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 990220 - Computers, Computerized Models, & Computer Programs- (1987-1989)
DESCRIPTION: This paper presents a new approach the authors have used for solving the optimal long-term problem of a hydro power system for maximum expected benefits (benefits from energy generated by a hydro power system over the planning period plus the expected future returns from water left in storage at the end of that period). The problem is formulated as a minimum norm problem in the framework of functional analytic optimization technique. The proposed method takes into account the stochasticity of the water inflows. The authors assume that their probability properties are pre-estimated from past history. Numerical results are presented for a real system in operation consisting of three rivers; each river has two series reservoirs. The computing time using this approach is very small compared to that of other approaches.
RESEARCH_ORG: Electrical Engineering Dept., The Univ. of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: PWRS-2:4

TITLE: Load models for large-scale stability studies from end-user consumption
AUTHORS: Vaahedi, E; El-Kady, M A; Libaque-Esaine, J A; Carvalho, V F
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ELECTRICAL TRANSIENTS; LOAD ANALYSIS; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; ENERGY CONSUMPTION; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; ONTARIO; STABILITY; CANADA; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; TRANSIENTS; VOLTAGE DROP; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 298000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Consumption & Utilization
DESCRIPTION: This paper summarizes improvements in the application of load models in power system stability studies by utilizing end-user energy consumption data to identify the composition of loads. The project included derivation and compilation of customer load characteristics for the Ontario Hydro System and subsequent interfacing with a transient stability program. Results from these models were compared with recordings of a recent Ontario Hydro system disturbance.
RESEARCH_ORG: Power System Operations Div., Ontario Hydro, Toronto
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: PWRS-2:4

TITLE: Unit commitment in a large-scale power system including fuel constrained thermal and pumped-storage hydro
AUTHORS: Aoki, K; Satoh, T; Itoh, M; Ichimori, T; Masegi, K
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; LOAD MANAGEMENT; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; OPERATION; OPTIMIZATION; POTENTIAL ENERGY; ENERGY; FUNCTIONS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MANAGEMENT; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 200100 - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Power Plants & Power Generation
DESCRIPTION: This paper presents a new method for solving efficiently a large-scale optimal unit commitment problem. The authors problem includes three types of units (i) usual thermal units, (ii) fuel constrained thermal units and (iii) pumped-storage hydro units. The solution method uses a Lagrangian relaxation. For maximizing the Lagrangian function, a 'variable metric method' is tried instead of the subgradient method. Moreover, a new device for efficiently obtaining a feasible solution is proposed. This leads to very good numerical results. All important operating constraints are incorporated.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: PWRS-2:4

TITLE: Components of forces of a reservoir acting on the foundation of high dams
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; HYDRAULICS; HYDROSTATICS; PRESSURE EFFECTS; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; STATIC LOADS; HIGH-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPRESSION; DEFORMATION; ELASTICITY; FOUNDATIONS; LEAKS; LEVELS; LIMITING VALUES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PERMEABILITY; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; ROCKS; WATER RESERVOIRS; ENGINEERING; FLUID MECHANICS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; SUPPORTS; SURFACE WATERS; TENSILE PROPERTIES; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: This article investigates the fluctuating hydrostatic and hydraulic forces acting on the dams of high-head hydroelectric power plants with variations in the reservoir level and the effects of these forces on dam displacement, foundation deformation, and the forced seepage of water through the ground rock in order to establish maximum allowable engineering indices for dam construction.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:4; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No. 4, 40-44(Apr 1987)

TITLE: Gas shows during construction of hydraulic tunnels
AUTHORS: Razumov, V K; Skiba, S I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CAUCASUS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TUNNELS; CONSTRUCTION; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; ROCK BURSTS; CARBON DIOXIDE; CIVIL ENGINEERING; CLAYS; COAL DEPOSITS; FRACTURE MECHANICS; GAS SATURATION; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; METHANE; MINING ENGINEERING; MOUNTAINS; RIVERS; ROCKS; TECTONICS; WATER INFLUX; ALKANES; ASIA; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; EASTERN EUROPE; ENGINEERING; EUROPE; GEOLOGIC DEPOSITS; GEOLOGIC FRACTURES; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; GEOLOGY; HYDROCARBONS; MECHANICS; MINERAL RESOURCES; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POWER PLANTS; RESOURCES; SATURATION; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; UNDERGROUND FACILITIES; USSR; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The authors investigate the occurrence of and the geological factors behind rock bursts during the construction of diversion tunnels of five hydroelectric power plants located in the mountainous regions of the Caucasus. Gas migration and saturation behavior is explained for the various forms of strata and rock found in the region. Carbon dioxide and methane are determined to be the prevalent gases. The influence of the tectonics of the region is assessed. Corollaries to coal mining engineering are drawn. Water influx as a result of rock bursts is briefly discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:4; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No. 4, 34-37(Apr 1987)

TITLE: Deformation of dams with a facing and their seismic stability
AUTHORS: Groshov, M E; Lombardo, V N
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; DEFORMATION; DESIGN; SEISMIC EFFECTS; SLOPE STABILITY; ASPHALTS; CIVIL ENGINEERING; CONSTRUCTION; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; ROCK MECHANICS; SOIL MECHANICS; STRAINS; STRESS ANALYSIS; STRESSES; BITUMENS; ENGINEERING; GEOLOGY; MECHANICS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OTHER ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; POWER PLANTS; STABILITY; TAR; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: The authors determine design and engineering parameters for a hydroelectric dam constructed of soil and pebbles and faced with asphalt from the stand point of its mechanical behavior and deformation under the effect of a seismic event. Optimal slope gradients are established for the materials under consideration. Seismic effects at all stages of dam life--from construction to reservoir filling to actual full-capacity operation--are incorporated into the analysis. Limiting values of stress and strain are established under seismic and hydrostatic loading.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:4; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No. 4, 27-33(Apr 1987)

TITLE: Experience in operating the ERO-3 speed relay and its modernization
AUTHORS: Kornev, V E; Zhirnov, E L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; RELAYS; PERFORMANCE; SPEED REGULATORS; TURBOGENERATORS; ANGULAR VELOCITY; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; DESIGN; EQUIPMENT PROTECTION DEVICES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INTEGRATED CIRCUITS; MICROPROCESSORS; RETROFITTING; VOLTAGE REGULATORS; COMPUTERS; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; CONTROL SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS; EQUIPMENT; MICROELECTRONIC CIRCUITS; POWER PLANTS; VELOCITY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: This article describes a speed regulator relay system in use in the Soviet Union for controlling the velocity of hydroelectric power turbogenerators and discusses the steps taken to modernize the system based on operating experience and new technology. Primary among these steps has been basing the system on microprocessor-based computerized control systems capable of protecting the generators from runaway velocity transients.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:4; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No. 4, 48-50(Apr 1987)

TITLE: Adjusting and modernization of the system converting units to synchronous capacitor operation at the Sayano-Shushenskoe hydroelectric station
AUTHORS: Markin, V N; Gorodnyanskii, V I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CAPACITIVE ENERGY STORAGE EQUIPMENT; WATER REMOVAL; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENERGY STORAGE; LOAD MANAGEMENT; RETROFITTING; TURBOGENERATORS; USSR; AIR FLOW; BLOWERS; COMPRESSED AIR; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; HYDRAULICS; PNEUMATICS; TANKS; AIR; ASIA; COMPRESSED GASES; CONTAINERS; CONTROL SYSTEMS; EASTERN EUROPE; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; EQUIPMENT; EUROPE; FLUID FLOW; FLUID MECHANICS; FLUIDS; GAS FLOW; GASES; MACHINERY; MANAGEMENT; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; REMOVAL; STORAGE; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: This paper details the design and performance of the pneumatic system installed at the Sayano-Shushenkoe hydroelectric power plant in the Soviet Union for purposes of expelling water from the turbine runner pits during conversion of the turbogenerators to synchronous capacitor operation. The system consists of compressed air tanks, lines, and blowers for the delivery of an air stream into the runner pits and is controlled by computer.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:4; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No. 4, 44-48(Apr 1987)

TITLE: Preservation of natural fish reproduction during hydrotechnical construction on rivers
AUTHORS: Gangardt, G G; Malevanchik, B S; Mikhailov, L P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; DESIGN; HYDRAULICS; FISHES; MIGRATION; REPRODUCTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY; USSR; AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; FISHERIES; PERFORMANCE; PLANNING; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; RESOURCE CONSERVATION; RIVERS; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; ECOSYSTEMS; ENGINEERING; EUROPE; FLUID MECHANICS; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; VERTEBRATES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: This article reviews and evaluates measures taken or in the planning stage at a number of hydroelectric power plants on rivers throughout the Soviet Union to provide passage facilities and spawning grounds for migratory fish. The design and hydrodynamics of a variety of actual and planned facilities are described as well as the response of the fish population to the facilities in place.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:4; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No. 4, 22-27(Apr 1987)

TITLE: Improvement of the effectiveness of spillway operation of high-head hydroelectric stations
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HIGH-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SPILLWAY; DESIGN; FLOW MODELS; HYDRAULICS; AERATION; BUBBLES; CIVIL ENGINEERING; DAMS; DYNAMIC LOADS; ENERGY LOSSES; ENERGY TRANSFER; FLOW RATE; INCLINATION; KINETIC ENERGY; LIQUID FLOW; PRESSURE EFFECTS; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; TWO-PHASE FLOW; WATER; ENERGY; ENGINEERING; FLUID FLOW; FLUID MECHANICS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; LOSSES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MECHANICS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POWER PLANTS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: This article formulates the hydraulics and energetics involved in the aerated two-phase flow of water over and down the spillway of a high-head hydroelectric power plant into the receiving pools and constructs a flow model describing kinetic energy transfer and losses and air bubble compression forces for different configurations and inclinations of the spillway surface for purposes of spillway design.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:4; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No. 4, 11-18(Apr 1987)

TITLE: Yacyreta hydroelectric project contract signed
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ARGENTINA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; EQUIPMENT; PLANNING; PARAGUAY; CANADA; CONSTRUCTION; CONTRACTS; FINANCING; MANUFACTURERS; PENNSYLVANIA; TURBINES; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; FEDERAL REGION III; LATIN AMERICA; MACHINERY; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; SOUTH AMERICA; TURBOMACHINERY; USA; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: On June 26, 1987 the $270 million contract for the supply of 20 large hydraulic turbines for the Yacyreta Hydroelectric Project was signed by the Entidad Binacional Yacyreta, (a binational agency created by the governments of Argentina and Paraguay for the development of Yacyreta), and by Voith Hydro, Inc., of York, Pennsylvania, and Canadian General Electric of Montreal, Canada. Under the terms of the contract, 9 turbine units will be supplied by Voith Hydro, Inc. from its York, Pennsylvania plant, 4 units by Canadian General Electric of Montreal, and 7 units by Metanac, a consortium of Argentine manufacturers, who will utilize technology and technical assistance from Voith and CGE. The Yacyreta Project is being built on the Parana River on the border between Argentina and Paraguay. Construction at the site commenced in late 1983. Voith's portion of this contrast represents approximately $130 million dollars worth of business for its York, Pennsylvania facility.
RELATION: Journal Name: Alternative Sources Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 93

TITLE: Upriver Dam rehabilitation
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; REPAIR; WASHINGTON; COST; DAMAGE; DAMS; ELECTRICAL FAULTS; FLOODS; LIGHTNING; OUTAGES; SCHEDULES; DISASTERS; ELECTRIC DISCHARGES; FEDERAL REGION X; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; USA; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: A lighting storm caused severe damage to the city of Spokane, Washington's Upriver Dam Hydroelectric Project in the early morning hours of May 20, 1986. Approximately $10 million in damages occurred when a lightning strike caused a fault on the transmission intertie to the project. The fault triggered a full load rejection of all generating units, causing loss of power to the spillway gates. Efforts to restart the units or provide auxiliary power to the gates were unsuccessful. As a result, the river level rose quickly and water overtopped and breached project embankments. Portions of the power canal were also eroded and the foundation of Powerhouse No.1 was partially washed away, causing the structure to rotate and settle several degrees out of plumb. Remedial design and construction plans aimed to not only quickly restored generating capacity, but also to provide a fail-safe operation of the spillway in the future. Restoration work and its scheduling are briefly described.
RELATION: Journal Name: Alternative Sources Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 93

TITLE: Utility relicensing plans
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; CAPACITY; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MODIFICATIONS; PAPER INDUSTRY; PLANNING; SURVEYS; US FERC; INDUSTRY; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; WOOD PRODUCTS INDUSTRY; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations
DESCRIPTION: Recent FERC figures indicate that between December 31, 1987 and the year 2000, some 3600 MW of capacity from 259 projects will come up for relicensing. The overwhelming percentage of this capacity is currently licensed to utilities, with the next largest percentage licensed to paper mills. Thirty-four utilities were asked what their plans were for low head hydro capacity additions. Between the 34 utilities there were some 2247 MW of installed low head capacity installed, and 512 MW planned - an expected jump of almost 30%. Most of the new hydro capacity over the next five years is expected to come in the form of upgrades.
RELATION: Journal Name: Alternative Sources Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 93

TITLE: Equipment decisions: comparing single units with multiple machines
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; EQUIPMENT; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; DECISION MAKING; ECONOMICS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Engineers disagree on whether it is better to use one machine or install multiple units at a hydroelectric site. Economics favor a single unit start from a capital cost standpoint, but the possibility of a unit going down or the length of time used to calculate a cost/benefit may favor multiple units. Technical considerations may override economics in some developments. The author's firm has concluded a greater average annual power production justifies unequally sized units, although he recommends going with a single unit if possible.
RELATION: Journal Name: Alternative Sources Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 93

TITLE: Dinerwig pumped-storage station
SUBJECT: 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; OPERATION; SPECIFICATIONS; UNITED KINGDOM; CONSTRUCTION; COST; DIAGRAMS; HYDRAULICS; MAINTENANCE; PERFORMANCE; POWER RANGE 1-10 GW; PUMP TURBINES; RELIABILITY; START-UP; SYSTEMS ANALYSIS; TURBOGENERATORS; WATER RESERVOIRS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; EUROPE; FLUID MECHANICS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MACHINERY; MECHANICS; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; WESTERN EUROPE; 250300* - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989); 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The Dinerwig pumped storage power plant, located in North Wales and rated at 1800 MW, is considered one of the largest of its kind in the world. This article gives a comprehensive description of all aspects of the plant, including design, construction, componentry, operation, reliability, maintenance, cost, and performance.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:3; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No.3, 45-51(Mar 1987)

TITLE: Problems of the manufacturing technology of mechanical equipment and steelwork of hydraulic structures
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC EQUIPMENT; FABRICATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; PIPELINES; AUTOMATION; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; DESIGN; EFFICIENCY; LABOR; MANUFACTURERS; OPTIMIZATION; ORGANIZING; PIPE JOINTS; PLANNING; PRODUCTIVITY; STEELS; TECHNOLOGY UTILIZATION; ALLOYS; EQUIPMENT; IRON ALLOYS; IRON BASE ALLOYS; JOINTS; POWER PLANTS; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: This article provides a comprehensive analysis of manufacturing technologies currently in use in the manufacture of hydroelectric power plant components, singles out areas where those technologies can be made more cost, labor, and materials effective, and suggests new strategies in management and technology which can effect those savings.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:3; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No.3, 19-22(Mar 1987)

TITLE: Experience in the construction and operation of steel pressure pipelines of hydropower developments
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; OUTAGES; PIPELINES; DAMAGE; FAILURES; STEELS; USSR; ACCIDENTS; DESIGN; DYNAMIC LOADS; FRACTURE MECHANICS; HYDRAULICS; OPERATION; PERFORMANCE; SERVICE LIFE; STRESS ANALYSIS; SYSTEM FAILURE ANALYSIS; ALLOYS; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; FLUID MECHANICS; IRON ALLOYS; IRON BASE ALLOYS; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; SYSTEMS ANALYSIS; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 360103 - Metals & Alloys- Mechanical Properties
DESCRIPTION: This article reviews Soviet experience in the construction and operation of hydroelectric and pumped storage power plants in the USSR and analyzes several outages at these plants resulting from pipeline accidents. Case studies of failure and damage scenarios that have occurred in pipelines and their components in the postwar period are given.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:3; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No.3, 12-19(Mar 1987)

TITLE: On-site investigations of the effect of external forces on the contact zone of the Bratsk dam
AUTHORS: Durcheva, V N; Solov'eva, Z I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; DYNAMIC LOADS; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; STATIC LOADS; FOUNDATIONS; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DEFORMATION; DESIGN; ELONGATION; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; HYDRODYNAMICS; HYDROSTATICS; INTAKE STRUCTURES; PIEZOMETRY; PRESSURE EFFECTS; SEASONAL VARIATIONS; STRAINS; STRESS ANALYSIS; STRESSES; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; FLUID MECHANICS; GEOLOGY; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; SUPPORTS; VARIATIONS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: This article assesses the loads acting on the dam and foundation of the Bratsk hydroelectric power plant during various fill and drain regimes as well as stress and strain interactions with the geological forces of the terrain. Diagrams of the uplift pressure are given which were determined using the stresses and strains of the foundation under the upstream face of the powerhouse and nonoverflow sections of the dam. The seepage heads were found to depend both on the upper water level and on the season. The maximum uplift pressure is observed in February and March at an upper water level somewhat below the normal water level but with a maximum depth of the open joints on the downstream face.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:3; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No.3, 35-38(Mar 1987)

TITLE: Construction of geodetic networks for studying crustal movements when creating hydraulic structures in seismic regions
AUTHORS: Ostropiko, P A; Kartashov, A P; Atrushkevich, P A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; GEODETIC SURVEYS; SEISMIC EFFECTS; SITE SURVEYS; USSR; CONSTRUCTION; DAMS; DESIGN; EARTHQUAKES; FORECASTING; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; PLANNING; REGIONAL ANALYSIS; SEISMICITY; TECTONICS; WATER RESERVOIRS; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; GEOLOGIC FRACTURES; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; GEOLOGY; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; POWER PLANTS; SEISMIC EVENTS; SURFACE WATERS; SURVEYS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: This article describes geodetic survey techniques and applies them to tectonic site surveys for hydroelectric power plants. Methods for conducting such surveys and implementing their results into the design and construction of hydroelectric power plants and their dams and reservoirs are explained. The use of the proposed geodetic techniques in the planning of the Bartogai and Bestyuba reservoirs is discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:3; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No.3, 27-30(Mar 1987)

TITLE: Long-term service checking of the concrete of the Chirkey dam
AUTHORS: Zelenevskii, Z L; Draginich, V V; Draginich, G O
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CONCRETES; ACOUSTIC TESTING; IN-SERVICE INSPECTION; DAMS; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; AGING; COMPRESSION STRENGTH; ELASTICITY; FRACTURES; MAINTENANCE; RELIABILITY; RESOLUTION; SAFETY; SERVICE LIFE; TENSILE PROPERTIES; TRANSDUCERS; ASIA; BUILDING MATERIALS; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; FAILURES; INSPECTION; MATERIALS; MATERIALS TESTING; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; NONDESTRUCTIVE TESTING; POWER PLANTS; TESTING; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: This article describes the methodology and instrumentation used in an acoustic and ultrasonic inspection of the concrete dam at the Chirkey hydroelectric power plant. The inspection, performed from 1982 through 1984, was run to determine possible mechanical property aging and fracture points in the concrete and was found to be superior, both in terms of accuracy and labor expenditure, to previous destructive or mechanical sampling methods. Test results are summarized.

SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 32 ENERGY CONSERVATION, CONSUMPTION, AND UTILIZATION; DIFFUSERS; ENERGY EFFICIENCY; FLOW MODELS; HYDRAULICS; PERFORMANCE; VORTEX FLOW; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; ENERGY LOSSES; FLOW RATE; FLOW VISUALIZATION; HYDRAULIC CONDUCTIVITY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; KINETIC ENERGY; OPTIMIZATION; PARAMETRIC ANALYSIS; REYNOLDS NUMBER; EFFICIENCY; ENERGY; FLUID FLOW; FLUID MECHANICS; LOSSES; MACHINERY; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 320303 - Energy Conservation, Consumption, & Utilization- Industrial & Agricultural Processes- Equipment & Processes

TITLE: Manual internal vibrator for compacting wet concrete in hydraulic structures
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; COMPACTORS; EFFICIENCY; PERFORMANCE; SIZING; CONCRETES; COMPACTING; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; FIELD TESTS; MANUFACTURERS; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; PERFORMANCE TESTING; PLANNING; REVIEWS; SPECIFICATIONS; ASIA; BUILDING MATERIALS; DOCUMENT TYPES; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; GEOLOGY; MATERIALS; POWER PLANTS; TESTING; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: This article assesses the use of vibratory compactors in the construction of concrete hydroelectric dams and proposes technologies both in construction materials and in dam and equipment design which would make possible the utilization of smaller, less cumbersome, and more efficient compactors with higher productivity ratings. Manufacturer behavior toward and responsiveness to construction experience and contractor demand are also reviewed. Specifications are given for a specific number of down-sized compactors.

TITLE: Use of the acoustic method for checking the quality of concrete of hydroelectric and pumped storage stations
AUTHORS: Filonidov, A M; Lyubinskii, V Yu
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CONCRETES; ACOUSTIC TESTING; IN-SERVICE INSPECTION; DAMS; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ACCURACY; AGING; CALIBRATION; COMPRESSION STRENGTH; DRILL CORES; ELASTICITY; INTAKE STRUCTURES; MECHANICAL TESTS; POISSON RATIO; SOUND WAVES; STRUCTURAL BEAMS; TENSILE PROPERTIES; TRANSDUCERS; YOUNG MODULUS; ASIA; BUILDING MATERIALS; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; INSPECTION; MATERIALS; MATERIALS TESTING; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; NONDESTRUCTIVE TESTING; POWER PLANTS; TESTING; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: This article describes acoustic methods used in the in-service inspection of the dams and peripheral concrete structures of the Toktogul, Kurpsai, and Bratsk hydroelectric and pumped storage plants. The tests were conducted to assess the compression strength, elasticity, and tensile strength of the concretes. Comparative evaluations against drill core studies proved the acoustic methods to be sufficiently accurate in predicting aging behavior and loss of mechanical and physical integrity in the concretes.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:3; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 21: No.3, 42-44(Mar 1987)

TITLE: Three-phase induction generator for single-phase line
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; CAPACITORS; COST; ELECTRIC CURRENTS; ELECTRIC POTENTIAL; ENERGY EFFICIENCY; INDUCTION; OPERATION; POWER CONDITIONING CIRCUITS; POWER RANGE 10-100 KW; REMOTE AREAS; CURRENTS; EFFICIENCY; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS; EQUIPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Hydroelectric generators of less than 20 kilowatts can be in remote areas served only by a single-phase line. For high efficiency and low cost, a three-phase induction generator should be used. This three-phase generator can operate with balanced voltages and currents when the ''phase-splitting'' circuit uses two capacitors connected to two different single-phase voltage sources.

TITLE: Raccoon Mountain pumped-storage plant: Ten years operating experience
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; PERFORMANCE; COOLING SYSTEMS; FAILURE MODE ANALYSIS; INSULATING OILS; MECHANICS; OPERATION; POWER RANGE 100-1000 MW; REMOTE CONTROL; REVIEWS; ROTORS; STATISTICS; STATORS; TRANSFORMERS; CONTROL; DOCUMENT TYPES; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; ENERGY SYSTEMS; EQUIPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MATHEMATICS; OILS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OTHER ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; SYSTEM FAILURE ANALYSIS; SYSTEMS ANALYSIS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130700 - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Operational experience at the 1 530 MW Raccoon Mountain underground pumped-storage plant can be relevant to other large hydro facilities. A number of unusual features were incorporated and individual unit size was only recently overtaken elsewhere. Direct water cooling of rotor and stator winding has been successfully applied to salient pole machines. A number of problems, including difficulties with oil-filled 161 kV current transformers, and some mechanical aspects, are reported. Designed for remote supervisory control, the plant has required closer attention. Operating statistics are included.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Electronics; (United States); Journal Volume: EC-2:3

TITLE: Assessing flushing-flow requirements for brown trout spawning gravels in steep streams
AUTHORS: Kondolf, G M; Cada, G F; Sale, M J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; TROUT; HABITAT; CALIFORNIA; FLUID FLOW; HYDROLOGY; STREAMS; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; FEDERAL REGION IX; FISHES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; USA; VERTEBRATES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Flushing flows are releases from dams designed to remove fine sediment from downstream spawning habitat. We evaluated flushing flows on reaches proposed for hydroelectric diversions on seven streams in the eastern Sierra Nevada, California, with wild populations of brown trout (Salmo trutta). The stream reaches are steep, are dominated by boulder cascades, and afford few opportunities for gravel deposition. Methods for estimating flushing flows from flow records, developed from studies in other localities, produced widely differing results when applied to the study streams, probably reflecting differences in the hydrologic and geomorphic characteristics of the streams on which the methods were developed. Tracer gravel experiments demonstrated that all sampled gravels were washed out by the flows of 1986, a wet year. Size analyses of gravel samples and hydraulic data from field surveys were used in tractive-force calculations in an attempt to specify the flow required to flush the gravels. However, these calculations produced some unrealistic results because the flows were nonuniform in the study reaches. This suggests that the tractive-force approach may not be generally applicable to small, steep streams where nonuniform flow conditions prevail.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 23:4

TITLE: Sedimentation and the economics of selecting an optimum reservoir size
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; WATER RESERVOIRS; DESIGN; OPTIMIZATION; CONSTRUCTION; DAMS; DREDGING; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; SEDIMENTATION; SEDIMENTS; ECONOMICS; ENGINEERING; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: An easily reproducible methodology is presented for the economic selection of an optimal reservoir size given an annual sedimentation rate. The optimal capacity is that at which the marginal cost of constructing additional storage capacity is equal to the dredging costs avoided by having that additional capacity available to store sediment. The cost implications of misestimating dredging costs, construction costs, and sediment delivery rates are investigated. In general, it is shown that oversizing is a rational response to uncertainty in the estimation of parameters. The sensitivity of the results to alternative discount rates is also discussed. The theoretical discussion is illustrated with a case study drawn from Highland Silver Lake in southwestern Illinois.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 23:8

TITLE: Scientific and technical progress in engineering-geodetic surveys
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 22 GENERAL STUDIES OF NUCLEAR REACTORS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; GEODETIC SURVEYS; SITE SURVEYS; NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS; AERIAL SURVEYING; COMPLEX TERRAIN; COMPUTERS; COORDINATES; DATA ACQUISITION; DEFORMATION; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; RANGE FINDERS; REACTOR SITES; REVIEWS; SEISMOLOGY; SLOPE STABILITY; TECTONICS; TOPOGRAPHY; USSR; ASIA; DOCUMENT TYPES; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; GEOLOGY; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; NUCLEAR FACILITIES; POWER PLANTS; STABILITY; SURVEYS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 220501 - Nuclear Reactor Technology- Environmental Aspects- Siting
DESCRIPTION: This paper reviews the progress made in the Soviet Union in geodetic survey methodology, instrumentation, and data processing facilities with regard to siting future hydroelectric, pumped storage, and nuclear power plants and to assessing the geologic behavior of sites already in existence for sings of deformation or settling or tectonic or seismic activity.

TITLE: Use of the rock preservation scale in geomechanical investigations and construction
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; PETROGRAPHY; ROCK MECHANICS; STRATIGRAPHY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ROCKS; MECHANICAL TESTS; CONSTRUCTION; DEFORMATION; FRACTURE PROPERTIES; GEOLOGIC AGES; LITHOLOGY; POROSITY; RIVERS; SHEAR; SITE SURVEYS; STATIC LOADS; STRESS ANALYSIS; USSR; WEATHERING; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; GEOLOGY; MATERIALS TESTING; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; SURVEYS; TESTING; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The rock preservation scale is a term used for the evaluation of rock properties pertinent to the engineering and construction of hydroelectric power plants and dams. Based on the microregionalization principle it is designed to eliminate many of the inconsistencies found in broader and more general assay methods which are unable to track or incorporate small heterogeneities in rock properties. In this paper it is applied to field engineering geology experiments at five different hydroelectric plants where the preliminary survey work was carried out with the participation of the author. Rocks of different origin, composition, strength and geologic history were included in the analysis and in almost 200 deformation and shear tests.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:2; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo; 21: No. 2, 23-28(Feb 1987)

TITLE: Measurement of water discharge in short sections of conduits by means of orifices
AUTHORS: Valentini, K L; Levin, B M; Lopatin, A N
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FLOWMETERS; OPERATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OUTLET STRUCTURES; DRAINAGE; FLOW RATE; FLOW REGULATORS; HYDRAULIC CONDUCTIVITY; OPENINGS; PERFORMANCE; PIPES; PRESSURE MEASUREMENT; SEDIMENTS; WATER; WATER RESERVOIRS; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; METERS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes a method and instrumentation for measuring the flow rate and volume of water in the concrete outlet structure of a hydroelectric power reservoir. Pressure measurements are taken through a series of holes in the pipe. The method is free of the disadvantages normally associated with measuring the sediment-laden flow for which the structure is designed. The metering system is designed to work in conjunction with a flow regulator to control the water level of the reservoir and also to clear sedimentation from behind the dam.

SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; RIVERS; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PLANNING; SITE SURVEYS; USSR; CONSTRUCTION; DESIGN; ECONOMICS; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; HYDROLOGY; WATER RESERVOIRS; WATER RESOURCES; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; EUROPE; GEOLOGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology

All aspects of hydroelectric power development on this scale are discussed, including resource evaluation, hydrology, engineering geology, plant design and construction, economics, generating capacity, and environmental impact potential.

TITLE: Horizontal displacements of rock foundations of dams
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; GEODETIC SURVEYS; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; STRATA MOVEMENT; FOUNDATIONS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; DEFORMATION; PRESSURE EFFECTS; ROCK MECHANICS; SLOPE STABILITY; STATIC LOADS; WATER RESERVOIRS; GEOLOGY; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; STABILITY; SUPPORTS; SURFACE WATERS; SURVEYS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: This paper uses geodetic survey methods to assess the horizontal displacements of dam foundations for several hydroelectric power plants in the Soviet Union. The effects of filling the reservoirs are outlined and the dependence of the degree of displacement on dam height is analyzed. The results are tabulated.

TITLE: Problems of improving geotechnical investigations for hydrotechnical construction
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; SITE SURVEYS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SOILS; MECHANICAL TESTS; SHEAR PROPERTIES; SLOPE STABILITY; BUILDING MATERIALS; FOUNDATIONS; INFORMATION SYSTEMS; OPTIMIZATION; PORE PRESSURE; SOIL MECHANICS; TEST FACILITIES; USSR; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; GEOLOGY; MATERIALS; MATERIALS TESTING; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; STABILITY; SUPPORTS; TESTING; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: This article puts forth guidelines and methodologies for assessing soils not only as foundations for hydroelectric power plants but also as building materials for their dams. A test facility is described for testing soils for their shear strength and slope stability. Several hydroelectric plants around the Soviet Union where these guidelines have been implemented during design and construction are reviewed. An information retrieval system serving as a data bank for the mechanical properties of soils is described.

SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; GEOLOGIC FORMATIONS; CLASSIFICATION; ROCK MECHANICS; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; DATA ANALYSIS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; GEOLOGIC MODELS; GEOLOGY; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; REVIEWS; STRESS ANALYSIS; TECTONICS; DOCUMENT TYPES; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; SURVEYS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: This article reviews current problems in the approach to and analysis of geomechanical data for hydroelectric power plant and dam siting studies. These problems include the classification of rock masses from an engineering geology standpoint, the approach to geological modeling and microregionalization of formations and structures, data acquisition inconsistencies in geophysical survey methods, and the estimation of the internal stress states of rock formations. Recommendations are outlined in each of these problem fields.

TITLE: Short-term generation scheduling of hydraulic multi-reservoir multi-area interconnected systems
AUTHORS: Amado, S M; Ribeiro, C C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; LOAD MANAGEMENT; SCHEDULES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INTERCONNECTED POWER SYSTEMS; BRAZIL; DYNAMIC PROGRAMMING; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPERATION; PLANNING; POWER GENERATION; WATER RESERVOIRS; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; ENERGY SYSTEMS; LATIN AMERICA; MANAGEMENT; POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; PROGRAMMING; PUBLIC UTILITIES; SOUTH AMERICA; SURFACE WATERS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 290100 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Analysis & Modeling
DESCRIPTION: This work presents a generation scheduling model for multi-reservoir interconnected systems, to be used in operation planning as an auxiliary tool in the determination of the feasibility of weekly operation policies. The nonlinearities associated with the operation of each hydro plant are represented in detail. The hydro generation and the energy interchanges between control areas are scheduled in order to meet the weekly operation targets. The problem is solved by Dynamic Programming and the Principle of Progressive Optimality is used to allow its temporal decomposition. Satisfactory computational results have been obtained and the model is now being incorporated into the operation planning of the Brazilian system, which is composed by about 50 reservoirs and 8 control areas.
RESEARCH_ORG: Centrais Eletricas Brasileiras S.A., Rio de Janeiro
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: PWRS-2:3

TITLE: Current state and ways to develop engineering geophysics
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; SITE SURVEYS; GEOLOGIC FORMATIONS; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; CONSTRUCTION; DATA ANALYSIS; OPTIMIZATION; PLANNING; REVIEWS; ROCK MECHANICS; SEISMOLOGY; TECTONICS; DOCUMENT TYPES; GEOLOGY; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; SIMULATION; SURVEYS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: This paper proposes methods for optimizing geophysical survey procedures and analysis in the engineering geology assessment of various sites for hydroelectric power plants. It also reviews the past performance of the All-Union Planning, Surveying, and Scientific-Research Institute of the Soviet Union during surveys and construction of large-scale hydroelectric plants and outlines and discusses new procedures for geophysical site monitoring during construction. Heavy emphasis is placed on seismic techniques.

DESCRIPTION: This paper describes procedures for assessing the hydrological and climatological conditions surrounding the design and construction of hydroelectric and pumped storage power plants which incorporate seasonal variations in reservoir and runoff availability as well as load management scenarios during freeze and thaw cycles and also help determine ice loading conditions in the planning and design stages. Several existing and potential hydroelectric power regions in the Soviet Union are assessed.

TITLE: A Newton optimal power flow program for Ontario Hydro EMS
AUTHORS: Marie, G A; Findlay, J A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LOAD MANAGEMENT; ALGORITHMS; ENERGY MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS; EQUATIONS; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; LINEAR PROGRAMMING; NEWTON METHOD; ONTARIO; OPTIMIZATION; PERFORMANCE; RELIABILITY; CANADA; ENERGY SYSTEMS; FUNCTIONS; ITERATIVE METHODS; MANAGEMENT; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; PROGRAMMING; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 290100 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Analysis & Modeling
DESCRIPTION: A Newton optimal power flow program was developed for the Ontario Hydro Energy Management System. Each iteration minimizes a quadratic approximation of the Lagrangian. All the equations are solved simultaneously for all the unknowns. A new technique based on linear programming is used to identify the binding inequalities. All binding constraints are enforced using Lagrange multipliers. The algorithm combines the fast convergence of the Newton technique with the speed and reliability of Linear programming. Most cases converged in three iterations or less.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: PWRS-2:3

TITLE: Continuous solution simulation in the short-term hydrothermal coordination problem
AUTHORS: Calderon, L R; Galiana, F D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; ALGORITHMS; LOAD MANAGEMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DIAGRAMS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; FORECASTING; LOAD ANALYSIS; OPTIMIZATION; PARAMETRIC ANALYSIS; PERSONNEL; RELIABILITY; TRAINING; WATER INFLUX; WATER RESERVOIRS; MANAGEMENT; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; SURFACE WATERS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 290100 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Analysis & Modeling
DESCRIPTION: This paper presents a new approach for the solution of the short-term hydrothermal coordination problem based on the continuation method, a parametric optimization technique which solves the given problem by creating and solving a family of problems related by a single continuation parameter. In this application the continuation parameter continuously modifies the system load curve and/or the water inflows to the different reservoirs. Among some of the advantages of this approach the authors find: (1) It is not necessary to start with a feasible solution to the original problem; (2) The parameter continuation process yields piece-wise linear analytic optimum trajectories rather than point-wise solutions; (3) The method is very reliable; (4) Infeasible problems can be systematically detected; (5) The approach yields some unique analytic insight, as well as having applications in unit commitment, in the evaluation of load management strategies, in fast recoordination following a revision of the load forecast or reservoir inflows, and in operator training. An algorithm to implement this continuous simulation approach is presented and illustrated by various hydrothermal coordination examples.
RESEARCH_ORG: Instituto de Investigaciones, Electricas (IIE), Cuernavaca, Morelos
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: PWRS-2:3

TITLE: An efficient hydrothermal scheduling algorithm
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ALGORITHMS; H CODES; LOAD MANAGEMENT; SCHEDULES; DECISION MAKING; FLOW MODELS; MEMORY DEVICES; MICROPROCESSORS; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; OPTIMIZATION; PERFORMANCE; TIME DEPENDENCE; COMPUTER CODES; COMPUTERS; ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS; MANAGEMENT; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MICROELECTRONIC CIRCUITS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 290100 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Analysis & Modeling; 990220 - Computers, Computerized Models, & Computer Programs- (1987-1989)
DESCRIPTION: In this paper a Hydrothermal Scheduling Algorithm (HSA) for deterministic inflows is presented. A nonlinear network flow model representing the hydrothermal scheduling problem is used. By exploiting the special network structure, a temporally expanded arborescence, the HSA code attains important computational savings in processing time and memory requirements allowing the use of microcomputers even for large scale problems. The main feature of the HSA code is a dynamic base choice that enables the decision maker to improve the convergence of the optimization procedure by the use of his practical experience. The performance of the algorithm is tested on the Southeast Brazilian Power System.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: PWRS-2:3

TITLE: Salient electrical design features of the Magat hydroelectric project
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; CONTROL THEORY; DEMONSTRATION PROGRAMS; ELECTRIC GROUNDS; EQUIPMENT PROTECTION DEVICES; PHILIPPINES; POWER GENERATION; RELAYS; ASIA; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; ISLANDS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The Magat River Multipurpose project on the Luzon grid of the National Power Corporation of the Philippines consists of a four unit 450 MVA powerplant placed in service towards end of year 1983 and early 1984, providing an additional installed capacity of 360 MW to the existing generation peak capacity of 2478 MW (1) of the Luzon grid, which is the country's largest grid with an installed capacity of 3906 MW, the other two being those of Visayas and Mindanao with a total installed capacity of 1095 MW. This paper describes the salient features of the electrical design including the main generation and station service single line schemes, the principal equipment parameters and layout, control and protection schemes and grounding system of the power plant.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Electronics; (United States); Journal Volume: EC-2:2

TITLE: Political economy of western water finance: cost allocation and the Bonneville Unit of the Central Utah Project
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; COST RECOVERY; POLITICAL ASPECTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ECONOMICS; ALLOCATIONS; BONNEVILLE POWER ADMINISTRATION; BUREAU OF RECLAMATION; COST; UTAH; FEDERAL REGION VIII; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; US DOE; US DOI; US ORGANIZATIONS; USA; 290200* - Energy Planning & Policy- Economics & Sociology; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: A common hypothesis is that federal water agencies pursue continued appropriations with little consideration of national economic efficiency. In the mid-1980s, faced with a vote on a supplemented municipal and industrial water repayment contract on the Bonneville Unit of the Central Utah Project, the Bureau of Reclamation confirmed this hypothesis. Through modifications in cost allocation procedures, the bureau shifted costs from municipal and industrial water to hydropower and irrigation. The result of this action was retention of the irrigation purpose in the Bonneville Unit, which would have been unjustified under previous cost allocation procedures.
RESEARCH_ORG: Univ. of Utah, Salt Lake City
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. J. Agric. Econ.; (United States); Journal Volume: 69:2

TITLE: Optimal long-range generation expansion planning for hydro-thermal system based on analytical production costing model
AUTHORS: Youn, L T.O.; Lee, K Y; Park, Y M
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; PLANNING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ALGORITHMS; COST ESTIMATION; GAUSSIAN PROCESSES; HAMILTONIANS; INVESTMENT; LOAD ANALYSIS; LOAD MANAGEMENT; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPTIMIZATION; OUTAGES; PEAK LOAD; POWER GENERATION; PROBABILITY; MANAGEMENT; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; MATHEMATICAL OPERATORS; POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; QUANTUM OPERATORS; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 290200 - Energy Planning & Policy- Economics & Sociology; 299003 - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation- Other- (-1989); 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: This paper presents a new algorithm for the optimal long-range generation planning for hydro-thermal system. The algorithm is based upon the analytical production costing model developed under the assumption of Gaussian probabilistic distribution of random load fluctuations and plant outages. The optimization problem consists of the master problem to determine the annual investment, and the hydro subproblem to determine the optimal hydro operation. The master problem is formulated as a Hamiltonian minimization problem, and the hydro subproblem is solved using the concept of peak-shaving operation on the original load curve.
RESEARCH_ORG: Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Southern Illinois Univ., Edwardsville, IL 62026
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: PWRS-2:2

TITLE: Optimal generation planning for a thermal system with pumped-storage based on analytical production costing model
AUTHORS: Lee, B Y; Park, Y M; Lee, K Y
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; ALGORITHMS; COST ESTIMATION; PLANNING; DIAGRAMS; GAUSSIAN PROCESSES; HAMILTONIANS; INVESTMENT; LOAD ANALYSIS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPTIMIZATION; OUTAGES; PEAK LOAD; POWER GENERATION; PROBABILITY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; MATHEMATICAL OPERATORS; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; QUANTUM OPERATORS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 290200 - Energy Planning & Policy- Economics & Sociology
DESCRIPTION: This paper presents a new algorithm for the optimal long-range generation planning for a thermal system with pumped-storage plants. The algorithm is based upon the analytical production costing model developed under the assumption of Gaussian probabilistic distribution of random load fluctuations and plant outages. The optimization problem consists of the master problem to determine the annual investment, and the pumped-storage subproblem to determine the optimal pumped-storage operation. The master problem is formulated as a Hamiltonian minimization problem, and the pumped-storage subproblem is solved using the concept of peak-shaving operation on the original load curve.
RESEARCH_ORG: Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Hong-Ik Univ., Seoul
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: PWRS-2:2

TITLE: Periodic optimal control with application to pumped storage plants
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; OPERATION; ALGORITHMS; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPERATING COST; COST; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: This paper suggests how nonlinear periodic optimal control of a pumped storage plant can be realized. The control problem consists in maximization of the plant benefits over an operational period. An optimal control law is proposed, yielding a bang-off-bang mode of operation. An algorithm for numerical solution of the problem was developed, and its effectiveness was demonstrated by simulation experiments.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 23:4

TITLE: Service restoration following a major failure on the Hydro-Quebec power system
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OUTAGES; POWER TRANSMISSION; REPAIR; QUEBEC; ELECTRICAL FAULTS; EXCITATION; FAILURES; LOAD MANAGEMENT; POWER SYSTEMS; POWER TRANSMISSION LINES; RESONANCE; STEADY-STATE CONDITIONS; TRANSFORMERS; CANADA; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; ENERGY SYSTEMS; ENERGY-LEVEL TRANSITIONS; EQUIPMENT; MANAGEMENT; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 200301 - Power Transmission & Distribution- AC Systems, EHV & UHV- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Service restoration following a major power failure can occasion voltage problems on weak EHV systems from the point of view of both steady-state and temporary operation. This is due to the use of long EHV transmission links between the production sites and the load centres, which can cause large amounts of reactive power to be generated, and low short-circuit level, leading to low-frequency resonance, further excited by the presence of transformers. This paper describes an approach to service restoration which should speed up the process of restoring service to customers while at the same time limiting the risks of damage to equipment.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Del.; (United States); Journal Volume: PWRD-2:2

TITLE: Network simplex method applied to AC load-flow calculation
AUTHORS: Barras, J; Alec, S; Pasche, C; Chamorel, P A; De Werra, D; Germond, A J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; LOAD ANALYSIS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; AC SYSTEMS; ACCURACY; ALGORITHMS; ALTERNATING CURRENT; CALCULATION METHODS; DIRECT CURRENT; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPERATIONS RESEARCH; OPTIMIZATION; PERFORMANCE; PLANNING; POWER TRANSMISSION LINES; RELIABILITY; TRANSFORMERS; VOLTAGE REGULATORS; CURRENTS; ELECTRIC CURRENTS; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; ENERGY SYSTEMS; EQUIPMENT; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 290100 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Analysis & Modeling
DESCRIPTION: Operational research methods, and particularly flow and transportation methods have many applications in the power system field: optimization of hydroelectric power system operation, seasonal or short-time planning of a hydro-thermal system and finally power system security. The purpose of this paper is to specify the network simplex method of the load-flow calculation in a power system. This study is not limited to the DC-flow calculation but particularly presents a model for the full AC load-flow calculation. The proposed model is an imaginary and real current one. It is based on a simplifying assumption which will allow decoupling of the problem and which is the basis of the algorithm called FLF (FLow Load-Flow algorithm). Power system elements such as lines, transformers, generators and voltage control busses are represented with adapted models. Systematic tests have been performed on some existing power systems, such as the IEEE 24-bus Reliability system. The performance of this method is compared with the results of a decoupled Newton-Raphson load-flow. The accuracy of the FLF algorithm is competitive with the Newton-Raphson method, but its speed still has to be improved. However the load-flow calculation is only a part of the power system security problem, where properties and characteristics of flow and transportation algorithms will offer greater perspective.
RESEARCH_ORG: Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, 1007 Lausanne
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: PWRS-2:1

TITLE: Long term power system simulation for real-time training with a reduced size program
AUTHORS: Di Lascio, M A; Moret, R; Poloujadoff, M
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 21 SPECIFIC NUCLEAR REACTORS AND ASSOCIATED PLANTS; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; PERSONNEL MANAGEMENT; FOSSIL-FUEL POWER PLANTS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PERSONNEL; TRAINING; POWER SYSTEMS; PWR TYPE REACTORS; COMPUTER CODES; REAL TIME SYSTEMS; SIMULATORS; ANALOG SYSTEMS; ENERGY SYSTEMS; FUNCTIONAL MODELS; MANAGEMENT; POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; REACTORS; SIMULATION; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; WATER COOLED REACTORS; WATER MODERATED REACTORS; 296000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 200100 - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Power Plants & Power Generation; 210200 - Power Reactors, Nonbreeding, Light-Water Moderated, Nonboiling Water Cooled
DESCRIPTION: This paper presents a brief description and discussion of the results of a reduced size computer program for long-term power system simulation. It includes detailed models of a hydro, a coal-fired and a pressurized water reactor (PWR) generation plant. Typical data taken from operating records have been used. Since the simulation runs faster then real-time, the program can be used as a power system simulator operator training.
RESEARCH_ORG: National Council for Scientific and Thech. Development - CNPq, Institute for Space Research - INPE, Caixa Postal 515, 12200, Sao Jose dos Campos, SP
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: PWRS-2:1

TITLE: Generation expansion planning for systems with a high share of hydro power
AUTHORS: Nordlund, P; Sjelvgren, D; Pereira, M V.F.; Bubenko, J A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; LOAD MANAGEMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPERATING COST; PLANNING; COST ESTIMATION; LINEAR PROGRAMMING; POWER GENERATION; SCHEDULES; STOCHASTIC PROCESSES; COST; MANAGEMENT; POWER PLANTS; PROGRAMMING; PUBLIC UTILITIES; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 296001 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 290100 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Analysis & Modeling; 290200 - Energy Planning & Policy- Economics & Sociology; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: This paper presents a method for integrating a detailed model of the hydroelectric system into existing power system planning tools. The purpose of the hydro model is not primarily to optimize hydro expansion, but to represent the influence of hydro regulation on the thermal system expansion. Stochastic production costing routines are used to calculate operating costs as a function of hydro production. Linear programming is used to determine the hydro production schedule that minimizes production costs along the planning period, taking into account a number of constraints in the hydro production system. A study with 16 cascaded hydro plants and 25 thermal units is presented and discussed.
RESEARCH_ORG: The Swedish State Power Board, Vallingby
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: PWRS-2:1

TITLE: A fast production scheduler for generation expansion planning in a hydro-thermal system
AUTHORS: Cote, G; Lafond, L; Pham, C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; ALGORITHMS; LOAD MANAGEMENT; SCHEDULES; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; COMPUTER-AIDED DESIGN; COMPUTER CODES; EXPORTS; IMPORTS; POWER GENERATION; RIVERS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MANAGEMENT; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 290100 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Analysis & Modeling
DESCRIPTION: A fast production scheduling algorithm suitable for generation expansion studies is described in this paper. It can handle several independent rivers, thermal plants, pumped storage plants, import, export, and internal non-firm markets. Inflows and load are deterministic and a one-reservoir limit is imposed on each river. The scheduling problem is formulated as a generalized network problem which is efficiently solved by an adaption of the simplex method. The algorithm is part of a program developed by Hydro-Quebec to conduct preliminary evaluations of alternative expansion plans. The program and the scheduling algorithm are presented.
RESEARCH_ORG: Institut de recherche d'Hydro-Quebec (IREQ), 1800 Montee Ste-Julie, Varennes, Quebec, J0L 2P0
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: PWRS-2:1

TITLE: B. C Company competes in small hydro market
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; MARKET; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; ECONOMICS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Small hydro-electric power plants are becoming a reality. Today, in spite of institutional roadblocks, there are more than 200 small installations powering a range of homes, resorts, logging camps, fish hatcheries and farms throughout British Columbia. The potential for hydropower development in mountainous B.C. is discussed. However, B.C. is not the only place suited to low head hydro - any location that has a small stream with a continuous water flow, and the ability to establish a drop in elevation, can be harnessed.
RESEARCH_ORG: Solar Energy Society of Canada, Inc., Vancouver (Canada)
RELATION: Journal Name: Sunworld; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:3

TITLE: Arch dam of the Khudoni hydroelectric station
AUTHORS: Dzhakeli, P A; Kobakhidze, V D; Koridze, G I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; HYDRODYNAMICS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; USSR; CONCRETES; FOUNDATIONS; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; HYDROSTATICS; PLANNING; POLYMERS; SITE SURVEYS; SLOPE STABILITY; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; ASIA; BUILDING MATERIALS; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; FLUID MECHANICS; GEOLOGIC FRACTURES; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; GEOLOGY; MATERIALS; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; STABILITY; SUPPORTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: This paper discusses the Khudoni hydroelectric station. The selection of the type and site of the dam are described. A plan of the hydro development with the chosen concrete arch dam is shown. Engineering-geologic and seismotectonic conditions of the chosen site are examined. Two types of design were examined for the arch dam, and they are described. Structural elements of the dam are discussed as is reinforcement, stress-strain state, underground contour and outlet works.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 20:7; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo; 20: No. 7, 5-11(Jul 1986)

TITLE: Concrete dam of the Lenin Dnepr hydroelectric station
AUTHORS: Durcheva, V N; Kazachenko, A N; Puchkova, S M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; REPAIR; RETROFITTING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; USSR; AGING; CONCRETES; CRACK PROPAGATION; DESIGN; FOUNDATIONS; HYDROSTATICS; MATERIALS TESTING; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; SERVICE LIFE; STABILITY; STRESS ANALYSIS; ASIA; BUILDING MATERIALS; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; MATERIALS; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; POWER PLANTS; SUPPORTS; TESTING; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: This paper examines the Dnepr dam, which has been operating for 50 years. The construction of the Dnepr hydroelectric station is described, and the problem of cracking is examined and illustrated. The dam was reconstructed and the characteristics damages of the dam are described. An additional powerhouse was constructed called Dnepr-II. The static behavior of the Dnepr dam is characterized by a thermal stress state of the concrete with extreme values of opening of the joints and of the hydrostatic levels in April and October. The current state of the dam is examined, including seepage through the dam, uplift in the construction joints and uplift in the foundation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 20:7; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo; 20: No. 7, 1-5(Jul 1986)

TITLE: Seepage regime in the foundation of the Kanev hydroelectric station
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FOUNDATIONS; HYDROSTATICS; IN-SERVICE INSPECTION; LEAKS; USSR; DAMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DRAINAGE; OPERATION; PERMEABILITY; RELIABILITY; STATIC LOADS; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; INSPECTION; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; POWER PLANTS; SUPPORTS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The Kanev hydroelectric station is shown and is discussed in terms of its foundation and the seepage regime therein. The structure of the foundation is described and observations of the seepage regime in the foundation of the powerhouse were carried out by means of embedded piezometers. Observations were made of the hydrostatic levels and heads. Seepage discharges along the powerhouse are shown, as is the distribution of seepage force on the basis of the powerhouse. The watertight and drainage elements of the concrete structures according to the on-site observations are operating effectively. The hydrostatic levels are found to vary almost linearly with variations of the lower pool level.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 20:7; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo; 20: No. 7, 47-52(Jul 1986)

TITLE: Detection of defects in a grout curtain by geophysical methods
AUTHORS: Koptev, V I; Gorshkov, Yu M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; DAMS; DEFECTS; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; FOUNDATIONS; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; RELIABILITY; ROCK MECHANICS; SITE SURVEYS; CONCRETES; DEFORMATION; DRILL CORES; FAILURES; GEOPHYSICS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LEAKS; NOMOGRAMS; PERMEABILITY; SEALS; WELL LOGGING; BUILDING MATERIALS; DIAGRAMS; GEOLOGY; MATERIALS; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; SUPPORTS; SURVEYS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 360603 - Materials- Properties
DESCRIPTION: The observed frequencies of failure of concrete dams of rock foundations due to various causes are shown. This paper discusses grouting as a way of reducing the risk of failures and the evaluation of the cutoff effect of grouting. A physical substantiation of a method of direct layerwise inspection of a grout curtain is given, and the results of testing obtained at one of the objects are described. The proposed method has a high differentiating ability in the vertical direction and a large radius of testing. The method is applicable both during grouting and after its completion. The essence of the method consists of evaluating the change in the hydraulic communication between the wells as a results of conducting grouting operations.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 20:7; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo; 20: No. 7, 23-27(Jul 1986)

TITLE: On-site observations of the state of structures at the Kanev lock
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; FLOW REGULATORS; IN-SERVICE INSPECTION; MONITORING; RELIABILITY; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; DRAINAGE; MAINTENANCE; NAVIGATION; RETROFITTING; RIVERS; SERVICE LIFE; SPILLWAY; WATER RESERVOIRS; ASIA; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; EASTERN EUROPE; EQUIPMENT; EUROPE; INSPECTION; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: This paper shows how the navigation structures of the Kanev hydroelectric station were equipped with monitoring and measuring instruments that enable the lock operating service to systematically check the state and behavior of the concrete and earth structures. The data of on-site observations shows the reliable state of the structures in the construction period and in the period of temporary operation. It is seen that the upper parts of the chamber walls moved toward the lock axis in the winter and toward the backfill in the summer. The ground water levels behind the lock chamber walls changed in conformity with the seepage flow from the upper to the lower pools.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 20:7; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo; 20: No. 7, 41-47 (Jul 1986)

TITLE: Measures to reduce the level of vibrations of turbine-generator units
AUTHORS: Kolesnikov, V I; Dolgopolov, A S; Engel', V E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; IN-SERVICE INSPECTION; MECHANICAL TESTS; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; TURBOGENERATORS; DAMPING; ELECTROMOTIVE FORCE; HYDRAULICS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RETROFITTING; ROTORS; STATORS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; FLUID MECHANICS; INSPECTION; MACHINERY; MATERIALS TESTING; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; TESTING; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Work are carried out on an umbrella-type SVCh 790/106-52 generator with one generator bearing located in the same oil bath with the thrust bearing through which the load is transmitted to the turbine cover, in order to determine the causes and to reduce the level of increased vibration. An analysis of the oscillograms obtained during the vibration tests show the causes of increased vibration. Deviations from the geometrically regular form of the bore of the generator stator were measured simultaneously through the ventilation channels of the rotor by means of a device consisting of a rod with a dial indicator fastened on it. The developed form of the rotor with respect to the poles and contour is given. The work on centering the unit with consideration of the natural sagging of the turbine block made it possible to reduce vibration of components of the unit by more than 50%.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 20:7; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo; 20: No. 7, 52-55(Jul 1986)

TITLE: Assignment of strength requirements of concrete for large dams
AUTHORS: Mikeladze, G T; Sudakov, V B; Malyshev, B N
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; CONCRETES; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; SERVICE LIFE; DAMS; MATERIALS TESTING; AGING; DESIGN; HYDRAULICS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RELIABILITY; SPECIFICATIONS; USSR; ASIA; BUILDING MATERIALS; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; FLUID MECHANICS; MATERIALS; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; TESTING; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 360603 - Materials- Properties
DESCRIPTION: The authors examine the strength of concrete for large hydraulic structures according to control samples and cores at an age of 360 days and find that it is considerably higher than the analogous indices at an age of 180 days. It is shown that in the design and construction of the largest dams, the assignment of the design strength grade of the main volume of concrete to an age of 360 days is a technically and economically expedient method, saving about 20 kg/m/sup 3/ cement.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 20:7; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo; 20: No. 7, 11-13(Jul 1986)

TITLE: Dependence of river pollution of stream flow regulation by reservoirs
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; RIVERS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; HYDROLOGY; WATER POLLUTION; WATER RESERVOIRS; ANNUAL VARIATIONS; CONTROL; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; MANAGEMENT; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; SEASONAL VARIATIONS; USSR; WATER POLLUTION ABATEMENT; WATER QUALITY; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY; EUROPE; GEOLOGY; POLLUTION; POLLUTION ABATEMENT; POWER PLANTS; SIMULATION; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; VARIATIONS; 520200* - Environment, Aquatic- Chemicals Monitoring & Transport- (-1989); 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: An analysis of the theoretical distribution functions of water quality at the sites of water use shows that the expected value of river pollution substantially depends on the character of stream flow regulation, although the integral masses of river water and pollutants passing through the sites remain unchanged. The author illustrates this nonlinear effect with numerical illustration. Results are given of the calculations of water quality performed during optimization of the Kuzbass water-management system. Data presented give additional arguments on behalf of stream flow regulation as an effective means of improving water quality in the basins of industrial regions. The author examines in particular the direct regulating effects associated with a change in diluting capacity of rivers in lower pools of reservoirs. Effectiveness of variants of stream flow regulation of the Kuzbass according to the results of computer tests of a simulation model of the water-management system in the entire range of hydrological conditions is shown.
