RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 20:7; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo; 20: No. 7, 33-35(Jul 1986)

TITLE: Programmed closing of gates upon loss of drive by a pump unit
AUTHORS: Karelin, V Ya; Arshenevskii, N N; Novoderezhkin, R A; Pospelov, B B; Zakharov, V N; Chirkov, P P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FLOW REGULATORS; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; RUNOFF; PUMPING; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; WATER PUMPS; FAILURES; HYDRAULICS; PIPELINES; PRESSURE DROP; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; RIVERS; WATER RESERVOIRS; ASIA; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; CONTROL SYSTEMS; EASTERN EUROPE; ENGINEERING; ENVIRONMENTAL TRANSPORT; EQUIPMENT; EUROPE; FLUID MECHANICS; MASS TRANSFER; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; PUMPS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: Dynamic loads in elements of hydromechanical equipment and structural elements of pumping stations reach maximum values upon loss of drive by the pump unit. To prevent increased loads on elements of the unit and water hammer in the pressure conduit, it is necessary that the total time of closing the shutoff limits the rotational speed of the rotor of the unit in the turbine direction. To find the optimal law of closing of the shutoff, calculations of the process of the loss of drive of a pump unit were calculated on a computer according to a program based on the simultaneous solution of equations of rotation of the rotor of the unit and equations of water hammer with consideration of elasticity of water and walls of the conduit. The method of determining a shutoff closing law developed here provides a minimum increase of pressure and dynamic loads on the unit.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 20:7; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo; 20: No. 7, 13-16(Jul 1986)

TITLE: Electric Consumers Protection Act of 1986
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; REGULATIONS; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY; LEGAL ASPECTS; LICENSING; PUBLIC UTILITY REGULATORY POLICIES ACT; STANDARDS; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; LAWS; NATIONAL ENERGY ACT; POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 293000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Policy, Legislation, & Regulation
DESCRIPTION: An overview of the Electric Consumers Protection Act of 1986 identifies it as the most important federal legislation dealing with hydroelectric development standards since the Federal Water Power Act of 1920. The author summarizes its major components, and identifies some of the existing and potential issues relation to its implementation. The most controversial issue is the selection of a new licensee for a project once the original licensee's term has expired. Other issues concern environmental criteria, comprehensive planning, amendments to the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act, and enforcement procedures. The article concludes with a summary of miscellaneous provisions, including antitrust, modifications and time calculations of projects, wheeling, and other concerns.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Law J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 8:1

TITLE: Alternative-energy industry: Power for the future
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 09 BIOMASS FUELS; BIOMASS; FORECASTING; COGENERATION; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; PLANNING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; REFUSE DERIVED FUELS; CAPACITY; CAPITALIZED COST; CONSTRUCTION; POWER DEMAND; POWER DISTRIBUTION; POWER PLANTS; PRICES; REGULATIONS; COST; DEUS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY SYSTEMS; FUELS; POWER; POWER GENERATION; PUBLIC UTILITIES; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; STEAM GENERATION; 296000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 299003 - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation- Other- (-1989); 290800 - Energy Planning & Policy- Heat Utilization- (1980-); 130000 - Hydro Energy; 140504 - Solar Energy Conversion- Biomass Production & Conversion- (-1989); 090400 - Solid Waste & Wood Fuels- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The alternative-energy industry will expand sharply during the next five years because of a growing need for additional electric-generating capacity, and a shift in the strategy of electric utilities in favor of distributing, as opposed to producing, electricity. Between 1989 and 1991, over 50,000 megawatts of electricity will need to be ordered in order to meet the country's electrical-generating requirements in the mid-1990's. Yet, many utilities are likely to be reluctant to build new power plants because of the financial, regulatory, and construction risks, as well as possible concerns that fuel prices may spiral in the future after a period of stability in the near term. Therefore, many utilities are likely to purchase rather than produce their generating requirements. Because alternative energy (primarily cogeneration, hydro, biomass, and waste/energy) represents low-cost, short lead-time, smaller and, therefore, more manageable increments of generating capacity, a sizable proportion of the nation's generating needs will be met by alternative-energy facilities.
RELATION: Journal Name: Strategic Plan. Energy Manage.; (United States); Journal Volume: 6:4

TITLE: Seismicity around Brazilian dam reservoirs
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; BRAZIL; DAMS; WATER RESERVOIRS; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; SEISMIC EFFECTS; SEISMICITY; EARTHQUAKES; PORE PRESSURE; SEISMIC EVENTS; STRESS ANALYSIS; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; LATIN AMERICA; SOUTH AMERICA; SURFACE WATERS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 580000 - Geosciences
DESCRIPTION: More than 30 cases of seismicity associated with dam reservoir sites are known throughout the world. Despite the lack of data in some areas, where seismicity occurred after reservoir impounding, there have been distinct seismic patterns observed in seismic areas after dam projects implantation. This has demonstrated that reservoir loading can trigger earthquakes. A mechanism of earthquake generation by reservoir impounding is proposed here with particular application to the Brazilian cases and to areas subject to low confining stress conditions in stable regions. Six artificial lakes are described and the associated earthquake sources are discussed in terms of natural or induced seismicity. Earthquake monitoring in Brazil up to 1967, when Brasilia's seismological station started operation, was mainly based in personal communications to the media. Therefore, there is a general lack of seismic records in relatively uninhabited areas, making it difficult to establish a seismic risk classification for the territory and to distinguish natural from induced seismicity. Despite this, cases reported here have shown an alteration of the original seismic stability in dam sites after reservoir loading, as observed by the inhabitants or records from Brasilia's seismological station. All cases appear to be related to an increase in pore pressure in permeable rocks or fracture zones which are confined between impermeable rock slabs or more competent rock. It is apparent that some cases show some participation of high residual stress conditions in the area.
RELATION: Journal Name: Environmental Geology and Water Sciences; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:3
JOURNAL_NAME: Environmental Geology and Water Sciences; (United States)

TITLE: Power from the sea
SUBJECT: 14 SOLAR ENERGY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; OCEAN THERMAL ENERGY CONVERSION; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; OCEAN THERMAL POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; BOILING; CLOSED-CYCLE SYSTEMS; COMMERCIALIZATION; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; COOLING SYSTEMS; DEMONSTRATION PLANTS; OPEN-CYCLE SYSTEMS; POWER GENERATION; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; SEAWATER; TURBINES; WORKING FLUIDS; CONVERSION; ENERGY CONVERSION; ENERGY SYSTEMS; FLUIDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MACHINERY; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; POWER PLANTS; SOLAR ENERGY CONVERSION; SOLAR POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; TURBOMACHINERY; WATER; 140800* - Solar Energy- Ocean Energy Systems; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: A review is presented of the technology for ocean thermal energy conversion, OTEC, for electricity generation. Warm seawater can generate electricity in two ways. In one warm water evaporates a working fluid with a low boiling point. In the second the seawater itself boils in a vacuum chamber. In each case the resulting vapor turns a turbine to generate power. Cold seawater from a depth of 600-1000 meters is used to condense the working fluid to complete the cycle. Both systems, research programs, and demonstration plants are described.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sci. Am.; (United States); Journal Volume: 256:1

TITLE: Tapping lakes in Norway: clean but risky energy
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; DAMS; DEER; LAKES; MIGRATION; NORWAY; RIVERS; SALMON; ANADROMOUS FISHES; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; EUROPE; FISHES; MAMMALS; POWER PLANTS; RUMINANTS; SCANDINAVIA; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; VERTEBRATES; WESTERN EUROPE; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 299003 - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation- Other- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Four hydroelectric projects are currently underway and two more are expected to begin within the next couple of years in Norway, using lake taps. The Ulla-Forre project is presently under construction which uses lake taps to link 30 lakes and many rivers through a network of tunnels and dams. Environmentalists are concerned that dams and other above-ground components of these projects will interfere with the migration routes of reindeer and spawning salmon.
RELATION: Journal Name: Environment; (United States); Journal Volume: 28:10

TITLE: Model tests of Schneider turbine for low-head hydropower plant
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; DESIGN; PERFORMANCE TESTING; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DATA ANALYSIS; INLAND WATERWAYS; IRRIGATION; RIVERS; STRUCTURAL MODELS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; TESTING; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: The Schneider turbine can generate power from relatively low-head hydroenergy sources such as rivers and irrigation canals. In the current work, the theory and analysis of the Schneider turbine have been established, together with the procedure for selection of the main design parameters leading to optimum performance. Moreover, a model of this turbine has been constructed and tested in a specially designed test rig. The successful operation of the Schneider turbine model under various values of relatively low heads proves that such design is suitable for low head applications. Also, the good agreement between the experimental results and the theoretical predictions validates the current theory and analysis.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Energy Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 112:3

TITLE: High head hydro powerplant evaluation
AUTHORS: Gordon, J L; Helwig, P C; Sturge, L G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HIGH-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; DESIGN; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; OPERATION; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; NEWFOUNDLAND; POWER RANGE 100-1000 MW; CANADA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ISLANDS; MACHINERY; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130700 - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: When the head on a hydroelectric powerplant is between about 250-700 m (800-2,300 ft) the turbine can be either an impulse or reaction Francis unit. For each type of unit the operating characteristics and design of the powerplant will be substantially different. This paper outlines a comparison of the two types of powerplant, which was undertaken for the 136 MW Cat Arm Development in Newfoundland, where a gross head of 386.5 m (1,268 ft) is harnessed. The initial cost-benefit analysis indicated that a Francis unit should be selected, but a Pelton unit was chosen, based on an analysis of the operating characteristics and other unquantifiable benefits.
RESEARCH_ORG: Hydro., Monenco Consultants, Ltd., P.O. Box 6088, Station A, Montreal, H3C 3Z8
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Energy Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 112:3

TITLE: Circulating water tunnel under Lake Ontario
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CIRCULATING SYSTEMS; TUNNELS; WATER SUPPLY; CONSTRUCTION; CORPS OF ENGINEERS; DIFFUSERS; ENGINEERING; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; LAKE ONTARIO; LICENSING; POWER RANGE 100-1000 MW; SCHEDULES; GREAT LAKES; LAKES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; UNDERGROUND FACILITIES; US DOD; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes the engineering and construction features of the Circulating Water System (CWS) at the 643 MW Somerset Station located on the south shore of Lake Ontario, approximately 45.06 km (28 miles) north-east of Buffalo, New York. The paper discusses the aspects of the CWS that are unique to Somerset Station (including fish deterrent/fish return system, staged diffuser, intake velocity cap, etc.), and the provisions made in the design to satisfy the stringent licensing requirements of regulatory agencies having jurisdiction over the project such as the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation and the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. Finally, the unconventional construction techniques which were used to enable the system to be built within the framework of a tight construction schedule and environmental constraints are discussed.
RESEARCH_ORG: Ebasco Services Inc., Two World Trade Center, New York, NY 10048
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Energy Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 112:3

TITLE: Local generating facilities in the reliability evaluation of power distribution systems
AUTHORS: Dialynas, E N; Allan, R N
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; PLANNING; SWEDEN; ALGORITHMS; FLOW MODELS; LOAD MANAGEMENT; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; OPTIMIZATION; POWER TRANSMISSION; SCHEDULES; EUROPE; MANAGEMENT; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; POWER PLANTS; SCANDINAVIA; WESTERN EUROPE; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: The aim of this paper is to discuss some operating procedures available in distribution systems which permit local generating plants to supply the load which cannot be supplied by the system bulk supply points during outage conditions. The paper describes analytical and computational techniques which simulate the operational behaviour of these local generating facilities. The increased information that can be gained from these improved techniques is illustrated by the analysis of a typical distribution system.
RESEARCH_ORG: Energy Systems Lab., National Technical Univ., Athens
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: PWRS-1:4

TITLE: Optimal parameter estimation for hydro-plant performance models in economic operation studies
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PERFORMANCE; ACCURACY; ALGORITHMS; EQUATIONS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; LEAST SQUARE FIT; NEWTON METHOD; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; OPTIMIZATION; SCHEDULES; SENSITIVITY; ECONOMICS; ITERATIVE METHODS; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; MAXIMUM-LIKELIHOOD FIT; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 290200 - Energy Planning & Policy- Economics & Sociology
DESCRIPTION: Optimal Economic Operational schedules in hydro-thermal electric power systems are obtained on the basis of models of the various subsystems involved. In this paper we are concerned with models of hydro-plant performance characteristics. Due to the diversity of plant types and installations, a number of models have been proposed in developing optimal operational strategies over the years. Here the authors choose four commonly used models. The problem of finding optimal estimates of model parameters is investigated for the Glimn-Kirchmayer model, the Hildebrand model, the Hamilton-Lamont model and the Arvanitidis-Rosing model. They develop the optimal estimator equations for each model using the weighted-least-squares approach. The result for three of the models is a set of nonlinear equations in the unknown parameters. They adopt Newton's method for actually implementing the optimal estimators. Due to the sensitivity of the algorithm's convergence characteristics to the initial guess of the unknowns, they explore and present procedures for generating initial guess values to improve the procedure's performance. Computational experience with the techniques is given in the paper to confirm its feasibility using test data from existing hydro-plants. The paper proposes and examines some extensions to the classical models to improve the accuracy of the modeling process.
RESEARCH_ORG: Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Technical Univ. of Nova Scotia, P.O. Box 1000, Halifax, Nova Scotia, B3J 2X4
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: PWRS-1:4

TITLE: Meeting the challenge of policy-relevant science: lessons from a water resource project
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; WATER POLICY; WATER RESOURCES; PLANNING; DECISION MAKING; RESOURCE CONSERVATION; ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; POWER PLANTS; RESOURCES; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 290400 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Resources
DESCRIPTION: Water resources scientists face complex tasks in evaluating aspects of water projects, but relatively few assessment procedures have been applied and accepted as standards applications. Decision-makers often rely on environmental assessments to evaluate the value and operation of projects. There is often confusion about scientists' role in policy decisions. The scientist can affect policy-making as an expert witness, an advocate or a surrogate. By understanding the policy process, scientists can make their work more policy relevant. Using the Terror Lake hydro project in Alaska as a guide, three lessons are discussed: (1) not all problems are able to be solved with technology; (2) policy-relevant technology is rarely imposed on a problem; and (3) the scientist need not just to react to the policy process, but can have an impact on how that process unfolds.
RESEARCH_ORG: Fish and Wildlife Service, Fort Collins, CO
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:5

TITLE: Sediment load regime of rivers in southern Kazakhstan
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SITE SURVEYS; INTAKE STRUCTURES; SEDIMENTATION; SEDIMENTS; HYDRAULICS; USSR; RIVERS; DAILY VARIATIONS; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; HYDROLOGY; MOUNTAINS; RUNOFF; SAMPLING; SEASONAL VARIATIONS; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; ENVIRONMENTAL TRANSPORT; EUROPE; FLUID MECHANICS; GEOLOGY; MASS TRANSFER; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; VARIATIONS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: Observations are made of the regime of sediments of mountain river southern Kazkhstan, carried out simultaneously with on-site investigations of water intake structures. Gauging sites were set up on natural stretches of rivers outside the backwater zone from the intake. The quantitative characteristics of the water and sediment discharges obtained by the author under on-site conditions while investigating intake structures are presented in a table. Observations established that the bed-load transport varies in conformity with the water runoff regime both during the season and during the day. A reliable relation is obtained for determining the specific bed-load discharge on mountain rivers based on extensive on-site data and having an accuracy acceptable for engineering and hydrological calculations.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 12:6

TITLE: Diagnosis of thermal flaws in the magnetic circuits of hydroelectric generators
AUTHORS: Naslyan, T A; Akopyan, R E; Gushchin, E V; Nemeni, T M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; MAGNETIC CIRCUITS; HOT SPOTS; THERMAL TESTING; TURBOGENERATORS; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; DEFECTS; STATORS; TEMPERATURE DISTRIBUTION; TEMPERATURE EFFECTS; TEMPERATURE MONITORING; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; EUROPE; MATERIALS TESTING; MONITORING; NONDESTRUCTIVE TESTING; POWER PLANTS; SIMULATION; TESTING; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: By means of mathematical simulation certain types of thermal flaws have been evaluated for the magnetic circuits of stators in hydroelectric generators of the Krasnoyarsk power plant. The temperature field of a stator with thermal flaws was calculated in order to examine the possibility of timely detection for local hot spots in it as well as for the total or partial ventilation failures in radial channels by using diagnostic equipment that provides a thermal check on the inner surface of the bore. A determination was made of the maximal temperatures reached in the area of local hot spots and on the end surface of a tooth in order to estimate the risks there.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. J. Nondestr. Test. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 22:1
JOURNAL_NAME: Sov. J. Nondestr. Test. (Engl. Transl.); (United States)

TITLE: Stress-strain state of earth dams, taking account of filtration
AUTHORS: Lyashko, I I; Deineka, V S; Rybachishin, S I; Skopetskii, V V
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; FILTRATION; SEISMIC EFFECTS; SOIL MECHANICS; STRESS ANALYSIS; UKRAINIAN SSR; WATER RESERVOIRS; EMBANKMENTS; SLOPE STABILITY; STRAINS; STRESSES; WATER SATURATION; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; MECHANICS; SATURATION; SEPARATION PROCESSES; STABILITY; SURFACE WATERS; USSR; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The stability of the banks of dikes, dams, and causeways is determined by their stress-strain state (SSS). In the present work, the numerical determination of the SSS of an earth dam of trapezoidal profile at a levy is considered, taking into account that the filtrational process extends only over a definite portion. Using the results for the stress-tensor components on the basis of a particular test, the stability of the banks of the hydroengineering structure is determined. The results of determining the SSS of the banks of the dam at the Korlovskii water reservoir on the Dnepr-Donbass canal are illustrated.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Appl. Mech. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 22:3

TITLE: Real-time kinematic catchment model for hydro operation
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; WATER SUPPLY; SOUTH AFRICA; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; COST; DATA ACQUISITION; DATA PROCESSING; DATA TRANSMISSION; DRAINAGE; FLOODS; KINETIC EQUATIONS; LEVEL INDICATORS; MICROPROCESSORS; OPTIMIZATION; RAIN; REAL TIME SYSTEMS; STREAMS; AFRICA; ATMOSPHERIC PRECIPITATIONS; COMMUNICATIONS; COMPUTERS; DISASTERS; ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS; EQUATIONS; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; MICROELECTRONIC CIRCUITS; POWER PLANTS; PROCESSING; SIMULATION; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: A 5,000 km/sup 2/ catchment in Transkei, Southern Africa is monitored with 10 rain gages which transmit data to a microcomputer model. The numerical model is based on the kinematic equations with both an overland flow/stream flow component and a subsurface component of flow for 14 sub-catchments. Both flood flows and base flows from the catchment are predicted using the model on a real-time basis. In addition to being able to predict flows ahead by the lag time of the catchment (of the order of one day), projection can be made further ahead using rainfall projections. The low cost of the receiving, transmitting and processing system is made possible by coupling simple tipping bucket type rain gages through a processor to a standard microcomputer. The numerical model is simple enough to operate on the microcomputer and can readily be extended to assist in operation of the hydroelectric station to optimize the available water.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Energy Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 112:2

TITLE: The hydrothermal optimal load flow, a practical formulation and solution techniques using Newton's approach
AUTHORS: El-Hawary, M E; Tsang, D H
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTER CALCULATIONS; LOAD ANALYSIS; OPERATION; ALGORITHMS; NEWTON METHOD; OPTIMIZATION; PLANNING; ITERATIVE METHODS; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 290100 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Analysis & Modeling
DESCRIPTION: This paper is concerned with the problem of optimal power flow in a hydro-thermal electric power system (HTOPF). The formulation and optimality conditions for systems with fixed head hydro-plants subject to an energy limited constraint are presented. The solution to obtain the optimal operational strategy is implemented using Newton's method. Due to the large scale nature of the problem, special sparsity oriented and structural property enhancements are explored and four versions for algorithmic implementation are detailed in the paper. Special attention is paid to finding realistic initial guess estimates for the algorithms reported. Results of computational experience with six standard test systems are reported in the paper.
RESEARCH_ORG: Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Technical Univ. of Nova Scotia, Halifax
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: PWRS-1:3

TITLE: Low head hydro review
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; MICRO-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; DESIGN; REVIEWS; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; USA; DOCUMENT TYPES; EQUIPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Low head hydroelectric power sources continue to be an important aspect of the overall energy picture in the United States. This article addresses the challenges in developing such sites and presents a section on equipment and construction progress.
RELATION: Journal Name: Alternative Sources Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 82

TITLE: Flood forecasting for Tucurui Hydroelectrical Plant, Brazil
AUTHORS: Solomon, S I; Basso, E; Osorio, C; Melo de Moraes, H; Serrano, A
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FLOODS; FORECASTING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; BRAZIL; PERFORMANCE TESTING; REGRESSION ANALYSIS; STATISTICAL MODELS; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; DISASTERS; LATIN AMERICA; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICS; POWER PLANTS; SOUTH AMERICA; STATISTICS; TESTING; 520500* - Environment, Aquatic- Site Resource & Use Studies- (-1989); 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: The construction of the Tucurui Hydroelectric Plant on the Tocantins River basin in Brazil requires flood forecasting to ensure the safety of the cofferdam. The latter has been initially designed for a flood with a return frequency of one in 25 years. Lack of adequate forecasting facilities during the earlier stages of construction has resulted in significant damages and construction delays. Statistical forecasting models were developed by Projeto de Hidrologia y Climatologie da Amazonia (PHCA) for the purpose of preventing further damage at the site. The application of these models during the 1980 flood season, when the highest flood on record occurred at the Tucurui site, proved of great assistance in preventing the flooding of the cofferdam. In conjunction with the development of these models a number of data collection platforms using data transmission through the GOES system were installed to provide the data required for forecasting.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:2

TITLE: Risk analysis for reservoir operation
AUTHORS: Loaiciga, H A; Marino, M A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; WATER RESERVOIRS; MANAGEMENT; PLANNING; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; DAMS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPTIMIZATION; RISK ASSESSMENT; SIMULATION; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: The planning of reservoir operations presents decision makers with a trade-off between competing functions, which are energy production and flood control in this study. To optimally resolve the trade-off between maximization of energy revenues and minimization of downstream losses, the interaction between the expected value and variance of revenues (accuring from the reservoir operation) is included in a stochastic daily reservoir operation planning model. By parametrically varying the expected value and variance of the objective function, the risk-average nature of decision makers is incorporated, resulting in a range of feasible alternative policies that reflect the decision maker's attitude toward revenue maximization and poor performance of the reservoir operation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:4

TITLE: Paper company drops hydro dam after conservation edict
SUBJECT: 32 ENERGY CONSERVATION, CONSUMPTION, AND UTILIZATION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION PERMITS; MAINE; LAND USE; PAPER INDUSTRY; ENERGY CONSERVATION; ECONOMIC IMPACT; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; INTERVENORS; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; FEDERAL REGION I; INDUSTRY; LICENSES; NORTH AMERICA; PERMITS; POWER PLANTS; USA; WOOD PRODUCTS INDUSTRY; 320301* - Energy Conservation, Consumption, & Utilization- Industrial & Agricultural Processes- Energy Sources; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 291000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Conservation
DESCRIPTION: The Great Northern Paper Company dropped plans to build a $96 million dam in Maine when opponents demonstrated the company had not taken advantage of opportunities to conserve electricity. The debate took place at the state level when permission to build the dam stipulated that the company must first implement any economical conservation measures. The company had tried to bypass the Land Use Regulation Commission (LURC) conditions with special legislation, but this effort failed. Great Northern withdrew its application, and will seek out in-house conservation along with a scaled-down operation and loss of jobs for the area.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy User News; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:11

TITLE: FERC rules environmental impact not to be issue in QF certifications
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 17 WIND ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; REGULATIONS; US FERC; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; WIND POWER PLANTS; CERTIFICATION; DAMS; ENDANGERED SPECIES; INTEREST GROUPS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 170500 - Wind Energy- Environmental Aspects; 290300 - Energy Planning & Policy- Environment, Health, & Safety; 299000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation
DESCRIPTION: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) ruled in two recent cases that the qualifying facility (QF) certification process is an inappropriate point for environmental review of independent power generation projects. The two cases involved the location of new hydro facilities at an existing dam site and the development of a wind farm. Recognizing that certifications of qualifying cogenerators and small power producers could become too expensive and time consuming if environmental impact became an important issue in the proceedings, FERC ruled that environmental review of small hydro projects is a separate matter and that the Endangered Species Act does not apply to orders granting QF status to wind farms. The two orders reflect FERC's effort to avoid complicating procedural requirements. Applicants for QF status, however, need to be recognized and work with environmental groups.
RELATION: Journal Name: Cogener. Small Power Mon.; (United States)

TITLE: Primary production of the Ust'-Ilim reservoir
AUTHORS: Kozhova, O M; Pautova, V N; Romanenko, T I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; BIOMASS; CLASSIFICATION; PRODUCTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; WATER RESERVOIRS; USSR; RIVERS; AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS; EUTROPHICATION; ALGAE; BIOCHEMISTRY; CHLOROPHYLL; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; PHYTOPLANKTON; SEASONAL VARIATIONS; WATER CHEMISTRY; WATER POLLUTION; WATER QUALITY; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; ASIA; CARBOXYLIC ACIDS; CHEMISTRY; EASTERN EUROPE; ECOSYSTEMS; ENERGY SOURCES; ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY; EUROPE; HETEROCYCLIC ACIDS; HETEROCYCLIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC ACIDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; PHYTOCHROMES; PIGMENTS; PLANKTON; PLANTS; POLLUTION; PORPHYRINS; POWER PLANTS; PROTEINS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; VARIATIONS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: In this article, the authors compare the available data on the Ust'-Ilim reservoir to obtain a generalized characteristic of the reservoir, which can serve as the background when conducting further investigations including monitoring. A diagram is presented showing sections along the reservoir. The phytoplankton biomass in each region studied is examined. The vertical distribution of algae and chlorophyll a in all regions and in all seasons corresponds to the regularities known for water bodies of such type. Eutrophication of the reservoir can be judged from the maximum values of the chlorophyll a concentration.
RESEARCH_ORG: Scientific-Research Institute of Biology, Irkutsk University
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 12:3

TITLE: Installing micro-hydro in the developing nations
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; OPERATION; INDONESIA; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ASIA; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; ISLANDS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130000* - Hydro Energy
DESCRIPTION: The difficulties encountered in installing a micro-hydroelectric power system in Korupun, a mission station/community located in the highlands of Irian Jaya, Indonesia are discussed. Initial construction resulted in the completion of a diversion structure, a 400 ft. power canal, a settling pond, intake works and a power house foundation. The site itself would use less than minimum stream-flow, a 900 ft. penstock and 150 ft. of net effective head to produce 12 kilowatts of electricity.
RESEARCH_ORG: Hydro Tech Systems, Inc., Chattary, WA
RELATION: Journal Name: Alternative Sources Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 78

TITLE: Arbuckle Mountain Hydroelectric project
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PLANNING; REGULATIONS; CALIFORNIA; DECISION MAKING; ECONOMICS; US DOE; FEDERAL REGION IX; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; US ORGANIZATIONS; USA; 130000* - Hydro Energy; 130400 - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 299003 - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation- Other- (-1989); 290200 - Energy Planning & Policy- Economics & Sociology
DESCRIPTION: Hydropower regulations, particularly those which must be met during the pre-construction phase, have become considerably more extensive and complicated over the last few years. This article, which outlines the pre-construction phase of the Arbuckle Mountain Hydroelectric project, provides a good example of the steps developers should be prepared to take before construction commences. The Department of Energy is funding $750,000 of the project's $1,200,000 budget to gain meaningful and reliable information for the public regarding the development and operation of an inexpensive, low head, domestically manufactured cross-flow turbine. To satisfy their requirements several studies and reports are being prepared for the DOE.
RESEARCH_ORG: Ott Water Engineers, Inc., Redding, CA
RELATION: Journal Name: Alternative Sources Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 78

TITLE: More kilowatts with less investment
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPTIMIZATION; ECONOMICS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; INVESTMENT; TURBINES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; MACHINERY; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 290200 - Energy Planning & Policy- Economics & Sociology; 299003 - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation- Other- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Experience with older hydro power stations reveals that turbines can almost always be operated for many years while the lifetime of the governing system is much shorter. An old governing system which is past its time is typically worn out and becoming a source of declining profitability if still in use. This is due to wear and tear or to technical obsolescence which renders it unsuitable for the up-to-date duties required. The development of new techniques brings ever-increasing performances. Consequently, considering the investment cost, it is worthwhile to modify, complete, improve or, in other words, modernize your governing system.
RELATION: Journal Name: Alternative Sources Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 78

TITLE: Hydro project updates
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; LICENSE APPLICATIONS; LICENSES; OPERATION; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations
DESCRIPTION: While the totals for the year are not in yet, a respectable number of hydropower license and exemption applications were submitted to the FERC in 1985. As of September 30th, the FERC reported that 296 license and 172 exemption applications had been received. Increased intervention from state agencies over environmental and recreational issues, and implementation of the cluster impact assessment procedure in additional river basins are expected to contribute to a slowdown in the rate of hydro development in 1986. Coupled with possible changes in the tax laws - such as the House proposal to place hydropower equipment in a 30 year straight-line depreciation category - hydro developers will have their hands full. A number of projects which have worked their way through the regulatory and financial maze and either come on line recently or commenced construction are presented.
RELATION: Journal Name: Alternative Sources Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 78

TITLE: Development of the Owyhee Dam project
AUTHORS: Jarrett, D P; Pace, H W; Stanaszek, J R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; OPERATION; OREGON; US DOE; FEDERAL REGION X; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; US ORGANIZATIONS; USA; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The Owyhee Project Power Committee and Owyhee Irrigation District developed the Owyhee Dam Power Plant, now operating in eastern Oregon. Unique features of the project include a power conduit connected to an existing penstock through Owyhee Dam, a 1000-foot long transmission line river crossing, and an FM radio communication system to a control station at the irrigation district's office in Nyssa, Oregon, approximately 35 miles from the powerhouse. The project was financed by the Oregon Department of Energy's Small Scale Energy Loan Program.
RESEARCH_ORG: Hosey and Associates Engineering Co., Bellevue, WA
RELATION: Journal Name: Alternative Sources Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 78

TITLE: Hydro turbine innovations: 1985 in review
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPTIMIZATION; TURBINES; DESIGN; MAINE; NEW HAMPSHIRE; VIRGINIA; FEDERAL REGION I; FEDERAL REGION III; MACHINERY; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; TURBOMACHINERY; USA; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: In many ways, 1985 could be called the year of the first for hydro turbine manufacturers. Voith Hydro Inc. introduced their first new pressure flume machine, while both Allis-Chalmers and Axel Johnson saw their first pit turbines installed in this country. In Virginia, Columbia Mills became one of the first siphon projects to come on line in the U.S. and, in Maine, C-E/Neyrpic's right-angle bulb turbine, long used in Europe, was installed in the U.S. for the first time. Flygt Corp. installed their submersible turbine generators in an irrigation project for the first time, and the Marlow project in New Hampshire was the first site in the U.S. to feature the HYDROLEC EH model turbine-generator sets.
RELATION: Journal Name: Alternative Sources Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 78

TITLE: Hydro legislative update
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LEGISLATION; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; TAX LAWS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; LAWS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 290200 - Energy Planning & Policy- Economics & Sociology; 299003 - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation- Other- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: During December of 1985, the House of Representatives completed action on a series of tax reform proposals which could have a significant impact on the hydropower industry. The House bill is similar to numerous other recent tax reform proposals in reducing marginal tax rates and eliminating numerous tax preferences. However, because of the substantial reduction in depreciation allowances under the House bill, compared with current law and other tax reform proposals, the House bill can be expected to have a significant negative impact on hydropower development.
RELATION: Journal Name: Alternative Sources Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 78

TITLE: Management of Lake Como: a multiobjective analysis
AUTHORS: Guariso, G; Rinaldi, S; Soncini-Sessa, R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MANAGEMENT; WATER RESERVOIRS; DAMS; FLOOD CONTROL; ITALY; LAKES; OPTIMIZATION; PLANNING; POWER GENERATION; CONTROL; EUROPE; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; WESTERN EUROPE; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes a heuristic approach for improving the performance of multipurpose reservoirs that have already been in operation for a certain number of years. The main characteristic of the method is that the analyst must first learn from the past experience of the manager and synthesize it into a simple operating rule. Then, the analyst must point out, with the help of the manager, what the acceptable modifications of such a rule are. After this has been accomplished, the optimal improvements of the operating rule can be obtained by using standard optimization techniques. Quite satisfactory results have been obtained by applying this approach to Lake Como (Northern Italy), which has been regulated since the end of World War II. In fact, the method shows that both flood protection on the lake shores and water supply to the downstream agricultural areas can be substantially improved, without lowering the mean yearly electricity production of the downstream run-of-river plants. For this reason the operating rule proposed by the method has been programmed on a microcomputer, which is now used every day by the manager as an essential support for his final decision. This and the fact that other actions suggested by this analysis have indeed been undertaken by the local authorities gave to this study the chance to have a positive and direct impact on the lake management.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:2

TITLE: Expansion optimization method for hydropower systems
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; POWER SYSTEMS; OPTIMIZATION; COOPERATION; EVALUATION; INVESTMENT; PLANNING; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY SYSTEMS; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: Expansion planning of hydropower systems with hydraulically connected power plants is dealt with. The performance criterion in optimization includes the anticipated profit and cost-benefit ratio for scenarios up to ten years. The problem is decomposed into three levels. On the lower levels, the optimal operation of the fixed system for the given hydrological years is determined. The dynamic optimization is done for weekly averages, and the coordination to the daily optimization is done by the so called production curves, which measure the value of the regulating power. Two methods, optimal open loop control and state-feedback control, are used for determination of the operation strategy of the system. On the top level, the optimal harnessing of the river system is done by automatic relaxation or by comparing some possible configurations. An interactive menu driven program package for the HP-1000 A700 computer is developed and some optimization results for a system with five hydraulically connected reservoirs and ten aggregated power plant groups are presented. 7 references, 4 figures, 1 table.
RELATION: Journal Name: Int. J. Energy Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: 6:1

TITLE: Recent legal developments and legislative trends in federal preference power marketing
AUTHORS: Vince, C A; Wodka, N A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; ELECTRIC POWER; MARKETING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; OWNERSHIP; ALLOCATIONS; CASE LAW; COMPETITION; LAWSUITS; LEGAL ASPECTS; LEGISLATION; POLITICAL ASPECTS; POWER DEMAND; REGULATORY GUIDES; DOCUMENT TYPES; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; LAWS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 293000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Policy, Legislation, & Regulation
DESCRIPTION: DOE and its regional federal power marketing agencies (PMAs) are at the center of the political and legal debate over the marketing of federal preference power. While the issues are complex, the focus of the controversy is the fact that federal preference power is so much less expensive than traditional sources of electricity that the demand outstrips available supply. An overview of court decisions and pending suits that have shaped the allocation and ratemaking practice of the PMAs and a discussion of the non-federally funded hydroelectric programs begins with background information on PMAs, preference customers, and relevant statutes. The authors identify a number of unresolved issues, and predict a volatile year ahead as the conflicts between preference advocates and their challengers escalate. Because the stakes are so high, it is likely that Congress will ultimately resolve the major issues rather than the judiciary.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Law J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:1

TITLE: Report on the Committee on Regulations - Part I of the Federal Power Act
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; US FERC; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; CASE LAW; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; LEGAL ASPECTS; LICENSE APPLICATIONS; REGULATORY GUIDES; DOCUMENT TYPES; LAWS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 293000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Policy, Legislation, & Regulation
DESCRIPTION: Regulatory developments during 1985 of hydroelectric licensing continued to evolve from the controversy over municipal preference in relicensing, efforts to streamline the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) licensing process, and exemptions for small alternative energy sources. Brief summaries of these cases and developments group those involving the status of license applicants and licenses, FERC jurisdiction, permit and license process, exemptions, and miscellaneous developments together.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Law J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:2

TITLE: Federal Power Act's controversial municipal preference: the Merwin Dam dispute and legislative proposals to amend federal hydro-licensing procedures
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; REGULATIONS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; US FERC; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; CASE LAW; DAMS; DECISION MAKING; LEGAL ASPECTS; LICENSE APPLICATIONS; PUBLIC POLICY; REGULATORY GUIDES; DOCUMENT TYPES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; LAWS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 293000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Policy, Legislation, & Regulation
DESCRIPTION: A review of the public preference controversy analyzes the Merwin Dam case and examines legislative proposals to modify or eliminate the municipal preference. If the controversy should spur congressional action in favor of a preference for existing licensees, the result could be to stabilize the hydropower market and save ratepayers up to $4.5 billion. The author concludes that enabling legislation is more of a limiting factor in altering policies than court decisions. While the methods employed by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) may be improper, its reasoning that municipal preference should not be a part of FERC relicensing proceedings is sound.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Law J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:2

TITLE: Hydroelectric developments: no dam. good
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INTAKE STRUCTURES; DESIGN; WASHINGTON; ANADROMOUS FISHES; CAPACITY; CONSTRUCTION; COST; DISCHARGE CANALS; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; PLANNING; SCREENS; UNDERWATER FACILITIES; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; FEDERAL REGION X; FISHES; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; USA; VERTEBRATES; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The design of a submerged intake structure for the Rocky Brook hydroelectric power plant in Washington is described. Buried in the creek bed, the design allows the creek to flow unimpeded, utilizing the current to keep the screen surface free of most buildup. A compressed air system back flushes the screen to remove any bed-load deposits that may occur. The design of the rest of the power plant is briefly described.
RELATION: Journal Name: WSEO Newsl.; (United States); Journal Volume: 9:1

TITLE: Risk costs for new dams: economic analysis and effects of monitoring
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; COST; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; RISK ASSESSMENT; AGRICULTURE; CALIBRATION; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ECONOMICS; INDUSTRY; POWER PLANTS; SIMULATION; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: New developments and illustrations of the introduction of risk and costs in cost-benefit analysis for new dams are presented. The emphasis is on a method of evaluation of the risk costs based on the structure of the local economy. Costs to agricultural property as well as residential, commercial, industrial, and public property are studied in detail. Of particular interest is the case of sequential dam failure and the evaluation of the risk costs attributable to a new dam upstream from an existing one. Three real cases are presented as illustrations of the method: the Auburn Dam, the Dickey-Lincoln School Project, and the Teton Dam, which failed in 1976. This last case provides a calibration tool for the estimation of loss ratios. For these three projects, the risk-modified benefit-cost ratios are computed to assess the effect of the risk on the economic performance of the project. The role of a warning system provided by systematic monitoring of the dam is analyzed: by reducing the risk costs, the warning system attenuates their effect on the benefit-cost ratio. The precursors, however, can be missed or misinterpreted: monitoring does not guarantee that the risks to human life can be reduced to zero. This study shows, in particular, that it is critical to consider the risk costs in the decision to build a new dam when the flood area is large and densely populated.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:1

TITLE: Economic losses to recreational fisheries due to small-head hydro-power development: a case study of the Henry's Fork in Idaho
AUTHORS: Loomis, J; Sorg, C; Donnelly, D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; FISHERIES; ECONOMIC IMPACT; IDAHO; RECREATIONAL AREAS; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; TOURISM; US FERC; ECONOMICS; FEDERAL REGION X; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; USA; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 290300 - Energy Planning & Policy- Environment, Health, & Safety
DESCRIPTION: The effect of small-head hydro-electric developments on a stream can range from reductions in fish population to elimination of recreational fishing on some portion of a stream. Using a survey of anglers, the Travel Cost and Contingent Value Methods were applied to calculate the economic losses in recreational cold water fishing that might result, if fishing quality dropped by 50% due to hydro-power development. A 50% reduction in fish catch on the Henry's Fork of the Snake River in eastern Idaho due to a dam would result in an annual loss of US $920,000 in fishing benefits. If, instead, a 50% reduction in size of fish caught occurs as a result of a dam on the Henry's Fork, the annual loss in fishing benefits would be US $1.07 million. Recommendations are made that the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) should routinely require quantification of the fisheries benefits foregone in small-head hydro applications, and FERC should use such information to determine overall project feasibility before awarding a permit. 29 references.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Environ. Manage.; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:1

TITLE: Maximize value of your hydroelectric site
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RETROFITTING; AUTOMATION; CAVITATION; MEASURING METHODS; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; MONITORING; OPERATION; CONTROL SYSTEMS; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The importance of retrofit of hydroelectric plants is discussed. Several presentations are reviewed from the Waterpower/'85 conference in Las Vegas. The presentations offered practical methods of optimizing an existing site-specifically, interchangeable but different turbine runners, diagnostic monitoring to prevent damage from cavitation, alternative component designs for penstocks and draft tubes, and application of advanced automatic control systems.
RELATION: Journal Name: Power; (United States); Journal Volume: 129:12

TITLE: Court says munis have relicensing preference
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; US FERC; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; COMPETITION; CONSUMER PROTECTION; LEGAL ASPECTS; LEGISLATION; LICENSE APPLICATIONS; OWNERSHIP; POLITICAL ASPECTS; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: A federal appeals court panel affirming municipal preference for hydroelectric plants which are up for renewal of their licenses reversed a Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) decision, and may lead to a Supreme Court appeal. Public power agencies and investor-owned utilities disagree over whether the municipal preference of the Federal Power Act of 1920 applies to new projects only. The case in question involves the Merwin plant in Washington which involved an earlier reversal of FERC's position and litigation. The Edison Electric Institute projects a loss to consumers of hydro projects worth billions of dollars if relicensing leads to a shift from private to municipal ownership.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. Light Power; (United States); Journal Volume: 63:12

TITLE: Nonlinear deformation of shells of the volute chambers of hydraulic turbines in an elastic medium
AUTHORS: Aronson, A Y; Bazhenov, V A; Gotsulayk, E A; Gulyaev, V I; Ogloblya, A I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; HYDRAULICS; SHELLS; DEFORMATION; CONCRETES; DUCTS; ELASTICITY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; BUILDING MATERIALS; FLUID MECHANICS; MACHINERY; MATERIALS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; TENSILE PROPERTIES; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Volute chambers are an important part of the water channels in high-pressure hydroelectric power stations. The chambers generally have the form of a torus with a variable profile. The shells of the chamber interact with the surrounding concrete through their external surface. While other studies have examined aspects of the design of volute chambers, the authors here present a solution of a problem on the nonlinear deformation of the shells of the volute chambers of hydraulic turbines interacting on one side with a concrete medium.
RELATION: Journal Name: Strength Mater. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 17:4; Other Information: Translated from Problemy Prochnosti, No. 4, pp. 97-102, April, 1985

TITLE: Long-range forecasts of inflow to reservoirs of large hydroelectric stations and their economic importance
AUTHORS: Komarov, V D; Dement'ev, N F
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; WATER RESERVOIRS; HYDROLOGY; WATER INFLUX; ECONOMICS; FORECASTING; PLANNING; RUNOFF; ENVIRONMENTAL TRANSPORT; MASS TRANSFER; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: The authors examine methods of long-range forecasting of inflow to reservoirs of large hydroelectric stations and ways to improve these forecasts. From long-term practice of issuing forecasts and their refinements it can be concluded that the existing forecasting methods make it completely possible to predict with sufficient accuracy all large abnormalities of inflow to reservoirs of large hydrostations. In this connection, the authors note that prediction of large hydrologic abnormalities should be regarded as the main purpose of hydrologic forecasts in general and of forecasts of inflow to hydrostation reservoirs in particular. The long-term experience of using hydrologic forecasts in water-management activities, including in routine management of the regime of reservoirs, showed a high economic effectiveness of forecasts of the volume of river discharge and inflow to reservoirs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Experimental investigation of a breakthrough wave on a stretch with abrupt expansion of the flow
AUTHORS: Lyatkher, V M; Mazbhits, G L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SPILLWAY; FUNCTIONAL MODELS; HYDRAULICS; WATER WAVES; FLOW MODELS; DAMS; EXPANSION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ONE-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; TWO-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; FLUID MECHANICS; GRAVITY WAVES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: The investigations in this article were conducted in a concrete flume with a horizontal bottom and dead walls on the ends. By analogy with mathematical modeling and in the practice of physical modeling the two-dimensional (planar) and a one-dimensional description of flows on various stretches along its length can be combined. On a river stretch where no noticeable deformations of the flow in plan are expected, the longitudinal scale of the model can be reduced with a corresponding increase of the bottom roughness of the model. The width and depth scales remain unchanged; correspondingly, the velocity and discharge scales remain unchanged. Precisely, this makes it possible to realize in practice two different approaches within the limits of one hydraulic model.
RESEARCH_ORG: All-Union Planning, Surveying, and Sci-Res Institute
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Maine approves user's dam, but mandates conservation
SUBJECT: 32 ENERGY CONSERVATION, CONSUMPTION, AND UTILIZATION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS; ENERGY CONSERVATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; MAINE; LAND USE; ECONOMICS; ENERGY AUDITS; ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY; PERMITS; POWER GENERATION; RETROFITTING; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; AUDITS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; FEDERAL REGION I; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; USA; 320104* - Energy Conservation, Consumption, & Utilization- Commercial & Industrial Buildings- (-1987); 130400 - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 291000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Conservation; 290300 - Energy Planning & Policy- Environment, Health, & Safety
DESCRIPTION: The Maine Land Use Regulation Commission (LURC) will permit the Great Northern Paper Co. to build a $96 million hydroelectric dam, but is stipulating that the firm must first implement any economical conservation measures. The requirement could allow LURC to revoke or suspend the permit. There were 23 conditions to the tentative approval of the project, but Great Northern is confident that the requirements can be met. The 40.5 MW dam will displace more costly electricity sources, but the possibility that in-plant conservation measure might equal or exceed the savings led LURC to require an independent audit to identify conservation opportunities and schedule an implementation program.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy User News; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:41

TITLE: Sheksna river as a route for interbasin water transfer
AUTHORS: Nezhikhovskii, R A; Polikarpov, G I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; WATER RESERVOIRS; WATER SUPPLY; USSR; DAILY VARIATIONS; DIAGRAMS; HOURLY VARIATIONS; LEVELS; RIVERS; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; VARIATIONS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The Sheksna reservoir was formed in 1963 with the construction of the Sheksna hydroelectric station 120 km from the source of the Sheksna from Lake Below. The upper Sheksna as a water transfer route without canalization is discussed. A graph is presented that shows variations of the hourly and daily water levels of the Sheksna during the spring of 1981. The authors calculate the longitudinal profiles of the water surface of the Sheksna for various combinations of the controlling factors. The lower Sheksna as a water transfer route is examined. Results of this study indicate that the use of the lower Sheksna as a route for transferring large water massdS will be accompanied by comparatively small channel deformation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 11:6; Other Information: Translated from Vodnye Resursy, No. 6, pp. 14-27, November-December, 1984

TITLE: New safety for old dams
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; RETROFITTING; SAFETY; COMPLIANCE; CONSTRUCTION; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; FINANCING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NEW YORK; PENNSYLVANIA; REGULATIONS; TUNNELING; WATER RESERVOIRS; FEDERAL REGION II; FEDERAL REGION III; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; USA; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: This article describes the new interest in dam safety as a result of a dam collapsing in Italy and killing residents of a nearby town. The interest comes four years after the Phase I program that identified more than 3,000 US dams as unsafe. Pennsylvania is the state that is farthest along in its rehabilitation program, and gives as one reason for its success that the Department of Environmental Resources has been successful in negotiating consent agreements with dam owners, then setting up schedules for bringing those dams into compliance. Adding hydropower to even a small dam often requires rehabilitation of the dam itself before the plant can be built. Hinkley Dam near Rome, NY is an example of this and is described in the article.
RELATION: Journal Name: Civ. Eng. (N.Y.); (United States); Journal Volume: 55:9

TITLE: Hydropower's newest generation
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; ENGINEERING; FORECASTING; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; WATER RESERVOIRS; WATER RESOURCES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: With the prices of fossil fuels rising and falling, utilities, developers and large electricity users have come to see the benefits of cheap, reliable hydropower. The nation's hydropower plants currently supply about 70,000Mw, or roughly 14% of the nation's electricity needs. This represents just 35% to 40% of the power that could be tapped. Some of the benefits described of hydropower include that it is renewable, nonpolluting, reliable, dependable, flexible and has a low operating and maintenance cost. The major problems cited with hydropower is the bureaucracy involved, such as the EPA-stopped construction of plants because of concern for the fish or their consideration over whether to use the water for recreational purposes or for hydropower.
RELATION: Journal Name: Civ. Eng. (N.Y.); (United States); Journal Volume: 55:8

TITLE: Pricing of natural resources in a regional economy
AUTHORS: Hertel, T W; Mount, T D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 32 ENERGY CONSERVATION, CONSUMPTION, AND UTILIZATION; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; RATE STRUCTURE; INDUSTRY; SUBSIDIES; NEW YORK; ECONOMETRICS; ECONOMIC POLICY; EMPLOYMENT; PRICES; REGIONAL ANALYSIS; ECONOMICS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; FEDERAL REGION II; FINANCIAL INCENTIVES; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; USA; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 320603 - Energy Conservation, Consumption, & Utilization- Municipalities & Community Systems- Public Utilities- (1980-); 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: A computable general equilibrium model for New York State is used to analyze the effects of existing natural resource subsidies as well as the impact of alternative schemes of equal cost. The resource under consideration is hydroelectric power generated by state-owned facilities. Simulations indicate that, measured in terms of employment, the state would be better off selling hydropower to manufacturing at the residential and commercial rate and providing industry with an equal cost labor subsidy instead. This would promote energy conservation through more efficient pricing. 28 references, 5 tables.
RELATION: Journal Name: Land Econ.; (United States); Journal Volume: 61:3

TITLE: A combined hydro-nuclear-solar project for electric power production
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 22 GENERAL STUDIES OF NUCLEAR REACTORS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 14 SOLAR ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; NUCLEAR POWER; SOCIAL IMPACT; TECHNOLOGY IMPACTS; NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS; SOLAR POWER PLANTS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY DEMAND; ORNL; SCIENTIFIC PERSONNEL; DEMAND; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NUCLEAR FACILITIES; PERSONNEL; POWER; POWER PLANTS; PROFESSIONAL PERSONNEL; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; US AEC; US DOE; US ERDA; US ORGANIZATIONS; 296000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 290600 - Energy Planning & Policy- Nuclear Energy; 299001 - Energy Planning & Policy- Solar- (1989-); 299003 - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation- Other- (-1989); 220500 - Nuclear Reactor Technology- Environmental Aspects; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 140300 - Solar Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Some of the main, general-perspective themes of Dr. Alvin Weinberg's leadership and long and varied work are: the effect of present and future nuclear energy projects on society, not only in the United States but throughout the world; analysis, comparison, and combination of various sources of energy; extensive multiple use of nuclear energy complexes (so-called NUPLEX, for nuclear complex) for various areas of the world; and use of ''Big Technology'' and ''Big Science'' for solving, or helping to solve, political problems. A combined hydro-nuclear-solar project for electric power production is discussed, as well as two other energy-related engineering projects. Some of the projects originated or were inspired by work done at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory under the leadership of Dr. Alvin Weinberg. Also reported are the technical characteristics and interrelationships of the three components of the envisaged hydronuclear-solar project.
RESEARCH_ORG: Technion-Israel Institute of Technology, Department of Nuclear Engineering, Haifa
RELATION: Journal Name: Nucl. Sci. Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 90:4

TITLE: Control and protection design of the revelstoke hydroelectric project
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; BRITISH COLUMBIA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONTROL SYSTEMS; EQUIPMENT PROTECTION DEVICES; COMPRESSED GASES; DATA ACQUISITION SYSTEMS; DESIGN; FIBER OPTICS; GAS-INSULATED SUBSTATIONS; OPERATION; PERFORMANCE; RELIABILITY; SWITCHES; CANADA; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; FLUIDS; GASES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; POWER SUBSTATIONS; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: The Revelstoke hydroelectric project on the B.C. Hydro system is a six unit 2910 MV.A remotely controlled powerplant utilizing 500 kV and 230 kV compressed gas insulated switchgear and fiber-optic data acquisition and control techniques. The initial four generating units were placed in service during 1984. The paper describes the basic design of the control and protection aspects of the project with emphasis on approaches taken to provide a high level of operating performance and reliability. Testing techniques and early operating experience are also reported.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Appar. Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: PAS-104:8
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Trans. Power Appar. Syst.; (United States)

TITLE: Electrical design of the Revelstoke hydroelectric project
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; BRITISH COLUMBIA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; PERFORMANCE; COMPRESSED GASES; ELECTRICAL INSULATION; GAS-INSULATED SUBSTATIONS; GEV RANGE 01-10; KEV RANGE 100-1000; OPERATION; POWER TRANSMISSION LINES; SWITCHES; CANADA; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; ENERGY RANGE; EQUIPMENT; FLUIDS; GASES; GEV RANGE; KEV RANGE; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; POWER SUBSTATIONS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 200300 - Electric Power Engineering- Power Transmission & Distribution- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The Revelstoke hydroelectric project on the B.C. Hydro system is a six unit 2910 MV.A powerplant, with four units placed in service in 1984. The paper describes the basic design of the electrical features of the project including the main and station service single lines and the equipment parameters adopted. Special emphasis is placed on the power equipment aspects and the extensive use of 500 kV and 230 kV Compressed Gas Insulated (CGI) bus and switchgear. Some testing and early operating information is reported.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Appar. Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: PAS-104:8
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Trans. Power Appar. Syst.; (United States)

TITLE: New York rules long-term rates available for small-hydro projects, case by case for others
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; RATE STRUCTURE; NEW YORK; PUBLIC UTILITY REGULATORY POLICIES ACT; REGULATIONS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; FEDERAL REGION II; LAWS; NATIONAL ENERGY ACT; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; USA; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: In what has become the continuing story of long-term rate development in New York, the New York Public Service Commission ruled that 15-year contracts providing rates equal to 90.8 mills/kWh on a levelized basis shall henceforth be automatically available only to qualifying hydroelectric projects with a capacity below 20 MW. To the extent it permits additional contracts based on the old rates, the Commission is requiring the rate payers to overpay qualified facilities (by an average of 16.7 mills/kWh) based on more-current avoided-cost estimates.
RELATION: Journal Name: Cogener. Small Power Mon.; (United States)

TITLE: Hydroelectric relicensing: a disputed call for congressional action
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; FEDERAL POWER COMMISSION; REGULATIONS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; OWNERSHIP; COMPETITION; LEGAL ASPECTS; LEGISLATION; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: Hydroelectric power is currently at the center of a controversy between investor-owned utilities and their public counterparts because few, if any, of the problems that beset fossil- and nuclear-fueled electricity production are associated with hydroelectric generation, together with the vague nature of current law and conflicting regulatory interpretation. At issue is municipal preference in hydroelectric relicensing proceedings and whether or not this preference exists under the Federal Power Act. The author traces the roots of the dispute from the Federal Power Act to the current range of bills in Congress that seek to clarify regulations. The prospects for legislative clarification are uncertain given the diametric opposition of the competing interests, although there is a distinct possibility that this congressional session will remove municipal preference.
RELATION: Journal Name: Public Util. Fortn.; (United States); Journal Volume: 115:4; Other Information: Washington and the utilities

TITLE: Productivity, scale economies, and technical change in Ontario Hydro
AUTHORS: Daly, M J; Rao, P S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; CANADA; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ECONOMICS; PRODUCTIVITY; TECHNOLOGY UTILIZATION; ONTARIO; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; PERFORMANCE; SIZING; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: The growing importance of electric utilities in the Canadian economy is reflected in the fact that the share of real domestic product attributable to this sector has increased from 2.1% in 1971 to 2.6% in 1979, with Ontario Hydro accounting for about one-third of the output. An empirical analysis of the production structure of Ontario Hydro reveals the degree of substitution between factor inputs and the contribution to total factor productivity growth of economies of scale, capacity utilization, and technical change. The analysis confirms that there is a legitimate rationale to over-capitalize and add more capacity in order to encourage the substitution of electricity for non-renewable sources. The analysis also suggests a number of steps that would improve Ontario Hydro's performance, with both the federal and provincial governments playing a role. 22 references, 6 tables.
RESEARCH_ORG: Economic Council of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario
RELATION: Journal Name: South. Econ. J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 52:1

TITLE: Thermal cracking in concrete of the Sayano-Shusheskoe dam
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; CONCRETES; CRACK PROPAGATION; TEMPERATURE EFFECTS; THERMAL FATIGUE; DAMS; USSR; CRACKS; FRACTURE MECHANICS; INSPECTION; LEAKS; MODULAR STRUCTURES; THERMAL DEGRADATION; THERMAL STRESSES; ASIA; BUILDING MATERIALS; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; FATIGUE; MATERIALS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; MECHANICS; STRESSES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 360603 - Materials- Properties
DESCRIPTION: The authors make several observations on the cracking of the Sayano-Shushenskoe Dam. First, they state that the dam was constructed of concrete with high thermal properties in blocks whose sizes considerably exceed the analogous parameters for hydraulic structures constructed elsewhere in the area. They state that solidity of the enlarged blocks was provided by traditional technological and technical measures not requiring considerable added expenditure. They conclude that by far the most cracks in the dam have been caused by the use of cantilever formwork which called for early striking of the concrete, and which have a negligible width and depth of penetration into the masses. They state that this cracking does not pose a danger to the structure and that therefore the use of the industrial cantilever formwork was justified. The authors conclude that through cracking in the first column of the dam, related to the presence of inspection galleries at the middle of its width, can be eliminated by locating the latter at a distance of not more than 0.2-0.25 of the column width from the column joint. Finally, they state seepage through the cracks is negligible.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:1; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 1, pp. 16-19, January, 1985

TITLE: Strength of hydrostation trash rack bars
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MECHANICAL FILTERS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; STRESSES; WAVE FORCES; AMPLITUDES; DAMAGE; FOULING; INTAKE STRUCTURES; MATERIALS TESTING; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; RODS; STATIC LOADS; FILTERS; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; POWER PLANTS; TESTING; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
