DESCRIPTION: Trash racks are one of the important parts of the mechanical equipment of hydroelectric stations since their breakage causes shutdown of the turbines until they are repaired. Therefore, the provision of trouble-free operation of racks is of importance. The author states that the most vulnerable part of the rack structure is the bars, which can be damaged both from the static load as a result of clogging and from the stresses occurring during vibration of the bars under the effect of the water passing through them. Used for explaining the processes in the case reported here is the Milovich theory, which does not however touch on all the causes and conditions of increase of oscillation amplitude as it is observed in the laboratory.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:1; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 1, pp. 36-40, January, 1985

TITLE: Approximate modeling of erosion processes in cohesive soils
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CLAYS; EROSION; INLAND WATERWAYS; HYDROLOGY; SOIL MECHANICS; LOAM; BENCH-SCALE EXPERIMENTS; DENSITY; GEOLOGIC MODELS; LIQUID FLOW; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SIMULATION; WATER; FLUID FLOW; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MECHANICS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; SOILS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The author prefaces this paper by stating that a study of the theory of turbulence, fluvial processes, and erosion of channels composed of cohesive soils does not permit solving, with sufficient reliability, a number of problems without appropriate physical modeling. He states that the conducting of on-site investigation is therefore the most reliable for studying these phenomena: however, such methods are costly and labor-intensive, and it is for this reason that laboratory investigations are resorted to. The paper reports on experiments conducted on loam of various densities and with clay of various densities.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:1; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 1, pp. 21-24, January, 1985

TITLE: On-site marking of the axes of the structures of the Shul'binsk hydroelectric station
AUTHORS: Orynbaev, B O; Bersenev, N G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; PLANNING; CALCULATION METHODS; COORDINATES; DESIGN; HYDRAULICS; FLUID MECHANICS; GEOLOGY; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: On-site marking and fixing of the axes of hydraulic structures requires a considerable amount of precision geodetic work; thus the development of a rational method of solving individual problems is of practical importance. This paper presents the authors' experience in marking the axes of structures of the Shul'binsk hydroelectric station with the use of equations of center lines composed on the basis of the design coordinates. For marking the axes, secondorder hydrotechnical triangulation was created in the form of a seven-point central system.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:1; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 1, pp. 19-21, January, 1985

TITLE: Effect of the degree of weathering of the initial rock on the strength properties of rock material
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; CONSTRUCTION; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; WEATHERING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ROCKS; DESIGN; RELIABILITY; ROCK MECHANICS; SOIL MECHANICS; USSR; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: In modern hydropower construction a way of reducing the cost of earth structures is the wide use of soils from useful excavations or from deposits located in the immediate area of the selected site, including low-strength or weathered rocks. This important economic principle found reflection when the design and technology for the construction of the earth-rock dam of the Lower Bureya hydro development project were chosen, and in which the zoned use of lowstrength rock material obtained when excavating the pit for the powerhouse of the hydrostation and when making rock cuts for roads was specified. This paper reports on an engineering-technical comparison of eight dam variants equivalent in reliability and which comparison confirmed the expediency of the Lower Bureya decision.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:1; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 1, pp. 33-35, January, 1985

TITLE: Water-management and power use of the Araks river
AUTHORS: Bagirov, Z A; Bravarnik, S E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; DESIGN; PLANNING; WATER SUPPLY; USSR; RIVERS; AGRICULTURE; FISHERIES; IRRIGATION; WATER RESERVOIRS; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; INDUSTRY; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130601 - Hydro Energy- Land Use & Aesthetics- (-1991 )
DESCRIPTION: This paper reports on the conclusion, from statistical evidence, that without re-regulation of the Araks discharge it would be impossible to meet projected needs of developing irrigation agriculture, fisheries, and other water consumers in the region. The paper discusses the planning, design, and construction of hydroelectric stations on the Araks, as well as the possibility of constructing regulating reservoirs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:1; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 1, pp. 42-47, January, 1985

TITLE: Calculation of safe parameters of air shock waves for underwater explosions
AUTHORS: Smolii, N I; Ganopol'skii, M I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; UNDERWATER EXPLOSIONS; BLAST EFFECTS; CALCULATION METHODS; CHEMICAL EXPLOSIVES; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; EXPLOSIVE FRACTURING; OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY; PRESSURE MEASUREMENT; SHOCK WAVES; UNDERWATER; COMMINUTION; EXPLOSIONS; EXPLOSIVES; FRACTURING; GEOLOGY; LEVELS; SAFETY; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The paper proposes a functional relationship for the calculation of the pressure at an air shock-wave front in underwater explosions of plaster-blasting charges. The maximum permissible mass of the charge and safe distance for objects can be calculated for an assigned value of the critical pressure at the air shock-wave front. The authors also state that this work was conducted as there are practically no significant results of experimental or theoretical investigations of this problem.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:1; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 1, pp. 31-32, January, 1985

TITLE: Consideration of the intraseasonal variation of the probability of maximum discharges
AUTHORS: Belikov, V E; Eremeeva, G I; Kagan, B Y
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FLOOD CONTROL; PLANNING; SITE SURVEYS; RUNOFF; CALCULATION METHODS; SIBERIA; CONSTRUCTION; FLOODS; HYDROLOGY; METEOROLOGY; RAIN WATER; RISK ASSESSMENT; RIVERS; SEASONAL VARIATIONS; ASIA; CONTROL; DISASTERS; EASTERN EUROPE; ENVIRONMENTAL TRANSPORT; EUROPE; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MASS TRANSFER; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; USSR; VARIATIONS; WATER; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The authors present an objective and interrelated calculation which considers intraseasonal variations of equiprobable maximum discharges which can be performed by means of the multiflood method based on more complete than usual use of available runoff information. The method presented here was developed by the Leningrad branch of the All-Union Planning, Surveying, and Scientific-Research Institute by calculations for the nine most studied rivers of Eastern Siberia and the Far East which are characterized by brief and comparatively low meltwater runoff, weak groundwater recharge, and as many as eight recurring, primarily isolated, rainfall floods. Several hydro-developments are under way on these sites, and the authors conclude that the calculation of annual variations of equiprobable discharges performed on the basis of the multiflood method can effect substantial economies in the construction and operation of hydrostations without exceeding the standard permissible degree of risk of destruction of the structure by water overflow.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:1; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 1, pp. 27-30, January, 1985

TITLE: Economic assessment of renewability of hydroelectric power resources
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; USSR; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SERVICE LIFE; WATER RECLAMATION; WATER RESOURCES; WATER USE; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; ECONOMICS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; EUROPE; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: Of the many types of energy being produced by nature, mainly one -- water energy -- has gained industrial significance in modern power-generating facilities. Indeed, for more than 50 years more than one quarter of the world's total electric energy needs has been provided by hydroelectric stations. In fact, in many countries hydro plants account for 10 to 15 percent of the total generating apparatus of power stations. Therefore, an economic analysis of renewability, as presented in this paper, can be considered for now only with respect to the hydroelectric power industry, although the conclusions reached from such analysis can to one degree or another be referred to other types of energy production.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:12; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 12, pp. 8-10, December, 1984

TITLE: Selection and substantiation of the system parameters of pumped-storage stations in the dynamics of development of power systems
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 25 ENERGY STORAGE; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; CAPACITY; EFFICIENCY; LOAD MANAGEMENT; OPERATION; START-UP; CALCULATION METHODS; DAILY VARIATIONS; LOAD ANALYSIS; OPTIMIZATION; PERFORMANCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MANAGEMENT; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; VARIATIONS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 250300 - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The complex character of the effect of a pumped-storage station (PSS) on the structure of an electric power system (EPS) is accompanied by rather profound changes in the latter's operating regime. Proper consideration of the effect of the start-up of a PSS on the structure and regime of an EPS when selecting and substantiating the parameters of a PSS can be provided only on the basis of using methods of optimization of the structure of the generating capacities of the EPS, which should underlie the method of solving the stated problem. However, the direct selection of the system parameters of PSS's in the dynamics of EPS development is a problem difficult to solve. In this paper, a step-by-step solution method is proposed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:12; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 12, pp. 4-7, December, 1984

TITLE: Earthquake resistance of the Nurek dam
AUTHORS: Lyatkher, V M; Ivashchenko, I N; Li, A T
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; IMPACT STRENGTH; SEISMIC EFFECTS; SHOCK ABSORBERS; STRESS ANALYSIS; USSR; EARTHQUAKES; INCLINED STRATA; SHEAR; SHOCK WAVES; SLEEVES; TENSILE PROPERTIES; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; GEOLOGIC STRATA; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; SEISMIC EVENTS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The 300-m-high Nurek dam was designed and constructed with compressed, economical profile with a steepness of the upstream slope of 1:2.25. Modern earth dams in seismically active regions are often designed with flatter upstream slopes. Longterm investigation into the design and construction of the Nurek dam have made possible considerable progress in solving the problem of increasing the reliability and earthquake resistance of high earth dams being built in regions with high seismicity. The Nurek dam was constructed with a high earthquake resistance in conformity with standards. The technical decision on reinforcing earth dams by means of structural methods of the antiseismic collar type, accomplished at the Nurek dam, is reliable, cost effective and promising. The authors conclude that it is expedient to continue the development and investigation of such measures and to broaden the sphere of their use.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:12; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 12, pp. 14-20, December, 1984

TITLE: Characteristics of the first stage of constructing the Hoabinh Dam in Vietnam
AUTHORS: Bogachenko, P T; Godunov, B I; Phunc Ne, T
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; DESIGN; ROCK MECHANICS; SOIL MECHANICS; VIET NAM; ALLUVIAL DEPOSITS; FLOODS; FOUNDATIONS; GROUND SUBSIDENCE; HYDRAULICS; SANDSTONES; SOIL CHEMISTRY; ASIA; CHEMISTRY; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; DISASTERS; FLUID MECHANICS; GEOLOGIC DEPOSITS; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; ROCKS; SEDIMENTARY ROCKS; SUPPORTS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: As a result of an analysis of the data, investigations, and on-site observations at the Hoa-Binh Dam, Vietnam, the authors conclude: infilling of the rock mass with sand, successful for the Aswan dam, cannot be mechanically transferred to other dams; the possibility of using the energy of the river flow for removing low-quality soils in large amounts from the foundation of rock-fill dams by regulating the sequence of dumping the elements of the dam was confirmed in model investigations and successfully accomplished in the construction of the HoaBinh dam; at the site of the Hoa-Binh dam, observations of the dumping of the sand-gravel soil into water into a high shoulder did not reveal segregation of this soil, however, the data from investigations in a single borehole contradict the observations -- further on-site observation must therefore be made.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:12; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 12, pp. 39-43, December, 1984

TITLE: Calculation of slope stability with the use of the hypothesis of cylindrical surfaces of sliding
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; ROCK MECHANICS; SLOPE STABILITY; SOIL MECHANICS; BENCH-SCALE EXPERIMENTS; CALCULATION METHODS; CYLINDERS; GEOPHYSICS; GROUND MOTION; PERFORMANCE TESTING; SLIDING FRICTION; STABILITY; FRICTION; MECHANICS; MOTION; TESTING; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The complexity and uncertainty of the physical aspect of the phenomenon of failure of an earth slope are manifested in the diversity of available methods of calculation. The modern hydraulic engineering literature contains methods using the theory of limit equilibrium and those based on calculation of the general stress-strain state of an earth structure, simultaneously estimating the stability of the slopes. The authors propose a probabilistic approach to calculation which makes it possible to give an objective estimate of the stability of earth slopes. In this case it is also possible to isolate the parameters which have the greatest effect on stability in order to conduct, if necessary, additional experimental investigations in pursuit of refinement.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:12; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 12, pp. 20-24, December, 1984

TITLE: Stochastic optimization of a multireservoir hydroelectric system: a decomposition approach
AUTHORS: Pereira, M V.F.; Pinto, L M.V.G.
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; OPTIMIZATION; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; ALGORITHMS; BRAZIL; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; MANAGEMENT; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PLANNING; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; ECONOMICS; LATIN AMERICA; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; POWER PLANTS; SIMULATION; SOUTH AMERICA; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 200102 - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Power Cycles
DESCRIPTION: A computational scheme that is able to determined at each stage the most economical generation decision for each plant of a hydrothermal system is presented. The algorithm is based on the stochastic extension of Benders decomposition and can be implemented from already existing operation models. The results can be used in the weekly or monthly generation scheduling activities in real-time operation. A case study with 37 reservoirs of the Brazilian system is presented and discussed.
RESEARCH_ORG: CEPEL, Centro de Pesquisas de Energia Eletrica, Rio de Janerio, Brazil
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:6

TITLE: Satellite survey saves utility time and money
SUBJECT: 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; AERIAL SURVEYING; INTERFEROMETRY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; SITE SELECTION; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; LAND USE; RIGHTS-OF-WAY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; 200203* - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Waste Management- Site Selection & Land Use; 250300 - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989); 130601 - Hydro Energy- Land Use & Aesthetics- (-1991 ); 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: The Oglethorpe Power Corp. saved money and made a more accurate survey for a proposed pumped storage hydro plant using an innovative satellite surveying technique. The $22,000 satellite service by Aero Service of Houston took only five days to cover the 26 areas of rugged terrain and heavy forest in Georgia. The utility is considering three sites for a 675 MW plant to begin operating in the mid-1990s. Aero Service uses a network of seven satellites designed for military use as a commercial user. The company devised the interferometric system, MACROMETER V-1000, to survey rights-of-way and other potential utility sites. It expects the service to become increasingly cost-effective. 2 figures.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. Light Power; (United States); Journal Volume: 63:5

TITLE: Calculation of wave diffraction on reservoirs of hydroelectric and nuclear power stations
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 22 GENERAL STUDIES OF NUCLEAR REACTORS; DAMS; HYDRODYNAMICS; WATER RESERVOIRS; WATER WAVES; DIFFRACTION; CALCULATION METHODS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS; WAVE PROPAGATION; COHERENT SCATTERING; FLUID MECHANICS; GRAVITY WAVES; MECHANICS; NUCLEAR FACILITIES; POWER PLANTS; SCATTERING; SURFACE WATERS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 220200 - Nuclear Reactor Technology- Components & Accessories
DESCRIPTION: Wave diffraction is an essential factor when determining the wave regime on protected water areas. On reservoirs of nuclear and hydroelectric power stations the role of moles (breakwaters) is performed by guide banks. At present, a number of theoretical solutions and methods of calculating wave diffraction on water areas protected by single or convergent moles are known. However, in such frequently encountered cases of the layout of water areas as protection by offset or overlapping moles, when the projection of the width of the inlet b less than or equal to O and secondary deformation occurs, the standard method cannot be used. Thus, it is necessary to develop a method to calculate wave diffraction free as far as possible of the shortcomings of the standard method. In this paper the author proposes a solution of the problem of wave diffraction on water areas which is obtained from the Helmholtz equation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:11; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 11, pp. 19-22, November, 1984

TITLE: Calculation of the air-capturing ability of a flow behind an aerator ledge
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SPILLWAY; DUCTS; HYDRAULICS; WATER; AERATION; AERODYNAMICS; AIR FLOW; CALCULATION METHODS; CAVITATION; EROSION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LIQUID FLOW; OXYGEN ENRICHMENT; TWO-PHASE FLOW; ENRICHMENT; FLUID FLOW; FLUID MECHANICS; GAS FLOW; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MECHANICS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POWER PLANTS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: Aerators are used for saturating the bottom layers of a flow with air, which is an effective measure for controlling cavitation erosion, and they also provide intense oxygen enrichment of the water. An aerator usually consists of a device providing separation of the flow from solid boundaries (ledge, ski-jump bucket, or their combination along with a groove) and a system ventilating the separation zone. The air can enter under the nappe through flow separation regions near the side walls and behind piers or through special air ducts, as for example, on the San Roque chute spillway. The main difficulty when calculating aerators is a determination of the air-capturing ability of the flow. It is necessary to know the discharge of the air entrained by the flow as a function of the vacuum in the space under the nappe, since these parameters are the initial ones for calculating the air ducts. The authors present here the calculation of the air-capturing ability of a flow behind an aerator ledge.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:11; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 11, pp. 37-39, November, 1984

TITLE: Consideration of the effect of maximum runoff when determining the reliability of structures
AUTHORS: Zalesskii, F V; Krashnikov, A F
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; RUNOFF; SERVICE LIFE; EROSION; FAILURES; FLOOD CONTROL; FOUNDATIONS; HYDRAULICS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RELIABILITY; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; CONTROL; ENVIRONMENTAL TRANSPORT; FLUID MECHANICS; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; MASS TRANSFER; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; SUPPORTS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: In that the ''Regulations on taking into account the degree of importance of buildings and structures when designing structural elements,'' the standard ST SEV 384-76 and the construction specifications and regulations SNiP II-50-74 examine the reliability of the structural element itself, the authors believe that when designing structures, especially hydraulic, it is also necessary to establish the principles of reliability with respect to the passage of the maximum runoff. Reference here is to water-conveyance works in various categories -- hydraulic, transport, reclamation, etc. The authors take into account the probability of the parameters of the hydrologic phenomenon acting on the structure and establish this probability on the basis of probability theory and mathematical statistics with consideration to the service life of the structure and to its degree of importance and the economic and social consequences of its failure.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:11; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stov, No. 11, pp. 41-43, November, 1984

TITLE: Results of investigating the effect of cavitation in hydroabrasive wear of elements of the water passageway of axial-flow pumps
AUTHORS: Mamazhonov, M M; Denisov, A I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; WATER PUMPS; ABRASION; CAVITATION; PERFORMANCE TESTING; WEAR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INSPECTION; LIQUID FLOW; MACHINE PARTS; PARTICULATES; TWO-PHASE FLOW; FLUID FLOW; PARTICLES; POWER PLANTS; PUMPS; TESTING; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: On-site observation of the operation of hydraulic machines and the long experience of operating and pumping stations show that abrasive and cavitation-abrasive wear play the main role in the failure of parts of hydraulic turbines and pumps operating on streams with a high turbidity. The effect of wear as a result of cavitation and the action of sediments are displayed as loss of efficiency of the machines and overconsumption of electric energy related to it, the need to conduct repair and restoration, and a decrease in the delivery of water as a consequence of an increase of the design gaps. As a result of this investigation the authors conclude that having established a generalizing relationship between the rate of cavitation-abrasive wear and the set of parameters will make it possible to select with some degree of validity the suction heads of various types and sizes of pumps which can have a significant effect on the amount if capital investment required in the construction of pump units.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:11; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 11, pp. 22-27, 1984

TITLE: Mechanical equipment of the Dnestr Multipurpose Hydropower Development
AUTHORS: Beketov, M V; Fedorov, B A; Oservaser, Y S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; USSR; CRANES; DAMS; INTAKE STRUCTURES; RIVERS; SPILLWAY; STRUCTURAL BEAMS; SUPPORTS; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; EQUIPMENT; EUROPE; MATERIALS HANDLING EQUIPMENT; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: A review of the mechanical equipment of the Dnestr. Multipurpose Hydropower Development discloses that the construction of a trestle with crabs of the service gantry cranes on the gated wall of the upper pool made it possible to operate the gates under conditions of incomplete construction, which provided start-up of all units on time. Secondly, the use of service gates during construction eliminated the construction of additional temporary flashboards and the concomitant consumption of metal. Third, the use of structural elements of the concrete-buggy trestle of the Sayano-Shushenskoe hydrostation instead of the earlier specified reinforced-concrete elements of the bridge and crane beams considerably simplified fabrication and shortened assembly time. Finally, the timely design developments for the mechanical equipment in the construction period, correlated to the actual conditions at the construction site, made it possible to accomplish the assembly works in the shortest possible time.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:11; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 11, pp. 10-12, November, 1984

TITLE: Ways to improve the technology of constructing concrete hydraulic structures
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CONCRETES; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INTAKE STRUCTURES; BUILDING MATERIALS; MATERIALS; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The authors state that there is a need for a critical analysis of the established technology of constructing massive concrete structures and for the search for new, cheap, faster, and less labor-intensive designs when constructing concrete dams. Improvement of the technology of constructing concrete hydraulic structures is possible, they say, by introducing the following suggestions: construction of massive structures mainly from a very stiff, low-cement concrete mix compacted by the vibrating roller method; use of poured self-compacting concrete mixes when constructing reinforced-concrete structural elements of hydrostations, water intakes, tunnel linings, etc.; and by development of the technology of delivering stiff concrete mixes by conveyors and their placement by rotary throwers when revetting slopes. This paper examines these elements in detail.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:11; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 11, pp. 4-6, November, 1984

TITLE: Calculation of the stability of deep strip foundations
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FOUNDATIONS; DEPTH; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; STABILITY; CALCULATION METHODS; DAMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INCLINATION; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; SOIL MECHANICS; STATIC LOADS; DIMENSIONS; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; SUPPORTS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: It has been demonstrated that it is possible to calculate the stability of surface foundations on a sand base for both vertical and inclined center loads, the solution being based on the hypothesis that failure of the base occurs along a line of sliding represented by a logarithmic spiral passing from the edge of the foundation to its emergence on the surface. However, the overwhelming majority of foundations being constructed on soft soils have a certain founding depth. In hydrotechnical construction deep strip foundations are used almost exclusively. In this connection, a calculation of the stability of foundations with consideration of their depth is crucial, since the founding depth has a substantial effect on the value of the critical force. In this paper the author investigates this problem.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:11; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 11, pp. 40-41, November, 1984

TITLE: Stability of the Zhitomir cellular buttress dam
AUTHORS: Zeryukov, V I; Karlin, S I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; DESIGN; IN-SERVICE INSPECTION; STABILITY; UKRAINIAN SSR; CRACKS; FLOOD CONTROL; FOUNDATIONS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; MONITORING; PERFORMANCE; RIVERS; ROCK MECHANICS; SPILLWAY; ASIA; CONTROL; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; INSPECTION; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; STREAMS; SUPPORTS; SURFACE WATERS; USSR; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: This paper reports on the results of inspections of the Zhitomir dam, which show that during its 15-year operation the negligible cracks that have appeared have not affected the strength of the structure. This confirms the main theoretical and construction decisions made in planning the dam. Secondly, to improve monitoring of the conditions of hydraulic structures in general, the authors recommend that they be equipped with measuring instruments such as height markers and piezometers.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:11; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 11, pp. 15-18, November, 1984

TITLE: Results of experimental drilling and blasting operations in preparing the rock foundation of the Krapivinskii hydroelectric station
AUTHORS: Azarovich, A E; Yanovskii, V N
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; EXPLOSIVE FRACTURING; PERFORMANCE TESTING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; ROCK DRILLING; USSR; CONCRETES; DAMS; FOUNDATIONS; JOINING; ROCK MECHANICS; ASIA; BUILDING MATERIALS; COMMINUTION; DRILLING; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; FABRICATION; FRACTURING; MATERIALS; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; SUPPORTS; TESTING; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The purpose of the experimental drilling and blasting operations in preparing the rock foundation of the Krapivinskii hydrostation was to test under specific conditions the parameters of blasting near the lower contour of the pit with reduced blasthole charges. Results show: the possibility of replacing shothole by blasthole charges with parameters calculated by a special method; the suitability of the method of calculating the parameters of DBO's with reduced blasthole charges developed earlier by Gidrospetsproekt, which provides preservation of the foundations of important structures with a reduction of labor intensity and work time, was confirmed; an analysis of the results of the experimental blasts and also for a number of hydrotechnical construction objects made it possible to evaluate the characteristics of irregularities of foundations with blasting preparation and to establish their practically allowable values for use in specifications; rational parameters of blasting near the foundation of the Krapivinskii hydrostation were determined.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:11; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 11, pp. 12-15, November, 1984

TITLE: Simulator study of a vertical axis wind turbine generator connected to a small hydro network
AUTHORS: Lefebvre, S; Dessaint, L; Dube, B; Nakra, H; Perocheau, A
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 17 WIND ENERGY; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LOAD MANAGEMENT; VERTICAL AXIS TURBINES; CONTROL; SIMULATION; AC SYSTEMS; DAMPING; DC SYSTEMS; ELECTRICAL FAULTS; INTERCONNECTED POWER SYSTEMS; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; OPERATION; ENERGY SYSTEMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MACHINERY; MANAGEMENT; POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; WIND TURBINES; 299003* - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation- Other- (-1989); 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 170602 - Wind Energy Engineering- Turbine Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The paper describes a simulator study of a vertical axis wind turbine generator connected to a small isolated hydro network. The connection to the network is done through a back-to-back dc link, which is used as a static frequency changer. The penetration level of the wind turbine is in the range 13% - 33% of the rating of the AC network. The study includes the transient performance of the dc link and the wind turbine drive during electrical braking and for system disturbances such as AC system faults. The study shows that the use of a stabilization signal in the dc link helps to reduce large torsional vibrations in the wind turbine low speed shaft. These vibrations are observed after AC system faults. The study also shows that it is possible to obtain satisfactory operation of the overall system by adopting suitable control strategies.
RESEARCH_ORG: Institut de Recherche d'Hydro-Quebec (IREQ), Varennes, Quebec
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Appar. Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: PAS-104:5
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Trans. Power Appar. Syst.; (United States)

TITLE: The use of photography to record geologic data
SUBJECT: 03 NATURAL GAS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 22 GENERAL STUDIES OF NUCLEAR REACTORS; DAMS; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; SITE SURVEYS; GEOLOGIC SURVEYS; PHOTOGRAPHY; LNG PLANTS; NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS; DATA PROCESSING; IMAGE PROCESSING; IMAGES; GEOLOGY; NUCLEAR FACILITIES; POWER PLANTS; PROCESSING; SURVEYS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 030300* - Natural Gas- Drilling, Production, & Processing; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 220501 - Nuclear Reactor Technology- Environmental Aspects- Siting
DESCRIPTION: Although photography is generally used today by geologists to record important data and features of interest, no strong effort has been made to systematically photo-document preliminary investigations and siting of critical facilities such as nuclear power plants, Liquified Natural Gas (LNG) terminals, or dams At a time when the safe siting of critical facilities is coming under ever closer scrutiny by regulatory agencies and the public, the importance and usefulness of photographic evidence and authentication is clear. Photography by no means replaces the accurate, detailed log or map. However, when used together, the photograph and graphic log or map can provide a clearer, more understandable representation of geologic data. This can be extremely important to the non-technical reviewer or decision maker. A simple method of presenting documentary photographs has been used for the proposed LNG facility at Little Cojo Bay, near Point Conception, California. This method combines both geologic data and photographic images through the use of clear mylar or acetate overlays.
RESEARCH_ORG: Slosson and Associates, Van Nuys, CA
RELATION: Journal Name: Bull. Assoc. Eng. Geol.; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:2

TITLE: Application of soil-stratigraphic techniques to engineering geology
SUBJECT: 03 NATURAL GAS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 22 GENERAL STUDIES OF NUCLEAR REACTORS; DAMS; SITE SELECTION; SOIL MECHANICS; LNG PLANTS; NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS; SEDIMENTS; AGE ESTIMATION; STRATIGRAPHY; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; GEOMORPHOLOGY; PALEONTOLOGY; QUATERNARY PERIOD; RADIOMETRIC ANALYSIS; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; CENOZOIC ERA; CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; GEOLOGIC AGES; GEOLOGY; MECHANICS; NUCLEAR FACILITIES; POWER PLANTS; QUANTITATIVE CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 030300* - Natural Gas- Drilling, Production, & Processing; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 220501 - Nuclear Reactor Technology- Environmental Aspects- Siting
DESCRIPTION: Soil-stratigraphic techniques are being increasingly applied to engineeringgeological investigations for siting liquified natural gas (LNG) facilities, nuclear reactors, dams, and other critical structures. Soil (pedological) profiles in Quaternary sections are useful to ascertain the approximate age of sitearea sediments, to reconstruct local geomorphic history, to date the last movement of faults, and in some cases to determine recurrence intervals of displacements associated with faults or large mass-movements. Exemplified in geotechnical investigations for a proposed LNG terminal near Point Conception (Little Cojo Bay), California, soil stratigraphy was employed to date last displacement of site-area faults, to estimate age of marine platforms, and to help reconstruct regional geomorphic history. Similarly, at the General Electric Test Reactor (GETR) site near Livermore (Vallecitos), California, soil stratigraphy was instrumental to date last displacement and recurrence of site-area slip surfaces engendered either by tectonic or by mass-wasting processes. Datable markers included four, strongly-developed buried paleosols, each of which marked epochs of regional landscape stability during the Quaternary.
RELATION: Journal Name: Bull. Assoc. Eng. Geol.; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:2

TITLE: Mortality of juvenile American shad and blueback herring passed through a low-head Kaplan hydroelectric turbine
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FISHES; MORTALITY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; CONNECTICUT RIVER; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; JUVENILES; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; VERTEBRATES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Immediate mortality of juvenile alosids, American shad Alosa sapidissima and blueback herring A. aestivalis, passed through the 17-MW Kaplan turbine at Holyoke Dam on the Connecticut River was estimated with mark-capture methods. Turbine-induced mortality was 62% at 16.5-MW generation, 82% at 12 MW, and 82% at 5.5 MW. The significantly lower mortality of fish at full power output is thought to be related to greater turbine efficiency. 15 references, 1 figure, 2 tables.
RESEARCH_ORG: Univ. of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA (United States)
RELATION: Journal Name: Trans. Am. Fish. Soc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 114:3

TITLE: Swan Lake Dam: a study in cost saving
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ALASKA; CAPITALIZED COST; COST; FEDERAL REGION X; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; USA; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The construction of the dam for the Swan Lake hydroelectric project in Alaska is discussed. The hydro project was built for an estimated $4.3 million less than conventional hydro dams of this scope. The project highlights are given.
RELATION: Journal Name: Alaska Constr. Oil; (United States)

TITLE: Toward a better procedure for contested hydroelectric relicensing
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; US FERC; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power

TITLE: Experience in operating the hydraulic structures of the Borisoglebsk hydroelectric station
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; HYDRAULICS; OPERATION; PERFORMANCE; USSR; CONSTRUCTION; DAMS; HYDRAULIC EQUIPMENT; INTAKE STRUCTURES; LEAKS; OUTLET STRUCTURES; REPAIR; STRATA CONTROL; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; EQUIPMENT; EUROPE; FLUID MECHANICS; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The authors examine the characteristics of the Borisoglebsk hydroelectric station, including: the concrete buttress dams, intake of the hydrostation, the headrace free-flow tunnel, the surge chamber, the penstocks, the water passageway, the powerhouse and the tailrace diversion. They further discuss the operating characteristics of the hydraulic structures and their repair. From the study they conclude: the long operating experience of the hydrostation on the whole shows a sufficiently high level of reliability of the hydraulic structures; most operating difficulties are related to rockfalls in the unsupported parts of the underground workings and seepage into the tunnels and rooms; and, the repair and construction works on the hydro development are distinguished by a great diversity--their necessary volume inevitably increases with time in connection with the constant aging of all structures.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:3; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 3, pp. 34-39, March, 1985

TITLE: Operation of the underground diversion of the Borisoglebsk hydroelectric station
AUTHORS: Yashkul', D M; Kaminarov, V I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TUNNELS; CLEANING; EROSION; ROCK MECHANICS; USSR; DUCTS; INTAKE STRUCTURES; LIQUID FLOW; OPERATION; ROCKS; SHUTDOWNS; STRATA CONTROL; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; FLUID FLOW; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; UNDERGROUND FACILITIES; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The authors state that the results of observations and inspections of unlined tunnels prove that exfoliation of rock and falls of individual blocks should be regarded as an ordinary event accompanying tunnel operation. They state that only extensive support of the roof and walls over the entire surface can completely protect tunnels from exfoliation of rocks. Under operating conditions this will require shutdown of the hydrostation for a long time, and considerable expenditure. They state that under established conditions it is more rational to periodically empty the tunnels for a short time for clearing accumulated rock material. They add that the installation of intercepting racks helps to reduce the amount of rock being carried by the flow to the units.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:3; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 3, pp. 39-42, March, 1985

TITLE: Characteristics of the ice and thermal regime of the Gunt River in connection with the design of the Pamir hydroelectric station
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; RIVERS; FREEZING; USSR; DESIGN; HEAT TRANSFER; HEATING; ICE; INTAKE STRUCTURES; PLANNING; SEASONAL VARIATIONS; TEMPERATURE DISTRIBUTION; THERMODYNAMICS; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; ENERGY TRANSFER; ENGINEERING; EUROPE; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; VARIATIONS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The authors examine the characteristics of the ice and thermal regime of the Gunt River in connection with the planning of a cascade of hydrostations on the river. The thermal regime of a mountain river is determined by the amount of heat contained in the water mass and its change along the length of the river as a consequence of heat exchange of the water surface with the atmosphere. On the basis of the characteristics of the winter thermal regime, the authors schematically divide the investigated river into six stretches. They determine by this analysis that under conditions of a winter of normal severity, the stretch of the site of the Pamir No. 1 hydrostation is in a zone of increased probability of icing, and so in the design it is necessary to use structural and regime measures to prevent icing of the stationary parts of gates and to heat the trash racks. Further, to prevent the flow of shuga to the water intake, it is advisable to construct a shuga-retaining boom.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:3; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 3, pp. 26-29, March, 1985

TITLE: Evaluation of the Polubarinova-Kochina formula for the dam problem
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; FLOW MODELS; EVALUATION; GROUND WATER; LEAKS; LIQUID FLOW; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; POROUS MATERIALS; FLUID FLOW; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MATERIALS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; WATER; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The stationary problem of unconfined groundwater flow through a rectangular dam has been solved by P. Ya. Polubarinova-Kochina. In this paper the analytical formulas are used to obtain accurate numerical values for the phreatic surface and for the height of the seepage face. These values provide a reference with which to compare numerical methods for seepage problems.
RESEARCH_ORG: Hochschule der Bundeswehr Muenchen, West Germany
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:3

TITLE: Hydropower engineering of the Northern Caucasus
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CAUCASUS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; EXPLOITATION; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; PLANNING; SITE SELECTION; CONSTRUCTION; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; DAMS; FUEL SUBSTITUTION; HYDROLOGY; LEVELS; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; SURFACE WATERS; USSR; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; ENGINEERING; EUROPE; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The results of an examination of the prospects of hydropower construction in the Northern Caucasus showed that the development of the unused part of the economic hydropotential will make it possible to save about 4 million tons of reference fuel. The authors add that to solve problems of the further development of hydropotential in the area it is necessary to examine from current standpoints the problem of siting regulating storages in the basin of the Terek River, for which schemes for the multipupose use of all main Terek tributaries should be developed. They conclude that when planning various watermanagement installations in the Northern Caucasus it is necessary to examine the economic expediency of using the drops of the water levels created on the hydraulic structures for including small hydrostations as part of these structures.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:3; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 3, pp. 13-17, March, 1985

TITLE: Calculation of the size of ice hummocks
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DYNAMIC LOADS; IMPACT STRENGTH; ICEBERGS; SIZE; CALCULATION METHODS; DISTRIBUTION; IMPACT SHOCK; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; SEASONAL VARIATIONS; ICE; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; POWER PLANTS; VARIATIONS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: Ice hummocks are often seen during the breakup of water bodies and are the result of shifting of the ice cover during spring movements and are confined both to the shore slope, or exposed stretches of the bottom, and to shallow waters. At the same time, the shore is often used for needs of construction, transportation, power engineering and economic purposes, and cases of damage to structures and disruption of operations by ice hummocks are known. The authors therefore study here the character and extent of the phenomenon as it affects the design of shore engineering structures. They add that existing standards do not fully reflect the composition of ice loads on structures, in connection with which it is expedient to theorize as regards the expected size of ice hummocks.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:3; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 3, pp. 29-31, March, 1985

TITLE: Stress-strain state of unsealed gravity dams
AUTHORS: Elizarov, E N; Khelevin, V I; Lamkin, M S; Smyslova, N N
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; SEISMIC EFFECTS; STRESS ANALYSIS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CALCULATION METHODS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; DYNAMIC LOADS; RELIABILITY; SEALS; STRAINS; STRESSES; POWER PLANTS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: Current methods for calculating dams permit investigating the stress-strain state of such structures; however, so far a lack of confidence in the possibility of a calculated substantiation of the reliability of high unsealed dams is sometimes encountered. In this paper the authors therefore attempt to confirm this possibility by a comparative analysis of the stress state of sealed and unsealed dams. The main conclusion of the work is that with fulfillment of the standard requirements imposed on the stress state, the unsealed dams with batter-arranged stepped joints have, under operating loads (in regions with a high seismicity the reliability of unsealed dams should be additionally investigated), a reliability no less than that of sealed dams, with vertical columnar masses being constructed under analogous conditions.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:3; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 3, pp. 17-22, March, 1985

TITLE: The Shamkhor hydro development
AUTHORS: Aliev, E V; Gamidov, R A; Polstyanov, P A; Seidov, A G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; DESIGN; USSR; CAPITALIZED COST; DAMS; DRINKING WATER; FLOODS; INTAKE STRUCTURES; IRRIGATION; LAND USE; RIVERS; TRANSPORT; WATER RESERVOIRS; WATER SUPPLY; ASIA; COST; DISASTERS; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; WATER; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 130601 - Hydro Energy- Land Use & Aesthetics- (-1991 )
DESCRIPTION: A river valley with an inselberg structure was selected as the site of the Shamkhor hydro development. The inselberg -- a residual upland located in the middle of the valley -- is used as the connecting link and is the unified barrier for joining the channel and floodplain dams which considerably reduced the volume of earthworks and construction time. Placement of soils from useful cuts in the dams sharply reduced transportation costs on hauling soils, and the location of borrow pits in the flowage lands reduced the areas of farmlands being taken away for construction. The selected variant of the location, layout, and design of an individual irrigation intake, instead of the original variant combined with the intake of the hydrostation, provides continuous delivery of water for irrigation and domestic drinking water supply in a wide range of reservoir water levels, with a considerable reduction of investments in the irrigation structures of the hydro development.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:3; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 3, pp. 1-8, March, 1985

TITLE: Engineering-geological conditions of construction of the Shamkor hydro development on the Kura River
AUTHORS: Malyutkin, B V; Molokov, L A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; USSR; DESIGN; DUCTS; FLOODS; FORECASTING; HYDROLOGY; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; RIVERS; ASIA; DISASTERS; EASTERN EUROPE; ENGINEERING; EUROPE; GEOLOGY; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The authors review here the assessment of the engineeringgeological conditions given during geological substantiation during construction of the Shamkhor hydro development on the Kura River. They state that on the whole the assessment proved to be reliable, and the slight refinements made during documentation of the pits did not lead to fundamental revision of the design decisions. They state that the noted differences between the actual geological structure and the geological prediction are confined to the junction of geomorphological elements -- between the ancient floodplain and inselberg and between the left-bank projection and the modern floodplain and channel. It is therefore recommended that such stretches be explored with a denser network of workings.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:3; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 3, pp. 8-12, March, 1985

TITLE: Deformation of river channels in the dam stretch
AUTHORS: Zubets, V M; Stankevich, V N
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; BYELORUSSIAN SSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RIVERS; DEFORMATION; WATER RESERVOIRS; DAMS; HYDRODYNAMICS; HYDROLOGY; LEVELS; MASS DISTRIBUTION; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; SEDIMENTS; VOLGA RIVER; ASIA; DISTRIBUTION; EASTERN EUROPE; ENGINEERING; EUROPE; FLUID MECHANICS; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; USSR; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The construction of small reservoirs leads to a radical change in the natural hydrologic regime of a river, this being expressed mainly in the annual redistribution of the water discharge and partial or complete retention of the sediment load by the reservoir. Scour of river channels in the lower pool, observed during operation of large reservoirs, usually leads to a drop of the water level and bottom, but in certain cases a rise of the bottom and water surface is noted. This was observed in the lower pool of the Volga-Lenin hydroelectric station. The authors present here the results of an investigation of deformations in the dam stretch of small reservoirs of Belorussia, showing that an analogous phenomenon of a rise of the bottom and water surface is observed in almost all cases.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:3; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 3, pp. 31-33, March, 1985

TITLE: Estimating the accuracy of arranging smooth blasting holes under field conditions
AUTHORS: Azarovich, A E; Kolosnitsena, E A; Shuifer, M I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; BOREHOLES; SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION; EXPLOSIVE FRACTURING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; CALCULATION METHODS; DAMS; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; INCLINATION; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; ROCK MECHANICS; CAVITIES; COMMINUTION; DISTRIBUTION; ENGINEERING; FRACTURING; GEOLOGY; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: On the basis of data obtained under field conditions, an estimation is made of the accuracy of arranging smooth blasting holes with separate consideration of two influencing factors -displacement of the hole mouths and variation of the slope angle of the holes relative to the design position. A criterion of the permissible deviation of distances between holes is obtained and recommended for use as a standard. It is finally recommended to take into account the presence of deviations in the distance between holes when assigning this parameter in a design on the basis of the calculated distance between the charges and value of the criterion of deviation of distances for specific conditions.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:3; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 3, pp. 22-26, March, 1985

TITLE: Big A affair. [Big Ambejackmockamus Falls, Penobscot River, Maine]
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; LAND USE; MAINE; ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY; PAPER INDUSTRY; ENERGY CONSERVATION; DAMS; ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY; PUBLIC OPINION; RECREATIONAL AREAS; RIVERS; WATER USE; FEDERAL REGION I; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; INDUSTRY; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; USA; WOOD PRODUCTS INDUSTRY; 130601* - Hydro Energy- Land Use & Aesthetics- (-1991 )
DESCRIPTION: This article describes the conflict between proponents of a hydroelectric power plant on Maine's Penobscot River and recreation interests. Great Northern Paper Company filed application to build a dam on a wild stretch of the river used by sports fishermen and white-water enthusiasts. Great Northern claimed that it needed to replace 380,000 barrels of oil and to forego the purchase of 36,000 megawatt-hours of electricity annually to improve its competitive edge in the marketplace. The controversy will be a big issue for Maine's Land Use Regulatory Commission. The final decision will hinge on the Commission's perception of the greater public benefit - hydropower or recreation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. For.; (United States); Journal Volume: 91:2

TITLE: Preparation of the structure of the Hoa-Binh hydro development for passage of the flood
AUTHORS: Bogachenko, P G; Godunov, B I; Tsedrov, G N
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; COMPUTER-AIDED DESIGN; FLOOD CONTROL; HYDRAULICS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RIVERS; VIET NAM; ASIA; CONTROL; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; FLUID MECHANICS; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: After damming the Da River (Vietnam) in January of 1983, construction of flood structures began. The authors describe model hydraulic investigations that were used to substantiate the technical decisions made for safe passage of the May-June floods through diversion canals.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:2; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 2, pp. 52-55, February, 1985

TITLE: Effect of welding technology on regularities of low-cycle deformation and failure of steel 13KhGMF butt joints
