DESCRIPTION: An increase of the single and specific capacity of turbogenerator units of hydroelectric stations necessitates the use of high strength steels in these structures. The authors discuss the various technological variants of forming the welded joints of steel-13KhGMF used in hydrotechnical construction. Since the working conditions of pressure conduits are distinguished by a certain cyclicity of the loads, absorbed problems of the effect of welding technology on regularities of deformation and failure of the welded joints of the steel during low-cyclic loading are of practical interest.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:2; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 2, pp. 28-31, February, 1985

TITLE: Watertight elements of earth hydraulic structures
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; WATERPROOFING; SEALING MATERIALS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; POLYMERS; MATERIALS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The authors examine nonsoil sealing materials for increasing the watertightness of earth dams. The authors suggest that polymer film facings are the most economic type of surfacing material.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:2; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 2, pp. 17-20, February, 1985

TITLE: Practical implications in the use of stochastic dynamic programming for reservoir operation
AUTHORS: Goulter, I C; Tai, F K
SUBJECT: 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DYNAMIC PROGRAMMING; PERFORMANCE TESTING; WATER RESOURCES; MANAGEMENT; OPERATION; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; PROGRAMMING; RESOURCES; SIMULATION; TESTING; 990200* - Mathematics & Computers; 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: A stochastic dynamic programming model is applied to a small hydroelectric system. The variation in number of stage iterations and the computer time required to reach steady state conditions with changes in the number of storage states is investigated. The increase in computer time required to develop the storage probability distributions with increase in the number of storage states is reviewed. It it found that for an average of seven inflow states, the largest number of storage states for which it is computationally feasible to develop the storage probability distributions is nine. It is shown that use of the dynamic program results based on a small number of storage states results in unrealistically skewed storage probability distributions. These skewed distributions are attributed to trapping states at the low end of the storage range.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:1

TITLE: Provision of strength of hydrostation trash racks
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; MACHINE PARTS; FATIGUE; FRACTURE PROPERTIES; TURBOGENERATORS; CRACKS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; REPAIR; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; POWER PLANTS; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Bars of welded trash racks in front of turbines under normal operating conditions are often damaged by transverse cracks, which leads to shutdown of the turbines for repair of the racks and to the loss of production of electric energy. The authors suggest that the racks be made of bars fastened with bolt ties. Cracks are infrequent in the bolt ties demonstrating excellent fatigue resistance.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:2; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 2, pp. 23-28, February, 1985

TITLE: Results of on-site observations of the state of structures at the Kanev hydroelectric station
AUTHORS: Karlin, S I; Shul'ga, V A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; MONITORING; OPERATION; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; MONITORS; USSR; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The authors report on on-site observations of the state of the hydraulic structure of the Kanev hydrostation which began during construction and are continuing during operation. They conclude that the measuring and monitoring equipment installed at the Kanev hydrostation permit systematic monitoring of the state and behavior of the main structures; the organization of on-site observations was successful and is recommended for use at other power stations.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:2; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 2, pp. 34-39, February, 1985

TITLE: Determination of the parameters of a model of a base from engineering-geologic survey data
AUTHORS: Ruppeneit, K V; Kustov, V P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FOUNDATIONS; COMPUTER-AIDED DESIGN; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; GEOLOGIC SURVEYS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; GEOLOGY; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; POWER PLANTS; SUPPORTS; SURVEYS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The authors present a mathematical model that aids in the design of foundations of hydroelectric power plants. The semi-infinite linearly deformable elastic solid model, SIE model, allows calculation of the effect of the shape in plan and rigidity of foundation, the mutual effect of foundations, etc. Engineering-geologic surveys are used to establish analogues for the SIE model.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:2; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 2, pp. 21-23 February, 1985

TITLE: Main engineering-geological problems of constructing the Hoa-Binh hydro development on the Da River (Vietnam)
AUTHORS: Molokov, L A; Dobrin, E Z; Skiba, S I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RIVERS; VIET NAM; ASIA; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; GEOLOGY; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The authors describe the construction of the Hoa-Binh hydro development which is being accomplished under complex engineering-geological conditions. These conditions are characterized by the following circumstances: complexity of the structural and tectonic conditions of the entire region; wide and intensive development of a karst on the divide between the Da and Ma Rivers within the basin of the reservoir being created and part of the dam barrier; presence of a thick stratum of very permeable alluvium in the base of the dam; diversity of the composition and properties of volcanites; markedly nonuniform and intense bedrock weathering processes.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:2; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 2, pp. 55-59, Februvary, 1985

TITLE: Evaluation of the reliability of hydraulic structures
AUTHORS: Lyatkher, V M; Ivashchenko, I N; Yancher, V B; Zolotov, L A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; EVALUATION; RELIABILITY; EMBANKMENTS; SPILLWAY; WATER RESERVOIRS; DAMAGE; FAILURES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: The overall property of a structure consisting in the ability to perform its functions during a certain time period when prescirbed operating rules are adhered to is defined by the term ''reliability.'' Because damages and failures of large hydraulic structures can have catastrophic consequences, the authors propose a method of determining absolute reliability of important structures. The method is intended to reduce the probability of failures and damages to zero. Available experience indicates that failures and damages occur nonetheless.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:2; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel'stvo, No. 2, pp. 6-13, February, 1985

TITLE: Florida Current volume transports from voltage measurements
AUTHORS: Larsen, J C; Sanford, T B
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; GULF STREAM; VOLUME; ACCURACY; CORRELATIONS; ELECTRIC POTENTIAL; FLOW RATE; MEASURING METHODS; CURRENTS; WATER CURRENTS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: The volume transport of the Florida Current is determined from the motionally induced voltage difference between Florida and Grand Bahama Island. Simultaneous measurements of potential differences and of volume transport by velocity profiling have a correlation of 0.97. The calibration factor is 25 +/- 0.7 sverdrups per volt, and the root-mean square discrepancy is 0.7 sverdrup. The induced voltage is about one-half the open-circuit value, implying that the conductance of the sediments and lithosphere is about equal to that of the water column. 11 references, 2 figures.
RESEARCH_ORG: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Seattle, WA
RELATION: Journal Name: Science (Washington, D.C.); (United States); Journal Volume: 227:4684

TITLE: Volume and heat transports of the Florida current: April 1982 through August 1983
AUTHORS: Molinari, R L; Wilson, W D; Leaman, K
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; GULF STREAM; HEAT FLUX; VOLUME; FLOW RATE; SEASONAL VARIATIONS; TEMPERATURE SURVEYS; VELOCITY; CURRENTS; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; SURVEYS; VARIATIONS; WATER CURRENTS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: Absolute velocity and temperature profiles are used to estimate the volume transport through the Straits of Florida and, in combination with historical midbasin data, to estimate the total meridional heat flux through a section at 27/sup 0/N. The mean annual volume transport of the Florida Current from April 1982 through August 1983 is 30.5 (+/-1) x 10/sup 6/ cubic meters per second. The net northward heat flux through the 27/sup 0/N section is 1.2 (+/-0.1) x 10/sup 15/ watts. The volume transport is characterized by high values in the late spring and early summer and low values in the late fall and early winter. There is a similar cycle in total heat flux. 17 references, 1 figure, 2 tables.
RESEARCH_ORG: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Miami, FL
RELATION: Journal Name: Science (Washington, D.C.); (United States); Journal Volume: 227:4684

TITLE: Florida Current: seasonal and interannual variability
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; GULF STREAM; FLOW RATE; VOLUME; ANNUAL VARIATIONS; MEASURING METHODS; SEASONAL VARIATIONS; CURRENTS; VARIATIONS; WATER CURRENTS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: Annual and interannual variations in the Florida Current, Caribbean and subtropical Atlantic are investigated with the use of historical sea level differences and wind field data. Observational and model evidence suggests that the seasonal transport cycle of the Florida Current is locally forced, either upstream in the Caribbean or downstream over topography. Although at seasonal and shorter periods sea level or bottom pressure fluctuations on the left side of the Florida Current contribute almost all of the variance of sea level difference across the Florida Straits and hence transport, this relation does not seem to apply at interannual time scales. Using results from the Subtropical Atlantic Climate Studies, it is estimated from historical sea level data that interannual transport fluctuations of the Florida Current are only of order 1 x 10/sup 6/ cubic meters per second. Interannual fluctuations in the 2- to 3-year period range in the Florida Straits seem to be correlated with sea level differences across the Caribbean and the subtropical Atlantic but not with Sverdrup transport fluctuations in the subtropical Atlantic. 26 references, 2 figures.
RELATION: Journal Name: Science (Washington, D.C.); (United States); Journal Volume: 227:4684

TITLE: Sea level variation as an indicator of Florida current volume transport: comparisons with direct measurements
AUTHORS: Maul, G A; Chew, F; Bushnell, M; Mayer, D A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; GULF STREAM; VOLUME; ACCURACY; MEASURING METHODS; SEA LEVEL; VARIATIONS; CURRENTS; LEVELS; WATER CURRENTS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: Sea level measurements from tide gauges at Miami, Florida, and Cat Cay, Bahamas, and bottom pressure measurements from a water depth of 50 meters off Jupiter, Florida, and a water depth of 10 meters off Memory Rock, Bahamas, were correlated with 81 concurrent direct volume transport observations in the Straits of Florida. Daily-averaged sea level from either gauge on the Bahamian side of the Straits was poorly correlated with transport. Bottom pressure off Jupiter had a linear coefficient of determination of r/sup 2/ = 0.93, and Miami sea level, when adjusted for weather effects, had r/sup 2/ = 0.74; the standard errors of estimating transports were +/-1.2 x 10/sup 6/ and +/-1.9 x 10/sup 6/ cubic meters per second, respectively. A linear multivariate regression, which combined bottom pressure, weather, and the submarine cable observations between Jupiter and the Bahamas, had r/sup 2/ = 0.94 with a standard error of estimating transport of +/-1.1 x 10/sup 6/ cubic meters per second. These results suggest that a combination of easily obtained observations is sufficient to adequately monitor the daily volume transport fluctuations of the Florida Current. 13 references, 2 figures, 2 tables.
RESEARCH_ORG: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Miami, FL
RELATION: Journal Name: Science (Washington, D.C.); (United States); Journal Volume: 227:4684

TITLE: Subtropical Atlantic climate studies: introduction
AUTHORS: Molinari, R L; Maul, G A; Chew, F; Wilson, W D; Bushnell, M; Mayer, D; Leaman, K; Schott, F; Lee, T; Zantopp, R; Larsen, J C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; GULF STREAM; TEMPERATURE SURVEYS; VOLUME; MONITORING; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; CURRENTS; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; SURVEYS; WATER CURRENTS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: This report is an introduction to the accompanying collection of reports that present the results of a 2-year period of intensive monitoring of the Florida Current. Both direct observing systems (ship-deployed current profilers and moored current meters) and indirect observing systems (coastal tide gauge stations, bottom pressure gauge arrays, a submarine cable, acoustic arrays, and radar installations) were used to measure temperature and volume transport. 21 references, 1 figure, 2 tables.
RESEARCH_ORG: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Miami, FL.
RELATION: Journal Name: Science (Washington, D.C.); (United States); Journal Volume: 227:4684

TITLE: Florida current: low-frequency variability as observed with moored current meters during April 1982 to June 1983
AUTHORS: Lee, T N; Schott, F A; Zantopp, R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; GULF STREAM; SEASONAL VARIATIONS; VOLUME; WATER CURRENTS; ATMOSPHERIC CIRCULATION; FLOWMETERS; CURRENTS; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; METERS; VARIATIONS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: A 1-year time series of volume transport through the Florida Straits near 27/sup 0/N was derived from an array of five subsurface current meter moorings. The transport estimates, determined on the basis of constant shear extrapolation of the subsurface velocities to the surface, are in good agreement with transports derived from submarine cable and Pegasus measurements. The annual transport cycle in 1982-1983 is complicated by large-amplitude fluctuations on time scales of 1 to 3 weeks, but it does exhibit a transport maximum in summer and a minimum in fall-winter, consistent with historical results and of similar magnitude. The energy density spectrum of transports is continuous with a slope of about -1.5 and does not show a gap between the periods of weeks and seasonal. Evidence was found for atmospheric forcing of transport fluctuations, with highest coherence between transport and the local meridional wind stress at periods of 10 and 15 days during the summer and 5 and 40 days during the winter. 16 references.
RELATION: Journal Name: Science (Washington, D.C.); (United States); Journal Volume: 227:4684

TITLE: Uprating hydroelectric systems: a sound investment
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; REPAIR; RETROFITTING; ECONOMICS; RELIABILITY; SYSTEMS ANALYSIS; POWER PLANTS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: While uprating large hydro projects does cost money - often around $200 to $700 per kilowatt - it is usually a wise investment to make. Many industry experts believe that uprating older systems is the most-efficient, cost-effective way to optimize energy production. Mr. Siebensohn discusses deciding whether to uprate, choosing what parts of the system to focus on, and assessing individual component choices. 2 references, 5 figures.
RESEARCH_ORG: General Electric's Apparatus and Engineering Services Division, Schenectady, NY
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Rev.; (United States); Other Information: Older facilities

TITLE: Hydro relicensing: the controversy continues
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; COMPETITION; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; POLITICAL ASPECTS; RATE STRUCTURE; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 293000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Policy, Legislation, & Regulation
DESCRIPTION: Relicensing is without a doubt the most-important hydro industry issue being discussed in Washington in 1985. Congressional proposals for defining relicensing procedures range from one that would virtually ensure private utility relicensing to one that heavily favors municipal preference. Others occupy the middle ground, attempting to create genuine competition that will bring down consumers' rates. In addition, the Merwin appeal will be decided on the fall of 1985, so the courts will be involved in whatever relicensing picture ultimately emerges. Attorney Williams traces the history of the relicensing debate and speculates about the politics thereof. 2 references, 1 table.
RESEARCH_ORG: McCarty, Noone and Williams, Washington, DC
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Rev.; (United States)

TITLE: Chinese equipment for US markets: traditional design, low cost
AUTHORS: Kissel, P C; Hansen, J C; Shen, P K
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; EQUIPMENT; CHINA; MARKET; TURBOGENERATORS; USA; ASIA; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 130700 - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Peter C. Kissel and James C. Hansen were members of a delegation of US businessmen invited to the People's Republic of China by the China Science and Technology Exchange Center and Carroway Engineering, Inc., to discuss China's small-scale hydroelectric equipment and the means of obtaining such equipment for exportation to the US. The delegation, led by Peter K. Shen, president of Carroway Engineering, visited with Chinese government officials in four cities and provinces in June 1985, and inspected two of the principal electrical machine factories that manufacture hydroelectric equipment for projects in the US. In this article, the authors discuss the negotiations necessary to obtain Chinese equipment and China's ability to supply the US market for turbine-generator equipment.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Rev.; (United States)

TITLE: Avoided costs: how are they determined
AUTHORS: Brown, P W; Ringo, M J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; COST ESTIMATION; RATE STRUCTURE; REGULATIONS; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC UTILITY REGULATORY POLICIES ACT; US FERC; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LAWS; NATIONAL ENERGY ACT; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: Even though methodologies for determining avoided costs vary widely from state to state (and sometimes from year to year), essentially the same factors have to be taken into account wherever rate setting occurs. This article explores methods used, and issues arising out of, long-term and short-term avoided cost rate determination.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Rev.; (United States)

TITLE: Hydro's future: revitalization of a national treasure
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; FORECASTING; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; RECOMMENDATIONS; TECHNOLOGY UTILIZATION; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The author, manager of the Electric Power Research Institute's hydropower program, has worked with other industry experts to formulate a concept of hydropower's future. The view, as discussed in this article, is one of hydropower as a national treasure which deserves improvement and revitalization. Further, this revitalization would occur mainly as a result of vigilant attention to the numerous possibilities for technological improvement. Dr. Birk is optimistic about the future, but his optimism is tempered by the realities that now surround the hydropower industry. He holds out the hope that, although the forces affecting hydropower in the US may not permit it to become much bigger, it will become a yet more valuable national treasure.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Rev.; (United States)

TITLE: Stator frame distortion: solving the problem of concrete creep
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CONCRETES; CREEP; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TURBOGENERATORS; STATORS; STRESS ANALYSIS; BUILDING MATERIALS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; MATERIALS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; POWER PLANTS; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: After 14 years of operation, the 16 generators at the R.H. Saunders generating station required in-place stator frame soleplate modifications to correct significant stator frame distortion. The probable cause of the distortion was concrete creep (see sidebar), combined with the effects of unbalanced magnetic air gaps and hydraulic forces. 2 references, 8 figures.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Rev.; (United States)

TITLE: Financier's view of today's hydro industry
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; FINANCING; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 290200 - Energy Planning & Policy- Economics & Sociology
DESCRIPTION: In the last 4 years, the independent hydroelectric industry has undergone important changes that have affected the financing of the industry. In this article, Mr. Mcleod identifies some of the key developments; identifies the special characteristics of hydroelectric projects; discusses financing hydroelectric projects today; and offers some hints on how to obtain project financing in today's market.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Rev.; (United States)

TITLE: Dramatic rescue: emergency shutoff gate passes test
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 25 ENERGY STORAGE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; PENSTOCKS; SAFETY ENGINEERING; ACCIDENTS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; ENGINEERING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; PIPES; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 250300 - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: It is nearly impossible to test an emergency shutoff gate under maximum design conditions without actually experiencing those conditions. At the Helms Pumped Storage project on September 29, 1982, the wheel-type shutoff gate in a large penstock performed successfully under emergency conditions. This article describes the gate and some of the details that may have contributed to its success in preventing an accident from becoming a disaster. 6 figures.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Rev.; (United States)

TITLE: Forest recreation issues: a critical assessment
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FORESTS; RECREATIONAL AREAS; RECOMMENDATIONS; ECONOMICS; EMBARGOES; ENERGY CONSERVATION; ENERGY DEMAND; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LIFE STYLES; QUALITY OF LIFE; WATER USE; DEMAND; POWER PLANTS; 530100* - Environmental-Social Aspects of Energy Technologies- Social & Economic Studies- (-1989); 290200 - Energy Planning & Policy- Economics & Sociology; 130601 - Hydro Energy- Land Use & Aesthetics- (-1991 )
DESCRIPTION: Energy is cited in this article as one of the issues that needs to be dealt with to assure a continuing supply of quality outdoor recreational choices. The effect of the oil embargo on recreational activities, boat sales and small businesses is described. Another issue discussed is the need for consideration of downriver fishing and whitewater needs by federal hydropower projects. The author recommends the creation of a outdoor recreation commission which would conduct hearings across the nation and present their findings in the form of recommendations to the President and to Congress.
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. For.; (United States); Journal Volume: 91:1

TITLE: Hydro-review's industry directory 1986
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; EQUIPMENT; LICENSING; MANUFACTURERS; DIRECTORIES; MAINTENANCE; REGULATIONS; DOCUMENT TYPES; POWER PLANTS; 130000* - Hydro Energy; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: The four main sections of the directory contain directories for companies, products, services, and state agencies. The company directory gives an alphabetical listing of all companies involved in the hydroelectric industry that responded. The product and service directories are broken down into various categories, with company names listed within each category. A state-by-state listing of all agencies that developers need to contact when going through the licensing process includes both state and regional contacts for federal agencies. The directory concludes with a compendium of the industry's trade and technical associations.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Rev.; (United States)

TITLE: Report of the Committee on Regulations Under Part I of the Federal Power Act
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; REGULATIONS; CASE LAW; LAWSUITS; LEGAL ASPECTS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; LAWS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: Major regulatory developments in the field of hydroelectric licensing centered on the continuing evolution of prior issues. These included the application of municipal preference in both licensing and relicensing, the continuing tension between the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission's duty to expedite the licensing process by granting exemptions to small projects versus its duty to examine the environmental effects of all projects, the conflicting jurisdiction over hydroelectric projects, and the question of annual charges. The report examines each of these issues in terms of hearings and court decisions.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Law J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 6:1

TITLE: Annual generation construction survey
SUBJECT: 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 21 SPECIFIC NUCLEAR REACTORS AND ASSOCIATED PLANTS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FOSSIL-FUEL POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS; CAPACITY; DATA COMPILATION; REGIONAL ANALYSIS; DATA; INFORMATION; NUCLEAR FACILITIES; NUMERICAL DATA; POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 200100* - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Power Plants & Power Generation; 210801 - Nuclear Power Plants- Economics- Construction & Operation- (-1987); 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation

Data are presented on the unit name, owner, capacity, manufacturer, architect/engineer, constructor, original and current service dates, and the per cent completion.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. World; (United States); Journal Volume: 199:1

TITLE: Itaipu network spans all EHV voltages
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; EHV AC SYSTEMS; CONSTRUCTION; HVDC SYSTEMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; BRAZIL; PARAGUAY; POWER TRANSMISSION LINES; AC SYSTEMS; DC SYSTEMS; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; ENERGY SYSTEMS; LATIN AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; SOUTH AMERICA; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 200300 - Electric Power Engineering- Power Transmission & Distribution- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The large Itaipu hydroelectric project on the Brazil-Paraguay border called for the construction of an interrelated network of 345-kV, 500-kV, 750-kV, and HVDC lines and substations on an unprecedented scale. The civil engineering and the electrical design are discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. World; (United States); Journal Volume: 199:1

TITLE: Downstream effects of dams on alluvial rivers
AUTHORS: Williams, G P; Wolman, M G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; RIVERS; HYDROLOGY; EQUILIBRIUM; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; SEDIMENTS; DATA; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: This study describes changes in mean channel-bed elevation, channel width, bed-material sizes, vegetation, water discharges, and sediment loads downstream from 21 dams constructed on alluvial rivers. Most of the studied channels are in the semiarid western US. Flood peaks generally were decreased by the dams, but in other respects the post-dam water-discharge characteristics varied from river to river. Sediment concentrations and suspended loads were decreased markedly for hundreds of kilometers downstream from dams; post-dam annual sediment loads on some rivers did not equal pre-dam loads anywhere downstream from a dam. Bed degradation varied from negligible to about 7.5 meters in the 287 cross sections studied. In general, most degradation occurred during the first decade or two after dam closure. Bed material initially coarsened as degradation proceeded, but this pattern may change during later years. Channel width can increase, decrease, or remain constant in the reach downstream from a dam. Despite major variation, changes at a cross section in stream bed elevation and in channel width with time often can be described by simple hyperbolic equations. Equation coefficients need to be determined empirically. Riparian vegetation commonly increased in the reach downstream from the dams, probably because of the decrease in peak flows. 120 references, 49 figures, 14 tables.
RELATION: Journal Name: U.S. Geol. Surv., Prof. Pap.; (United States); Journal Volume: 1286
JOURNAL_NAME: U.S. Geol. Surv., Prof. Pap.; (United States)

TITLE: Algorithms for optimizing hydropower system operation
AUTHORS: Grygier, J C; Stedinger, J R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; ALGORITHMS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; WATER RESERVOIRS; MANAGEMENT; COMPUTERS; DYNAMIC PROGRAMMING; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; LINEAR PROGRAMMING; OPTIMIZATION; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; ECONOMICS; ENGINEERING; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; PROGRAMMING; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 990200 - Mathematics & Computers
DESCRIPTION: Successive liner programming, an optimal control algorithm, and a combination of linear programming and dynamic programming (LP-DP) are employed to optimize the operation of multireservoir hydrosystems given a deterministic inflow forecast. The algorithm maximize the value of energy produced at on-peak rates, plus the estimated value of water remaining in storage at the end of the 12-month planning period. The LP-DP algorithm is clearly dominated: it takes longer to find a solution and produces significantly less hydropower than the other two procedures. Successive linear programming (SLP) appears to find the global maximum and is easily implemented. For simple systems the optimal control algorithm finds the optimum in about one fifth the time required by SLP but is harder to implement. Computing costs for a two-reservoir, 12-month deterministic problem averaged about seven cents per run using optimal control and 37 cents using successive linear programming.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:1

TITLE: Hydrogen production at hydro-power plants
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 08 HYDROGEN; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENERGY EFFICIENCY; HYDROGEN PRODUCTION; HYDROGEN STORAGE; ELECTROLYSIS; GAS TURBINES; HYDROGEN FUEL CELLS; WATER; DIRECT ENERGY CONVERTERS; EFFICIENCY; ELECTROCHEMICAL CELLS; FUEL CELLS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; LYSIS; MACHINERY; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POWER PLANTS; STORAGE; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 080101 - Hydrogen- Production- Electrolysis; 080203 - Hydrogen- Cryogenic Storage; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Many utilities have actively explored the possibilities of increasing output at existing hydroplants by replacing or supplementing existing generating units. But hydroelectric plants are still utilizing only a portion of the river's hydraulic energy due to hydrologic and economic restraints One possibility for increasing the efficiency of hydropower plants is the conversion of water to hydrogen through electrolysis by using the excess energy or wasted energy not yet utilized, and then conversion of hydrogen to electricity via a gas turbine or fuel cells. The electricity produced in the off-peak or no-demand time, or at the time of huge river flows in the spring can be stored in the form of hydrogen, and later, when the peak energy is needed the hydrogen converted to electricity. One of the advantages of the proposed system is that the resource for production of hydrogen (the water) is available directly at the site.
RESEARCH_ORG: Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, Washington, D.C.
RELATION: Journal Name: Int. J. Hydrogen Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:9

TITLE: Optimal exploitation of energy resources: solar power and electricity generation in below-sea-level basins
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 14 SOLAR ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; DEAD SEA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; FLOW MODELS; HYBRID SYSTEMS; SOLAR PONDS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; INLAND WATERWAYS; ISRAEL; SEA LEVEL; ASIA; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; EQUIPMENT; LAKES; LEVELS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MIDDLE EAST; PONDS; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SOLAR COLLECTORS; SOLAR EQUIPMENT; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 141000 - Solar Collectors & Concentrators; 142000 - Solar Energy- Heat Storage- (1980-); 296001 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 299001 - Energy Planning & Policy- Solar- (1989-)
DESCRIPTION: This paper analyzes the generation of hydroelectric power by the transfer of seawater to locations which are significantly below sea level (e.g., the Dead Sea in Israel and the Qatara depression in Egypt) combined with solar energy that via evaporation will perpetuate the hydroelectric power capacity. Two scenarios are depicted. The first focuses on optimal planning of the canal capacity and optimal use of its water to generate hydroelectric power while filling the basin to its steady-state level. The second includes the impact of solar pools as a new technology whose date of adoption is a random event. It is shown that the optimal flow of water through the canal depends on the relationship between optimal canal capacity and the rate of water evaporation in the basin. The optimal design of the canal project can be considered a hybrid between depletion of a natural resource (the height differences in filling up the basin) and use of a renewable resource (solar energy to evaporate the basin water). The optimal policy is shown to consist of sequential intervals, some of which may vanish under certain conditions: first, the operation of the canal at full capacity; then the gradual decrease of water flow at a rate equal to the elasticity of the marginal product of electricity generation times the sum of interest rate and the marginal evaporation rate; and, finally, the stabilization of the water flow at the rate of steady-state evaporation. The stochastic model with the introduction of solar pools technology treated as a random event is formulated as a two-stage maximization problem. 6 references, 3 figures.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Environ. Econ. Manage.; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:4

TITLE: Adversary hydro relicensing applications: using economic efficiency criteria
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; COMPETITION; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; LICENSE APPLICATIONS; OWNERSHIP; REGULATIONS; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; ECONOMICS; POWER PLANTS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: Many adversary proceedings for the relicensing of hydroelectric facilities involve a contest between a relatively large investor-owned electric utility with relatively high prices and a relatively small municipal utility with very low prices. One of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission's stated criteria for determining such contests is that ''the goal of economic efficiency is enhanced by assigning hydropower to its highest-value use...'' This article invokes simple economic theory to show how this test can be implemented. Its analysis identifies four primary considerations which lead to the conclusion that in these cases the license should remain with the investor-owned utility and that any regulatory or legislative ''municipal preference'' is undesirable. 1 figure.
RELATION: Journal Name: Public Util. Fortn.; (United States); Journal Volume: 114:13

TITLE: Sedimentation problem in water Conservancy in China
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CHINA; RESOURCE CONSERVATION; WATER RESOURCES; EROSION; RIVERS; SEDIMENTATION; SEDIMENTS; SOILS; ASIA; RESOURCES; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: The state-of-the-art of river sedimentation management in China is reviewed. Attention is focused on the sediment load carried by main rivers in China; the related sediment problems encountered in developing water resources; and the methods in dealing with those problems. There are 50 rivers with annual maximum sediment load exceeding 10 million tons in China. There are more than 400,000 sq km of loess plateaus and hills in the drainage basin of the Yellow River. Inadequate conservation of soil and water leads to erosion, transportation and deposition of sediment, giving rise to much trouble in water conservation works. These problems include flood control, navigational concerns, reservoir sedimentation, and sediment problems of lowhead diversion dams or hydroelectric projects. Methods for dealing with sediment problems include water and soil conservation and use of turbid water with emphasis on terracing, strip cropping, forestation, grass and crop rotation. Several types of structures may be built along a gully such as small reservoirs, check dams, drop structures, drainage ditches, and irrigation canal systems for diverting hyperconcentrated flow into farmland or to warp land. Processes for diverting water while preventing sediment from entering water intakes at hydroelectric plants are becoming more advanced. 4 references, 3 figures, 2 tables.
RESEARCH_ORG: Institute of Water conservancy and Hydroelectric Power Research, Beijing, China
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 9:4

TITLE: Solar energy and hydroelectric power generation in the Dead Sea: a dynamic analysis
AUTHORS: Hochman, E; LaFrance, J; Zilberman, D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DEAD SEA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; DYNAMIC PROGRAMMING; EQUILIBRIUM; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPTIMIZATION; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; LAKES; POWER; PROGRAMMING; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SIMULATION; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: A dynamic optimal control model is developed for generating hydroelectric power in the Dead Sea. Properties of the optimal utilization path and steady state equilibria are analyzed, and the applicability of the model for other types of water development projects is discussed. Estimates of the basic equations for the Dead Sea project and a numerical application are presented.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 20:11

TITLE: Consumers face $5. 9 million rate increase
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; RATE STRUCTURE; IRRIGATION; FINANCING; NORTH DAKOTA; ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT; ECONOMIC IMPACT; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; FEDERAL REGION VIII; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; USA; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 290400 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Resources; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: Testimony at hearings before the Garrison Diversion Compromise Commission claimed that rural consumers in the Upper Midwest could face $5.9 million in electric rate increases if the commission deauthorizes the project and hydroelectric rates go up to pay the costs of the 1944 Pick-Sloan project originally assigned to irrigation. If there is no irrigation development, the revenue that irrigation must raise to repay the $67 million debt assigned to irrigation must be reassigned to hydroelectric power. The commission represents a compromise between supporters and opponents of the Garrison Diversion project. Spokesmen for regional utilities spoke in support of the project as an investment whose costs have escalated because of delays at the expense of economic development in North Dakota.
RELATION: Journal Name: N.D. REC Mag.; (United States); Journal Volume: 31:5

TITLE: Output increase from existing hydroelectric plants
AUTHORS: Davis, D W; Buckley, J J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; EFFICIENCY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; FORECASTING; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; PLANNING; USA; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; MACHINERY; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The potential for increasing the energy output was investigated at all existing hydroelectric plants in the US, regardless of ownership, for increases through enlarging power-houses, modifying or replacing turbines and generators, and improving water handling works. The hydroelectric power generation system analyzed in this study is comprised of 1288 individual plants, totaling about 3000 individual generation units, with installed capacity of 63,375 MW, generating 272,552 gigawatt hr of electrical energy per year. The potential energy increase was found to be about 11% requiring an increase of 22% in installed capacity. Virtually all the increase due to capturing existing spill through enlargement of existing powerhouses (adding additional units). Equipment uprating and improvements only would likely contribute on an aggregate national scale no more than 1.4% increase. Potential for increased energy output for operation improvements and storage reallocation is possible at sites with existing flood control storage (a national aggregate increase of about 0.6%). The existing hydropower generation system on the whole is making quite efficient use of the energy resources available at the existing sites. 5 references, 5 figures, 5 tables.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Water Resour. Plann. Manage. Div., Proc. Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 110:4
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Water Resour. Plann. Manage. Div., Proc. Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States)

TITLE: Water flows during dam-power retrofit
AUTHORS: Van Weele, B; McClung, E M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; TURBOGENERATORS; RETROFITTING; DAMS; FLUID FLOW; IRRIGATION; WATER; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The design and construction efforts required for retrofitting a 6.9-MW hydro-turbine/generator within a small 20-year-old earth-filled irrigation dam includes all the engineering challenges of a much larger project, particularly when the water flow to the rice fields could not be interrupted, even during the digging of the 870-ft hydro tunnel.
RESEARCH_ORG: Parsons, Brinckerhoff, Quade and Douglas, Inc., Sacramento, CA
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. World; (United States); Journal Volume: 198:9

TITLE: Cost estimates for hydropower at existing dams
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Guidelines for quick and simple hydropower project cost estimates are developed for preliminary site assessments. The guidelines are based upon a concept which incorporates a single equation utilizing design power and head for total equipment cost and a ''site factor'' to determine total project cost. Total project cost is estimated by multiplying the equipment cost, obtained from the equation, and the site factor. Total project cost data from a number of hydropower projects are compiled to provide guidelines for choosing the site factor, which is shown to vary greatly, especially for micro (less than or equal to100 kW) and mini (less than or equal to1,000 kW) hydropower projects. Envelope curves for site factors are given, and a ''weighting factor,'' which is the fraction distance between upper and lower envelope curves, is chosen for each site. The choice of weighting factor for a given site is based upon comparison with recently completed projects, a knowledge of the components which can greatly increase civil works costs, and engineering judgement. The weighting factor is then used in calculations to determine optimum plant capacity. The methodology was used in a survey of the hydropower potential at exis
RESEARCH_ORG: St. Anthony Falls Hydr. Lab., Dept. of Civ. and Mineral Engrg., Univ. of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Energy Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 110:3

TITLE: Effect of ice cover on hydropower production
AUTHORS: Yapa, P D; Shen, H T
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PRODUCTIVITY; ST LAWRENCE RIVER; ICE; DAMS; ELECTRIC POWER; ICEBERGS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: For hydropower developments in northern regions, the annual occurrence of river ice cover presents various problems of operation and management. The existence of an ice cover can lead to a substantial loss in power production. This loss in power due to the presence of ice cover, however, can be minimized with appropriate ice control measures. In this technical note, a quantitative analysis of power loss is carried out for the St. Lawrence Power Project. Major factors that affect the magnitude of power loss are examined to provide some information for future ice-related hydropower operations. The St. Lawrence River, which conveys water from the Great Lakes Basin to the Atlantic Ocean, has been utilized for hydroelectric power production since the early 1900's. The St. Lawrence Seaway and Power Project, constructed in 1954-58, developed the hydropower potential of the upper St. Lawrence River. The Moses-Saunders Power Dam is located about 100 miles downstream of the outlet of Lake Ontario. Since the development of this power project, the regulation of flow through the dam in relation to the ice conditions has been an important element in its winter operation. The existence of an ice cover reduces the power production capability of the river significantly.
RESEARCH_ORG: Dept. of Civ. and Environ. Engrg., Clarkson Univ., Potsdam, NY
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Energy Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 110:3

TITLE: Old Lowell gets new hydropower
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; MASSACHUSETTS; FEDERAL REGION I; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MACHINERY; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; USA; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: A 15mw hydroelectric powerhouse constructed on the bank of the Merrimack River in Lowell, Massachusetts, will employ two horizontal tubular turbines made in Japan. The construction of the low-head hydroelectric plant is described.
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 213:9

TITLE: Modelling and optimization of hydrothermal generation scheduling
AUTHORS: Lyra, C; Soares, S; Tavaries, H
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LOAD MANAGEMENT; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; HYDRAULICS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPERATION; OPTIMIZATION; PLANNING; POWER GENERATION; SCHEDULES; FLUID MECHANICS; MANAGEMENT; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: An approach is proposed to optimize the operation of energy production systems over middle term planning periods. Randomness of primary load is explicitly considered. A precise model is used to represent the hydraulic system (with individualized reservoir in cascade, water transportation delays, nonlinear generation, ...) as well as the non-hydraulic system (thermal generations, interchanges, load shedding, ...). Difficulties resulting from the large scale are overcome by decomposition techniques.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Appar. Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: PAS-103:8
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Trans. Power Appar. Syst.; (United States)

TITLE: Yangtze engineers aim high
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; DESIGN; PLANNING; CHINA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MANAGEMENT; ASIA; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Planning for the Three Gorge Dam on the Yangtze River started in 1951. The Three Gorge flood-control, power, irrigation and navigation scheme will be one of the world's largest civil-engineering works comprising an 11 million cubic m gravity dam, two powerplants to house 26,500-Mw turbine generators, two 80 m high vertical shiplifts, a double lane lock on the left bank capable of transporting 50 million long tons of cargo a year up 87 m in three equal steps, spillways, low-level outlets and powerplant discharges capable of passing a maximum probable flood of 120,000 cu m per sec. A new construction agency will be established specifically for Three Gorge and a system of bonuses and penalties will be incorporated. 6 figures.
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 213:4

TITLE: Public utilities wrestle with private companies over 'preference' in hydroelectric-plant relicensing
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; OWNERSHIP; COMPETITION; ECONOMICS; LEGISLATION; OPERATING LICENSES; PUBLIC UTILITIES; REGULATIONS; LICENSES; POWER PLANTS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 293000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Policy, Legislation, & Regulation
DESCRIPTION: Changing economics has drawn Congress into the controversy between public and investor-owned utilities over the relicensing of hydroelectric plants. At issue is whether the ''preference'' given to public power in the initial licensing should be a continuing entitlement, and whether private licensees, who hold most of the original licenses, will have to relinquish their holdings to a public power agency regardless of their operating record. The law is not clear in giving preference to state or municipal over private applicants or whether this also applies to relicensing. The controversy arises over the designation of falling water as a public resource requiring public control. The high cost of fossil fuels has made hydroelectric power increasingly attractive to municipal utilities.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. Light Power; (United States); Journal Volume: 62:7

TITLE: Seepage regime of the hydraulic fill dam of the Mingechaur hydropower development
AUTHORS: Melent'ev, V A; Nosovova, O N; Mityushina, I M; Sergeeva, N S; Chugaeva, G A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; EVALUATION; MAINTENANCE; PERFORMANCE TESTING; DESIGN; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; USSR; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; POWER PLANTS; TESTING; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: On-site observations used to monitor the condition of the Mingechaur hydraulic-fill dam on the Kura River, USSR, were initiated in the mid-1950's at the time of construction. These revealed no evidence of seepage until the 1965-70 era, at which time, the readings of individual piezometers monitoring seepage indicated a general rise of the line of seepage. Theoretical and experimental studies were conducted to establish the cause and to determine the stability of the dam slopes and the earthquake resistance of the structure. Anomalous variations in the piezometers were noted and were concluded to be unrelated to intensifications of slope stability and determinations of earthquake resistance show the dam to be safe. 12 references, 4 figures, 1 table.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:1; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 18: No. 1, 3-8(Jan-1984)

TITLE: Determination of optimum minimum flow from a dam by using energy analysis
AUTHORS: Williams, J B; McKellar, Jr, H N
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 63 RADIATION, THERMAL, AND OTHER ENVIRON. POLLUTANT EFFECTS ON LIVING ORGS. AND BIOL. MAT.; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS; PRODUCTIVITY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENERGY ANALYSIS; POWER GENERATION; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; OPTIMIZATION; SIMULATION; ECOSYSTEMS; POWER PLANTS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 560304 - Chemicals Metabolism & Toxicology- Invertebrates- (-1987); 560305 - Chemicals Metabolism & Toxicology- Vertebrates- (-1987); 560303 - Chemicals Metabolism & Toxicology- Plants- (-1987); 290100 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Analysis & Modeling; 290300 - Energy Planning & Policy- Environment, Health, & Safety
DESCRIPTION: The proposed restoration of an abandoned hydroelectric dam on the Quinebaug River, Connecticut, is studied using energy analysis. The analysis considers the effects of alternative minimum flow releases, ranging from 0 to 34 cubic meters per second (cms), on the total energy flow of the affected system. The principal system components affected by differing minimum flows are hydroelectric power generation, aquatic habitat, and gross aquatic ecosystem productivity. The minimum flow alternative resulting in the highest annual energy flow in the affected system is considered optimal. From this purely analytical point of view, the optimum minimum flow is 0 cms, due to the short length and low productivity of the regulated reach, and the lack of floodplain interactions. Simulations of longer and more productive river reaches were conducted. For very short, unproductive reaches, in the absence of a floodplain, the contribution of aquatic community productivity to total system energy flow is negligible compared to hydroelectric generation. Optimum minimum flows are higher for longer and more productive reaches. For such cases the operation of hydroelectric dams could reduce total system energy flow because the energy supplied by hydroelectric generation may be offset by losses in aquatic productivity due to diminished riverine habitat.
RELATION: Journal Name: Environ. Manage.; (United States); Journal Volume: 8:4

TITLE: Thumbs down on big Alaska hydro project
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; ALASKA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; REGULATIONS; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; US FERC; FEDERAL REGION X; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; USA; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 130400 - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: A Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) draft environmental impact statement (EIS) argues that the Alaska Power Authority would be better of scrapping a proposed $5.2 billion hydro project on the Susitna River in favor of coal- and gas-fired plants or smaller hydropower projects. The EIS cites several major impacts, including accelerated soil erosion and permafrost thaw, reduced growth and migration of salmon, reduced moose and black bear populations, innundation and clearing of 56,000 acres, and socio-economic impacts during construction. Much of the damage could be avoided with thermal generation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Dly.; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:98

TITLE: Optimization of design parameters of complex surge tanks
AUTHORS: Arshenevskii, N N; Berloin, V V; Murav'ev, O A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; OPTIMIZATION; CONSTRUCTION; COST; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; ECONOMICS; POWER PLANTS; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: The problem of optimizing the design of a surge tank is solved in the scope of the more general problem of optimizing the design of the pressure conduits of hydrostations and structures on them. The optimization problem consists of finding, for a given system of pressure conduits and design regimes, a combination of design parameters for the surge tank such that it determines its minimum cost. The initial data of the optimization problem are: the geometric characteristics of the conduits; the design regimes of buildup and drop of the load, the elevations of the upper pool level corresponding to them and the roughness coefficients of the conduit lining; the maximum allowable piezometric head in the diversion and minimum allowable decline of the level in the tank; range of variation of the design parameters being optimized; unit cost of structural elements of the tank. 5 figures, 1 table.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:4; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 18: No. 4, 12-14(Apr 1984)

TITLE: Experience in operating the Bratsk Reservoir
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; USSR; WATER RESERVOIRS; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; CONSTRUCTION; DAMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; WATER RESOURCES; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; ENGINEERING; EUROPE; POWER PLANTS; RESOURCES; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The Bratsk reservoir is the largest in the USSR and second largest in the world. Initially, the reservoir was expected to be filled by the end of 1966. However, the actual filling was not completed until September of 1967. During filling and in the first years of operation it was constantly necessary to deal with floating timber in order to ensure normal operation of the hydrostation, navigation safety, conditions for fishery, and fulfillment of the sanitary requirements. During seasonal variations of the reservoir level about 160 sq km of the shore zone was subjected to variable flooding and waterlogging. Maximum erosion occurred on expanded stretches, and within their limits on slopes composed of loam and sand deposits. Within the narrows, where the banks are composed mainly of hard and soft rocks and wave action is weak, erosion is negligible. Wind setup and setdown cause maximum denivellation of the water surface. The maximum increase of the level during setup reaches 232 cm and the maximum decrease during setdown is 24 cm. Seiche oscillations with various amplitudes and periods are observed on the reservoir surface. The main uses of the complex are hydropower, water transport, timber floating, water supply, and fishery. For the successful development of the shores of reservoirs it is necessary to select the construction sites with consideration of possible occurrence of karstic and landslide processes; the construction of heavy structures requires special karst-control measures. 3 references, 3 figures, 1 table.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:4; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; No. 4, 31-35(Apr 1984)

TITLE: Federal hydropower licensing and preference system
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; COMPETITION; US FERC; CASE LAW; LAWS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: The preference system for licensing and relicensing competing hydropower projects has evolved over the years, with preference for preliminary permits currently going to municipalities and for relicensing to existing licensees. A review of court cases suggests an effort to tighten the procedures for licensing and relicensing by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission along with a continuing adherence to the order of preferences. The article concludes that fairness and the public interest will be served best if comparisons of competing projects are made at the preliminary permitting rather than the licensing stage.
RELATION: Journal Name: Public Util. Fortn.; (United States); Journal Volume: 113:7

TITLE: Alpine hydro work tests French
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HIGH-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; COST; DAMS; FRANCE; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; EUROPE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; WESTERN EUROPE; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The $600 million Grand Maison hydroelectric project being constructed in the French Alps is described. The 525 ft. high, 1800 ft. long embankment will impound a 112,600-acre ft. reservoir in the mountains east of Lyon. Construction problems are discussed; construction costs are running 35% over budget. Despite construction problems and high costs, it is expected that the main dam will be completed in the fall of 1984.
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 212:10

TITLE: Federal hydro power is underpriced, complain environmental groups
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 32 ENERGY CONSERVATION, CONSUMPTION, AND UTILIZATION; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; SUBSIDIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; CONTRACTS; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; ECONOMICS; LEGISLATION; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; FINANCIAL INCENTIVES; POWER; PUBLIC UTILITIES; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 320603 - Energy Conservation, Consumption, & Utilization- Municipalities & Community Systems- Public Utilities- (1980-)
DESCRIPTION: Two environmental groups are lobbying against the Federal Reclamation Hydroelectric Power Plants Authorization Act (H.R.4275), which would extend the 50-year sales contract for another 30 years that sells Hoover Dam output at reduced prices to publicly-owned utilities. The groups see this as a $6 million subsidy, and want investor-owned utilities to be able to compete for the power at market prices. Spokesmen for the National Wildlife Federation and the Environmental Defense Fund are taking an unprecedented position on the side of investor-owned utilities.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Dly.; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:47

TITLE: Federal study evaluates new hydro potential
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SITE SELECTION; CORPS OF ENGINEERS; EVALUATION; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; US DOD; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 290500 - Energy Planning & Policy- Research, Development, Demonstration, & Commercialization
DESCRIPTION: A comprehensive study by the US Army Corps of Engineers has identified candidate sites for hydroelectric power development to the year 2000. The sites are identified according to North American Electric Reliability Council regions. The project included a series of four screenings to identify (1) those projects with the physical potential for hydroelectric development, (2) projects capable of producing enough energy to repay generation equipment costs, (3) environmental impacts and their economic costs, and (4) near- and long-term projects. Nearly 2000 of the original 60,000 sites survived the fourth level of screening. 1 table.
RELATION: Journal Name: EPRI J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 9:2

TITLE: More power from hydro
AUTHORS: Lihach, N; Birk, J; Sullivan, C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; EFFICIENCY; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OUTAGES; RELIABILITY; EPRI; PERFORMANCE; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 290500 - Energy Planning & Policy- Research, Development, Demonstration, & Commercialization; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: Utilities are striving to upgrade the already impressive performance of hydroelectric plants at a reasonable cost. The Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) solicited utility industry feedback on what kinds of improvements to pursue, with forced outages, scheduled outages, plant efficiency, and new equipment reliability ranking as top candidates. Innovative approaches to operation and maintenance are springing up, but more effective channels for sharing technical information are neeeded. 7 references, 2 figures, 1 table.
RELATION: Journal Name: EPRI J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 9:2

TITLE: Mathematical modeling of hydraulic regimes in the transition between the surge tank and conduits of a hydroelectric station
AUTHORS: Arshenevskii, N N; Berlin, V V; Murav'ev, O A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; DESIGN; HYDRAULICS; VALIDATION; FLUID MECHANICS; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; SIMULATION; TESTING; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: A computer model characterizing the hydraulic regimes of the transition between the surge tank and conduits of a hydroelectric station was developed. This computer model allows analytical determination of the relationship between the specific energies of flows in the fork of a surge tank in the complete range of their hydraulic characteristics. It was established that the resistance coefficient of a transition between the surge tank and conduits is composed of a constant component depending on the geometry of the transition and a variable component depending on the type of discharges in the branches. Good agreement between predicted and observed values of specific energy of the transition between the surge tank and conduits was obtained. 5 references, 4 figures, 2 tables.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:3; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 18: No. 3, 10-14(Mar 1984)

TITLE: Stochastic streamflow models for hydroelectric systems
AUTHORS: Pereira, M V.F.; Oliveira, G C; Costa, C C.G.; Kelman, J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; STREAMS; HYDROLOGY; BRAZIL; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; ECONOMICS; PLANNING; STOCHASTIC PROCESSES; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; LATIN AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; SOUTH AMERICA; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 296001 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The development of a monthly streamflow model for the Brazilian hydroelectric system is described. The model is based on the disaggregation of lag 1 autoregressive annual flows into monthly values. Model features include addition of new sites, nonparametric generation of monthly flows, and correction of negative values. A methodology for assessing model adequacy is described and applied in a case study comparing the proposed model and a multivariate monthly autoregressive model. The economic effect of model selection is illustrated in a realistic generation planning case study: it is shown that investment differences resulting from the application of different models may reach US $1 billion.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 20:3

TITLE: High-head spillway with swirling of the flow in the outlet section
AUTHORS: Donchenko, E G; Lysenko, P E; Chepaikin, G A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SPILLWAY; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; CONSTRUCTION; DESIGN; PERFORMANCE TESTING; TUNNELS; DAMS; HIGH-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; TESTING; UNDERGROUND FACILITIES; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: A spillway with a regulating device called an eddy gate, which swirls the flow in the outlet section of the spillway, was proposed as an alternative to the ordinary tunnel spillway of a high-head river hydropower project to reduce the construction time, cost, and work involved. Energy dissipation is accomplished inside the proposed spillway and thus, energy dissipators at the spillway exit are not required. Ordinary, simple vertical-lift and radial gates can be used in the proposed spillway to regulate and discharge the flow. The hydraulic model investigation performed indicates that at all openings of the main gate of the spillway, the gate operated in the same manner as in ordinary tunnel spillways. Swirling of the flow in the outlet section behind the gate did not affect the operation of the gate. The proposed spillway does not require a long shutdown for converting from a diversion regime to a service regime because the gates can be installed during the construction. 4 figures.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:3; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 18: No. 3, 17-20(Mar 1984)

TITLE: Experience in the operation of hydraulic structures and equipment of hydroelectric stations
AUTHORS: Al'terman, D Z; Dmitrukhin, A F
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; WATER HAMMER; INHIBITION; HYDRAULICS; HYDRODYNAMICS; MAINTENANCE; FLUID MECHANICS; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130700 - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Water hammer in pressure conduits occurring at hydroelectric stations following rapid unloading of the units can be reduced provided the turbine gate apparatus is closed according to a specially prescribed program. In this paper, an economical design of a programmed closing device is presented. The device can be readily retrofitted at existing installations. At various hydrostations the hammer pressure can be reduced by thirty to fifty percent of its existing value without an additional increase of speed when dropping the load. A decrease of water hammer in the conduits and the resultant reduction of working stresses in the casing will extend the permissible service life, reduce operating costs, and save metal on the repair and replacement of the conduits. 2 references, 5 figures, 1 table.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotech. Constr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:3; Other Information: Translated from Gidrotekh. Stroit.; 18: No. 3, 34-36(Mar 1984)

TITLE: Cheap electricity rates lure Alumax to Quebec
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 32 ENERGY CONSERVATION, CONSUMPTION, AND UTILIZATION; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; MARKETING; INDUSTRY; ELECTRIC POWER; QUEBEC; ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; FINANCIAL INCENTIVES; RATE STRUCTURE; CANADA; ENERGY SOURCES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; PUBLIC UTILITIES; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 320301 - Energy Conservation, Consumption, & Utilization- Industrial & Agricultural Processes- Energy Sources; 320603 - Energy Conservation, Consumption, & Utilization- Municipalities & Community Systems- Public Utilities- (1980-); 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: Alumax Inc. decided to invest in a new smelter in Quebec on the basis of a special electricity rate of less than a penny per kilowatt hour, which is part of a strong bid by Hydro-Quebec to attract new industry. Two other companies will receive similar 4-year, 60% discounts. The utility recently brought 10,269 Mw of its James Bay hydroelectric power project on-line, and has a surplus capacity of about 25.2 billion kwh per year. Special rates will continue for a 20-year period.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy User News; (United States); Journal Volume: 9:7

TITLE: Floating hydro saves cash
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; COST; BARGES; POWER PLANTS; 299003* - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation- Other- (-1989); 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: A barge-mounted powerplant is being designed to garner power from the upper Mississippi River and installed in Genoa, Wisconsin. For most of the year the powerplant will generate 10 Mw of electricity while anchored between the spillway openings at a lock and dam. During floods or spring runoff, however, the powerplant will be disconnected, floated to the riverbank and moored. The floating plant is about 40% less expensive than building a conventional facility and could be used at any size lock and dam.
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 212:5

TITLE: Modeling rapidly varied flow in tailwaters
AUTHORS: Ferrick, M G; Bilmes, J; Long, S E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER GENERATION; RIVERS; HYDROLOGY; DAMS; FLOW RATE; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; ONE-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; SIMULATION; WATER CURRENTS; WATER QUALITY; WATER REQUIREMENTS; CURRENTS; ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: An understanding of the downstream propagation of sharp-fronted, large-amplitude waves of relatively short period is important for describing rapidly varying flows in tailwaters of hydroelectric plants and following the breach of a dam. A numerical model of these waves was developed by first identifying the primary physical processes and then performing an analysis of the solution. A linear analysis of the dynamic open channel flow equations provides relationships describing flow wave advection, diffusion, and dispersion in rivers. A one-dimensional diffusion wave model modified for application to tailwaters simulates the important physical processes and is straightforward to apply. The modified equation and von Neumann analyses provide insight into the effects of numerical parameters theta, ..delta..x, and ..delta..t upon stability and dissipative and dispersive behavior of the solution, but the Hirt analysis is found to yield incorrect phase relationships. The capability and accuracy of the model are enhanced when physical diffusion of a river wave is balanced by numerical diffusion in the model. Field studies were conducted in two greatly different tailwaters to assess our understanding of large-scale, rapidly varying flow waves. The accurate simulation of waves having wide-ranging amplitudes, shapes, periods, and base flows attests to the soundness of both the physical basis of the model and the numerical solution technique. These studies reveal that diffusion of short-period waves in natural, free-flowing rivers is significant and that inertia is negligible.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 20:2

TITLE: Market-based method for relicensing federal hydroelectric sites
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; SITE SELECTION; BIDS; CAPITALIZED COST; COMPETITION; LEASES; RATE STRUCTURE; COST; POWER PLANTS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296001 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: A procedure is proposed which can resolve a problem that will otherwise be a source of intense conflict with in the electric utility industry for a long time to come; namely, competition from publicly owned electric systems for acquisition of federally licensed hydroelectric projects held by investor-owned systems when their existing licenses expire. A method of resolving the conflict which will best serve the interests of both taxpayers and electric ratepayers and electric rate-payers nationwide is described.
RESEARCH_ORG: QED Research Inc., Palo Alto, CA
RELATION: Journal Name: Public Util. Fortn.; (United States); Journal Volume: 113:2

TITLE: California hydro job OK'd
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; PLANNING; CALIFORNIA; CONSTRUCTION; COST; TUNNELS; FEDERAL REGION IX; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; UNDERGROUND FACILITIES; USA; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: This article discusses a construction contract for the 200-MW peak usage Balsam Meadow hydroelectric project, the first power project start in the state to follow new public utilities commission funding guidelines. The plan calls for blasting nearly 4 miles of 18-ft. diameter tunnels through granite as well as construction of a rockfill dam and an underground powerhouse. Other packages for the three-year job will add roads and mechanical and electrical work. In an average hydro year the project will displace 340,000 bbl of oil and gas. Annual hydrocarbon emissions in the Los Angeles basin will be reduced by 500 tons.
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 212:3

TITLE: Clean water, dirty dams: oxygen depletion and the Clean Water Act
AUTHORS: Attey, J W; Liebert, D R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; CLEAN WATER ACT; ENFORCEMENT; DAMS; WATER POLLUTION; OXYGEN; DISSOLVED GASES; SURFACE WATERS; CASE LAW; ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY; LEGAL ASPECTS; WATER QUALITY; ELEMENTS; ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY; FLUIDS; GASES; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; LAWS; NONMETALS; POLLUTION; POLLUTION LAWS; SOLUTES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 520600 - Environment, Aquatic- Regulations - (-1989); 290300 - Energy Planning & Policy- Environment, Health, & Safety
