TITLE: Comparison between the tectonic stress measured in situ and stress parameters from induced seismicity at Monticelo Reservoir, South Carolina
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SOUTH CAROLINA; WATER RESERVOIRS; STRESS ANALYSIS; DAMS; EARTHQUAKE MAGNITUDE; EARTHQUAKES; SEISMIC SOURCES; SEISMIC WAVES; SHEAR; FEDERAL REGION IV; NORTH AMERICA; SEISMIC EVENTS; SURFACE WATERS; USA; 580201* - Geophysics- Seismology & Tectonics- (1980-1989); 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: During May and early June 1979, five three-component digital seismographs were deployed near the Monticello Reservoir, South Carolina, to determine the stress drops of reservoir-induced earthquakes and compare them with earlier hydrofracture stress measurements of Zoback and Hickman (this issue). Records for 327 events were obtained; 10 of these events, each recorded on four or more stations, were analyzed to determine stress drops. Depths for the 10 events ranged from 0.5 to 1.4 km. Fault plane orientations were calculated from an inversion of the body wave displacements; individual radiation pattern corrections were applied in calculating the moments at each station. Final estimates of seismic moment were obtained from the individual estimates of the source radius, and stress drop was then calculated once from the final estimates of seismic moment and source radius for each event. Moments of the 10 digitally recorded earthquakes ranged from 2.5 x 10/sup 17/ to 2.7 x 10/sup 18/ dyne cm for the P wave data and from 4.6 x 10/sup 17/ to 4.6 x 10/sup 18/ dyne cm for the S wave data. The stress drops (S wave data only) generally ranged from about 0.2 to 4 bars. Four earthquakes were recorded by a strong motion instrument at the dam site. Magnitudes (M) for these events ranged from 2.8 to 3.0. Moments taken as averages of the values from each component ranged from 1.7 to 3.4 x 10/sup 20/ dyne cm and the stress drops from 13 to 92 bars. The variation in shear stress inferred from in situ measurements at the deeper levels indicates an inconsistency between the thrust-faulting mechanisms of the earthquakes and the state of stress which is more consistent with thrust faulting at 0.2-km depth and strike slip or normal faulting below. Thus the estimates of shear stress from in situ measurements of the same order as the stress drops of the Mapprox. =2.8-3.0 events but about 1 order of magnitude larger than the stress drops obtained for the smaller events.
RESEARCH_ORG: U.S. Geological Survey, Menlo Park, California 94025
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 87:B8

TITLE: Geology of the area of induced seismic activity at Monticello Reservoir, South Carolina
AUTHORS: Secor, Jr, D T; Smith, W A; Snoke, A W; Peck, L S; Pitcher, D M; Prowell, D C; Simpson, D H
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SOUTH CAROLINA; GEOLOGIC HISTORY; WATER RESERVOIRS; STRATIGRAPHY; DAMS; DIKES; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; PETROLOGY; SEISMICITY; STRESS ANALYSIS; FEDERAL REGION IV; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; GEOLOGY; NORTH AMERICA; SURFACE WATERS; USA; 580100* - Geology & Hydrology- (-1989); 580201 - Geophysics- Seismology & Tectonics- (1980-1989); 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: This study provides geological background information necessary for an evaluation of the earthquake hazard in an area of induced seismic activity at Monticello Reservoir, South Carolina. This region contains a thick stratified sequence of Proterozoic Z and Cambrian metasedimentary and metavolcanic rocks. In the early to middle Paleozoic, this sequence was recrystallized and deformed under metamorphic conditions that ranged from greenschist to amphibolite facies and experienced at least two episodes of folding. The region has been intruded by late kinematic to postkinematic granitoid plutons of Silurian and Carboniferous ages and by numerous northwest trending diabase diks of Late Traissic and Early Jurassic age. The region south of Monticello Reservoir in the Carolina slate belt experienced two episodes of faulting in the late Paleozoic and/or early to middle Mesozoic. The older group of faults trends approximately east, has only small displacements, and is characterized by extensive silicifiction of the fault zones. The younger group of faults trends approximately north has experienced dip slip displacements up to 1700 m and is characterized by carbonate mineralization in the fault zones. Both sets of faults are cut by an undeformed diabase dike of Late Triassic or Early Jurassic age. The induced seismic activity around Monticello Reservoir is occurring in a heterogeneous quartz monzonite pluton of Carboniferous age. The pluton contains large enclaves of country rock and is cut by numerous, diversely oriented small faults and joint. These local inhomogeneities in the pluton together with an irregular stress field are interpreted to control the diffuse seismic activity around the reservoir. In view of the apparent absence of lengthy faults it is unlikely that a large-magnitude earthquake will occur in response to the stress and pore pressure changes related to the impoundment of Monticello Reservoir.
RESEARCH_ORG: Department of Geology, University of South Carolina, Columbia, South Carolina 29208
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 87:B8

TITLE: In situ study of the physical mechanisms controlling induced seismicity at Monticello Reservoir, South Carolina
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SOUTH CAROLINA; WATER RESERVOIRS; FRACTURE MECHANICS; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; HYPOCENTERS; PERMEABILITY; PRESSURE DEPENDENCE; RISK ASSESSMENT; SEISMICITY; STRESS ANALYSIS; FEDERAL REGION IV; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; NORTH AMERICA; SURFACE WATERS; USA; 580201* - Geophysics- Seismology & Tectonics- (1980-1989); 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: In two -1.1-km-deep wells the magnitudes of the principal in situ stresses, pore pressure permeability and the distribution of faults, fractures, and joints were measured directly in the hypocentral zones of earthquakes induced by impoundment of Monticello Reservoir, South Carolina. Analysis of these data suggests that the earthquakes were caused by an increase in subsurface pore pressure sufficiently large to trigger reverse-type fault motion on preexisting fault planes in a zone of relatively large shear stresses near the surface. The measurements indicated (1) near-critical pore pressure at depth relative to preimpoundment conditions, (3) the existence of fault planes in situ with orientations similar to those determined from composite focal plane mechanisms, and (4) in situ hydraulic diffusivities that agree well with the size of the seismically active area and time over which fluid flow would be expected to migrate into the zone of seismicity. Our physical model of the seismicity suggests that infrequent future earthquakes will occur at Monticello Reservoir as a result of eventual pore fluid diffusion into isolated zones of low permeability. Future seismic activity at Monticello Reservoir is expected to be limited in magnitude by the small dimensions of the seismogenic zones.
RESEARCH_ORG: U.S. Geological Survey, Menlo Park, California 94025
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 87:B8

TITLE: Hydraulic-turbine control is simple for small power production
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 42 ENGINEERING; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; SPEED REGULATORS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ELECTRIC POWER; INDUCTION GENERATORS; PUMPS; SAFETY; SYNCHRONIZATION; TORQUE; TURBOGENERATORS; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; POWER; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 420800 - Engineering- Electronic Circuits & Devices- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: How small hydraulic turbines produce power to drive one of two basic types of generators (induction or synchronous) to generate electric power is examined. Most small hydraulic turbines/generators are used to supplement power to the utility grid. Summarizes the differences between induction and synchronous generators, and notes that for most small-hydropower applications, the induction generator is usually the best choice. Advantages of the synchronous generator are that it is suitable for isolated operation, it contributes to the maintenance of system voltage and power factor, and, in general, it has higher efficiencies. Safety precautions are outlined. Exact speed regulation needed at utility hydro plants is unnecessary when the turbine/generator is merely supplementing power to the main grid.
RELATION: Journal Name: Power; (United States); Journal Volume: 126:8

TITLE: Computers help control hydropower
AUTHORS: Rosenthal, J L; Lufker, L J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 25 ENERGY STORAGE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; AUTOMATION; COMPUTERS; OPERATION; CONTROL SYSTEMS; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 250300 - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Automation is not confined to the operation of nuclear and fossil generation facilities; it also has direct application to both run-of-the-river and pumped-storage hydropower plants. At the St Lawrence-FDR and Blenheim-Gilboa stations of the Power Authority of the State of New York, computers monitor and supervise power generation and water flow to optimize the overall efficiency of these major hydro projects.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. World; (United States); Journal Volume: 196:8

TITLE: Rock engineering: La Grande Complex, Quebec
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; QUEBEC; EXCAVATION; EXPLORATION; GEOLOGY; POWER RANGE 10-100 GW; ROCK DRILLING; ROCKS; SUPPORTS; TUNNELS; CANADA; DRILLING; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; UNDERGROUND FACILITIES; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The paper presents an overview of rock engineering considerations in the Complex as related particularly to excavation and support problems. Examples are chosen to show the range of geological conditions encountered together with the engineering philosophy that has governed their treatment. Experience gained with unlined tunnels and channels for hydraulic purposes is discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geotech. Eng. Div., Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 108:GT8
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Geotech. Eng. Div., Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States)

TITLE: Hydraulic-turbine control is simple for small power production
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; CONTROL SYSTEMS; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SAFETY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Exact speed regulation needed at utility hydro plants is unnecessary when turbine/generator is merely supplementing power to the main grid. Control of two basic types of generator - induction or synchronous - is described. The advantages of each of them are pointed out. Safety precautions to be taken are indicated.
RELATION: Journal Name: Power; (United States); Journal Volume: 126:8

TITLE: Computer representation of electrical system interaction with hydraulic turbine and penstock
AUTHORS: Coprington, J B; Faivey, H T; Harrison, M; Periera, L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; CONTROL; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ENGINEERING; HYDRAULICS; PENSTOCKS; PROGRAMMING LANGUAGES; TURBINES; FLUID MECHANICS; MACHINERY; MECHANICS; PIPES; POWER PLANTS; SIMULATION; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: In the design of a hydroelectric generating plant, the major engineering disciplines assume responsibility for various items of equipment. It is difficult to examine the dynamic relationships that may exist between the penstock, the turbine and governor, and the generator and electrical system. Computer models are available to represent hydraulic transient phenomena in detail, and separate detailed representations of the electrical system are also available. This paper discusses a computer modelling approach that uses a high level computer language to represent hydraulic effects, including water hammer, concurrently with a detailed representation of the turbine, generator, controls and the electrical system.
RESEARCH_ORG: Acres Consulting Services, Niagara Falls, Canada
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Power Appar. Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: PAS-101:8
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Trans. Power Appar. Syst.; (United States)

TITLE: An approach to optimizing reservoir operation for downstream aquatic resources
AUTHORS: Sale, M J; Brill, Jr, E D; Herricks, E E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; WATER RESERVOIRS; OPERATION; ECONOMICS; FISHES; FLOOD CONTROL; FLOW RATE; ILLINOIS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPTIMIZATION; PLANNING; RECREATIONAL AREAS; WATER RESOURCES; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; CONTROL; FEDERAL REGION V; NORTH AMERICA; RESOURCES; SURFACE WATERS; USA; VERTEBRATES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: The issue of instream flow maintenance for downstream aquatic resources is a relatively new environmental quality consideration required in planning water resources projects. A mathematical programing methodology is proposed to examine the relationship between biological instream flow needs (IFN) and more traditional water project objectives, such as water yield, flood control, reservoir recreation, or economic efficiency. This optimization approach combines the linear decision rule (LDR) modeling technique with an objective function representing the value of reservoir releases to downstream fisheries. The IFN performance objective is based on an index of physical habitat conditions called weighted usable area (WUA) which has been developed by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. Data from a multipurpose reservoir in central Illinois have been used to demonstrate the application of the nonlinear programing model and a heuristic solution algorithm employing piecewise linearization of the habitat objective functions and linear programing.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:4

TITLE: Reliability programming in reservoir management. 3. System of multipurpose reservoirs
AUTHORS: Simonovic, S P; Marino, M A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; WATER RESERVOIRS; OPERATION; ECONOMICS; FLOOD CONTROL; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; IRRIGATION; LEVELS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OKLAHOMA; OPTIMIZATION; PIPELINES; POWER GENERATION; RELIABILITY; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; RISK ASSESSMENT; TEXAS; WATER QUALITY; WATER SUPPLY; CONTROL; ENGINEERING; ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY; FEDERAL REGION VI; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; USA; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: A reliability programming technique, which includes the concept of 'reliability or risk' in an optimization, is applied to multiple multipurpose reservoir systems. The procedure can be applied to any multipurpose multiunit reservoir system with two general types of linkage: normal channel flow for reservoir releases and pipelines or pumping canals. Thus each reservoir could be connected to every other reservoir, and each could receive releases from any or all other reservoirs as dictated by a particular system configuration. A two-level solution algorithm is proposed. A solution can be obtained for a reservoir system with few purposes (flood control, power production, irrigation, water supply, and water quality enhancement) and random inflows and demands. The random inflows and demands are represented by conditional distribution functions. The objective function of economic efficiency, representing the tradeoff between benefits and risks embodied by a risk-loss function, is included in the present approach. The reliability programming model is nonlinear and can be split into two models: search model and special linear programming model. The procedure is illustrated using a portion of the Red River system in Oklahoma and Texas, a system of three multipurpose reservoirs. The three reservoirs individually satisfy purposes (flood protection hydroelectric power generating, water supply, and water quality enhancement, and two of the reservoirs work together to satisfy additional water requirements (flood control and water quality enhancement downstream). Input data necessary for solving the optimization model are presented.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:4

TITLE: A stochastic dynamic programing model for the operation of the Mediterranean-Dead Sea project
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DEAD SEA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; WATER RESOURCES; MEDITERRANEAN SEA; DRAINAGE; DYNAMIC PROGRAMMING; FLOW RATE; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPTIMIZATION; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; STOCHASTIC PROCESSES; ENGINEERING; LAKES; POWER PLANTS; PROGRAMMING; RESOURCES; SEAS; SURFACE WATERS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Construction of the Mediterranean-Dead Sea Project and exploitation of the elevation differences becomes possible as a result of the reduction in the Dead Sea water levels due to increased withdrawals from its drainage basin over the past 50 years. These withdrawals would be replaced by a controlled inflow of water from the Mediterranean, which would generate hydroelectric power. An optimization of the annual Mediterranean water inflows, taking into account the high variability of the remaining natural inflows to the Dead Sea, is carried out by applying a stochastic dynamic programing algorithm to maximize the discounted expected value of the plant benefits. In addition the algorithm determines the operational level of the Dead Sea with respect to the probability of occurrence of high hydrologic flows.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:4

TITLE: Analysis of the effect of changing discharge on channel morphology and instream uses in a braided river, Ohau River, New Zealand
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; NEW ZEALAND; RIVERS; DEPTH; FISHES; FLOW RATE; LEVELS; MORPHOLOGY; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; AUSTRALASIA; DIMENSIONS; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; VERTEBRATES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Constant discharges of 26.5, 56.7, 105, 240, and 507 m/sup 3/ s/sup -1/ were released down the Ohau River from Ohau A power station, and measurements of water depths and mean velocities made along cross sections in a braided section of the channel. Frequency distributions of water depth and velocity are presented both singly and jointly for each discharge; the methods used provide much more information on the changing character of the river than is provided by conventional hydraulic geometry relations. As discharge increases, existing channels become wider, deeper, and faster and frequency merge to become a single-larger channel. However, additional channels are generated with the same characteristics as those existing at lower discharges, and the total number of channels at a cross-section remains constant. Hence the increase of water surface area tends to be by addition of faster, deeper water to a constant area of shallow, slow water (whose location in the river bed changes). This process has the major implication for instream uses such as salmonid spawning in that the area suitable for these uses may remain constant over a wide range of flows. In some respects, then, the braided river is morphologically more stable than a single-thread river.
RESEARCH_ORG: Water and Soil Science Centre, Christchurch, New Zealand
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:4

TITLE: Turbine rpm relay for hydroelectric power plants
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; SPEED REGULATORS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PERFORMANCE; OPERATION; RELAYS; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: During startup, operation and shutdown of hydroelectric power plants, the rpm relay signals the plant automatic control system when the turbines rpm's reach the specific level given by the relay setting. The operation of the turbine speed regulator is discussed. This speed regulator may be used to modernize existing hydroelectric power plants or in the construction of new plants.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 11:7; Other Information: Translated from Elektr. Stn.; 11: No. 7, 52-53(Jul 1982)

TITLE: Karstic mountain almost conquered. [Guatemala]
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; GUATEMALA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; DESIGN; ECONOMICS; INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; CENTRAL AMERICA; COOPERATION; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; ENERGY SOURCES; LATIN AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: International design and construction teams building a 300-Mw hydroelectric system high in central Guatemala's rugged mountains since 1977 have persevered through karstic-limestone nightmares, logistical bottlenecks and political upheaval to bring the $700-million Rio Chixoy project close to completion. The costly power push, requiring the largest construction effort in Guatemala's modern history, plays a critical role for the future. When all five Pelton-wheel turbines are spinning late next year, their output will more than double electricity production in Central America's poorest, most populous country. Despite numerous delays, design changes and cost increases above the original $240-million bid package, work has progressed to the final stages on a 360-ft-high rockfill dam, 16-mile power tunnel and aboveground powerhouse.
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 208:23

TITLE: Induced seismicity and style of deformation at Nurek reservoir, Tadjik SSR
AUTHORS: Keith, C M; Simpson, D W; Soboleva, O V
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; WATER RESERVOIRS; SEISMICITY; DAMS; DEFORMATION; HYPOCENTERS; SLIP; USSR; WAVE PROPAGATION; ASIA; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; SURFACE WATERS; 580201* - Geophysics- Seismology & Tectonics- (1980-1989); 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: Induced seismicity is occurring at the 315-m high Nurek dam in Tadjikistan, USSR. An intense burst of seismicity accompanied the second burst of seismicity accompanied the second stage of filling of the reservoir from 120 to 200 m during August to December 1976. Hypo-central locations and fault plane solutions determined using data from a 10-station telemetered network surrounding the reservoir show the activity to be concentrated on a series of narrow, planar fault zones near the central basin and on more diffuse zones along the upstream edges of the reservoir. The activtiy extends to depths of 8 km and appears to be confined within the upper plate of the Ionakhsh thrust, a listric fault which outcrops 1 km north of the dam. The dominant mode of deformation in the post-Paleozoic sediments of the Tadjik Depression is thrusting. Fault plane solutions for the induced seismicity show short segments of strike slip and thrust faulting for the most intense activity near the central basin and normal and thrust faulting along the upstream edges of the reservoir. None of the fault zones delineated by the induced seimicity corresponds to faults mapped at the surface, while none of the surface faults mapped in the reservoir area has shown an increase in seismicity. The spatial distribution of seismicity within the active zones is in general agreement with that expected from models of the changes in strength associated with reservoir loading. The temporal distrubition of seismicity shows a migration outward from the center of the reservoir, probably associated with diffusion of pore pressure.
RESEARCH_ORG: Lamont-Dohery Geological Observatory of Columbia University, Palisades, New York 10964
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 87:B6

TITLE: New England hydropower does a double take
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FEDERAL REGION I; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ECONOMICS; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT; WATER RESOURCES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; RESOURCES; USA; 296000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Recession and falling oil prices have reversed the economic incentives to develop small hydroelectric plants in New England. Ignorance of hydropower and conservative generating projections by utilities have helped to slow development. Only 250 of the 11,000 hydropower sites anticipated after the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978 was passed have been developed, but the industry remains hopeful that growth will continue. A federal study ranking New England hydropower above other renewable resources in cost-effectiveness is also encouraging. New England's dependence on oil and the availability of abandoned dams help to make water-generated power attractive. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: N.Engl. Bus.; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:9

TITLE: Lawrence hydroelectric project: resurrection of a low-head dam
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SPECIFICATIONS; DAMS; MASSACHUSETTS; FEDERAL REGION I; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; USA; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The Lawrence Hydroelectric Project, located on the Merrimac River in Lawrence, Mass, is one of the first hydro projects completed since the oil crisis and has set an important precedent for the development of other low-head generation systems in New England. The hydroelectric project is built alongside the old 920-ft-long granite dam. The plant uses two bulb-type Kaplan turbine/generator units, each rated at 8.4 MW.
RELATION: Journal Name: Power; (United States); Journal Volume: 126:4

TITLE: Textile plant spends $2. 5M for hydro
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 32 ENERGY CONSERVATION, CONSUMPTION, AND UTILIZATION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FINANCING; RETROFITTING; TEXTILE INDUSTRY; TURBINES; INDUSTRY; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBOMACHINERY; 296000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 320301 - Energy Conservation, Consumption, & Utilization- Industrial & Agricultural Processes- Energy Sources; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: A new $2.5 million turbine and a rebuilt 1906 hydroelectric power house could save a South Carolina textile plant $360,000 a year in avoided electricity costs. An existing 3000-kilowatt turbine combined with the new generator will produce over 30% of the plant's electric power. Payback calculations have been lowered from the original 9.9-year estimate because electricity prices are expected to rise about 22% a year. The double-regulated Kaplan-type hydroturbine's adjustable blades and wicket gate maximize available water flow from the Saluda River. It replaces two fixed-blade turbines dating from the first of the century. The power generated will supply lighting and processing needs, with excess generation sold to Duke Power Co. when the plant is not operating. A $2 million federal loan from the US Department of Housing and Urban Development will finance the project. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy User News; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:11

TITLE: Helping small scale hydro come back
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMP TURBINES; ECONOMICS; OPERATION; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The design, performance, and economics of vertical pumps run in reverse as turbines for small-scale hydroelectric power plants were studied. The results indicate that turbine-pumps provide significant advantages. They are simple to install, operate, and maintain. The pump tested can operate at efficiencies up to 87%, covering 30 to 60 ft of head, and flow rates up to 600 cfs. On the basis of cost per kilowatt hour, the reverse pump is competitive with a tubular turbine, and better than a Kaplan turbine. Capital investment for a pump is smaller than for a turbine. In cases where water can be impounded, a reverse pump can attain full water utilization. (The previous analysis was based on run of river operations.) A relatively small plant of 336 kW can provide power at a cost of 3.8 cents per kWh, which is lower than the units discussed above. When a small scale hydro power developer is limited by the amount of capital he can raise, the reverse pump arrangement should become attractive.
RELATION: Journal Name: Compressed Air; (United States); Journal Volume: 87:3

TITLE: Entrainment mortality of ichthyoplankton: detectability and precision of estimates
AUTHORS: Vaughan, D S; Kumar, K D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; ICHTHYOPLANKTON; ENTRAINMENT; MORTALITY; DATA COVARIANCES; PROBABILITY; SAMPLING; STATISTICS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; MATHEMATICS; PLANKTON; POWER PLANTS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The ability to detect and to develop a precise and accurate estimate of the entrainment mortality fraction is an important step in projecting power plant impacts on future fish populatin levels. Recent work indicates that these mortalities may be considerably less than 100% for some fish species in the early life stages. Point estimates of the entrainment mortality fraction have been developed based on probabilistic arguments, but the precision of these estimates has not been studied beyond the simple statistical test of the null hypothesis that no entrainment mortality exists. The ability to detect entrainment mortality is explored as a function of the sample sizes (numbers of organisms collected) at the intake and discharge sampling stations of a power plant and of the proportion of organisms found alive in the intake samples (intake survival). Minimum detectable entrainment mortality, confidence interval width, and type II error (probability of accepting the null hypothesis of no entrainment mortality when there is mortality) are considered. Increasing sample size and/or decreasing sampling mortality will decrease the minimum detectable entrainment mortality, confidence interval width, and type II error for a given level of type I error. The results of this study are considered in the context of designing useful monitoring programs for determining the entrainment mortality fraction. Preliminary estimates of intake survival and the entrainment mortality fraction can be used to obtain estimates of the sample size needed for a specified level of confidence interval width or type II error. Final estimates of the intake survival and the entrainment mortality fraction can be used to determine the minimum detectable entrainment mortality and the type II error.
RELATION: Journal Name: Environ. Manage.; (United States); Journal Volume: 6:2

TITLE: TVA hydro scheduling model: practical aspects
AUTHORS: Shane, R M; Gilbert, K C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; WATER RESERVOIRS; MANAGEMENT; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; COMPUTER CODES; COMPUTER GRAPHICS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INTERACTIVE DISPLAY DEVICES; TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY; DISPLAY DEVICES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 290400 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Resources
DESCRIPTION: Computer programs and mathematical methods have been developed to model long term week-to-week variations in water level, discharge and electrical generation for the 42 reservoirs operated by TVA. The model has an interactive structure with CRT graphics for easy use by TVA reservoir management personnel to evaluate the impact of new operating requirements on established objectives, check reservoir system status to warn of possible future problems, forecast reservoir system operation and develop new long range operation guides. Notable features of the model include: (1) The observation of important system operating constraints and priorities; (2) extreme event analysis capability; (3) a special linear programming structure that provides the flexibility to modify operating objectives and experiment with new types of long range efficiency guides; and (4) interactive CRT graphical output analysis.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Water Resour. Plann. Manage. Div., Proc. Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 108:WR1
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Water Resour. Plann. Manage. Div., Proc. Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States)

TITLE: Restoration of insulation of stator winding cores in hydroelectric generators
AUTHORS: Kutukov, L G; Klyuchanskii, O A; Seregin, L N
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 42 ENGINEERING; STATORS; ELECTRICAL INSULATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LIFETIME; MICA; PERFORMANCE; POWER PLANTS; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 420800 - Engineering- Electronic Circuits & Devices- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: An effective method was developed for restoring winding insulation of stators in hydroelectric generators that enables a significant increase in lifetime and an increase in reliability of the hydroelectric generator. In conjunction with the fact that most hydroelectric generators are subject to damaged stator windings owing to ionization processes, mass introduction of the method will yield a significant economic effect. The method enables performance of work to eliminate these defects during the period of major overhaul of a generator.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 11:2; Other Information: Translated from Elektr. Stn.; 11: No. 2 (Feb 1982)

TITLE: Evaluation of a system to automatically sample zooplankton from the discharge of dams
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SAMPLERS; EVALUATION; ZOOPLANKTON; AUTOMATION; CONNECTICUT; COST; DAMS; RIVERS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; EQUIPMENT; LABORATORY EQUIPMENT; NORTH AMERICA; NORTH ATLANTIC REGION; PLANKTON; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; USA; 520400* - Environment, Aquatic- Thermal Effluents Monitoring & Transport- (-1989); 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Automatic plankton samplers installed at two dams on the Connecticut River continuously monitored crustacean zooplankton from October 1977 through 1979 and allowed a significant reduction in man-hours involved in an extensive sampling program. Automatic samplers efficiently sampled most species and size classes of crustacean zooplankton in a similar, but not consistently identical manner as a commonly used towed-net plankton sampler. The smallest sized zooplankton were captured more efficiently than the largest. Mesh selection and sampler avoidance exerted different influences on automatic samplers and towed nets. Future use of the samplers and direct comparison of results to results obtained by other methods was supported.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:1

TITLE: Organizational and political considerations in the municipal development of small hydropower
AUTHORS: Heidell, P A; Kirshen, P H
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; POLITICAL ASPECTS; NORTH ATLANTIC REGION; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DAMS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; LOCAL GOVERNMENT; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; USA; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 293000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Policy, Legislation, & Regulation; 299003 - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation- Other- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The potential for hydroelectric power development at existing dams is great in oil dependent New England where there are over 10,000 dams presently in existence. Over 400 developments have been proposed in the region, the majority of which are small scale, and do not have major environmental impacts. Nevertheless, the variety of constraints may hinder development. A study of three efforts by municipalities in unique positions to develop hydropower reveals that organizational and political considerations are significant factors affecting development. Successful hydropower development requires: (1) the cooperation and interaction of citizens, government, and the private sector; (2) community interest and education; and (3) strong resolve.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:1

TITLE: Method for studying microbial biofilms in flowing-water systems
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; MICROORGANISMS; FILMS; OCEAN THERMAL POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; CORROSION; FILM FLOW; FLOW RATE; WATER; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ECOSYSTEMS; FLUID FLOW; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POWER PLANTS; SOLAR POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 520400 - Environment, Aquatic- Thermal Effluents Monitoring & Transport- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: A method for the study of microbial biofilms in flowing-water systems was developed with special reference to the flow conditions in electrochemical concentration cells. Seawater was circulated in a semiclosed flow system through biofilm reactors (3 cm s/sup -1/) with microscope cover slips arranged in lamellar piles parallel with the flow. At fixed time intervals cover slips with their biofilm were removed from the pile, stained with crystal violet, and mounted on microscope slides. The absorbances of the slides were measured at 590 nm and plotted against time to give microbial biofilm development. From calibration experiments a staining time of 1 min and a rinse time of 10 min in a tap water flow (3 cm s/sup -1/) were considered sufficient. When an analysis of variance was performed on biofilm development data, 78% of the total variance was found to be due to random natural effects; the rest could be explained by experimental effects. The absorbance values correlated well with protein N, dry weight, and organic weight in two biofilm experiments, one with a biofilm with a high (75%) and one with a low (approx.25%, normal) inorganic content. Comparisons of regression lines revealed that the absorbance of the stained biofilms was an estimate closely related to biofilm dry weight.
RELATION: Journal Name: Appl. Environ. Microbiol.; (United States); Journal Volume: 43:1

TITLE: Estimation of potential biomass resource and biogas production from aquatic plants in Argentina
AUTHORS: Fitzsimons, R E; Laurino, C N; Vallejos, R H
SUBJECT: 09 BIOMASS FUELS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; ANAEROBIC DIGESTION; ARGENTINA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FERTILIZERS; PRODUCTION; WATER POLLUTION CONTROL; METHANE; BIOSYNTHESIS; WATER HYACINTHS; DAMS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; LAKES; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; ALKANES; BIOCONVERSION; CONTROL; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; DIGESTION; HYDROCARBONS; LATIN AMERICA; MANAGEMENT; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; PLANTS; POLLUTION CONTROL; POWER PLANTS; PROCESSING; SOUTH AMERICA; SURFACE WATERS; SYNTHESIS; WASTE MANAGEMENT; WASTE PROCESSING; 090122* - Hydrocarbon Fuels- Preparation from Wastes or Biomass- (1976-1989); 140504 - Solar Energy Conversion- Biomass Production & Conversion- (-1989); 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The Argentine government's Agua y Energia Electrica is planning to construct a hydroelectric power-generation facility on the middle Parana River, which is already heavily infested with aquatic weeds such as water hyacinth. These species will probably proliferate in the lakes that will be formed by the power project and perhaps seriously interfere with the facility. As a solution to this problem, Argentine biochemists propose mechanical harvesting and anaerobic fermentation of the aquatic plants to produce biogas and fertilizer. According to an evaluation of this potential resource, gross methane production could reach 37-153 billion CF (1.0-4.1 billion m/sup 3/)/yr, and the digested residue could provide 60,500-244,000 tons (54,900-221,400 metric tons)/yr of nitrogen, which represents 2-8 times Argentina's current nitrogen fertilizer demand.
RESEARCH_ORG: Centro de Estudios Fotosinteticos y Bioquimicos, Ullo, Agrentina
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:8

TITLE: Effects of flushing Spencer Hydro on water quality, fish, and insect fauna in the Niobrara River, Nebraska
AUTHORS: Hesse, L W; Newcomb, B A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 63 RADIATION, THERMAL, AND OTHER ENVIRON. POLLUTANT EFFECTS ON LIVING ORGS. AND BIOL. MAT.; FISHES; BIOLOGICAL STRESS; MORTALITY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; NEBRASKA; WATER QUALITY; AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS; DISSOLVED GASES; OXYGEN; RECOMMENDATIONS; SEDIMENTS; WATER POLLUTION; WATER RESERVOIRS; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; ECOSYSTEMS; ELEMENTS; ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY; FEDERAL REGION VII; FLUIDS; GASES; NONMETALS; NORTH AMERICA; POLLUTION; POWER PLANTS; SOLUTES; SURFACE WATERS; USA; VERTEBRATES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 560305 - Chemicals Metabolism & Toxicology- Vertebrates- (-1987)
DESCRIPTION: Hydroelectric facilities with a low generating capacity (approximately one megawatt) such as Spencer Hydro on the Niobrara River in Nebraska are important, as referenced by the renewed interest in the revival of many that were deactivated with the advent of large fossil fuel and nuclear generating stations. The water reservoir impounded by the Spencer Dam is shallow and entrapped sediment quickly fills the pond, reducing power generating potential and threatening the internal components of the hydro station. This action requires periodic flushings to allow settled sediment to move past the station, resulting in adverse impacts on water quality, fish, and fish-food organisms in the 63.3 km of Niobrara River downstream from the dam. Investigations in 1979 revealed unacceptable low levels of DO (3.5-4.0 mg/liter), pronounced increases in turbidity (>400%) and suspended solids (4-fold), and a doubling of dissolved solids. Thirty species of fish were affected, with a conservative count of 22,471 dead fish plus others under extreme stress. Young fish were most affected. There also were large changes in the abundance of many species of immature aquatic insects. A series of corrective recommendations are proposed to alleviate the problem and enhance the fishery in the lower river.
RESEARCH_ORG: Nebraska Game and Parks Commission, Norfolk
RELATION: Journal Name: North Am. J. Fish. Manage.; (United States); Journal Volume: 2:1
JOURNAL_NAME: North Am. J. Fish. Manage.; (United States)

DESCRIPTION: The use of centrifugal pumps running in reverse as a substitute for small hydroturbines is described. All types of centrifugal pumps, from radial-flow to axial-flow geometry, can be operated in reverse and used as hydraulic turbines.
RELATION: Journal Name: Power; (United States); Journal Volume: 125:12

TITLE: Squeezing more from hydroelectric power
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; SITE SELECTION; ENGINEERING; EPRI; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 296000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 130000 - Hydro Energy
DESCRIPTION: Hydroelectric power, the one renewable energy source that is fully commercialized, ranked behind coal and natural gas in 1980, but ahead of nuclear and oil as a source of electric energy. The Electric Power Research Institute has groups studying new engineering techniques and ways to limit environmental impacts so that new sites, both large and small, can be developed. Research aimed at improving plant availability and output and on the economics of small hydro developed a simple, inexpensive preliminary site screening process. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: EPRI J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 6:10

TITLE: An analysis of mesh sizes required for screening fishes at water intakes
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FISHES; IMPINGEMENT; INHIBITION; INTAKE STRUCTURES; DESIGN; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; FORECASTING; POWER PLANTS; SCREENS; UNITED KINGDOM; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; DATA; EUROPE; INFORMATION; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; NUMERICAL DATA; VERTEBRATES; WESTERN EUROPE; 520500* - Environment, Aquatic- Site Resource & Use Studies- (-1989); 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Twenth-four species of marine and freshwater fish were examined to determine mesh size requirements for fish screens placed at water intakes. Curves relating fish length to the mesh size requirements are given for these species and a model for predicting mesh size requirements as a function of fish shape and size is presented. This is of superior accuracy in general application to a previous model given by Bell (1973) and appears to hold good for a wide range of fish species. Its practical application is discussed.
RESEARCH_ORG: Marine Biological Lab., Fawley, United Kingdom
RELATION: Journal Name: Estuaries; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:4

TITLE: Decomposition method for the long-term scheduling of reservoirs in series
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; WATER RESERVOIRS; ALGORITHMS; RIVERS; STOCHASTIC PROCESSES; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: This paper presents a method for determining the weekly operating policy of a power system of n-reservoirs in series; the method takes into account the stochasticity of the river flows. The method consists of rewriting the stochastic nonlinear optimization problem of two state variables which are solved by dynamic programming. The release policy obtained with this method for reservoir is a function of the water content of that reservoir and of the total amount of potential energy stored in the downstream reservoirs. The method is applied to a power system of four reservoirs, and the results obtained are compared to the true optimum. 16 refs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 17:6

TITLE: Wind and water: expanding energy technologies
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 17 WIND ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; MARKET; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; WIND POWER; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 299003* - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation- Other- (-1989); 130000 - Hydro Energy; 170000 - Wind Energy
DESCRIPTION: Interest in wind and water as renewable, non-polluting energy sources that are inexpensive to operate is receiving increasing attention. Utilities view clusters, or wind farms, as one solution to the problem of intermittent winds and high construction costs as research improvements in windmill design encourage optimistic estimates of wind supplying 20% of world energy needs and two percent of US electric power by 2000. Hydropower already contributes 4.1% of US energy and 12% of its electricity, but appropriate policies and incentives could bring abandoned and undeveloped small sites into use. 21 references, 4 tables. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Ed. Res. Rep.; (United States); Journal Volume: 2:19

TITLE: Hydro is back in vogue
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; ECONOMICS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; LOCAL GOVERNMENT; SITE SELECTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 130000* - Hydro Energy; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 290400 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Resources
DESCRIPTION: Small hydro power is attractive again as a result of new laws guaranteeing a market and investment tax credits as well as the economic, environmental, and availability advantages. Advocates who estimate that water will provide half the new capacity in the next century see it as an alternative to new coal and nuclear plants. Private companies have applied for over 2000 permits to study and develop hydro sites as the economic opportunities become known, although many will not progress beyond the feasibility-study stage. A preference clause gives municipalities the advantage, but creative joint applications by private companies give the advantage to the private sector. A national review of potential sites also reports retired plants that could be relicensed and recaptured. A directory lists the director and addresses of five regional Federal Energy Regulatory Commission offices where more information is available. 1 table. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Public Power; (United States); Journal Volume: 39:6

TITLE: Experimental investigation of apparatuses for electrical braking of 215 MW hydroelectric generators
AUTHORS: Gruzdev, I A; Ivanov, S A; Ragozin, A A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; BRAKES; PERFORMANCE; RELIABILITY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; USSR; ASIA; DATA; EASTERN EUROPE; EQUIPMENT; EUROPE; INFORMATION; MACHINE PARTS; NUMERICAL DATA; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The design, operation and performance of electric braking device for electric generators in hydroelectric power plants are discussed. Tests performed to determine the efficiency and parameters of the basic equipment for electrical braking devices and to investigate the electromechanical transient processes and to compare experimental and calculated results are described. It was found that the reliability of operation and the speed of the power portion of the electric braking device on generator voltage is fairly high. The activation time and shutoff time of the resistors without accounting for the detection portion of the control scheme does not exceed 0.04 s. A significant change in resistances of the resistors from the moment of installation of the braking device, even without activation under load was found. This results in a need during operation to monitor the resistances of the resistors and, if necessary, correct the controlling effects from the braking device. Calculations and experimental studies confirmed the fairly high efficiency of the braking devices of hydroelectric generators at the Zeiskaya Hydroelectric Power Plant under conditions of the existing scheme for power transmission. Similar devices can be recommended for use at power plants where there is a severe problem with regard to dynamic stability. (LCL)
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 10:11; Other Information: Translated from Elektr. Stn.; No. 11, 35-38(Nov 1981)

DESCRIPTION: British Columbia's potential alternatives to oil, including both large- and small-scale hydroelectric sites, biomass from forest wastes, and coal deposits, make nuclear power unnecessary. No clear energy development policy has been developed as yet because the environmental impacts associated with each will be controversial. Environmental concern is strong in the province because of its natural beauty. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Environment; (United States); Journal Volume: 23:8

The results of the first test of its kind have given experimental data contributing to this technology. Synchronous and non-synchronous vibrations were found to contribute to runout loading. TITLE: Turbines in the ocean
AUTHORS: Smith, F G.W.; Charlier, R H
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; GULF STREAM; WATER CURRENT POWER GENERATORS; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; COASTAL WATERS; EFFICIENCY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; FLORIDA; TURBOGENERATORS; UNDERWATER OPERATIONS; WATER CURRENTS; CURRENTS; FEDERAL REGION IV; NORTH AMERICA; SURFACE WATERS; USA; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: It is noted that the relatively high-speed ocean currents flowing northward along the east coast of the U.S. may be able to supply a significant proportion of the future electric power requirements of urban areas. The Gulf Stream core lies only about 20 miles east of Miami here its near-surface water reaches velocities of 4.3 miles per hour. Attention is called to the estimate that the energy available in the current of the Gulf Stream adjacent to Florida is approximately equivalent to that generated by 25 1,000-megawatt power plants. It is also contended that this power could be produced at competitive prices during the 1980s using large turbines moored below the ocean surface near the center of the Stream. Assuming an average ocean-current speed between 4 and 5 knots at the current core, the power density of a hydroturbine could reach 410 watts per square foot, about 100 times that of a wind-driven device of similar scale operating in an airflow of approximately 11 knots.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sea Front.; (United States); Journal Volume: 27

TITLE: Hydropower: an old technology for a new era
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; REMOTE AREAS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; SOCIAL IMPACT; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 296000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 130000 - Hydro Energy; 530000 - Environmental-Social Aspects of Energy Technologies- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: If properly managed, non-polluting hydropower offers stable prices, sustainability, and a proven technology. Hydropower developed throughout history to meet social and political needs, yet remains a largely untapped world resource. Large dams could solve many of the world's energy and food problems, but careful planning is required to avoid undesirable health and social costs, notably those caused by the displacement of people whose homes are flooded. The potential for small hydro can be of value for developed and Third World countries alike. Integrated water projects which are complementary and involve local planning and government involvement are needed. Recent changes in direction reflect the demand for power for mineral extraction and smelting in remote areas and involve international cooperation to follow the Chinese example of building a range of small to large dams to minimize the impacts and optimize the value to future generations. 48 references, 8 figures, 1 table. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Environment; (United States); Journal Volume: 23:7

SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; YANGTZE RIVER; CHINA; POWER RANGE 1-10 GW; ASIA; POWER PLANTS; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: A brief overview is given of the construction of 2 powerhouses (capacity 2715 MW), 3 single-stage navigation locks, a spillway and 2 silt sluices which comprise the first stage of the Gezhouba hydroelectric project on the Yangtze River. Second stage construction is mentioned, as is the Three Gorge scheme to be built upstream.
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 207:8

TITLE: Turbine screen protects fish at PG and E hydroelectric plant
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; DESIGN; INTAKE STRUCTURES; SCREENS; TURBINES; MACHINERY; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Hazards to fish from small hydro plants has less to do with head height than with runner elevation and mechanical injury from collision with objects. The need to keep fish out of turbines led to the design of a louvered screen that passes migrating fish by the turbine. A fish holding and counting system showed that about 75% of the salmon and steelhead were guided around the turbines. Earlier tests had determined that only 10% of the fish actually passing through the turbine flow were killed. A trash rack prevents clogging and maintains water pressure on the turbine. The screen can be modified to either a vertical or a horizontal plane. 2 figures. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. Light Power; (United States); Journal Volume: 59:8

TITLE: Introduction to the James Bay hydroelectric project
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; QUEBEC; WATER RESERVOIRS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; CANADA; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; ENGINEERING; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SIMULATION; SURFACE WATERS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 530100 - Environmental-Social Aspects of Energy Technologies- Social & Economic Studies- (-1989); 296001 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 290300 - Energy Planning & Policy- Environment, Health, & Safety
DESCRIPTION: Simulation modeling helped to assess the anticipated environmental and engineering problems for the James Bay project in Quebec, an area in which ecological recovery is slowed by the cold climate. Development plans for the sparsely populated region included 150 mostly earthen dams and lakes. Secondary development required facilities and roads for up to 16,000 people. The model approach is designed to anticipate and monitor environmental impacts and to integrate this knowledge into impact models of future reservoirs. 3 references, 2 figures 1 table. (DKC)
RESEARCH_ORG: Societe d'Energie de la Baie James, Montreal, Quebec
RELATION: Journal Name: Simulation; (United States); Journal Volume: 37:2

TITLE: Hydroelectric: economic, technical comparison of low head hydroelectric systems
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; ECONOMICS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: As an alternative electric energy source, low head rivers and other water-power energy sources are receiving growing attention. Harnessing or upgrading these small scale, low head hydroelectric installations is necessary in order to compete with today's energy market. Improvements have come about by using turbines with a different and simplified technology from that developed for classic turbines. Turbine types for use in small scale, low head hydroelectric plants as energy recovery systems are presented and compared from economical and technical viewpoints, and typical installation units are described.
RESEARCH_ORG: Hydro Energy Syst Inc, New York, NY

TITLE: Electric river: salomon still run the Columbia, but hydropower is the bigger catch. [Full use of potential of Columbia River]
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; COLUMBIA RIVER; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; WATER RIGHTS; WATER RESOURCES; REGIONAL COOPERATION; COMPETITION; IRRIGATION; RESOURCE DEPLETION; COOPERATION; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 290400* - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Resources; 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: Centralized computers control virtually the entire length of the Columbia River to feed hydroelectric power plants, supply irrigation, prevent flooding, and aid migrating fish as it drops 2700 feet on its 1214 mile flow to the Pacific Ocean. The river carries a burden which may not be sustainable in the face of competing and incompatible demands. In spite of all the Columbia River development, the Pacific Northwest suffers a loss of topsoil which threatens food production, possible power interruptions wich threaten industrial development, and a decline in the salmon population. The river's size encouraged the feeling that it couldn't be depleted, but political pressure from Southern California now threatens to place even greater demands. A national water policy and an end to regional fighting is needed before massive water transfers should be developed. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Sci. 80 (Eighty); (United States); Journal Volume: 2:6

TITLE: Hydroelectric: renewed interest in old power source
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; DAMS; MODIFICATIONS; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; EFFICIENCY; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; FINANCING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 130000* - Hydro Energy; 296001 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The possibility of refurbishing retired small hydroelectric sites and identifying sites for new stations is receiving new interest in northern states hoping to lower the high costs of imported oil dependence. A 50 to 100% growth in hydropower capacity is expected as a result of a Corps of Engineers study that estimated 55 gigawatts could be generated from existing sites alone. Sites in Massachusetts, New York, Michigan, Minnesota, and Idaho show the greatest potential. Refurbishing efforts will upgrade the efficiency at 3,009 of the most promising of 20,000 low-head dams, which are becoming economically feasible again. Improvements range from minor changes to eliminate penstock leakage to major structural and equipment modifications that raise the reservoir level or provide new storage sites. Generating efficiency increases with water control, such as better gate design and special turbines to handle flood water. Rewinding worn turbines can improve plant efficiency. Streamlining license and permit procedures to make small development projects easier will help, but this will be offset if the loan program loses its funding. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Chilton's Oil Gas Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:7

TITLE: Off-handed push from Congress, speculators plunge into small hydro
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FINANCIAL INCENTIVES; LEGAL INCENTIVES; INVESTMENT; PERMIT APPLICATIONS; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: New federal provisions and regulations make investments in hydroelectric power development very attractive. Permit applicants now including national companies as well as local public or private interests have brought increased competition, multiple filings, shortages of permit review staff, and speculation. Federal loan programs mainly benefiting government or cooperative organizations rather than private firms have been or will be curtailed. A guaranteed market plus high oil prices still provide big incentives to small-scale hydro development. Hydroelectric systems produced about 12% of total US electric power in 1980, but estimates of a much greater potential capacity as well as economic, security, and environmental advantages, continue to attract new projects. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Natl. J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 13:22

TITLE: Falling water's new potential
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; TECHNOLOGY UTILIZATION; ECONOMICS; DESIGN; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 130000* - Hydro Energy; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: An ongoing study by the US Army Corps of Engineers indicates that there are enough realistic potential hydropower sites in the country to allow flowing water to produce as much electrical power as is being generated today by all othe means combined. The lifting of certain regulations coupled with the rising price of fossil fuels is now stimulating many utilities that abandoned small hydroplants years ago (because they weren't economical) to go back and redevelop them. One of the factors currently inpeding further development is controversy over converting free-flowing streams into reservoirs. Proponents point out that important design technology is now available to upgrade the dams and that power generation is an important tradeoff. 2 figures.
RELATION: Journal Name: Compressed Air; (United States); Journal Volume: 86:5

TITLE: Egypt: after the Aswan Dam
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; EGYPTIAN ARAB REPUBLIC; WATER RESERVOIRS; HEALTH HAZARDS; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; EMBANKMENTS; NILE RIVER; AFRICA; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; HAZARDS; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 290300* - Energy Planning & Policy- Environment, Health, & Safety; 530000 - Environmental-Social Aspects of Energy Technologies- (-1989); 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Ten years after its completion, the controversial Aswan High Dam's hydrologic and human consequences are clearer because of a joint US-Egyptian interdisciplinary study. Water supply and distribution is emerging as a major world resource problem with the recognition that unsafe drinking water and inadequate sanitation contribute to health problems. Dams provide water supplies, but they also create conditions favorable to the spread of water-borne diseases. The Aswan Dam solved problems of flooding and drought by opening 2.5 million acres to year-round irrigation, although some of the reclaimed land has been lost to urban expansion and shoreline erosion, and provides hydroelectric power. The negative effects include increasing soil salinity, changes in the water table, excessive downstream water plant growth, and diseases such as schistosomiasis and other intestinal parasites, and the social impact on the Nubians, whose homeland was flooded. Planners must use the information gathered in this study to see that the benefits outweigh the human costs. 22 references, 7 figures.
RELATION: Journal Name: Environment; (United States); Journal Volume: 23:4

TITLE: Increased heterozygosity at the Mdh-B locus in fish inhabiting a rapidly fluctuating thermal environment
AUTHORS: Zimmerman, E G; Richmond, M C
SUBJECT: 63 RADIATION, THERMAL, AND OTHER ENVIRON. POLLUTANT EFFECTS ON LIVING ORGS. AND BIOL. MAT.; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 59 BASIC BIOLOGICAL SCIENCES; COLD EFFLUENTS; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; GENETIC VARIABILITY; TEMPERATURE EFFECTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; DAMS; FISHES; GENOTYPE; RIVERS; TEXAS; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; BIOLOGICAL VARIABILITY; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; SOUTHWEST REGION; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; USA; VERTEBRATES; 560205* - Thermal Effects- Vertebrates- (-1987); 520400 - Environment, Aquatic- Thermal Effluents Monitoring & Transport- (-1989); 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 550400 - Genetics
DESCRIPTION: Populations of a common forage fish, red shiner Notropis lutrensis, were sampled from four localities on the Brazos River, Texas, affected by cold-water discharge from a hydroelectric dam and from unaltered sites in the same region. Polymorphism at the Mdh-B locus, encoding supernatant malate dehydrogenase, indicates that populations within 57 km of the dam are distinctive from other regional populations and possess a unique Mdh-B allele, have significantly higher levels of heterozygosity at the Mdh-B locus, represent a homogeneous set that have significantly different Mdh-B zygotic frequencies from other regional populations, and have significantly different Mdh-B zygotic proportions than would be expected under a Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium. Increased levels of heterozygosity in fish within 57 km of the dam were correlated with discharge-associated fluctuations in water temperature at sampling stations.
RELATION: Journal Name: Trans. Am. Fish. Soc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 110:3

TITLE: TVA hydro scheduling model: theoretical aspects
AUTHORS: Gilbert, K C; Shane, R M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; WATER RESERVOIRS; MANAGEMENT; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; COMPUTER CODES; ENERGY ACCOUNTING; H CODES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PROGRAMMING; TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY; ACCOUNTING; ENERGY ANALYSIS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 290400 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Resources
DESCRIPTION: The optimization procedures used in the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) HYDROSIM model are described. Scheduling of the TVA operated reservoir system poses a stochastic, nonlinear, multireservoir problem with both nonviolable (physical) and violable (operating) constraints. A linear programming procedure for implementing the preemptive priority constraints and a nonlinear search procedure for minimizing the power cost function are described. A guide development program based on stochastic dynamic programming is also described.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Water Resour. Plann. Manage. Div., Proc. Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 108:WR1
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Water Resour. Plann. Manage. Div., Proc. Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States)

TITLE: Estimation of small-scale hydropower potential
AUTHORS: Poppe, D A; Yeh, W W.G.
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; APPROPRIATE TECHNOLOGY; ENERGY MODELS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; SITE SELECTION; SITE SURVEYS; STATISTICAL MODELS; WATER RESERVOIRS; WATERSHEDS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: The high cost and increasing scarcity of fossil fuels have renewed interest in exploiting the remaining undeveloped hydroelectric energy potential of the United States. Since many of the technically ''easy'' large-scale hydropower sites have already been developed, recent attention has focused on small-scale (less than 15-MW potential) sites. An attempt has been made to identify and develop a statistical method of determining the hydropower potential of watersheds in California that in area are directly under 500 square mi from generally available watershed characteristics. Streamflow records, necessary for the traditional methods of estimating hydropower potential are often only short term or unavailable for many watersheds. By relating hydropower potential to watershed characteristics other than streamflow, estimates can be made regardless of whether streamflow records are available.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Water Resour. Plann. Manage. Div., Proc. Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 108:WR1
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Water Resour. Plann. Manage. Div., Proc. Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States)

TITLE: Computer model for small-scale hydropower policy analysis
AUTHORS: Kirshen, P H; Amlin, J S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; NORTH ATLANTIC REGION; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; LICENSING; PROGRAM MANAGEMENT; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MANAGEMENT; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SIMULATION; USA; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: A computer simulation model of the obstacles and incentives to the development of small-scale hydropower in New England is presented. It serves as an effective communication tool between analysts and policymakers, helping them understand the implication of policy recommendations to increase small-hydropower development. Only four of the factors affecting development are included in the model: economics, licensing, construction, and retirement. From a financial point of view, the most promising developers are municipalities and investor-owned utilities. In the year 2000, it may be feasible to develop sites costing approximately double the present costs. Small-scale hydropower will generally be developed now only if developers are willing to accept risks. The inflationary effects of licensing and the complexity of the process might be the major disincentives associated with licensing.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Water Resour. Plann. Manage. Div., Proc. Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 107:WR1
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Water Resour. Plann. Manage. Div., Proc. Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States)

TITLE: Tectonics and seismicity of the Toktogul reservoir region, Kirgizia, USSR
AUTHORS: Simpson, D W; Hamburger, M W; Pavlov, V D; Nersesov, I L
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; USSR; SEISMICITY; ASIA; DAMS; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; GROUND MOTION; MICROEARTHQUAKES; PLATE TECTONICS; WATER RESERVOIRS; EARTHQUAKES; EASTERN EUROPE; EUROPE; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; MOTION; SEISMIC EVENTS; SURFACE WATERS; TECTONICS; 580201* - Geophysics- Seismology & Tectonics- (1980-1989); 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The 214 m high Toktogul Dam will impound a 19.5-km/sup 3/ reservoir on the Naryn River in central Kirgizia. The reservoir lies along the Talas-Fergana fault, a major tectonic feature of central Asia. The nature of Cenozoic movements along the fault is in debate; however, there is considerable evidence of present-day right-lateral movement. The region is one of moderate to high seismicity. A magnitude 7.6 earthquake occurred in 1946, approximately 65 km from the dam, near the intersection of the Talas-Fergana fault and Chatkal ranges. Construction of the dam was completed in 1975 and by late 1979 the water level in the reservoir reached three fourths its final planned depth. Low-magnitude, induced earthquakes began as the water level first exceeded 100 m in late 1977. A microearthquake survey using portable instruments was carried out in July--August 1978 and a seven-station telemetered network was installed in October 1978. The largest of the induced earthquakes has been of magnitude 2.5; the activity is in the immediate vicinity of the dam at very shallow depths (2--5 km) and is related to water level. Preliminary analysis of data gathered during 1978--1979 shows a zone of activity, extending to 5 km depth, supporting geological evidence for an active reserve fault beneath the dam and parallel to the canyon of the Naryn River. Where the reservoir crosses the Talas-Fergna fault, 15 km upstream from the dam, the water level has not yet reached 100 m and seismicity along the Talas-Fergana has not shown any significant change related to filing of the reservoir.
RESEARCH_ORG: Lamont-Dohety Geological Observatory of Columbia University, Palisades, New York 10964
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 86:B1

TITLE: Solar Norway
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 14 SOLAR ENERGY; ECONOMIC GROWTH; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; NORWAY; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; BIOMASS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; SOLAR HEATING; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; EUROPE; HEATING; POWER; SCANDINAVIA; WESTERN EUROPE; 299000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation; 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 140901 - Solar Thermal Utilization- Space Heating & Cooling
DESCRIPTION: The analysis of Norway's energy future discusses the long-term potential role of renewable energy sources. It is found that Norway has sufficient renewable energy sources to supply all demands generated under conditions of continued economic growth, doubling the production of goods and services. A fully renewable energy system is outlined and could probably be operable and economically feasible by the year 2015. Hydropower would dominate such a system, with biomass and solar heating possibly being other major sources. 18 references, 3 figures, 2 tables.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Syst. Policy; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:4

TITLE: Old hydro generators: a valuable power resource
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MAINTENANCE; RETROFITTING; INSPECTION; POWER GENERATION; POWER PLANTS; 296000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Old hydro stations represent a valuable power resource. They should be maintained to assure their continuity of service and, where possible, they should be uprated to maximize power output for peaking or base load. After evaluating the condition of the turbine and generator, owners can determine whether or not efficiency and reliability have deteriorated. Deficiencies can be corrected during a planned outage or renewal parts kept on hand should a forced outage occur. By planning ahead, repair or uprate work costs can be reduced. All parts of a hydroelectric generating system should be evaluated for reliability. Uprate potential should be assessed when it appears that the turbine and/or generator can be uprated and auxiliary and control equipment must be given equivalent attention to assure system reliability. 2 figures.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. Forum; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:1

TITLE: Down by the old mill stream: a look at hydropower in the northeast
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; NORTH ATLANTIC REGION; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FINANCING; REGULATIONS; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; LEGAL ASPECTS; LICENSING; PUBLIC UTILITY REGULATORY POLICIES ACT; WATER RESOURCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; LAWS; NATIONAL ENERGY ACT; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; RESOURCES; USA; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The development, redevelopment, and preservation of small-scale hydro power sites at several specific locations in northeastern US are discussed in terms of licensing requirements, effects of recently enacted laws such as PURPA, financing, ownership, and socio-economic impacts. (LCL)
