TITLE: Fishery at the brink
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; COLUMBIA RIVER; SALMON; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; IRRIGATION; DAMS; FISHING INDUSTRY; FLOW RATE; HABITAT; POPULATION DYNAMICS; STANDARDS; WATER SUPPLY; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; FISHES; INDUSTRY; POWER PLANTS; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; VERTEBRATES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The gradual decline of the Columbia River salmon run, once the richest in North America, is traced. Alteration of the habitat and tremendous over exploitation of the fisheries have been the major contributors to this decline. All four salmon species native to the Columbia River have suffered. Up to 50% of the total catches from the river during the past year have been identified as products of artificial propagation. At present, because of demands of irrigation and electric power, the remaining fish have no guaranty of the minimum flows they need to survive. Demand by the Columbia River fisheries that the state governments of Oregon and Washington set minimum flow standards is gaining recognition.
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. For.; (United States); Journal Volume: 87:1

TITLE: Effects of hypolimnetic discharge on fish health below a reservoir
SUBJECT: 63 RADIATION, THERMAL, AND OTHER ENVIRON. POLLUTANT EFFECTS ON LIVING ORGS. AND BIOL. MAT.; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CHEMICAL EFFLUENTS; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; TROUT; SENSITIVITY; AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS; BACTERIA; BIOASSAY; DAMS; DOSE-RESPONSE RELATIONSHIPS; OXYGEN; PARASITES; TOLERANCE; TOXICITY; TURBULENCE; VIRUSES; WATER POLLUTION; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; ECOSYSTEMS; ELEMENTS; FISHES; MICROORGANISMS; NONMETALS; POLLUTION; POWER PLANTS; VERTEBRATES; 560400* - Other Environmental Pollutant Effects; 560305 - Chemicals Metabolism & Toxicology- Vertebrates- (-1987); 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Rainbow, brown, and brook trouts, and yellow perch from two locations in the Buford Dam, Georgia, tailwater and trout from a hatchery that used the tailwater as a water supply were examined for infections, lesions, and liver metal concentrations. Nine genera of parasites, 19 species of bacteria, and one species of virus infected the fish. River fish had no clinical signs of disease resulting from the pathogens. In the hatchery some deaths were caused by bacterial infections, but many moribund fish were not infected. Bacterial isolations from river fish were most frequent in fish collected near the dam and near the date of lowest dissolved oxygen (DO) concentration. Microscopic lesions were found in the gills, liver, spleen, and trunk kidney of many of the fish that did not have bacterial infections. Rainbow trout were most affected by the conditions in the tailwater and hatchery, and brook trout and yellow perch were least affected. Occurrence of lesions that indicated exposure to a toxicant corresponded to increases in Fe and Mn concentrations of the water, but not to Cu concentrations. Mn levels in liver were high compared to published reports. Cu concentrations in liver varied with fish species, and those of brook trout were lower than published values for this species exposed to no effect Cu levels. Liver concentrations of Zn and Cd did not indicate exposure to high levels of these metals. Cu, Zn, Fe, Mn, and DO concentrations of the tailwater were levels that indicated possible harmful effects to fish. Acclimation to the tailwater conditions may have allowed survival of fish. Low pH, oxidation-reduction potential, and DO concentrations, and high metal concentrations resulted from release of hypolimnetic water from the impoundment. Most bioassay data are not reliable for prediction of toxicity in tailwaters because of the water characteristics, acclimation of fish, and possible synergistic actions.
RELATION: Journal Name: Trans. Am. Fish. Soc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 110:1

TITLE: Effects of hypolimnetic discharge on fish health below a reservoir
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; BACTERIA; DISSOLVED GASES; FISHES; LIVER; METALS; PARASITES; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; BODY; DIGESTIVE SYSTEM; ELEMENTS; FLUIDS; GASES; GLANDS; MICROORGANISMS; ORGANS; VERTEBRATES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Several species of fish in the Chattahoochee River below the Buford Dam in Georgia and trout at a hatchery that used the tailwater for water supply were examined for infections, lesions, and liver metal concentrations. Nine genera of parasites, 19 species of bacteria, and one species of virus infected the fish. Bacterial isolations from river fish were most common in fish collected near the dam and at the time of lowest DO concentration. Microscopic lesions occurred in the gills, liver, spleen, and trunk kidney of many fish that did not have bacterial infections. Concentrations of manganese, copper, zinc, iron, and cadmium are reported. The level of many of these materials was high enough to harm the fish. However, acclimation to the tailwater conditions may have permitted survival of fish in the river.
RELATION: Journal Name: Trans. Am. Fish. Soc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 110:1

TITLE: Lifting hydro's potential
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 25 ENERGY STORAGE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; EPRI; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; SITE SELECTION; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 296001 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 250300 - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Electric utilities are taking another look at potential sites for hydroelectric installations, reevaluating sites that had been uneconomic to develop and those that can be renovated or expanded. Both large- and small-scale facilities now offer the advantages of free fuel, no air or thermal pollution, and no waste - making hydro an attractive way to increase utility capacity. The Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) is participating in screening studies which evaluate the unique characteristics of specific sites and recommend technical improvements for better water control and a higher output. Pumped-hydro facilities are increasing, with new attention going to underground storage as new aboveground sites become harder to find. The institutional hurdles of licensing and regulation, interference with recreational and shoreline activities, down-stream water temperature changes, fish migration, and insurance are often in conflict. EPRI's screening program includes a simplified cost/benefit analysis and a site characterization, which utilities can use for their evaluation. Future research will explore a new financing arrangement that will lower front-end costs. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: EPRI J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:10

TITLE: Gas bubble disease in smallmouth bass and northern squawfish from the Snake and Columbia Rivers
AUTHORS: Montgomery, J C; Becker, C D
SUBJECT: 63 RADIATION, THERMAL, AND OTHER ENVIRON. POLLUTANT EFFECTS ON LIVING ORGS. AND BIOL. MAT.; 59 BASIC BIOLOGICAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FISHES; SENSITIVITY; GAS BUBBLE DISEASE; PATHOLOGY; SUPERSATURATION; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; AIR; BLOOD CIRCULATION; EMBOLI; EMPHYSEMA; FRESH WATER; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MORPHOLOGY; QUANTITY RATIO; SOLUBILITY; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; DISEASES; FLUIDS; GASES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POWER PLANTS; RESPIRATORY SYSTEM DISEASES; SATURATION; VASCULAR DISEASES; VERTEBRATES; WATER; 560400* - Other Environmental Pollutant Effects; 550900 - Pathology; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: In 1975 and 1976, 179 smallmouth bass (Micropterus dolomieui) and 85 northern squawfish (Ptychocheilus oregonensis) were collected by angling from the lower Snake and mid-Columbia rivers, southeastern Washington. All fish were examined externally for gas bubble syndrome. Emboli were found beneath membranes of the opercula, body, and fins of 72% of the smallmouth bass and 84% of the northern squawfish. Hemorrhage was also noted on the caudal, anal, and pectoral fins of several smallmouth bass. Presence of gas bubble syndrome corresponded to the spring runoff when total dissolved gas supersaturations in river water exceeded 115%.
RELATION: Journal Name: Trans. Am. Fish. Soc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 109:6

TITLE: Severe gas bubble disease in a warmwater fishery in the midwestern United States
AUTHORS: Crunkilton, R L; Czarnezki, J M; Trial, L
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 63 RADIATION, THERMAL, AND OTHER ENVIRON. POLLUTANT EFFECTS ON LIVING ORGS. AND BIOL. MAT.; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FISHES; MORTALITY; SUPERSATURATION; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; AIR; ATMOSPHERIC PRESSURE; BIOASSAY; DAMS; FRESH WATER; GAS BUBBLE DISEASE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MASS; NITROGEN; QUANTITY RATIO; SOLUBILITY; TIME DEPENDENCE; WATER RESERVOIRS; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; DISEASES; ELEMENTS; FLUIDS; GASES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; NONMETALS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POWER PLANTS; SATURATION; SURFACE WATERS; VASCULAR DISEASES; VERTEBRATES; WATER; 520100* - Environment, Aquatic- Basic Studies- (-1989); 560400 - Other Environmental Pollutant Effects; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Gas bubble disease below Harry S. Truman Dam, sited on the upper Osage River and spilling into Lake of the Ozarks, caused the largest fish kill on record in Missouri. This is the first recorded evidence of serious supersaturation in the Midwest. Total gas saturation levels up to 139% killed nearly a half million fish in the upper 85 km of the Osage Arm, Lake of the Ozarks, during April to June, 1978 and 1979. Gas supersaturation occurred throughout the 150 km of this main-stem reservoir. Nitrogen was the primary gas responsible for gas bubble disease mortalities. Pelagic and near-shore species suffered the earliest and heaviest mortalities, but fish characteristic of deeper waters were increasingly killed as supersaturation persisted. Instream cage bioassays defined the zone of lethal supersaturation. Significant mortality occurred in bottom-dwelling fish of several species, due to long-term intermittent exposure. Susceptibility to gas bubble disease was related to fish size.
RELATION: Journal Name: Trans. Am. Fish. Soc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 109:6

TITLE: Analysis of supersaturated air in natural waters and reservoirs
AUTHORS: D'Aoust, B G; Clark, M J.R.
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SUPERSATURATION; MEASURING METHODS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; DAMS; MONITORING; QUANTITATIVE CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; RIVERS; SAMPLING; WATER RESERVOIRS; CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; SATURATION; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 520200* - Environment, Aquatic- Chemicals Monitoring & Transport- (-1989); 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Supersaturation of water by air or other gases can be caused by temperature increase, air or gas injection by pressurized pumping, or turbulent injection by falling water that traps air. The physics of supersaturation are outlined, and alternative sampling and analysis techniques used to evaluate the extent of supersaturation are described. These techniques range from complex, exacting procedures commonly used in the biomedical analytical laboratory to simple, portable methods suited to field application or continuous monitoring. Analytical techniques tested during 1976-78 in the Columbia and Snake river system, both of which were seriously supersaturated as a result of entrainment of air into water spilling over hydroelectric dams, are comparatively evaluated.
RESEARCH_ORG: Virginia Mason Research Center, Wash/British Columbia Dept of Env
RELATION: Journal Name: Trans. Am. Fish. Soc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 109:6

TITLE: Analysis of supersaturated air in natural waters and reservoirs
AUTHORS: D'Aoust, B G; Clark, M J.R.
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 63 RADIATION, THERMAL, AND OTHER ENVIRON. POLLUTANT EFFECTS ON LIVING ORGS. AND BIOL. MAT.; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SUPERSATURATION; QUANTITATIVE CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; THERMAL EFFLUENTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; TURBULENCE; AIR; ATMOSPHERIC PRESSURE; BUBBLES; CARBON DIOXIDE; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; FRESH WATER; GAS BUBBLE DISEASE; GAS CHROMATOGRAPHY; MASS; MATHEMATICS; NITROGEN; OXYGEN; SAMPLING; SOLUBILITY; TEMPERATURE EFFECTS; TIME DEPENDENCE; WATER RESERVOIRS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; CHROMATOGRAPHY; DISEASES; ELEMENTS; FLUIDS; GASES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; NONMETALS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SATURATION; SEPARATION PROCESSES; SURFACE WATERS; VASCULAR DISEASES; WATER; 520100* - Environment, Aquatic- Basic Studies- (-1989); 560200 - Thermal Effects; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 560400 - Other Environmental Pollutant Effects
DESCRIPTION: Supersaturation of air or other gases in water can be caused by a temperature increase, air or gas injection by pressurized pumping, or turbulent injection by falling water which traps air when spills are allowed by hydroelectric projects. Evaluation of this problem requires both an understanding of the physics of the situation and practical knowledge of a number of alternative techniques for analysis. These range from complex, exacting procedures commonly used in the biomedical analytical laboratory to simple, portable methods well suited to use in the field or continuous monitoring. The authors have reviewed and refined several of these methods, have developed others, and have compared relevant techniques in the field and laboratory.
RELATION: Journal Name: Trans. Am. Fish. Soc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 109:6

TITLE: Gas bubble disease in smallmouth bass and northern squawfish from the Snake and Columbia Rivers
AUTHORS: Montgomery, J C; Becker, C D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FISHES; EMBOLI; HEMORRHAGE; GAS BUBBLE DISEASE; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; AIR; COLUMBIA RIVER; DAMS; ENTRAINMENT; SUPERSATURATION; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; DISEASES; FLUIDS; GASES; PATHOLOGICAL CHANGES; RIVERS; SATURATION; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; SYMPTOMS; VASCULAR DISEASES; VERTEBRATES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Supersaturation of the Columbia and Snake River systems was caused by entrainment of air into water spilling over hydroelectric dams. Total gas saturations of 100% or more have occurred during the spring in each river system. External signs of gas bubble diseases were noted in adult Smallmouth bass and northern squawfish collected from the lower Snake and mid-Columbia rivers during 1975-76. Emboli occurred beneath membranes of the opercula body, and fins of 72% of the smallmouth bass and 84% of the northern squawfish. Hemorrhage was also noted on the caudal, anal, and pectoral fins of several fish.
RELATION: Journal Name: Trans. Am. Fish. Soc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 109:6

TITLE: Severe gas bubble disease in a warmwater fishery in the midwestern united states
AUTHORS: Crunkilton, R L; Czarnezki, J M; Trial, L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FISHES; MORTALITY; GAS BUBBLE DISEASE; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; DAMS; MISSOURI; RIVERS; SUPERSATURATION; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; DISEASES; MIDWEST REGION; NORTH AMERICA; SATURATION; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; USA; VASCULAR DISEASES; VERTEBRATES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Supersaturation of the water of the Osage River below the Harry S. Truman Dam resulted in an epidemic of gas bubble disease that caused the largest fish kill in the history of Missouri. This is the first recorded evidence of serious supersaturation in the midwestern U.S. Total gas saturation levels up to 139% killed nearly 500,000 fish in the Osage River and the Lake of the Ozarks during April-May 1978. Nitrogen was the primary gas responsible for gas bubble disease mortalities. Instream cage bioassays defined the zone of lethal supersaturation. Significant mortality occurred in pelagic and near-shore species, deepwater species, and bottom-dwelling species. Susceptibility to disease was related to fish size.
RELATION: Journal Name: Trans. Am. Fish. Soc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 109:6

TITLE: A review of dissolved gas supersaturation literature
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; GAS BUBBLE DISEASE; REVIEWS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; DISSOLVED GASES; RIVERS; SUPERSATURATION; SURFACE WATERS; DISEASES; DOCUMENT TYPES; FLUIDS; GASES; SATURATION; STREAMS; VASCULAR DISEASES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Gas bubble disease in a condition that affects aquatic animals residing in fresh or marine waters that are supersaturated with atmospheric gases. The majority of research concerning dissolved gas supersaturation has been stimulated by a serious supersaturation problem that was first observed in the Columbia and Snake river systems in 1970. Available literature dealing with dissolved gas supersaturation and recorded cases of gas bubble disease are reviewed. The causes of supersaturation, the organisms affected by supersaturation, factors influencing susceptibility of aquatic organisms to gas bubble disease, and various other related topics are explored.
RELATION: Journal Name: Trans. Am. Fish. Soc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 109:6

TITLE: Gas bubble disease: introduction
AUTHORS: Fickeisen, D H; Schneider, M J; Wedemeyer, G A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; GAS BUBBLE DISEASE; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; DAMS; FISHES; NITROGEN; OXYGEN; RIVERS; SUPERSATURATION; WATER RESERVOIRS; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; DISEASES; ELEMENTS; NONMETALS; SATURATION; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; VASCULAR DISEASES; VERTEBRATES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 290300 - Energy Planning & Policy- Environment, Health, & Safety
DESCRIPTION: In 1970, gas bubble disease was identified as a serious problem affecting salmonids in the Columbia and Snake river systems. The source of supersaturation was entrainment of air into water spilling over hydroelectric dams. Regional research projects focusing on tolerance bioassays were immediately implemented. Since then, the scope of gas bubble disease research has broadened to include problems in other aquatic systems, with other species. Emphasis has shifted from defining tolerance limits in bioassay systems to exploring behavioral and physiological aspects. Various methods of degasifying supersaturated water have been developed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Trans. Am. Fish. Soc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 109:6

TITLE: China: its power and people
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CHINA; ELECTRIC POWER; CULTURAL RESOURCES; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; POWER GENERATION; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY; ASIA; ENERGY SOURCES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; US ORGANIZATIONS; 296000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 530100 - Environmental-Social Aspects of Energy Technologies- Social & Economic Studies- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The visitor to China sees a people in motion, with the Tennessee Valley Authority slated to play a role in the direction to be taken by China's electric power technology. Comparable to the Tennessee Valley of the 1930's, China's vast hydroelectric and coal resources offer an opportunity for cooperation that will benefit both countries. Large dams are planned for the Yangtze River, but the Chinese need both technical and safety assistance as well as foreign financing. Reliable power plants are already in operation, but power generation is inadequate for the country's needs. Chinese patience and modest expectations are admirable and should be an example for Americans. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Public Power; (United States); Journal Volume: 38:5

TITLE: Circuits of peak power plants based on hydraulic and air accumulation
SUBJECT: 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; COMPRESSED AIR STORAGE POWER PLANTS; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; EFFICIENCY; ENERGY STORAGE; GAS TURBINES; HYDRAULIC ACCUMULATORS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; UNDERGROUND STORAGE; ACCUMULATORS; CONTAINERS; MACHINERY; MECHANICAL ENERGY STORAGE EQUIPMENT; POWER PLANTS; STORAGE; TANKS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 250200* - Energy Storage- Compressed & Liquified Gas; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Two plans are proposed for the development and improvement of air accumulating gas turbine plants (AGTP), where water is used along with air as a usefully used component and also directly as a working fluid. Under the first plan, the plant apart from its main function, of delivery to the power system of peak power can also be used for the exploitation of reserves of underground water for economic purposes. The second plan calls for the integration of AGTP with a hydraulic electric power plant. The second plan is suitable for a region where an underground cavity can be created in the form of a free volume in bedrock withstanding high pressure. As a whole, the combined power plants can be a fairly effective source for providing peak loads of power systems in the regions where the conditions of their construction are met.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 9:9; Other Information: Translated from Elektr. Stn.; 9: No. 9, 63(Sep 1980)

TITLE: Rotation frequency relay for hydrogenerator
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TURBOGENERATORS; RELAYS; PERFORMANCE; CONTROL SYSTEMS; CAPACITORS; FREQUENCY CONTROL; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; RECTIFIERS; TRANSISTORS; VOLTAGE REGULATORS; CONTROL; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The rotation frequency relay (RFR) is one of the most critical elements of automatic control system of the hydrogenerators. Accurate fixing of braking, subsynchronous and acceleration angular speeds contribute to operational reliability of many units of mechanical and electrical parts of the hydrogenerator and vise versa. Both experimental and theoretical investigations were performed on hydrogenerators. It was concluded that the rotation frequency relay, where an integrated voltage of the regulator generator is used as reference voltage and the elements of comparison are executed on the operating amplifiers, has a fairly high accuracy and stability of settings, and practically does not require regulation for manufacture and operation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 9:9; Other Information: Translated from Elektr. Stn.; 9: No. 9, 56-62(Sep 1980)

TITLE: Investigation of the electric strength of insulation of a 500 kV disconnecting switch for the Sayano-Shushenskoye hydroelectric power station
AUTHORS: Rudakova, V M; Tabardanova, M P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; POWER TRANSMISSION LINES; SWITCHES; ELECTRICAL INSULATION; ELECTRIC DISCHARGES; ELECTRIC POTENTIAL; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; LIGHTNING; LIGHTNING ARRESTERS; POWER PLANTS; USSR; ASIA; DATA; EASTERN EUROPE; ELECTRIC POWER; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; ENERGY SOURCES; EQUIPMENT; EUROPE; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 200300 - Electric Power Engineering- Power Transmission & Distribution- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The electric strength of contact clearance and of supporting insulation was determined by a smooth rise in voltage of commercial frequency an positive polarity of oscillatory pulses with the edge of the first semiwave of 4000 ..mu..sec, and aperiodical pulses of 290/3000 ..mu..sec, on lightning pulses of both polarities. The minimum length at which the sustained voltage of contact clearance meets the norms of the specifications for a small-sized disconnecting switch of 500 kV is equal to 3.1 m. The test of switches with grounding of one contact produces reduced discharge voltage characteristics of contact clearance and can lead to an unjustified increase in the margins of electric strength of the switch.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 9:9; Other Information: Translated from Elektr. Stn.; 9: No. 9, 42-45(Sep 1980)

TITLE: Salto Grande. [1890-MW project on Vruguay River]
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; ARGENTINA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; URUGUAY; BILATERAL AGREEMENTS; DAMS; INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; AGREEMENTS; COOPERATION; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; INTERNATIONAL AGREEMENTS; LATIN AMERICA; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SOUTH AMERICA; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 530100 - Environmental-Social Aspects of Energy Technologies- Social & Economic Studies- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: A joint hydroelectric project, the Salto Grande Dam on the Uruguay River, serves six million people in Argentina and Uruguay. The construction day was continuous from April 1974 until the first turbine began on schedule in July 1979. Although planning began in 1890 by individual visionaries who saw the river's potential, serious efforts did not get underway for another 50 years. The project became a technical training school and has built up a recognized management team in the process. Financing became available only after the 1973 oil embargo. The benefits of regional cooperation to develop a common resource enables the two countries to provide water resources, electric power, navigable streams for commerce and recreation, a common highway, and an interconnecting railroad. The cooperative infrastructure established to meet the needs of project personnel has improved living conditions for the area. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Americas; (United States); Journal Volume: 32:9

TITLE: Australasian utilities fight environmental protests
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; AUSTRALIA; ELECTRIC POWER; NEW ZEALAND; POWER GENERATION; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; ECONOMIC GROWTH; EMPLOYMENT; PUBLIC OPINION; AUSTRALASIA; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; POWER; 296000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 130000 - Hydro Energy; 290200 - Energy Planning & Policy- Economics & Sociology; 530000 - Environmental-Social Aspects of Energy Technologies- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Electric utilities in Australia are meeting increased opposition to plant construction from community and union groups. The newly completed Newport D plant was built behind guarded fences even though the station is essential to meet new power demand. A hydroelectric project proposed for Tasmania has sparked intense controversy from those who feel alternative energy sources will provide more jobs and do less environmental damage. New Zealand's South Islanders are protesting a new hydro project because a previous project is still generating surplus power. The utilities are pushing for new generating capacity to meet the anticipated demand of new industry, especially aluminum smelting and refining. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 17:9

TITLE: Cable lines for 500 kV
AUTHORS: Makienko, G P; Kuznetsov, A L; Stolbov, Yu V
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; EHV AC SYSTEMS; POWER TRANSMISSION LINES; OIL-FILLED CABLES; DESIGN; INSTALLATION; ELECTRICAL INSULATION; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; HIGH PRESSURE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LABOR; SPECIFICATIONS; AC SYSTEMS; CABLES; CONDUCTOR DEVICES; DATA; ELECTRIC CABLES; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; ENERGY SYSTEMS; EQUIPMENT; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA; POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; 200300* - Electric Power Engineering- Power Transmission & Distribution- (-1989); 130000 - Hydro Energy
DESCRIPTION: Application, design, and installation of the cable line in steel pipe with oil under pressure for 500 kV is considered. The cable construction and design specifications are presented. Manpower requirements for the installation of the cable, extending from the hydrogenerators to the outdoor switchgears or to the change point where they are connected to overhead power lines, are discussed and data provided.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 9:8; Other Information: Translated from Elektr. Stn.; 9: No. 8, 51-55(Aug 1980)

TITLE: Single-machine high-frequency excitation system of turbogenerators of the type TVV-320-2 and TVV-500-2
AUTHORS: Naumov, V F; Lukashev, N I; Savchenko, E V
SUBJECT: 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; EXCITATION SYSTEMS; PERFORMANCE; POWER PLANTS; TURBOGENERATORS; AMPLIFIERS; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; ELECTRIC POTENTIAL; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; FREQUENCY RANGE; OSCILLOGRAPHS; RECTIFIERS; SPECIFICATIONS; STABILITY; TRANSISTORS; VOLTAGE REGULATORS; DATA; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; ELECTRONIC EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES; 200104* - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Components; 130700 - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: The series TVV turbogenerators of 165 to 500 MW are equipped with a high-frequency (HF) excitation system consisting of a high-frequency (500 Hz) exciter of the inductor type, a diode rectifier, a pilot exciter with permanent magnets and an automatic excitation regulator on magnetic amplifiers, fed by the pilot exciter. Due to the low reliability of the pilot exciter and the unit of its articulation with the exciter, an HF excitation circuit without pilot exciter has been developed and tested. The advantages of the single machine excitation HF system of the TVV turbogenerators designed as a result of modernization of the standard two machine excitation system with the regulator of the type EPA-500 are discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 9:8; Other Information: Translated from Elektr. Stn.; 9: No. 8, 45-47(Aug 1980)

TITLE: Complex of operations for increasing reliability of hydraulic turbogenerator units of the At-Bashinsk hydroelectric power plant
AUTHORS: Engel, V E; Kolen Kolesnikov, V I; Dolgopolov, A S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TURBOGENERATORS; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; SUPPORTS; AMPLITUDES; BEARINGS; DESIGN; FREQUENCY DEPENDENCE; SHOCK ABSORBERS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Vibrational testing conducted on the structure of the room containing the suspension type hydraulic generators is described. Results indicated that a high vibration value (2A-50..mu..) was caused by close coincidence of the frequency of inherent vibrations of the covering of the floor with the frequency of induced vibrations generated by the bearing bases the hydro units - that is, a resonance phenomenon occurred. Under all conditions of its operation, a small vertical vibration was transferred by the hydraulic unit to the covering, where it was amplified many times. Redesigning of the bearing base of the generators provided a substantial decrease in vibration of the covering of the floor; this increased the degree of breakdown prevention.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 9:8; Other Information: Translated from Elektr. Stn.; 9: No. 8, 64(Aug 1980)

TITLE: China has vast hydroelectric potential
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CHINA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; ASIA; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: Tremendous opportunities exist for hydroelectric development in China. With a theoretical potential of 580 GW, corresponding to an annual production of 5 x 10/sup 12/ kWh, China leads the world in water-power resources. To date China has developed only 2 1/2% of that potential. But the growing demand for energy being created by the current modernization program calls for an unprecedented rate of development of these water-power resources, and China is seeking the cooperation of the world's developed countries to achieve this goal. Hydroelectric installations today have a combined capacity of 14,600 MW, not including installations below 500 kW. This is already about 90 times the amount that existed before the birth of New China, in 1949.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. World; (United States); Journal Volume: 194:3

TITLE: Reviving low-head and small hydro: II
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NORTH ATLANTIC REGION; WESTERN REGION; FEDERAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS; FINANCING; IMPLEMENTATION; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; US DOE; USA; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: Following an examination of the rationale and the renewed need for hydroelectric power development in the USA, feasibility, design criteria, and economic viability in Part I, Part II reviews DOE's demonstration projects, plant capital costs, and the DOE loan program for feasibility studies. Some case histories of small-hydro rehabilitation and refurbishment projects on the West Coast and in New England are discussed. (MCW)
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. World; (United States); Journal Volume: 194:3

TITLE: Small hydro puts new challenge to consultants
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENGINEERING; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; DESIGN; PROFESSIONAL PERSONNEL; PERSONNEL; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: The design of large hydroelectric projects has become so complex that it requires teams of engineers who rely on computerized scheduling and accounting systems. The skills required for small hydro projects are now challenging the specialized talents of modern consultants when a generalist's knowledge and simple organization are needed. Montreal Engineering has met this challenge by reintroducing the reporting and operating procedures used in the 40s and 50s for a number of small projects. A case history illustrates how this was done. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 17:8

TITLE: Reviving low-head and small hydro: 1
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; ECONOMICS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; FINANCING; POWER GENERATION; RETROFITTING; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 130000 - Hydro Energy
DESCRIPTION: High fuel costs, especially for oil, have raised widespread interest in refurbishing and reactivating retired low-head, low-capacity power dams that had been considered uneconomical to operate. Nongenerating dam sites are also being investigated for power production; however, comprehensive hydrological, safety, and economic feasibility data are required before such projects can reach the construction stage. DOE has various financial assistance programs, while the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission is trying to ease environmental constraints to encourage the licensing of more small-hydro installations. 11 figures, 3 tables.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. World; (United States); Journal Volume: 194:2

TITLE: Low-head hydro equipment makers see strong demand
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMMERCIALIZATION; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; FINANCIAL INCENTIVES; FINANCING; US DOE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130000* - Hydro Energy; 296001 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The Department of Energy's (DOE) withdrawal of funding for low-head hydro construction seems to have had a beneficial effect on development of the industry. With no free money available, developers are moving ahead on their own to develop small hydro equipment. Although it abandoned construction support, the DOE has concentrated on sponsoring feasibility studies. The studies are financed by a three-year, $30-million program of forgivable loans to develop small-scale hydro. If a study shows that a project is not feasible, the loan does not have to be paid. Traditionally, small-hydro generating plants have been built and operated by electric utilities or by municipal governments. An interesting trend in the recent surge of small-hydro growth is the emergence of the independent hydro entrepreneur. Some examples of small-head hydro projects are discussed in the article. While the typical small hydro project has a capacity of 1 megawatt, some of the new projects plan for 10 to 15 megawatts of power from low-head hydro. (SAC)
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. Light Power (Boston); (United States); Journal Volume: 58:7

TITLE: Accelerated growth of smallmouth bass in a pumped storage system. [Micropterus dolomieui]
AUTHORS: Heisey, P G; Mathur, D; Magnusson, N C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 59 BASIC BIOLOGICAL SCIENCES; FISHES; ANIMAL GROWTH; PREDATOR-PREY INTERACTIONS; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; WATER RESERVOIRS; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; DATA; GROWTH; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; VERTEBRATES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 550100 - Behavioral Biology
DESCRIPTION: A 12-year study of the smallmouth bass population, Micropterus dolomieui, in a pumped storage reservoir revealed an accelerated growth that was related to the abundance of gizzard shad, Dorosoma cepedianum. Prior to the gizzard shad introduction, the growth of smallmouth bass was generally poorer than that reported for the mid-Atlantic region. Large drawdowns (9 m per day, 15.6 m per week) may have increased the vulnerability of gizzard shad by concentrating both prey and predator. In the lower reservoir, where water levels fluctuated irregularly and much less (up to 1 m per day), smallmouth bass growth was not greatly improved following the introduction of gizzard shad.
RESEARCH_ORG: Muddy Run Ecological Lab., Drumore, PA
RELATION: Journal Name: Trans. Am. Fish. Soc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 109:4

TITLE: Observations on communities of brook and brown trout separated by an upstream movement barrier on the Firehole River
SUBJECT: 59 BASIC BIOLOGICAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; TROUT; BEHAVIOR; POPULATIONS; RIVERS; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; FISHES; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; VERTEBRATES; 550100* - Behavioral Biology; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Division of a fluvial fish community by stream impoundment can give rise to dissimilar upstream and downstream assemblages which may themselves differ from the original community. These changes are often ascribed to the modification of physical habitat or water quality. Less well documented are effects on fluvial fish communities of an upstream-1 movement barrier alone. Observations were made on contrasting communities of brook trout (Salvelinus fontinalis) and brown trout (Salmo trutta) separated by Kepler Cascades in the Firehole River of Yellowstone National Park, Wyoming, a series of waterfalls that form an upstream-movement barrier. (ACR)
RELATION: Journal Name: Prog. Fish-Cult.; (United States); Journal Volume: 42:3; Journal Issue: 3

TITLE: Hydro to be main power source for Venezuela. [Guri Project, on Orinoco tributary, to be one of worlds largest]
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; VENEZUELA; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; FOSSIL FUELS; FOSSIL-FUEL POWER PLANTS; INTERCONNECTED POWER SYSTEMS; POWER TRANSMISSION; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; FUELS; LATIN AMERICA; POWER; POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SOUTH AMERICA; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 296001 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: With one of the world's major river systems flowing through the country, Venezuela does not lack for a renewable energy resource with which to conserve her oil for export. Within a fragmented, government-owned utility system, there is emerging a grand design which will create the Guri hydro project as the main source of the country's electricity supply in the closing years of the century. Utilizing the OPEC country's oil and natural gas and the newly discovered coal deposits, new fossil-fuel power plants are being added at Tacoa, Planta Centro, and Arrega to bridge the electricity demand until the Guri project starts adding electricity to the system in 1982. With electricity demand increasing at a nine percent annual rate, Guri is intended to serve as a base-load plant to supply the whole country via a multi-branch 800 kV transmission system. It is a single dam with two possibly three, power houses on a major tributary of the Orinoco river. The master plan is based on three elements. First the crest height of the water will be raised and a second power house will be installed to add 7120 MW to the present installed capacity. Second is a similar operation at Macagua on the Orinoco which will add 1400 MW to that plant's installed capacity. The third part of the plan involves the construction of at least one new power station between the existing dams. A site for that plant has not been chosen. Construction techniques and progress are highlighted in the article. (SAC)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 17:6

TITLE: Pieman River scheme sustains Tasmania's hydro power plan
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; TASMANIA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; CONSTRUCTION; DESIGN; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; POWER DEMAND; WATER RESOURCES; AUSTRALASIA; AUSTRALIA; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; ISLANDS; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Recent progress is reported on Tasmania's Pieman River project, which will contribute to the long-term hydroelectric development of the West Coast. Details of the construction in progress cover power stations, dams, highways, and a settlement for workers. The completed project will prevent a shortfall in power supplies that would have occurred in the early 1980s because of rising demand. The water-powered scheme was selected after a review of alternative generating sources, including thermal, nuclear, solar, and wind power. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 17:5

TITLE: Electrodialytic desalinization of water for cooling turbo-generator windings in hydroelectric power plants
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TURBOGENERATORS; COOLING SYSTEMS; WATER; DESALINATION; ELECTRIC CONDUCTIVITY; ELECTRIC CURRENTS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ELECTRODIALYSIS; FICK LAWS; ION EXCHANGE; THEORETICAL DATA; WATER CHEMISTRY; CHEMISTRY; CURRENTS; DATA; DEMINERALIZATION; DIALYSIS; ELECTRICAL PROPERTIES; ENERGY SYSTEMS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; POWER PLANTS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 400400 - Electrochemistry
DESCRIPTION: The method of salt elimination using electrodialytic devices is discussed. The utilization of these devices makes it possible to considerably simplify the water preparation circuit for cooling turbogenerators in hydroelectric power plants. It is concluded that the salt elimination process should include a sodium-cation filter, an electrodialytic device and a mixing filter. Furthermore, the brine from the concentrate chambers of the electrodialytic devices can be used for regeneration of sodium-cation filters.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 9:5; Other Information: Translated from Elektr. Stn.; 9: No. 5, 30-32(May 1980)

TITLE: Rising oil and gas prices are making hydropower look better every day
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ECONOMICS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; LICENSE APPLICATIONS; POWER GENERATION; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; POWER PLANTS; 296000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 130400 - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 290200 - Energy Planning & Policy- Economics & Sociology; 294000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Fossil Fuels
DESCRIPTION: Economics favor the expansion of hydroelectric power projects as fossil-fuel prices climb and the nuclear industry continues under attack. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) is receiving a record number of license applications for new facilities as well as for expanding and rehabilitating existing generating plants. Hydropower is often used at peak demand times and is most economical at that point. Estimates of the hydropower potential in each of the states by the Corps of Engineers are compared with applications to FERC for conventional plants and pumped storage. The applicants include industries and municipalities as well as electric utilities. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Natl. J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:17

TITLE: Stranglehold on the Skagit
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; SKAGIT RIVER; PUBLIC OPINION; POWER PLANTS; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Feature article:Proposed hydroelectric projects along the Skagit River in Washington and British Columbia are threatening the survival of the river's wild valleys. The projects are the construction of the High Ross, Wash., dam and the construction of a dam in the Thunder Creek Valley, Wash. Expected electricity production from the hydroelectric projects is discussed. Environmental losses caused by the projects are considered. Major opposition to the projects can be expected from the coalition of Indian tribes that have treaty fishing rights on the Skagit River, as well as from local valley residents who are concerned about the safety of the dams or who believe that the projects are not consistent with the Nat'l Wild and Scenic River status given to the downstream sections of the Skagit River. (1 map, 1 photo)
RELATION: Journal Name: Natl. Parks Conserv. Mag.; (United States); Journal Volume: 54:4

TITLE: Transportation of chinook salmon, Oncorhynchus tshawytscha, and steelhead, Salmo gairdneri, smolts in the Columbia River and effects on adult returns
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 59 BASIC BIOLOGICAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FISHES; MIGRATION; AGE DEPENDENCE; COLUMBIA RIVER; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; DAMS; LAND TRANSPORT; POPULATION DYNAMICS; POPULATIONS; REPRODUCTION; STATISTICS; TIME DEPENDENCE; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; MATHEMATICS; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; TRANSPORT; VERTEBRATES; 520100* - Environment, Aquatic- Basic Studies- (-1989); 551000 - Physiological Systems; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Chinook salmon, Oncorhynchus tshawytscha, and steelhead, Salmo gairdneri, were captured at Little Goose Dam in the Snake River during their seaward migration and transported 400 km downstream to the lower Columbia River below Bonneville Dam. Their survival was increased from 1.1 to 15 times as compared with control fish which passed by seven mainstem low-level dams and reservoirs. Variations in survival were mainly dependent on species and environmental conditions in the river during the period fish were transported. The homing ability of the adult fish was not significantly diminished; less than 0.2% of strays occurred among adult returns from groups transported. Transportation did not affect ocean age or size of returning adult steelhead, but ocean age of returning adult chinook salmon may have been affected. Steelhead returned to Little Goose Dam at a substantially higher rate (1.4 to 2.7%) than chinook salmon (0.1 to 0.8%) from groups transported. The timing of adult returns of both species to Little Goose Dam was not related to the time of capture and downstream release of smolts.
RESEARCH_ORG: National Marine Fisheries Service, Seattle, WA
RELATION: Journal Name: Fish. Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 78:2

TITLE: Black River hydro project: local gain at whose cost
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LEGAL ASPECTS; EMINENT DOMAIN; LAND USE; SAFEGUARDS; VERMONT; NORTH AMERICA; NORTH ATLANTIC REGION; POWER PLANTS; USA; 130601* - Hydro Energy- Land Use & Aesthetics- (-1991 ); 299003 - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation- Other- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: It is argued that regulatory procedures for projects such as the Black River Hydroelectric Project should include a comprehensive regional political - economic analysis to safeguard the interests of those whose lands are to be appropriated. (SPH)
RELATION: Journal Name: Sol. Law Rep.; (United States); Journal Volume: 1:6

TITLE: Modeling reservoir system with pumped storage. [Richard B. Russell Dam and Lake on Savannah River]
AUTHORS: McMahon, G F; Bonner, V R; Eichert, B S
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PLANNING; PUMPED STORAGE; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; SAVANNAH RIVER; WATER RESERVOIRS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; DAMS; GEORGIA; LAND USE; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; RECREATIONAL AREAS; WATER RESOURCES; ENERGY STORAGE; NORTH AMERICA; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; RESOURCES; RIVERS; SIMULATION; SOUTHEAST REGION; STORAGE; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; USA; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 130601 - Hydro Energy- Land Use & Aesthetics- (-1991 )
DESCRIPTION: The Richard B. Russell Dam and Lake Project is presently under construction and is being placed in tandem between Hartwell and Clark Hill, two existing multipurpose hydropower plants on the Savannah River in Georgia. System operational simulations were performed in support of a feasibility study for the installation of pump turbines at Russell, using a version of a Corps of Engineers' computer program modified for system power and pumped storage. Information developed from the simulations include system hydropower production, pumping energy requirements, daily reservoir pool fluctuations, and reservoir elevation statistics. This information was useful in judging the effects of the addition of pumped storage on system hydropower production and reservoir recreation useability, as well as in ascertaining efficient system operational methods. 13 references, 2 figures, 4 tables.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Water Resour. Plann. Manage. Div., Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 106:WR1
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Water Resour. Plann. Manage. Div., Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States)

TITLE: Mysis relicta: effects of turbidity and turbulence on short-term survival
AUTHORS: Gregg, R E; Bergersen, E P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; SHRIMP; MORTALITY; TURBIDITY; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; TURBULENCE; FEEDING; HABITAT; SURVIVAL TIME; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; ARTHROPODS; CRUSTACEANS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INVERTEBRATES; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 520100 - Environment, Aquatic- Basic Studies- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The effects of wide range of turbidity and turbulence levels on the short-term survival of Mysis relicta under laboratory conditions were examined. The levels of turbulence and turbidity used bracket the conditions which Mysis relicta may be expected to encounter in one area of Twin Lakes, Colorado during the operation of a pumped storage power plant. Turbulence caused a highly significant increase in mortality; mortality was not significantly affected by the three levels of turbidity tested (0.735 to 779, and 1470 to 1558 American Public Health Association turbidity units of glacial flour sediments) nor by the interaction of turbidity and turbulence. Mortality of Mysis relicta subjected to turbulence increased significantly over the 8-day experiment. Exhaustion from inability to feed and from continuous swimming during turbulent periods is suggested as the possible cause of increased mortality observed over time during the experiment.
RELATION: Journal Name: Trans. Am. Fish. Soc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 109:2

TITLE: New roles for hydropower
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; ECONOMICS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER GENERATION; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SITE SELECTION; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; 130000* - Hydro Energy
DESCRIPTION: A re-examination is underway of the role hydroelectric power can play as a renewable and non-polluting resource. If all the existing hydro sites were developed, nearly all the oil presently burned to generate electricity could be saved. The economics of small hydro plants is improving as the cost of fuel and meeting environmental standards increases for fossil fuel plants. Summaries are given of feasibility studies and hydro projects undertaken by Bechtel in several locations to expand existing irrigation projects, add a pumped-storage capability to thermal plants, and increase water supplies as well as generate power. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Aware; (United States); Other Information: Reprinted from Bechtel Briefs, December 1979

TITLE: Realization of incomplete phase conditions of enlarged units in hydroelectric plants
AUTHORS: Ananiantz, S S; Guchinn, E V; Chistikov, A P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TURBOGENERATORS; EQUIPMENT PROTECTION DEVICES; OPERATION; ELECTRIC COILS; ELECTRICAL INSULATORS; ELECTROSTATICS; OVERVOLTAGE; RESONANCE; TRANSFORMERS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130700 - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: The practical meaning of incomplete conditions as applied to large hydrogenerators resides in the possibility of delivering a large part of the unit power when one phase of the transformer or autotransformer is damaged. Investigations were conducted on the subject and discussion presented. It was concluded that for elimination of overvoltages due to the occurrence of ferroresonance and electrostatic induction that can occur when incomplete phase conditions are realized through the autotransformer group with split lower voltage windings, an increase can be recommended in the capacitive inductance between the winding phases and grounding by switching equalizing condensers.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 9:2; Other Information: Translated from Elektr. Stn.; 9: No. 2, 41-44(Feb 1980)

TITLE: Diffusion of a passive scalar with random advection
AUTHORS: Molyneux, J E; Witten, A J
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 22 GENERAL STUDIES OF NUCLEAR REACTORS; CHEMICAL EFFLUENTS; FLOW MODELS; FLUID FLOW; STATISTICAL MODELS; ADVECTION; CONTAMINATION; DIFFUSION; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; POWER PLANTS; QUANTITY RATIO; STOCHASTIC PROCESSES; STREAMS; TIME DEPENDENCE; MASS TRANSFER; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SURFACE WATERS; 520200* - Environment, Aquatic- Chemicals Monitoring & Transport- (-1989); 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 220503 - Nuclear Reactor Technology- Environmental Aspects- Chemical & Thermal Effluents
DESCRIPTION: To investigate the instantaneous release of a passive additive into a flow, we assume that the concentration of the additive is governed by the one-dimensional advective diffusion equation in which the advecting flow velocity is a given time-dependent stochastic process. We determine both the one- and two-space-time point probability distributions of the random concentration field. This problem, or more elaborate variations of it, is a rather idealized model for a variety of environmentally important flow situations, for example, the accidental or planned release of a contaminant into a river by a power station, and, as such, it has been investigated by a number of authors. Previous treatments, however, have concentrated on deriving information about the statistical moments of the concentration. Although such information is important, it may be inadequate for accessing the true effects of a flow additive on the environment. Our investigation demonstrates the possibility of obtaining a more complete statistical description.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 16:1

TITLE: Guide unifies dam safety work
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; EMERGENCY PLANS; SAFETY; EVALUATION; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; IMPLEMENTATION; REGULATIONS; STANDARDS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 130400 - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations
DESCRIPTION: A uniform high standard for safety practices at all Federal dams has been developed. The directive highlights programs for inspecting existing dams to measure them against modern criteria, establishing a high-level dam safety office or officer, developing specific procedures for enacting the guidelines, and making implementation of the guidelines a high-priority budget item. The guidelines call for emergency action planning - evaluation of emergency potential determining possible modes of dam failure, inundation mapping, notification plans, and evacuation plans.
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 204:2

TITLE: Causes for disruption of equilibrium stability of hydroelectric-generator cores
AUTHORS: Ter-Gazaryan, G N; Kherkheulidze, I A; Tsiskreli, G D; Khuberyan, K M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TURBOGENERATORS; STABILITY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; STEELS; STRESS ANALYSIS; ALLOYS; IRON ALLOYS; IRON BASE ALLOYS; POWER PLANTS; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: The factors responsible for a steel wave in a hydroelectric generator are considered. The critical forces disrupting the stability of the plane shape of active-steel lamination assemblies are determined. The critical forces are compared with the actual forces at joints; it is shown that the latter may lead to disturbance of stability under certain conditions.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Electr. Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 51:5

TITLE: Turbogenerator and hydroelectric generator construction at the ''elektrosila'' leningrad-pskov electric-machine combine
