TITLE: Preliminary study of the effect of pumped-storage plant operation on zooplankton
AUTHORS: Tseyeb, Y Y; Zhdanova, G A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; ZOOPLANKTON; MORTALITY; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; WATER PUMPS; WATER RESERVOIRS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; PLANKTON; POWER PLANTS; PUMPS; SURFACE WATERS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The hydromechanical effect of hydroelectric stations on zooplankton is customarily regarded as a constantly acting and comparatively harmless factor, since its destruction is inevitable when water masses are passed through hydroelectric stations, but its capacity for restoration is high (i.e., destruction of the zooplankton of the forebay is compensated by its production in the after bay). It is not known how correct such an opinion is, or what is the true balance of losses and reproduction of zooplankton in the forebays and after bays of hydroelectric stations. However, hydroelectric plants of a new type, pumped-storage plants, have been constructed in recent years and others are planned for the Dnieper reservoirs. The operational principle and purpose of these plants is that they employ special vertical turbine-electric pumps that pump water at night from the reservoirs into pumped-storage facilities at high levels, and then release this water during daytime peaks through pipes to the turbines that generate additional electric power. Such pumped-storage plants are planned, in particular, as part of the Danube-Dnieper water economy complex and for some reservoirs in the North European regions of the USSR.
RESEARCH_ORG: Ukrainian Academy of Sciences, Kiev, USSR
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrobiol. J. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 16:4

TITLE: Power Authority calls for wise investment in hydropower
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; ALASKA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; INVESTMENT; CONSTRUCTION; FINANCING; PLANNING; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; POWER; USA; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: Wise investment in hydropower is one of the most valuable long-term economic actions the state of Alaska can take. A review of the hydro projects shows that investigations needed for construction of the Susitna hydroelectric project will be initiated, while Green Lake and Solomon Gulch projects at Sitka and Valdez will enter their second construction season. Swan Lake and Terror Lake hydropower construction for Ketchikan and Kodiak will also be initiated in 1980 followed by Tyee Lake hydropower for Petersburg and Wrangell. Projects still under investigation which may prove feasible for construction in the future are at Cordova, Homer, Seward, Bristol Bay, the Tlingit-Haida area, the lower Kuskokwim and Yukon area, and at some smaller rural communities. Other communities may be able to develop wood or peat fueled generation, wile still others might be able to develop small tidal or wind power generation. The Alaska Power Authority is attempting to expedite these projects, and the end result should be a significant degree of electrical energy independence by the end of the next decade.
RELATION: Journal Name: Alaska Constr. Oil; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:1

TITLE: Hydroelectric facilities licensing - a FERC jurisdictional primer
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; US FERC; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; LEGAL ASPECTS; NAVIGATION; PERMITS; REGULATIONS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: The 1890 Rivers and Harbors Appropriation Act was the first federal step toward requiring permits for water power facilities. Prior to that time, the only restrictions were against obstructing navigation on water under federal control. The Federal Power Act of 1935 gave the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) jurisdictional and regulatory control over hydroelectric facilities for the purpose of promoting their construction. FERC jurisdication attaches where any hydroelectric project is located on a navigable stream or on a nonnavigable stream, but either impacts on downstream navigation or was built after 1935 and affects interstate or foreign commerce. Hydroelectric projects or project works on public lands or reservation and those which use surplur water or water power from a government dam are jurisdicational. 66 references.
RESEARCH_ORG: Belnap, McCarthy, Spencer, Sweeney, and Harkaway, Washington, DC
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Law J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 1:1

TITLE: Empty victories: Indian treaty fishing rights in the Pacific Northwest
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; AMERICAN INDIANS; WATER RIGHTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; SALMON; POPULATION DYNAMICS; ECONOMIC IMPACT; FISHING INDUSTRY; LEGAL ASPECTS; MANAGEMENT; RESOURCE CONSERVATION; SOCIAL IMPACT; WATER RESOURCES; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; FISHES; INDUSTRY; MINORITY GROUPS; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; VERTEBRATES; 530100* - Environmental-Social Aspects of Energy Technologies- Social & Economic Studies- (-1989); 520600 - Environment, Aquatic- Regulations - (-1989); 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 290400 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Resources
DESCRIPTION: Cases dealing with the U.S. Pacific Northwest Indian treaty rights controversy are analyzed. The major themes that run throughout the 125 yr dispute are outlined to provide a legal and historical context for the cases. Although the Indians have won great victories in the courts concerning their right to a share of the Columbia River basin salmon, hydroelectric generation, commercial fishing, and other industrial uses of the river threaten the continued existence of the salmon. Without further clear and consistent guidance, the court victories will be empty, because as long as the treaties are litigated and relitigated in court, constructive long-range planning is neglected and the fish stocks dwindle. (237 references)
RESEARCH_ORG: Lewis and Clark College Northwestern School of Law
RELATION: Journal Name: Environ. Law; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:2

TITLE: Influence of route of entry on toxicity of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons to the cricket (Acheta domesticus)
SUBJECT: 63 RADIATION, THERMAL, AND OTHER ENVIRON. POLLUTANT EFFECTS ON LIVING ORGS. AND BIOL. MAT.; 59 BASIC BIOLOGICAL SCIENCES; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ANTHRACENE; TOXICITY; BENZANTHRACENE; BENZOPYRENE; INSECTS; SENSITIVITY; NAPHTHALENE; PYRENE; BIOLOGICAL PATHWAYS; COAL; INTAKE; METABOLISM; REPRODUCTION; REPRODUCTIVE DISORDERS; SYNTHETIC FUELS; ANIMALS; AROMATICS; ARTHROPODS; CARBONACEOUS MATERIALS; CONDENSED AROMATICS; ENERGY SOURCES; FOSSIL FUELS; FUELS; HYDROCARBONS; INVERTEBRATES; MATERIALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; 560304* - Chemicals Metabolism & Toxicology- Invertebrates- (-1987); 551000 - Physiological Systems; 010900 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- Environmental Aspects; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: In the present study, acute and chronic toxicities of five PAHs (naphthalene, anthracene, benz(a)anthracene, pyrene, and benzo(a)pyrene) and an oxygenated PAH derivative (anthrone) were determined in a terrestrial insect, Acheta domesticus (L.), with emphasis on the influence of route of entry on toxicity. Hexamethylphosphoric triamide (hempa) was included in the chronic tests since this chemosterilant is a useful reference compound for investigations of reproductive effects of chemicals in insects.
RELATION: Journal Name: Bull. Environ. Contam. Toxicol.; (United States); Journal Volume: 25

TITLE: Power-poor nation taps jungle river for energy
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ECUADOR; HIGH-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; DAMS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; PLANNING; RIVERS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LATIN AMERICA; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SOUTH AMERICA; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: The Paute River 1,690-MW hydroelectric power project near Cuenca will triple the power generating capacity of Ecuador. Progress on this practically inaccessible site is reported. The centerpiece will be the 560-ft-high Amaluza Dam. The underground powerhouse is slated to come on line in 1982.
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 203:24

TITLE: James Bay units come on stream
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; QUEBEC; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; ENGINEERING; LABOR RELATIONS; LAND USE; SPECIFICATIONS; WATER RESOURCES; CANADA; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; RESOURCES; 130000* - Hydro Energy
DESCRIPTION: The first unit of James Bay station, North America's largest hydroelectric project, began delivering power in October of 1979 after a six-year construction period. The full capacity of 5,328 MW should be reached in early 1981. The 16 La Grange-2 (LG-2) units, located 1500 km north of Montreal, required extensive planning to overcome the human and natural problems of coming on line ahead of schedule and below budget. The sub-arctic drainage basin, with only a 376-meter drop and no major falls, required massive earthworks to develop a hydraulic head and provide storage capacity. Provincial and national debate were prolonged before a development strategy was adopted. Problems that had to be resolved included: Indian and Eskimo claims on the land; inter-union conflicts and demands; and evidence that the rate of increase in power demand in Quebec is declining. Specifications for the LG=2 site are provided. LG-1, LG-3, and LG-4 plants will, when completed in 1982, bring the LaGrange generating units to a total of 12. Phase Two projects include LG-1 and four plants on the Eastmain and Laforge rivers. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 16:12

TITLE: Analysis of heating of terminal sections of the stator core of a powerful hydrogenerator
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TURBOGENERATORS; STATORS; HEATING; EVALUATED DATA; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; POWER RANGE 100-1000 MW; PREDICTION EQUATIONS; TEMPERATURE DISTRIBUTION; DATA; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; EQUATIONS; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130700 - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: A procedure for the analysis of heating of terminal sections of the stator core of powerful hydrogenerators under different operating conditions, based on experimental data obtained from idling and short circuit tests, was proposed. A comparison of the temperature increases calculated from the proposed formula and from direct measurement of two hydrognerators (240 MW and 300 MW capacities) was given in two graphs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 8:12; Other Information: Translated from Electr. Stn.; 8: No. 12, 28-32(Dec 1979)

TITLE: Dickey-lincoln: the hydro-hydra that refuses to die
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; PUBLIC OPINION; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 290400 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Resources
DESCRIPTION: The Dickey-Lincoln hydroelectric project, located on the Upper St. John River near the Canadian border in the northeastern U.S., was proposed in the 1930's and authorized for construction in 1965. Conservationists have blocked the project claiming that costs of the project far outweigh its benefits. The financial, social, and environmental costs and benefits of the project are examined. Congressional proponents and opponents of the project are listed. The Nat'l Wildlife Fedn. has testified that it is opposed to the Dickey-Lincoln project. (2 drawings)
RELATION: Journal Name: Conserv. News; (United States); Journal Volume: 44:22

TITLE: Back to small-scale hydro
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; ECONOMICS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; POWER GENERATION; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT; ENERGY SOURCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 130000* - Hydro Energy; 296001 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Alexander Hamilton's post-Revolution plan ofor developing small-scale hydro power is reexamied in light of the present need to supply industrial production with domestic energy. The 1200 participants in a government-sponsored inthernational conference on the subject discussed the possibilities of producing electric and mechanical power as well as the commerical production of hydrogen and ozone. The Administration and the US Army Corps of Engineers will be responsive to local initiatives to develop a resource estimated to include 5400 existing dams and another 4500 underdeveloped sites - about 512,000 MW of capacity. While front-end costs are high-, small-scale hydro requires a short lead time, needs little maintenance, provides life-time fuel savings, and is environmentally sound. Former Bureau of Reclamation Commissioner Ellis L. Armstrong points out that, worldwide, hydropower considered likely to be developed is about 2.2 million MW installed capacity, with a yearly productive potential of nearly 10 million gigawatt-hours of energy equivalent to about 40 million bbl of oil per day burned in power plants.
RELATION: Journal Name: Public Power; (United States); Journal Volume: 37:6

TITLE: Turlock harnesses power in its irrigation canal. [Hickman, CA; two 500-kW generators]
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; DESIGN; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; IRRIGATION; POWER GENERATION; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SITE SELECTION; ENERGY SOURCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 130000* - Hydro Energy
DESCRIPTION: The Turlock Irrigation District (TID) has harnessed a 17-foot water drop in its prinicpal irrigation canal to power two 500-kilowatt generators. The eight-month irrigation season will provide power during the region's peak electrical demand for air conditioning. The economics for exploiting low-head hydroelectric power did not develop in this country until fuel costs began to rise. While inadequate for total energy needs, these projects are a step toward energy independence. An extensive feasibility study preceded TID's choice of two sites for low-head hydro development. Much of the engineering and construction work was done in-house to cut cots. TID reserves are financing the project. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Public Power; (United States); Journal Volume: 37:6

TITLE: Mini hydro plants boost China's power supply
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; CHINA; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; ASIA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 130000* - Hydro Energy; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: Hydropower has been the main contributor towards the development of electricity in the People's Republic of China. As well as the larger projects, the construction of mini hydro plants - with units of 1 MW or less - has played an important part in satisfying the country's energy needs. An intensive building program was started in 1970. By the end of 1978, some 84,500 mini hydro plants were in operation with a total installed capacity of 10% of China's total. Some counties depend upon mini hydro plants for as much as 90% of their energy needs. The plants are ideal for remote areas with only small water resources, where economic or technical difficulties could otherwise have delayed development. The majority of mini hydro plants are located in the south of China in the provinces of Kwangtung, Guangxi, Sichuan, Hunan, and Fujian. The design, construction, and operation of the structures are carried out on a local level, i.e., by the communes. Projects usually include other benefits to the locality, such as irrigation, navigation, and fish breeding.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 16:11

TITLE: Repair of 220-500 kV high-pressure cable
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; EHV AC SYSTEMS; POWER TRANSMISSION LINES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OIL-FILLED CABLES; REPAIR; ELECTRIC CABLES; FREEZING; MEDIUM PRESSURE; NITROGEN; AC SYSTEMS; CABLES; CONDUCTOR DEVICES; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; ELEMENTS; ENERGY SYSTEMS; EQUIPMENT; NONMETALS; POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 200301 - Power Transmission & Distribution- AC Systems, EHV & UHV- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: A detailed description of the construction of high-pressure cable lines in steel piping was presented. Liquid nitrogen was used to freeze the cables for repair. Oil pressure during service was 1.4 +- 0.3 MPascals. Step-by-step instructions for the repair or replacement of the cables were given with estimates for the time and number of men required for portions of the job. Three diagrams indicated the equipment layout for the repairs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 8:11; Other Information: Translated from Electr. Stn.; 8: No. 11, 55-58(Nov 1979)

TITLE: Effects of dams and impoundments on migrations of juvenile chinook salmon and steelhead from the Snake River, 1966 to 1975
SUBJECT: 59 BASIC BIOLOGICAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 60 APPLIED LIFE SCIENCES; DAMS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; MIGRATION; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; SALMON; POPULATION DYNAMICS; TROUT; WATER RESERVOIRS; BEHAVIOR; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; FLOW RATE; ISOLATED VALUES; MORTALITY; REPRODUCTION; RIVERS; TEMPERATURE EFFECTS; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; DATA; DATA FORMS; FISHES; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; VERTEBRATES; 550100* - Behavioral Biology; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 553000 - Agriculture & Food Technology
DESCRIPTION: Migrations of juvenile chinook salmon, Oncorhynchus tshawytscha, and steelhead, Salmo gairdneri, from tributaries of the Snake River were monitored as far downstream as the Dalles Dam on the Columbia River in most years during the period 1966 to 1975. New dams constructed on the Snake River adversely affected survival and delayed migrations of juveniles. Significant loses of juveniles in 1972 and 1973 were directly responsible for record-low returns of adults to the Snake River in 1974 and 1975. Major causes of mortality were passage through turbines at dams, predation, and delays in migration through reservoirs in low-flow years, and prolonged exposure to lethal concentrations of dissolved gases caused by spilling at dams during high-flow years. Migrations of juvenile steelhead were generally later than those of chinook salmon and generally coincided with maximum river discharge. Lack of river runoff in 1973 caused a significant number of steelheads to stop migrating and to hold over in reservoirs. Mortality of chinook salmon and steelhead resulting from new dams has differed with respect to area and cause. Magnitude and composition of seaward migration has changed from 3 to 5 million wild fish in the mid-1960's to 8 to 10 million fish of both wild and hatchery origin in the 1970's.
RESEARCH_ORG: National Marine Fisheries Service, Seattle, WA
RELATION: Journal Name: Trans. Am. Fish. Soc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 108:6

TITLE: Conveyor pacing dam to possible early finish
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CONVEYORS; PERFORMANCE; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; AUTOMATION; COMPUTERS; CONTROL SYSTEMS; ENERGY CONSERVATION; REMOVAL; SOILS; EQUIPMENT; MATERIALS HANDLING EQUIPMENT; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: It is predicted that using a sophisticated computer-controlled conveyor on the $240-million Warm Springs Dam being built near San Francisco will be finished 14 months ahead of schedule. It will eventually carry 22 million out of 30 million cu yds of fill required for the dam. The computer will help conserve as well as control energy use. Progress at the site and performance of the conveyor are described.
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 203:17

TITLE: System costs sensitive to partial outages
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 21 SPECIFIC NUCLEAR REACTORS AND ASSOCIATED PLANTS; FOSSIL-FUEL POWER PLANTS; OUTAGES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS; AVAILABILITY; NUMERICAL DATA; RELIABILITY; TABLES; DATA; DATA FORMS; INFORMATION; NUCLEAR FACILITIES; POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 200100 - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Power Plants & Power Generation; 210000 - Nuclear Power Plants
DESCRIPTION: Data published by the EEI Prime Movers Committee compares frequency and severity of outages for all types of generating units. The data show that large units suffer higher average unit outages than small units, and that partial forced outages overshadow full forced outages both in number and in total hours.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. World; (United States); Journal Volume: 192:7

TITLE: Low-head hydro lures $1-billion market
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RETROFITTING; DAMS; ECONOMICS; LICENSING; MARKET; REGULATIONS; USA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: Retrofitting many existing small dams for hydropower becomes economically attractive as energy costs continue to rise. It could represent a $1-billion construction market in the US during the next 3 years. A study shows that the potential both for adding turbines at existing dams and for upgrading power production at existing hydropower sites to be 8,775 MW. The inventory also shows a 15,732-MW potential at totally undeveloped sites. Experiences at some small hydro sites are reviewed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 203:13

TITLE: Low head hydroelectric power in New England: the Black River project
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FINANCING; LICENSING; PLANNING; VERMONT; ECONOMICS; LEGAL ASPECTS; POWER GENERATION; US FERC; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; NORTH ATLANTIC REGION; POWER PLANTS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; USA; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The town of Springfield, Vermont, decided to revive its hydropower resource in 1975. Its plan called for the renovation of existing small dams and construction of others. Four years later, it is in the midst of creating a municipal utility, acquiring by condemnation utility company lines in the town, and doing further studies for its FERC license application. After spending $1.5 million, Springfield is still years away from generating its own power. This case study illustrates the problems facing a city trying to use water power to generate electricity. Pending changes in FERC licensing procedures will alleviate some of the problems Springfield has encountered, but others remain.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sol. Law Rep.; (United States); Journal Volume: 1:3

TITLE: Meteorology and energy
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 14 SOLAR ENERGY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; FORECASTING; METEOROLOGY; CLIMATES; EARTH ATMOSPHERE; ENERGY CONVERSION; ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY TRANSPORT; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; NUCLEAR ENERGY; SOLAR ENERGY; WEATHER; CONVERSION; ENERGY; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 500000* - Environment, Atmospheric- (-1989); 140000 - Solar Energy; 150200 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: In the consideration of the meteorological aspects of energy problems, the latter is divided into three main groups: energy production, energy transport and exploration, and new energy resources. Increased energy production will have an impact on the environment. Although at present there is insufficient information for precise forecasts, meteorologists and hydrologists will be able to make reasonable assumptions for the future. Human use of energy is strongly influenced by variations of weather. Such systems as electric power transmission networks, shipping of hydrocarbons by sea, and pipelines for the transportation of large quantities of oil and gas, are all particularly sensitive to weather and climate. The meteorologist provides basic data on weather and climate to facilitate energy exploration. The new energy resources addressed in this article are solar, wind, geothermal, and nuclear. The World Meteorological Organization's Executive Committee established a set of priorities in dealing with energy problems. This paper also briefly examines the burden imposed on global energy resources.
RELATION: Journal Name: EDIS; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:4

TITLE: Grand Coulee gets one-cycle breakers
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CIRCUIT BREAKERS; PERFORMANCE; EHV AC SYSTEMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; GRAPHS; OPERATION; USA; AC SYSTEMS; DATA; DATA FORMS; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT PROTECTION DEVICES; INFORMATION; NORTH AMERICA; NUMERICAL DATA; POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; 200301* - Power Transmission & Distribution- AC Systems, EHV & UHV- (-1989); 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Single-cycle circuit breakers installed early this year now protect the world's largest hydro installation. Each of the eight breakers has an interrupting capability of 58 kA symmetrical. To meet the one-cycle clearing requirement, engineers modified the design of a standard two-cycle air-blast breaker. Testing of components was performed for up to 10,000 operations.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. World; (United States); Journal Volume: 192:1

TITLE: Can low-head hydro make a comeback
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; CONSTRUCTION; DEMONSTRATION PROGRAMS; ECONOMICS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The Federal push to develop low-head hydroelectric power may be turned over to the private sector because of efforts to balance the Federal budget. Feasibility studies over the past two years have led the government to renege on some construction assistance. Of the 56 sites studied, about one-quarter are promising enough to proceed, while half will require further study and a quarter will be dropped. DOE's role in developing these projects, which will benefit only local users, has been questioned. DOE loans, however, will be repayable from any project built to demonstrate feasibility and making a profit. DOE's interest in low-head hydro as a substitute for oil is expected to improve as the prices of fossil fuels increase.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. Light Power (Boston); (United States); Journal Volume: 57:7

TITLE: Itaipu enters main construction phase
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; BRAZIL; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; PARAGUAY; DAMS; POWER TRANSMISSION LINES; LATIN AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; SOUTH AMERICA; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 296001 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: At the end of March dewatering between the main cofferdams was completed to prepare for construction of the world's largest power station at Itaipu. Placement of a record 11 million m/sup 3/ of concrete has called for some novel approaches to its preparation and delivery round the site.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 16:7

TITLE: Thermocouple temperature monitoring
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; EHV AC SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC CABLES; TEMPERATURE MONITORING; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; HVAC SYSTEMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DATA TRANSMISSION; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; POWER TRANSMISSION LINES; THERMOCOUPLES; TURBOMACHINERY; AC SYSTEMS; CABLES; COMMUNICATIONS; CONDUCTOR DEVICES; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; MONITORING; POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; TURBINES; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: In a macrocosmic project such as the huge Grand Coulee hydropower dam on the Columbia River, microcosmic devices, such as thermocouples, can play a vitally important role in monitoring ambient temperatures in high-voltage power cables and in stator cores of the hydrogenerators. The third power plant at the damsite, now under construction, will have some 400 of these devices installed within cable tunnels and main generating equipment. The use of these devices is described.
RESEARCH_ORG: Bureau of Reclamation, Grand Coulee Dam, WA
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. World; (United States); Journal Volume: 191:12

TITLE: New Zealand takes fresh look at hydro power
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; NEW ZEALAND; CONSTRUCTION; ECONOMICS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT; AUSTRALASIA; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: A Royal Commission report suggests that New Zealand can meet its electricity needs from indigenous non-nuclear sources into the next century. This means that hydro power will continue to play a dominant role as rising oil prices enhance the attraction of small hydro developments previously felt to be uneconomical. Major hydro projects are underway on both North and South Islands, while a new plan was recently approved for the Upper Clutha Valley and repairs begun at the Tekapo power station.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 16:6

TITLE: Examination of the vibration state in hydrogenators
AUTHORS: Dolgopolov, A S; Kolesnikov, V I; Engel, V E; Rasulov, M B; Rybkin, A A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TURBOGENERATORS; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; MEASURING METHODS; USSR; ASIA; DATA; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; EUROPE; INFORMATION; MACHINERY; NUMERICAL DATA; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Work performed at 5 hydroelectric power plants in the USSR to detect and remove sources of increased vibrations in turbogenerators is described. Hydrogenerators in the power range from 10 to 150 MW were inspected. (LCL)
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 8:5; Other Information: Translated from Elektr. Stn.; 8: No. 5, 51-53(May 1979)

TITLE: Take a new look at small hydro: low-head technology and existing dams offer a significant power potential
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; ECONOMICS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; FINANCING; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; SITE SELECTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 299000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation; 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: A significant contribution to meeting energy demand is increasingly seen by rehabilitating existing small dams and developing low-head technology, which the DOE has designated as having near-term commercial potential. Feasibility studies have provided limited information so far, but a 1977 survey by the Corps of Engineers estimated that existing dams could generate 54,600 MW. The study did not differentiate between low and high-head dams, but it is assumed that most non-generating dams would be low-head (less than 20 meters high). An earlier report by the Federal Energy Regulatory commission estimated a potential of 80,000 MW if existing and new sites are developed. Economic feasibility is site-specific and is now being studied by the Corps. The rising prices of conventional fuels are expected to improve the economic feasibility of small hydro - especially the economic relief available if oil imports can be reduced, but Federal participation is needed to provide the institutional and financial support.
RELATION: Journal Name: Public Power; (United States); Journal Volume: 37:3

TITLE: Development of pumped storage in a power system
AUTHORS: Cochran, A M; Isles, D E; Pope, I T
SUBJECT: 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; ECONOMICS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; OPERATION; COMPUTER CALCULATIONS; GRAPHS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MONTE CARLO METHOD; POWER DEMAND; POWER SYSTEMS; STABILITY; THEORETICAL DATA; DATA; DATA FORMS; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 250300* - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989); 130000 - Hydro Energy
DESCRIPTION: The pumped-storage hydroelectric scheme is by far the most widely used and best-developed method of storing electrical energy. Because it is a net consumer of energy and its function is to make better use of other energy producing plants it is clear that there must be a practical limit to the proportion of pumped-stoage plant which can be accommodated on the system. A 3-stage method has been adopted. The first stage is a feasibility assessment, which gives an indication of the quantity of pumped storage that could be accepted on the system. The other two stages involve a more detailed examination of the effect of pumped storage on long-term system security using Monte Carlo simulation and a study of total generating costs, including both capital and running costs. The methods are appropriate for assessing the characteristics of future pumped-storage developments on power systems with a significant proportion of existing hydroelectric and pumped-storage plants. They should also be applicable to systems containing very little hydraulic plant.
RESEARCH_ORG: North of Scotland Hydroelectric Board, Edinburgh, Scotland
RELATION: Journal Name: Proc. Inst. Electr. Eng. (London); (United States); Journal Volume: 126:5

TITLE: On-time diversion avoids year delay
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; BRAZIL; COST; PARAGUAY; RIVERS; LATIN AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; SOUTH AMERICA; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Survey report:Engineering strategies employed in the construction of a 12,600 Mw hydroelectric power plant on the Parana River in South America are reviewed. The Parana, which has an average flow of 293,000 cfs, separates the nations of Brazil and Paraguay. The flow of the Parana was diverted to extend two rock cofferdams across the river. The successful temporary diversion of the river saved about one year of construction time for the plant. Total cost of the plant project will reach $9 billion. The main dam in the system will contain about 7.9 million cu yd of concrete blocks. The dam is a project of Itaipu Binacional, a joint Brazilian-Paraguayan organization. (1 drawing, 5 maps, 7 photos)
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 202:16

TITLE: On-time diversion avoids year delay
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; SOUTH AMERICA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; DAMS; RIVERS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; LATIN AMERICA; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The construction of the hydroelectric power plant on the Parana River between Brazil and Paraquay is described with emphasis of the means used to direct the river flow through a diversion channel while the prinicipal dams and spillway are being built. (LCL)
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 202:16

TITLE: Guri hydropower capacity expands sevenfold
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; VENEZUELA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; COST; DAMS; POWER GENERATION; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SOUTH AMERICA; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: Expansion of Venezuela's Guri hydropower project will nearly triple the size of the concrete structure, extend its adjacent embankments by miles, and add a second powerhouse, increasing its generating capacity sevenfold and making it one of the most powerful hydroelectric dams in the world. Preliminary work worth about $80 million is already under way and on Oct. 15 a prime contract was let for the expansion estimated at $1.5 billion to $2 billion. Upon completion of the Raul Leoni Dam in 1987, it will impound 110 million acre-ft of water and may briefly claim a record generating capacity of 10,087 MW. A year later Itaipu Dam will be completed on the Parana River between Brazil and Paraguay, taking the title with an installed capacity of 12,600 MW. (MCW)
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 197:6

TITLE: Application potential for hydro power
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; EXPLOITATION; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; EVALUATION; GLOBAL ASPECTS; PLANNING; PROLIFERATION; REGULATIONS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 296001 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Less than one-sixth of the world's hydro power potential has so far been exploited, and today water power is being regarded as one of the new renewable energy technologies for the future. Water power stands apart from the other exotic renewable energy forms: (1) it has already been exploited on a massive scale; (2) it is a flexible system of energy supply that can be arranged for continuous operation regardless of the time of day; (3) the technology of energy conversion is well known and basically simple in concept; (4) the industrial infrastructure for the manufacture of equipment is well-established in many countries; and (5) environmental impact is largely beneficial in that it offers flood control guaranteed water supply for irrigation, scope for transportation by river, and recreational opportunities. Globally, there are 3 main avenues along which the development of hydro power can proceed: proliferation of small hydro sites - up to 10 MW - to meet local energy demands in isolated communities; development of pumped storage and other modification of existing river sites to increase capacity for operation on mid- and peak-load duty and to provide back-up storage; and development of large hydro power sites in remote areas to supply base-load energy for the Third World countries and for export to areas of high energy consumption presently using fossil fuel. Some basic issues in each case are examined. (MCW)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 16:4; Other Information: Based on paper to conference on energy alternatives, Honolulu, January 9--12, 1979

TITLE: Optimization method for electric generation expansion planning by nonlinear programming. Part 2. kW model
SUBJECT: 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 21 SPECIFIC NUCLEAR REACTORS AND ASSOCIATED PLANTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPTIMIZATION; PLANNING; NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; CAPACITY; ELECTRIC POWER; EXPANSION; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; NONLINEAR PROGRAMMING; POWER SYSTEMS; SHUTDOWNS; ENERGY SYSTEMS; NUCLEAR FACILITIES; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; PROGRAMMING; 200100* - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Power Plants & Power Generation; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 250300 - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989); 210800 - Nuclear Power Plants- Economics
DESCRIPTION: The kW model is used to find the optimal kW installation capacities of new (hydro, thermal and nuclear) plants and the optimal weekly running kW capacities of existing and newly added plants. It is a nonlinear programming model built to handle one year in time units of one week. Generating units of the same technical and economic performances are grouped into one equivalent unit. Electric power generated from run-off hydroplants and interchange powers are taken into account in advance in setting up the daily load duration curves. Weekly scheduled outages of nuclear and thermal units due to maintenance shutdown and the economic shutdown are taken into account. Night and weekend shutdown during each week and hydroplant maintenance shutdown can be taken into account at the sacrifice of computing time. All the variables of the kW model are continuous, although discrete variables can be handled.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. Eng. Jpn. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 99:2

TITLE: Harnessing the ocean currents
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; WATER CURRENT POWER GENERATORS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; COMPRESSED AIR; FLORIDA; GULF STREAM; HYDROGEN PRODUCTION; NYLON; OXYGEN; PARACHUTES; POWER GENERATION; WATER CURRENTS; AIR; CRYOGENIC FLUIDS; CURRENTS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ELEMENTS; FLUIDS; GASES; NONMETALS; NORTH AMERICA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC POLYMERS; PETROCHEMICALS; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; PLASTICS; POLYAMIDES; POLYMERS; SOUTHEAST REGION; USA; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Recent tests were conducted in the Gulf Steam off Florida of a device using 50 parachutes 2-ft in diameter. The device consists of parachutes on a cable turning a driveshaft. The parachutes open in an ocean current on the drive side and collapse on the return trip. The rigging was towed behind a 41-ft Hatteras cruiser and the power generated was monitored with NASA instruments. At one-half knot, the water low velocity energy converter generated 500 watts. The tapped energy could be used to compress air. The air could be piped to power generators on the shore. Or water could be electrolyzed to create hydrgen and oxygen. The hydrogen could be shipped to inland power plants designed to burn it. The parachutes would be made of nylon. It is estimated that a large WLVEC could produce about 1,000 MW of electricity. The WLVEC could also be used off Japan and Southeast Africa. (MCW)
RELATION: Journal Name: Mech. Illus.; (United States); Journal Volume: 75:610

TITLE: Optimization method for electric generation expansion planning by nonlinear programming. Part I. kWh model
SUBJECT: 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 21 SPECIFIC NUCLEAR REACTORS AND ASSOCIATED PLANTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPTIMIZATION; PLANNING; NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; CAPACITY; LINEAR PROGRAMMING; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; POWER SYSTEMS; SENSITIVITY ANALYSIS; ENERGY SYSTEMS; NUCLEAR FACILITIES; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; PROGRAMMING; 200100* - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Power Plants & Power Generation; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 250300 - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989); 210800 - Nuclear Power Plants- Economics
DESCRIPTION: The kWh model finds the kWh outputs of each plant and reservoir capacities of hydro and pumped storage plants and minimizes the sum of fixed charges for constructing the reservoirs and generating facilities, also the fuel costs of thermal and nuclear plants. It is a linear programming problem whose constants are represented by nonlinear functions of kW running capacity of each plant. The optimal pattern of nuclear and thermal units is found by solving the linear programming problem derived for the pumped storage and hydroplants. Excluding the upper bound constraints, the number of constraint equations are few and do not increase with the number of units, although the number of variables increases. The computing time increases only in proportion to the number of groupings of generating units. Sensitivity analysis can be done easily. The detailed operational behavior of each generating unit can be taken into account.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. Eng. Jpn. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 99:2

TITLE: Problem of monitoring hydrogenator stator vibration
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TURBOGENERATORS; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; GRAPHS; MEASURING METHODS; STATORS; USSR; ASIA; DATA; DATA FORMS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; EUROPE; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: A summary and an analysis are presented on the monitoring of stator vibrations for more than 30 hydrogenators with a capacity of 10,000 to 75,000 kW. (LCL)
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 8:2; Other Information: Translated from Elektr. Stn.; 8: No. 2, 40(Feb 1979)

TITLE: Economic development of small hydro
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; DAMS; DESIGN; ECONOMICS; EQUIPMENT; POWER GENERATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 296001 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: A survey of existing small dams indicates that the utilization of potential low-head hydroelectric power could reduce US oil consumption by 380,000 barrels per day. General Electric Company can make feasibility studies on upgrading existing sites, design systems for developing new plants, and supply the necessary generating equipment. Low-head hydro is independent of outside fuel supplies as well as combining high reliability with simplicity. A 50-year life span permits both short- and long-term benefits.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. Forum; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:2

TITLE: Susitna survey: concern for the land

DESCRIPTION: Work conducted by USACE and USBLM in the evaluation of a proposed dam site on the Upper Susitna River, Alsk., is outlined. Environmental and geologic studies conducted to determine the feasibility of a planned hydroelectric power plant in the isolated region are described. Problems encountered in getting drilling and construction equipment to the dam site are reported. (2 maps, 8 photos)
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Spectrum; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:4

TITLE: Dip basket for collecting juvenile salmon and trout in gatewells at hydroelectric dams
AUTHORS: Swan, G A; Krema, R F; Farr, W E
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FISHES; SAMPLERS; COLUMBIA RIVER; DAMS; DESIGN; OPERATION; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; LABORATORY EQUIPMENT; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; VERTEBRATES; 520100* - Environment, Aquatic- Basic Studies- (-1989); 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
