TITLE: Numerical model investigation of tidal phenomena in the Bay of Fundy and Gulf of Maine
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; BAY OF FUNDY; TIDE; GULF OF MEXICO; TIDAL POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; ATLANTIC OCEAN; FRICTION FACTOR; BAYS; CARIBBEAN SEA; POWER PLANTS; SEAS; SURFACE WATERS; 580500* - Oceanography- (1980-1989); 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: A numerical model is developed to examine tidal properties of the Bay of Fundy and Gulf of Maine. The model is run with a pure M2 tidal input on the open boundary, and calibrated by adjusting the friction coefficient to achieve good agreement with inshore observations. An examination of aspects of the tidal regime is made, with particular attention paid to the upper reaches of the bay. Mean energy and work values are computed. The fundamental period of the system is estimated. The effects of tidal power plants on the tidal regime are examined.
RESEARCH_ORG: Environment Canada, Marine Environmental Data Services Branch, Ottawa, Canada
RELATION: Journal Name: Mar. Geod.; (United States); Journal Volume: 2:2

TITLE: Transportation of adult American shad past dams on the Connecticut River, Massachusetts, 1973 to 1976
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CONNECTICUT RIVER; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; TRUCKS; DAMS; EVALUATION; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; MORTALITY; DATA; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; VEHICLES; 520100* - Environment, Aquatic- Basic Studies- (-1989); 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Adult American shad (Alosa sapidissima) were obtained from the Holyoke Dam fish lift, Massachusetts, and transported 68 km by truck to the pool above the Turners Falls Dam. From 1973 to 1976, 6373 shad were transported; average annual mortality was 25%. Mortality of trucked fish was related to river temperature and the number of fish transported at any one time. During trucking a differential mortality occurred between sexes: 2.4 times more females died than males.
RESEARCH_ORG: US Fish and Wildlife Serivce, Hadley, MA
RELATION: Journal Name: Proc. Soc. Exp. Biol. Med.; (United States); Journal Volume: 41:1
JOURNAL_NAME: Proc. Soc. Exp. Biol. Med.; (United States)

TITLE: First power starts at Soviets' record arch; end is in sight
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HIGH-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; DESIGN; DAMS; USSR; EUROPE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The design and construction of the Inguri hydroelectric power plant in the U.S.S.R. which will be completed in 1981 are described. This project, which has been under construction for 18 years, contains the world's tallest arch dam. Although the dam is not complete, 3 of the five turbogenerators in the power-irrigation complex have been put in operation. (LCL)
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 201:24

TITLE: Coal, hydro will light the lamps of China
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; CHINA; POWER GENERATION; COAL; RESERVES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; WATER RESOURCES; ASIA; CARBONACEOUS MATERIALS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; FOSSIL FUELS; FUELS; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 294001 - Energy Planning & Policy- Coal; 296001 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Coal is the People's Republic of China's dominant source of energy, providing more than 80% of the country's generation and energy output, according to officials of a 19-member delegation that recently concluded a six-week tour of US coal mines, equipment manufacturing plants, and government research facilities. China's total generating capacity is generally an unknown quantity in the rest of the world, but an educated guess would put it currently at about 70,000 MW--perhaps even more, depending on installations after 1972. One member of the delegation estimated China's hydro now at 10% of total installed capacity. Chia Yun-Chen, secretary of the China Coal Society says that the only major problem is acquiring the ability to tap the resources. There is much coal, but how to mine it is a problem. There is not much hydro generation but there are available water resources, the 3,400 mile long Yangtze River. There are no operating nuclear plants, but some are under construction. Coal will be the main source of power in the future, along with hydro, Chia adds.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. World; (United States); Journal Volume: 190:11

TITLE: Solomon Gulch hydroelectric project takes shape
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ALASKA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; PLANNING; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; POWER PLANTS; USA; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The planning and current construction activities for the Solomon Gulch hydroelectric plant near Valdez, Alaska which is scheduled for dam completion in 1980 and power plant operation in 1981 are discussed. The main dam will be 115 ft high and 360 ft wide. The two paralled 48-in. dia penstocks will be constructed from surplus pipe left over from the Alaska pipeline project. Construction on the 12 MW plant began in October 1978. (LCL)
RELATION: Journal Name: Alaska Constr. Oil; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:12

TITLE: Power development and water allocation in Ohio River Basin
AUTHORS: Fuessle, R W; Lyon, R M; Brill, Jr, E D; Stout, G E; Wojnarowski, K E
SUBJECT: 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; OHIO VALLEY REGION; WATER RESOURCES; CONSUMPTION RATES; USES; AVAILABILITY; COOLING; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS; OHIO; OHIO RIVER; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; GREAT LAKES REGION; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; RESOURCES; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; USA; 200101* - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Cooling & Heat Transfer Equipment & Systems; 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: Widespread adoption of evaporative cooling towers will significantly increase water consumption by power plants over the coming decades. The analysis presented includes consideration of allocation issues associated with other growing competitive uses: (1) municipal; (2) industrial; (3) irrigation; and (4) in stream uses. Given hypothetical plant siting strategies suggested by the initial work of the Ohio River Basin Energy Study, consumption will represent high percentages of flows in the tributary basins of the lower Ohio River Basin, especially during 7-day, 10-yr low-flow conditions. Consumption levels are shown for tributary river basins in Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, and Ohio. Alternatives to high levels of consumption are suggested. In addition to presenting an analysis of water allocation in the Ohio Basin, the paper suggests a useful framework for analyzing water allocation in other regions.
RESEARCH_ORG: Univ. of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Water Resour. Plann. Manage. Div., Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 104:WR1
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Water Resour. Plann. Manage. Div., Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States)

TITLE: Power from yesterday's dams
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MODIFICATIONS; NORTH ATLANTIC REGION; CAPACITY; DAMS; FEDERAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS; MAINE; NEW HAMPSHIRE; POWER DEMAND; RAIN; WEATHER; ATMOSPHERIC PRECIPITATIONS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: The potential for hydroelectricity in New England is immense. There are more than 2,800 dams in the six states of Maine, New Hampshire, Vermont, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, and Connecticut. But only 200 of them produce electricity, many far below their full capacity. At the other 2,600 dams, water simply pours over the top, wasting the potential for efficient use of the energy thus created. In the summer of 1977, President Carter ordered the US Army Corps of Engineers to survey the capacity of existing dams. The Army engineers concluded that New England's hydroelectric output of 4.5 billion kWh per year could be more than tripled just by harnessing its smaller dams and increasing the capacity of its existing hydroelectric plants. With no new dams or lakes, there could be enough electricity to meet all the needs of a million people. A boost for the development of small dams has just come from Congress's passage of a three-part legislative package which will provide low-interest Federal loans to encourage the redevelopment of existing small dams of less than 15 MW of capacity. The possible development of sites in New England is described. The projects include the large-scale Dickey-Lincoln School Lakes project on the St. John River in Maine; a new hydroelectric project in Springfield, Vermont; The Goodrich Falls Project, New Hampshire; and a power station in Franklin, New Hampshire. Sustained periods of rainless weather can reduce the capability of hydro to supply power, but water stored behind dams can be released to create a near-instantaneous surge of power when needed for times of peak power demand. (MCW)
RELATION: Journal Name: Environment; (United States); Journal Volume: 20:9

TITLE: Information requirements for improving hydropower
AUTHORS: Yeh, W W.G.; Becker, L; Sohn, R L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; AVAILABILITY; INFORMATION NEEDS; DATA ACQUISITION SYSTEMS; FORECASTING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; WATER RESERVOIRS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: A method of analysis is described with the objective of determining how (and whether) aerospace-derived information system technology can effectively increase hydropower production. The increase in annual hydropower benefits is derived from more accurate reservoir inflow forecasting based upon the use of new or improved sensors and satellite data relay systems. Sensitivity analyses are presented for watershed parameters imbedded in conceptual watershed models. Results are related to hydropower production and sensor requirements via a reservoir optimization model to establish information system requirements. A numerical example is presented using a typical multiple purpose reservoir system located in northern California.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Water Resour. Plann. Manage. Div., Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 104:WR1
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Water Resour. Plann. Manage. Div., Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States)

TITLE: Dickey--Lincoln project may be nearing reality after two decades
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PLANNING; NORTH ATLANTIC REGION; CONSTRUCTION; COST; DAMS; ECONOMIC IMPACT; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; EVALUATION; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; MAINE; PLANTS; PUBLIC OPINION; SCHOOL BUILDINGS; SOCIAL IMPACT; WATER RESOURCES; BUILDINGS; EDUCATIONAL FACILITIES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; RESOURCES; USA; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: A large hydroelectric facility known as the Dickey--Lincoln School project was first proposed two decades ago. It appeared that Congress might soon appropriate construction funds for the long-stalled St. John River (Maine) project, but delay is again anticipated while Dickey--Lincoln is again to be evaluated--this time to assure its compatibility with new White House water resource policies. The project's abundant supply of economically-priced electric power would help stabilize New England's electric rates, lessen New England's dependence on imported oil, and mean jobs for the area. Of 20 alternatives examined by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, none matches its peaking-power capability or its economic feasibility. The project would consist of Dickey Dam on the upper St. John River in the village of Dickey in the town of Allagash and 11 miles downstream, in the Town of St. Francis, would be the Lincoln School Dam. The project would operate primarily as a peaking power plant, providing some 17% of New England's peaking requirements in the mid-1980s. (MCW)
RESEARCH_ORG: Northeast Public Power Association, Wellesley, MA
RELATION: Journal Name: Public Power; (United States); Journal Volume: 36:6

TITLE: High stakes showdown at FERC over recapture
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; LEGAL ASPECTS; OWNERSHIP; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DECISION MAKING; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; INVESTMENT; LICENSING; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; RIVERS; US FERC; USA; WATER RESOURCES; WATER RIGHTS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 130400 - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 520600 - Environment, Aquatic- Regulations - (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: An examination of the future of public power in the 1980s and beyond involves the important law on the books: the preference provisions written into the landmark Federal Act of 1920 that public agencies should have first call on the hydroelectric energy generated by the rivers of America. These provisions are critical in that, in the years ahead, the most-valuable and versatile electrical energy availability will be that generated by falling water. The preference right of public agencies to recapture or take over 50-year licenses originally issued to private power companies is, in the view of public power lawyers, spelled out in Sections 7(a) and 15 of the Federal Power Act of 1920. This interpretation is disputed by attorney who represent the investor-owned companies who own these franchises. Two recapture cases at issue before FERC are: a site on the Weber River, brought by the City of Bountiful, Utah, against Utah Power and Light Co. and the right to hydro sites on the Mokelumne River in California, brought by the City of Santa Clara against Pacific Gas and Electric Co. This will be one of the most far-reaching electric power decisions ever made by the Commission. Other licenses are expiring and more cases may be filed soon. A history surrounding the writing of the law is briefly examined. (MCW)
RELATION: Journal Name: Public Power; (United States); Journal Volume: 36:6

TITLE: Small hydro offers utilities big benefits
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; AVAILABILITY; CALIFORNIA; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; FEDERAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS; FLORIDA; ILLINOIS; MASSACHUSETTS; MICHIGAN; MINNESOTA; NEBRASKA; OHIO; PUBLIC UTILITIES; PUERTO RICO; US DOE; WASHINGTON; GREAT LAKES REGION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MIDWEST REGION; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; NORTH ATLANTIC REGION; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; POWER PLANTS; SOUTHEAST REGION; US ORGANIZATIONS; USA; WEST INDIES; WESTERN REGION; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: In fiscal year 1978, the Department of Energy spent $10-million for research, development, and demonstration of small hydroelectricity (defined as power produced by generators with a maximum capacity of 15,000 kW, at dams no higher than 65 feet). In the first phase of its program, the Department has awarded contracts totaling $2.9-million for 57 feasibility studies of proposed hydroelectric projects, and a majority of these contracts have been awarded to publicly owned systems. In the second phase, DOE will help fund hydroelectric projects at existing dams where positive feasibility assessments have already been made. Development of the hydropower potential at existing hydropower and non-hydropower dams could result in the generation of almost 160 billion kWh of electricity per year and save 727,000 barrels of oil per day. This is 7 1/2 times the savings associated with the President's goal of solar heating 2.5-million homes by 1985.
RELATION: Journal Name: Public Power; (United States); Journal Volume: 36:6

TITLE: Bulb-turbine unit makes U. S. debut at Rock Island
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; USA; CAPACITY; COLUMBIA RIVER; DAMS; PERFORMANCE; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; TURBINES; WASHINGTON; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; POWER PLANTS; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 296001 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Rock Island Dam, the first to span the Columbia River, is also the first hydro project in the U.S. to make use of the bulb unit for a low heat development. Selection of the bulb unit provided the answer to the question of how to feasibly increase the generating capacity of Rock Island Dam on the Columbia River. Through competitive bidding the Alsthom--Neyrpic firm, now Alsthom--Atlantic, was awarded a contract in 1974 to furnish and install eight 54,000 kW bulb units for the Rock Island second powerhouse. Construction and erection of the units has now progressed to the point that two are in operation and all eight are expected to be on line by mid-1979. Performance of the units on which installation has been completed has met design specifications.
RESEARCH_ORG: Chelan County Public Utility District, Wenatchee, WA
RELATION: Journal Name: Public Power; (United States); Journal Volume: 36:6

TITLE: Pumped storage plant to outwit terrain with nuclear plant's aid
SUBJECT: 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; TUNNELS; EXCAVATION; CALIFORNIA; DESIGN; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NORTH AMERICA; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 250300* - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989); 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Equipment and methods used to excavate the underground tunnels and chambers for the 1050 MW Helms pumped stoage power plant in California's High Sierras are described. When completed in 1981 off-peak power from the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant will be used for pumping. (LCL)
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 201:16

TITLE: Small hydro' generates new interest
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ECONOMICS; PLANNING; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; POWER GENERATION; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; USA; WESTERN REGION; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Some communities with suitable geologic and geographic conditions may find that small hydropower plants will offer an economical alternative to purchasing power from an existing utility grid. This is the case in California, where a fair number of these projects are either under way or in the planning stages.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. World; (United States); Journal Volume: 190:7

TITLE: Tennessee Valley Authority v. Hill: protection of endangered species under Section 7 of the Endangered Species Act of 1973
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ENDANGERED SPECIES; LAWSUITS; TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY; DAMS; DECISION MAKING; ECOSYSTEMS; ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY; ETHICS; LEGISLATION; ANIMALS; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; PLANTS; US ORGANIZATIONS; 290300* - Energy Planning & Policy- Environment, Health, & Safety; 130400 - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The Supreme Court's decision to uphold the Endangered Species Act in the case of the Tellico Dam, which would jeopardize the snail darter, is reviewed. The decision clarifies the position that endangered species take priority over a project at any stage in development and that flexibility must come from Congress rather than the courts. Amendments to the Act may be introduced to deal with situations like Tellico. The controversy also raises the question of the Federal government's role and commitment in protecting endangered species. The management priorities of the Act noted the failure of traditional resource management priorities of the Act noted the failure of traditional resource management and acknowledges the ethical responsibility of valuing species by other criteria than their economic value to man. 42 references and footnotes.
RELATION: Journal Name: Nat. Resour. J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:4

TITLE: Excavation of World's largest underground powershouse
AUTHORS: Hamel, L; Nixon, D; Asce, M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; EXCAVATION; QUEBEC; TUNNELS; UNDERGROUND; CANADA; LEVELS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: Located in the nordic region of northwestern Quebec is the $16 billion La Grande River hydroelectric power development complex. On completion, the installed capacity will total 10,190 MW with an anticipated annual production of 68 billion kW-hr. The heart of this complex is LG-2, which includes the world's largest underground powerhouse. Such an undertaking presents formidable problems in organization, logistics, contract administration, and construction techniques. To date these problems have been dealt with successfully. How this was accomplished is described.
RESEARCH_ORG: James Bay Energy Corp., Quebec, Canada
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Constr. Div., Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 104:No. CO3
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Constr. Div., Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States)

TITLE: James Bay hydro blooms in remote, barren wilds
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; CANADA; COST; DAMS; DESIGN; PLANNING; SITE SELECTION; WATER RESERVOIRS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: A description is given of the construction of the La Grande hydroelectric power complex, a $14-billion, 10,190 MW power plan in the James Bay region of Quebec, Canada. The project includes four hydroelectric power sites along the La Grande River, a 535-mile James Bay tributary that drops 1,250 ft east to west in the section being developed. When completed in 1982, the 28.6 miles of dams and dykes will be topped out to allow filling of the 32-million acre-ft reservoir that will provide most of the seasonal regulation. A construction schedule, vital statistics, and cost breakdowns are provided. (PMA)
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 201:5

TITLE: Small hydro sets can yield competitive energy
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; CONSTRUCTION; COST; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; ECONOMICS; EQUIPMENT; SITE PREPARATION; SITE SELECTION; POWER PLANTS; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Small hydro sites are becoming more attractive as fuel prices rise and major hydro sites are taken. Studies in several countries show a potential for non-hydro power dams, and manufacturers are evaluating and developing cost-effective small-package equipment for them. Short cuts for evaluating the costs of a small hydro plant are outlined and shown to have a relatively expensive initial cost, with lower life-time costs. The author illustrates how to estimate and rank sites according to costs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 15:8

TITLE: Papua New Guinea seeks industry to support river development
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; NEW GUINEA; ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT; ECONOMIC IMPACT; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; FORESTS; INFLATION; MANPOWER; MINERAL RESOURCES; PLANNING; RIVERS; SOCIAL IMPACT; TRANSPORT; WATER RESOURCES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 130000 - Hydro Energy; 530100 - Environmental-Social Aspects of Energy Technologies- Social & Economic Studies- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Feasibility studies support the Papua New Guinea government's plans for hydroelectric development on the Purari River if industry can be attracted to the largely unsettled area to absorb most of the power generated. A 30-month design and mobilization period, followed by 5/sup 1///sub 2/ years of construction are indicated for the proposed 1800 megawatt project. The region could develop into an international industrial megapolis supplied with cheap power and transport, abundant fresh water, and large supplies of forest and mineral resources. The government is exploring the drain on manpower resources and the inflationary and environmental effects of rapid development on the rest of the country.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 15:7

TITLE: Tasmania pushes western river developments
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; TASMANIA; ENERGY DEMAND; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; PERSONNEL; PLANNING; POWER GENERATION; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; RIVERS; WATER RESOURCES; AUSTRALASIA; AUSTRALIA; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 130000 - Hydro Energy
DESCRIPTION: Tasmania is investigating the possibility of reducing its dependence on oil imports by developing power plants on the Gordon, King, and Franklin Rivers. Feasibility studies must plan for the inaccessibility caused by a harsh climate and rugged terrain where helicopter supply systems are required. A broad range of professional expertise is involved in the studies. Tasmania already has 22 hydroelectric stations, enough to meet present and expanding needs until the late 1980s. Two alternative plans have been devised for integrating the three rivers into the existing grid. Further construction on the Piemen River is also underway.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 15:7

TITLE: African rivers hold promise of major energy supply
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; AFRICA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; DAMS; ECONOMIC IMPACT; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; ENERGY SUPPLIES; IRRIGATION; POWER GENERATION; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RIVERS; WATER RESOURCES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 200100 - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Power Plants & Power Generation; 520500 - Environment, Aquatic- Site Resource & Use Studies- (-1989); 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: Completion of a group of hydroelectric projects in southern Africa will provide a source of renewable energy to the area and could result in a subcontinental power grid. A project planned for the Orange River, South Africa's largest water system, will eventually include nine dams, 20 power stations, tunnels, and a system of irrigation canals. Projects for the Cunene River (which forms the Angolan-Namibian border), the Zambesi, Kafue, Zaire, and Great Ruaha Rivers are all described in terms of construction status and total planned generating capacity.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 15:7

TITLE: Modeling pumped-storage facilities using dynamic programming
SUBJECT: 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; OPTIMIZATION; ALGORITHMS; DYNAMIC PROGRAMMING; PERFORMANCE; SYSTEMS ANALYSIS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; PROGRAMMING; SIMULATION; 250300* - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989); 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes the modeling of power production in an electric utility containing pumped-storage and thermal generating units. Dynamic programming is the principal algorithm used. The state of the system is defined by the energy stored in the pond. 4 refs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Simul. Counc. Proc. Ser.; (United States); Journal Volume: 8:1

TITLE: Portugal plans more diverse electricity supply
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PORTUGAL; ELECTRIC POWER; CAPACITY; CONSTRUCTION; ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT; EQUIPMENT; FINANCING; FOSSIL-FUEL POWER PLANTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INDUSTRY; INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION; INVESTMENT; NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS; PLANNING; POWER DEMAND; WATER RESOURCES; EUROPE; NUCLEAR FACILITIES; POWER; POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 200100 - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Power Plants & Power Generation; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Two years of drought have persuaded Portugal to broaden its generating capacity from a reliance on hydroelectric plants to include fossil fuel and eventually nuclear plants. The International Monetary Fund has so far declined to finance the projects, but Portuguese officials are confident of eventual foreign backing for capital and equipment. The Portuguese population and industry appear to be stable since nationalization of major industries, including the electric power industry, in June 1976. A desire to augment industrialization also entered into the planning for thermal plants. Details of the proposed additions to the hydo system and the planned thermal units are described in terms of capacity, location, construction schedules, and design.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 15:5

TITLE: Evaluating the vibration state of a hydrogenerator stator winding from the results of selective measurements
AUTHORS: Bryzgalov, V I; Kulak, V M; Sokolov, A E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TURBOGENERATORS; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; MEASURING METHODS; STATORS; TABLES; DATA; DATA FORMS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: From operating experience with the generators at the Krasnoyarsk Hydroelectric Station it follows that in order to provide high operating reliability of large hydrogenerators with direct water cooling of the stator winding it is necessary to provide periodic operational monitoring of the stator winding vibration. A mathematical solution for determining stator winding vibration by using vibration measurements on selected stator elements, the statistical characteristics of those elements and probability theory is described. The calculated results were in good agreement with experimental data. It was shown to be practical to evaluate the vibration state of a hydrogenerator stator winding from the position of the interval of probable values of the maximum winding vibration relative to the level of the allowable winding vibration. (LCL)
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 7:5; Other Information: Translated from Elektr. Stn.; 7: No. 5, 28-31(May 1978)

TITLE: Angles screens and louvers for diverting fish at power plants
AUTHORS: Taft, E P; Mussalli, Y G
SUBJECT: 63 RADIATION, THERMAL, AND OTHER ENVIRON. POLLUTANT EFFECTS ON LIVING ORGS. AND BIOL. MAT.; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FISHES; ENTRAINMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; SALMON; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; POWER PLANTS; VERTEBRATES; 560400* - Other Environmental Pollutant Effects; 200200 - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Waste Management; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Technical report:Angled screens and louvers can divert fish to bypasses within power plant cooling water intake structures. Laboratory and prototype application studies have shown that louvers are more than 90% effective in diverting several fish species, while angled traveling screens are 100% effective in directing fish to bypasses. Since screens act as a diversion device and a screening medium, backup screens for removing debris and non-diverted fish, such as required behind louver systems, are not necessary in screen systems. Louvers require an approach-to-bypass ratio of 1.0:1.5 for efficient operation, while screens are efficient at a 1:1 ratio. Bypass flows and pumping costs are lower in screen systems. Angle screen and fish transport systems are being constructed at two power plants on Lake Ontario. (5 diagrams, 11 references, 2 tables)
RESEARCH_ORG: Stone and Webster Engineering Corp, Boston
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Hydraul. Div., Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 104:5
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Hydraul. Div., Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States)

TITLE: DOE explores soft path energy options for California by year 2025
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 14 SOLAR ENERGY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 17 WIND ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY POLICY; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; ENERGY SOURCES; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; NORTH AMERICA; USA; WESTERN REGION; 299000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation; 293000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Policy, Legislation, & Regulation; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 140400 - Solar Energy- Environmental Aspects; 150400 - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 170500 - Wind Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: California may provide the ultimate demonstration of the extent to which energy choices are inextricably entangled with environmental considerations. The Department of Energy funded a preliminary study that concluded that the state could get along in the year 2025 by developing and using energy technologies based on renewable resources within its own borders. The criteria selected for the energy forms were that they be environmentally gentle; be adaptable to local conditions, resources, and control; be more likely to fail gracefully than catastrophically; be resistant to malevolent actions; be comprehensible; and be matched in energy quality to end-use needs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Prof. Eng. (Wash., D.C.); (United States); Journal Volume: 48:5

DESCRIPTION: The proposed mathematical model permits study of the features of stable and unstable asynchronous operation of hydrogenerators with and without exitation. Large modern hydroelectric generators lose asynchronous stability rapidly when the initial active power approaches the rated power. Dangerous overloads can occur during asynchronous instabilities. The mathematical model may be used to study these instabilities without subjecting the actual equipment to overload situations.

TITLE: Pattani scheme leads southern Thai development
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; THAILAND; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; CAPACITY; CONSTRUCTION; DAMS; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT; ECONOMICS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; FISHING INDUSTRY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; IRRIGATION; POWER DEMAND; WATER RESOURCES; ASIA; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; INDUSTRY; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 130000 - Hydro Energy
DESCRIPTION: The $117 million Pattani hydroelectric project is expected, on the basis of feasibility studies, to meet the increasing demand for electricity in southern Thailand. The earth and rockfill dam will store 995 million cubic meters of water, and the power plant's three units will have a combined capacity of 60 megawatts. A 16 percent increase in power demand was observed during 1976 to jump sharply to 29 percent. The multipurpose Pattani project will include irrigation development, flood control, and fisheries in addition to power generation. Political unrest among Moslems and those seeking separation from the Thai government will be taken into consideration during construction, but will not interfere with the government's intention of supporting development in the Moslem-dominated regions.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 15:3

TITLE: View of Iceland
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ICELAND; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT; ENERGY CONSUMPTION; ENERGY DEMAND; ENERGY SOURCES; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; SEISMIC WAVES; VOLCANIC REGIONS; ELECTRIC POWER; EUROPE; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; 292000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Supply, Demand & Forecasting; 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 150102 - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- Non-USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Iceland has abundant resources in the form of water power and geothermal energy, but development of these sources will be costly and often dangerous. Numerous waterfalls and hydroelectric facilities provide nearly all of the country's electric power, while the geothermally active mid-Atlantic rift crosses Iceland and provides heat for buildings. There is a threat of frequent volcanic eruptions and seismic activity, however, and the present energy supplies have been felt to be adequate to meet the modest domestic demand. If the Icelandic people elect a large-scale energy development for export purposes, the author projects decades of problems and frustrations.
RELATION: Journal Name: Bull. At. Sci.; (United States); Journal Volume: 34:3

SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; FORECASTING; DAMS; ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY SUPPLIES; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ELECTRIC POWER; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Upgrading and retrofitting existing small dams in the United States could add an estimated 40 million kilowatts to the power supply. The placement of non-dam hydrogenerators in small streams could produce substantial additional power without harmful environmental side effects.
RELATION: Journal Name: Environment; (United States); Journal Volume: 20:2

TITLE: Field control replaces design conservatism at world's largest underground powerhouse
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; DESIGN; EXCAVATION; UNDERGROUND; LEVELS; POWER PLANTS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The excavation of 16,635,060 yd/sup 3/ (12,725,821 m/sup 3/) of rock at LG-2, part of the $16 billion, 10,190 megawatt, La Grande River hydropower project in Quebec, Canada, has been completed. The world's largest underground powerhouse, with a capacity of 5328 MW, will be constructed in a 3.7 million yd/sup 3/ (2.8 million m/sup 3/) rock excavation there. Economy and safety were achieved by field control rather than by design conservatism.
RESEARCH_ORG: James Bay Energy Corp., La Grande, Quebec
RELATION: Journal Name: Civ. Eng. (N.Y.); (United States); Journal Volume: 48:2

It is recommended that installation of electronic braking equipment on capsule generators may result in a high national economic effect.

SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 30 DIRECT ENERGY CONVERSION; ELECTROCHEMICAL CELLS; SALINITY GRADIENTS; SALINITY GRADIENT POWER PLANTS; POWER GENERATION; BRINES; ELECTRODIALYSIS; FRESH WATER; MEMBRANES; OSMOSIS; POWER POTENTIAL; SEAWATER; DIALYSIS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; WATER; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 300000 - Direct Energy Conversion
DESCRIPTION: A large source of energy exists at the interface between water bodies of different salinities. Two techniques, pressure-retarded osmosis and reverse electrodialysis, appear to be promising entrees into this energy source. Although the present cost of membranes suitable to these methods is too high, a research and development effort should make this salinity gradient energy competitive with other energy sources.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy (Stamford, Conn.); (United States); Journal Volume: 3:1

TITLE: Lost megawatts flow over nation's myriad spillways
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; POWER POTENTIAL; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ECONOMICS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; DAMS; RIVERS; USA; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: The power-producing potential of small hydroelectric plants at existing dams in New England and other sections of the US is discussed. The Corps of Engineers estimates that 5100 MW of electrical generating capacity could be obtained from more efficient turbogenerators installed at existing dams. The economic, environmental, and time advantages of developing and using these sources of hydroelectric power are emphasized. (LCL)
RELATION: Journal Name: Mil. Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 70:454

TITLE: Huge hydroelectric complex to aid in meeting energy needs
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PLANNING; CONSTRUCTION; DAMS; DIESEL ENGINES; EXCAVATION; POWER SYSTEMS; QUEBEC; CANADA; ENGINES; INTERNAL COMBUSTION ENGINES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; 130000* - Hydro Energy
DESCRIPTION: In an effort to continue to meet Quebec's need for electricity, Hydro-Quebec chartered the Societe d'energie de la James Bay (SEBJ) to tap the vast hydroelectric resources in northern Quebec. The SEBJ is responsible for the hydroelectric development of rivers of the Quebec side of James Bay, which is the southern extension of Hudson Bay. To meet the growth of Quebec's electricity needs, SEBJ has undertaken the development of the La Grande River hydroelectric resources. The complex, one of the largest hydroelectric developments in the world, began construction in 1973 and work will continue until 1985. The project will have a total installed capacity of 10,440,000 kW, with an annual energy production of 68.4 billion kWh. The project includes the construction of four generating stations and will involve the partial diversion of the Caniapiscau and Eastmain Rivers. The complex's six reservoirs and forebays, with a total capacity of 3366 billion cubic feet, will require the construction of about 150 dikes and dams, involving a total volume of fill of 200 million cubic yards.
RELATION: Journal Name: Diesel Gas Turbine Prog.; (United States); Journal Volume: 44:1

TITLE: Experimental determination of the frequency characteristics and electrmagnetic parameters of large synchronous generators
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TURBOGENERATORS; PERFORMANCE TESTING; AC SYSTEMS; ELECTROMAGNETS; FREQUENCY MEASUREMENT; POWER GENERATION; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; MAGNETS; POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; TESTING; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Determination of the frequency curves and their use to determine the electromagnetic parameters of a 500 MW SVF-1690/175-64 hydrogenerator installed at the Krasnoyarsk Hydroelectric Station are discussed. For the tests, the rotor was established along the longitudinal axis relative to phase A. The rotor position was determined from the maximum transformation coefficient between the excitation winding and the stator winding during application of an industrial frequency (50 Hz) current to phase and slow turning of the rotor. The results showed that: the calculated values of hydrogenerator parameters may differ significantly from the actual values, thus experimental determination of these parameters is necessary; the electromagnetic parameters of the SVF-1690/175-64 hydrogenerator are close to the parameters of large turbogenerators, and its attenuation (damping) system is equivalent to the body, which in the calculations should be taken into consideration by several equivalent damping circuits; the frequency characteristics determined by the harmonic effect method provide all the electromagnetic parameters both for the longitudinal and transverse axes of the machine; and the methods of performance of the experiment, analysis of the data and calculation of the parameters are simple and convenient in engineering practice.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 7:1; Other Information: Translated from Elektr. Stn.; 7: No. 1, 47-56(Jan 1978)

TITLE: Small hydro project potential at existing dams
AUTHORS: Janopaul, R N; Willer, D C
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; INVENTORIES; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CALIFORNIA; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; COMPETITION; DESIGN; ECONOMICS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SUBSTITUTION EQUIVALENT; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; IDAHO; MISSOURI; MONTANA; NEVADA; POWER GENERATION; POWER TRANSMISSION LINES; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; USA; ENERGY SOURCES; MIDWEST REGION; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; POWER; POWER PLANTS; ROCKY MOUNTAIN REGION; WESTERN REGION; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: A recent Corps of Engineers study found that of the 50,000 dams in this country, only 800 are being used to produce electrical energy. Some of these 50,000 dams once produced power, but as the initial equipment wore out and alternative sources of electrical energy became cheaper, it was not economically feasible to refurbish them. The Corps believes that if all of the dams which could produce power were reactivated, or if new generating capacity were installed, they could supply a total of 54,600,000 kW and generate almost 160 billion kWh. It would take 265 million barrels of oil each year to generate that amount of power. The total energy shortage can never be solved with these small hydro projects. More massive projects are needed. However, many cities and public utilities could install some generating units at existing dams and produce energy at less cost than that of alternatives. These are the advantages: the natural resource is already there, and it is a renewable one. There is usually no environmental impact--no air or water pollution. And the process is clean, quiet, small scale, and unobtrusive, and frequently takes place near a population center, eliminating the need for long or high-voltage transmission lines. Technology of generating hydroelectricity exists, and in highly sophisticated form. For small hydroelectric projects at existing dams, generation can easily be achieved in five years from the conception date.
RELATION: Journal Name: Mil. Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 70:457

TITLE: Vermont town plans new municipal system with hydro
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 32 ENERGY CONSERVATION, CONSUMPTION, AND UTILIZATION; COMMUNITIES; PUBLIC UTILITIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; VERMONT; DAMS; ECONOMICS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; HEARINGS; LEGAL ASPECTS; LOAD MANAGEMENT; LOCAL GOVERNMENT; MANAGEMENT; PUBLIC OPINION; REGULATIONS; RIVERS; SCHOOL BUILDINGS; WATER RESOURCES; BUILDINGS; EDUCATIONAL FACILITIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; NORTH AMERICA; NORTH ATLANTIC REGION; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; USA; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 320601 - Energy Conservation, Consumption, & Utilization- Municipalities & Community Systems- Conservation Services- (1980-)
DESCRIPTION: Springfield, Vermont, in an effort to lower utility bills at its all-electric high school, is planning to reactivate six old hydroelectric projects on the Black River and develop a municipal electric service. The project will also include a reservoir and several power plants with a 30-MW output as a peaking unit. Projected state power shortages in the 1980s may lead to intermediate power generation. Public hearings are underway to determine the best method of ownership and the proper cost to Springfield, although local officials expect the final decisions to be made by the state Supreme Court. Proponents of a municipal system foresee significantly lower electric bills after the project is completed in spite of intense opposition from the Central Vermont Public Service Co.
RESEARCH_ORG: Northeast Public Power Association, Wellesley, MA
RELATION: Journal Name: Public Power; (United States); Journal Volume: 36:4

TITLE: Tolerances of fishes to dissolved gas supersaturation in deep tank bioassays
AUTHORS: Fickeisen, D H; Montgomery, J C
SUBJECT: 63 RADIATION, THERMAL, AND OTHER ENVIRON. POLLUTANT EFFECTS ON LIVING ORGS. AND BIOL. MAT.; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; FISHES; GAS BUBBLE DISEASE; GASES; TOLERANCE; BENCH-SCALE EXPERIMENTS; BIOASSAY; BIOLOGICAL ADAPTATION; COLUMBIA RIVER; MONTANA; SUPERSATURATION; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; DISEASES; FLUIDS; NORTH AMERICA; RIVERS; ROCKY MOUNTAIN REGION; SATURATION; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; USA; VERTEBRATES; 560400* - Other Environmental Pollutant Effects; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Four species of fish were tested for tolerance to dissolved atmospheric gas supersaturation in 10-day bioassays. Based on median times to death at four levels of gas saturation, the fish displayed the following increasing order of tolerance: mountain whitefish (Prosopium Williamsoni) < cutthroat trout (Salmo clarki) < largescale sucker (Catostomus machrocheilus) < torrent sculpin (Cottus rhotheus). Increasing hydrostatic pressure due to water depth reduced the levels of saturation of dissolved gases and increased survival. Torrent sculpins typically developed large bubbles of gas which caused them to float and would contribute indirectly to death.
RELATION: Journal Name: Trans. Am. Fish. Soc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 107:2

TITLE: Hydroelectric solar energy conversion
SUBJECT: 14 SOLAR ENERGY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; COASTAL REGIONS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; SOLAR ENERGY CONVERSION; CARNOT CYCLE; DESERTS; EFFICIENCY; EVAPORATION; INLAND WATERWAYS; SEAS; TIDE; ARID LANDS; CONVERSION; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY CONVERSION; ENERGY SOURCES; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SURFACE WATERS; THERMODYNAMIC CYCLES; 140700* - Solar Thermal Power Systems; 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: A means of direct conversion of solar energy to hydroelectric energy is discussed. The mechanism is appropriate to low-lying coastal desert regions with high potential evaporation rates. Formulas for output power are obtained. Climate and related data appropriate to suitable locations are included. Consider an arid domain with large annual potential evaporation and vanishingly small precipitation. Let the domain be approximately at sea level (or a natural depression) and close to a great body of water. A large deep basin is excavated in the domain and a canal is constructed from the sea to the depression. Hydroelectric energy is obtained from the fall of the sea water into the depression. The water so fed into the basin evaporates during the sunlight hours. The generators run over the maximally efficient portion of the 24-h day. The cycle of fall, together with evaporation and lift, effects a Carnot cycle.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Sources; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:3/4

TITLE: Argentina tapping hydropower to the tune of $12 billion by '85
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ARGENTINA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PLANNING; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SOUTH AMERICA; 130000* - Hydro Energy
