TITLE: Hydroelectric power and science provisions of the 1950 Niagara Treaty
AUTHORS: Friesen, B F; Day, J C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; LEGAL ASPECTS; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; ELECTRICITY; GREAT LAKES; INTERNATIONAL LAWS; LAND USE; PUBLIC OPINION; RIVERS; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; TREATIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; LAKES; LAWS; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 520600 - Environment, Aquatic- Regulations - (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: An important international Niagara River management issue concerns allocation of the average 202,000 cubic feet per second river discharge for hydroelectric power and scenic purposes. Major water diversions from Niagara Falls are necessary for power production. Flow is allocated by the 1950 Niagara Treaty which is intended to maximize power benefits and preserve and enhance the scenic falls spectacle. This paper examines the extent to which the Treaty objectives have been achieved. Based on analyses of government documents, engineering data, and falls-viewing patterns, it is concluded that the 1950 Treaty led to enhancement of the falls spectacle and increased power generation. But significant additional power diversions probably are attainable without adverse effect upon the existing falls spectacle. Reducing daytime summer Horseshoe Falls flow and scheduling spring and autumn flow according to viewing patterns are possible means of increasing power diversions. Existing generating facilities could use considerably more water and the value of additional Niagara hydroelectricity is very high in terms of generation-cost savings over alternative power sources. Because of the cultural importance of the falls. Treaty modifications to permit increased power diversions are not recommended without prior public opinion sampling and on-site viewing experiments. These findings highlight the need for more careful study before long-term international agreements are concluded and illustrate the need for more flexible treaty arrangements to permit periodic adjustments for changing conditions.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 13:6

TITLE: Jenpeg start-up underlines Manitoba power disputes
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PERFORMANCE; MANITOBA; ADVERSARIES; DESIGN; ENERGY POLICY; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION; POWER DISTRIBUTION; POWER GENERATION; POWER TRANSMISSION; PUBLIC OPINION; PUBLIC RELATIONS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; STANDARDS; TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER; TURBINES; USSR; CANADA; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; EUROPE; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 296001 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The trouble-plagued Manitoba Hydro's Soviet-designed turbine had a successful startup and operation after lengthy construction delays and cost overruns. Concerns that the Soviet units would not operate properly were dispelled by the good performance and ended, at least temporarily, a series of disputes. Hydro selected the low-bidding Soviet company in order to get bulb-type turbines, which can be arranged compactly and have better operating efficiency at a low operating head. Five more units are scheduled for production next year. The Jenpeg project is one of the first major Soviet efforts on this continent and the first bulb-type turbine. Difficulties between Canada and the Soviet Union arose because of the project's delays, many of which resulted from the Soviet preference for on-site construction and their unfamiliar standards and philosophies. A review of the controversies reveals public disagreement within the country over how the utility and government should function during development projects. Manitoba Hydro is tying into U.S. power grids for sales and exchanges to such an extent that its exports to the U.S. may exceed those to Ontario. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 14:11

TITLE: Mekong development prospects revive
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PLANNING; WATER RESOURCES; ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT; CAMBODIA; DAMS; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; ECONOMIC IMPACT; ECONOMICS; FORECASTING; INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION; IRRIGATION; LAOS; POWER GENERATION; RIVERS; SOCIAL IMPACT; SOUTH VIETNAM; THAILAND; WATER RESERVOIRS; ASIA; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 530100 - Environmental-Social Aspects of Energy Technologies- Social & Economic Studies- (-1989); 520500 - Environment, Aquatic- Site Resource & Use Studies- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: New efforts to develop the Pa Mong area spanning the Mekong River will require the cooperative efforts of Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia, and Thailand. Regulation of the Mekong and its tributaries include plans for a multi-purpose damsite at Pa Mong to generate power, establish domestic and industrial fisheries, irrigate farmland, control floods, and provide a minimum depth for navigation. Smaller dams without power houses will be built in the Nam Lik and Nam Mong tributaries. Specification and projected capacities are detailed for the powerhouse, dams, and reservoirs. Estimates made in 1969 called for nearly 45,000 persons to be displaced with little disruption. Other projections foresee an increase of 280% in food production, new raw materials and transportation opportunities to stimulate industries, and general economic benefits. Although funds have been invested through the World Bank, Cambodia has still not agreed to participate. An interim committee of the other countries is proceeding to develop plans. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 14:10

TITLE: RVMG 110 and 220 kV valve arresters for cold climate regions
AUTHORS: Vitkin, A L; Rozet, V E; Tabardanova, M P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; EQUIPMENT PROTECTION DEVICES; DESIGN; ELECTRIC DISCHARGES; ELECTRICAL PROPERTIES; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; RESISTORS; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: RVMG series valve arresters for hydroelectric power plants with magnetic arc suppression for operation in cold climate regions are designed for decrease of the atmospheric temperature to -60/sup 0/C (periodically to -64/sup 0/C), wind velocity to 40 m/sec and conductor stress up to 700 N. The arresters are largely unitized with series production RVMG series arresters designed for operation in moderate climate zones. The use of new cold-resistant arrester designs intended for use in the open air gives a significant saving due to elimination of the necessity for construction of enclosed, heated distribution units in the Far North and East.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 6:10; Other Information: Translated from Elektr. Stn.; No. 10, 73-74(Oct 1977)

TITLE: USSR's Nurek earthfill rises to a record, sets stage for a higher one
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LAND USE; POWER GENERATION; RIVERS; SITE SELECTION; SOILS; USSR; EUROPE; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: Construction of the Nurek Dam is briefly described and the lessons learned are to be applied during construction of the higher Rogun earthfill dam upstream. Rogun is expected to reach 1,066 ft and generate 3,600 MW with six units twice the size of Nurek's. The project is in the southern Tadzhikistan Republic. (MCW)
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 199:12

TITLE: Disasters as a necessary part of benefit-cost analyses
AUTHORS: Mark, R K; Stuart-Alexander, D E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; FAILURES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INSURANCE; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; ECONOMICS; HAZARDS; POWER PLANTS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Although it is well known that some low-probability events can be very costly, benefit-cost analyses for water projects generally have not included the probable value of these costs. The significance of expected costs is reflected in the growing difficulty of obtaining liability insurance against dam failure, even at highly inflated prices. The need to include events such as dam failures, impoundment-induced earthquakes, and landslides in the benefit-cost analyses of reservoir projects is discussed. Actual methods of estimation are not considered.
RELATION: Journal Name: Science; (United States); Journal Volume: 197:4309

TITLE: Small hydro sites, once scorned, get a second look
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; EQUIPMENT; PLANNING; CAPACITY; COMMERCIALIZATION; ECONOMIC POLICY; ECONOMICS; ENERGY FACILITIES; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; FINANCING; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS; LEGISLATION; NATIONAL ENERGY PLAN; POWER GENERATION; PUBLIC UTILITIES; US ERDA; WATER RESOURCES; ENERGY POLICY; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; US ORGANIZATIONS; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: High generating costs for conventional thermal power plants have prompted renewed interest in small-scale hydroelectric units that could be constructed to serve industrial plants or to allow utilities to lower their base power costs. Indications of this new interest include an ERDA program for encouraging the development of small sites having hydroelectric potential, new generating equipment designed for small sites, a Federal grant program, and feasibility studies. Grant money will be aimed at municipal, cooperative, industrial, and nonprofit development. An estimate by the Army Corps of Engineers indicates a potential 49,000 dams are capable of generating 33,000 megawatts (MW). The Corps study also projects a higher capacity is available from existing thermal plants with more powerful generators and more efficient turbines. A regional breakdown in new capacity is based on the Corps' estimate for a total potential of 54,000 MW. A list of equipment suppliers includes both foreign and domestic manufacturers of small-scale equipment. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy User News; (United States); Journal Volume: 2:35

TITLE: Small hydroelectric units: where to find them
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; EQUIPMENT; RETROFITTING; INFORMATION; MANUFACTURING; MARKET; CONSTRUCTION; POWER PLANTS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: A list of 14 manufacturers of small hydroelectric units includes the supplier's name, address, phone number, and person to contact. Remarks after eight of the manufacturers indicate the company's experience and range of equipment. The remainder did not respond to the request for information. One-year lead times were quoted because of the need to make each unit according to specific head and flow conditions. The hope is expressed that more manufacturers will develop as interest grows in retrofitting small-scale dams with hydro units. (DCK)
RESEARCH_ORG: Charles Pool and Associates, Inc., Ketchikan, AK
RELATION: Journal Name: Civ. Eng. (N.Y.); (United States); Journal Volume: 47:9

TITLE: Modernization of a small hydro plant. [Cornell Hydro in northern Wisconsin]
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MODIFICATIONS; CAPACITY; CONSTRUCTION; ECONOMICS; ENERGY CONSERVATION; ENERGY EFFICIENCY; FLOOD CONTROL; MANAGEMENT; PERFORMANCE; POWER GENERATION; RETROFITTING; EFFICIENCY; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Old, unprofitable hydroelectric plants were usually abandoned until a project to rebuild the Cornell Hydro plant in Wisconsin demonstrated how money, time, and energy can be saved. The powerhouse was demolished and rebuilt with modifications that maintain a constant minimum river flow, increase the flood passage capacity, save energy with single small transformers for each generator, and use heat recovered from the generators for space heating. Stripped-down turbines maintain a constant flow, speed, and smooth start-up. Crane rental cost was eliminated by using a small mobile crane that can be shared by other installations. The project took less than two years to complete and cost $520 per kilowatt of installed capacity. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Civ. Eng. (N.Y.); (United States); Journal Volume: 47:9

TITLE: Environmental impacts of hydroelectric power plants
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INLAND WATERWAYS; RIVERS; SUSQUEHANNA RIVER; AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS; BENTHOS; EROSION; EUTROPHICATION; PLANNING; SURFACE WATERS; WATER QUALITY; ECOSYSTEMS; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 290300 - Energy Planning & Policy- Environment, Health, & Safety; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Hydroelectric power plants sited on rivers and streams change the natural conditions of these water bodies through both short-term and long-term impacts. Therefore, changes in water quality, erosion, fluctuation in water temperature and water flow, and eutrophication must be studied in planning future hydroelectric installations. The objectives of this paper are to describe briefly the reported physical, chemical, and hydrodynamic changes associated with hydroelectric dams and to relate some of these changes to the fish and benthic communities of the lower Susquehanna River. Several aspects of the impacts of hydroelectric projects are briefly considered and changes in the lower Susquehanna River, the site of four large dams, are evaluated in light of disruption of the upstream runs of the previously existing migratory fishes. Changes in the structure of the benthic community are also analyzed based on literature reviewed. 46 references.
RESEARCH_ORG: Lawler, Matusky, and Skelly Engineers, Tappan, NY
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Hydraul. Div., Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 103:HY9
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Hydraul. Div., Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States)

TITLE: IRIS: a computerized high head pump turbine design system
SUBJECT: 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; COMPUTER-AIDED DESIGN; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; PUMPS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; I CODES; COMPUTER CODES; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 250300* - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989); 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: ''IRIS'' is a computerized design and structural optimization system capable of generating all the major hydraulic and mechanical design parameters of high head pump/turbines from limited input data. The program will size the unit and select the proper hydraulic passage configuration according to performance requirements and optimize the dimensions of all the major components, generate command tapes used by a numerically controlled flame cutter, estimate cost, and issue manufacturing process planning. It also generates finite element models for the ''in depth'' analysis of critical components.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Fluids Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 99:3

TITLE: New England utilities drop opposition to Dickey Dam
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; PLANNING; ALLOCATIONS; COMPETITION; CONSTRUCTION; COST; DAMS; ECONOMICS; ENERGY POLICY; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; MARKET; POWER DISTRIBUTION; POWER GENERATION; PUBLIC OPINION; PUBLIC UTILITIES; REGULATIONS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 296002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Transmission & Distribution- (-1989); 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Construction of the Dickey-Lincoln School Lakes Hydroelectric Power Project, designed to supply 15 percent of New England's peaking power, will no longer be delayed by opposition from private utilities. First proposed in 1959, the project is now hoped to be operational by the mid-1980s. Lobbying activities against the dam will be discontinued by Boston Edison and 16 other electric companies. Support of the dam as economically feasible and beneficial comes from the Army Corps of Engineers (which will operate the project), the Department of Interior (which will market the power), members of Congress, and the increasing public demand for power. Opposition from the private companies was primarily in response to the preference clause giving government-operated utilities first chance to buy the power. The private companies fear that they will not get their fair share as demand grows. The project, with an anticipated cost of $668 million for construction and transmission facilities, will become part of the regional New England Power Pool. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy User News; (United States); Journal Volume: 2:34

TITLE: Experience in operational monitoring of hydrogenerator stator vibration
AUTHORS: Kabanov, P S; Luzhnova, S G; Miroshnichenko, V D; Petrov, Yu V; Khovko, V N; El'kind, Yu M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; JOINTS; MAINTENANCE; MONITORING; RELIABILITY; REPAIR; STATORS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Operational monitoring of the vibration of hydrogenerator stators makes it possible to have early objective diagnosis of defects, provides a better foundation for planning yearly major overhaul and timely correction in the process of operation. This will provide a significant decrease in the amount of maintenance and an increase in the operational reliability of hydrogenerators. The use of standard vibration measurement equipment permits operational monitoring of the vibration of hydrogenerator stators. It is necessary to have more detailed study of the weakening of the joint connections of the stator core and loosening of the rotor rims of hydrogenerators. Maintenance enterprises should develop the technology and corresponding standard instructions for repairing the joints of the stator core and rewedging the rims of hydrogenerator rotors in order to improve hydrogenerator operation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 6:8; Other Information: Translated from Elektr. Stn.; No. 8, 79-82(Aug 1977)

TITLE: Transmission of part of the power of hydrogenerators through two transformer phases
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER TRANSMISSION; POWER TRANSMISSION LINES; TRANSFORMERS; ASYMMETRY; FAILURES; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; OPERATION; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 200300 - Electric Power Engineering- Power Transmission & Distribution- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: On failure of one of the three transformer phases when no reserve phase is present a significant part of the generator power may be transmitted through two-leg wye (open delta) circuits. About 25 to 35% of the rated power of the unit can be transmitted through two phases without going outside the limits of the GOST (All-Union State Standards) requirements. Comparatively simple tests performed by the hydroelectric station personnel usually make it possible to increase the power transmitted through two phases to 40 to 50% of the rated power of the generator.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 6:8; Other Information: Translated from Elektr. Stn.; No. 8, 49-52(Aug 1977)

TITLE: Pumped-storage can be unique
SUBJECT: 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; BUILDING MATERIALS; CONCRETES; DAMS; OFF-PEAK ENERGY STORAGE; PENSTOCKS; PLANNING; REINFORCED CONCRETE; WATER RESERVOIRS; ENERGY STORAGE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MATERIALS; PIPES; POWER PLANTS; REINFORCED MATERIALS; STORAGE; SURFACE WATERS; 250300* - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989); 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: A pumped-storage hydroelectric power plant, designed to store energy from a hydroelectric-fossel-fuel-nuclear power complex, is described. The pumped storage reservoir will also serve as a cooling pond for the nuclear plant. A discussion is given of the concrete and earth-fill dams and embankments, the intake structure, the steel and concrete-encased steel penstocks, the power house, and the tailrace structures. (PMA)
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. World; (United States); Journal Volume: 188:3

TITLE: Laos hydro scheme survives political storm
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; DESIGN; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; LAOS; PLANNING; ASIA; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Hydraulically generated electrical energy is the most important export product and source of foreign exchange in Laos, likely to become more predominant in the future. The second phase of the Nam Ngum development in Laos is intended to earn foreign exchange by exporting some of its output to neighboring Thailand. When the Indochina war came to an end and new political alignments formed in the area, construction was hampered by closure of the frontier. Since then, work has resumed, but with a greater participation of Laotian labor than hitherto and the project is well on the way to completion.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 14:8

TITLE: India builds power network, risking rock faults, monsoons
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; DAMS; INDIA; IRRIGATION; POWER RANGE 100-1000 MW; TUNNELS; ASIA; POWER PLANTS; 130000* - Hydro Energy
DESCRIPTION: One of India's most ambitious multipurpose river valley projects is nearing completion after a campaign that included construction of a 260-ft-high dam in seven months between monsoon seasons and excavation of 16 miles of tunnel in young, unstable mountains, where tunneling had never before seemed feasible. The $800-million Beas Project is part of a master plan to irrigate and bring power to India's northwest, developed after signing the Indus Water Treaty in 1960 with Pakistan. It divides the Indus Basin between the two countries and gives total jurisdiction over the Beas, Sutlej and Ravi rivers to India, though development of the Ravi has not yet begun. The plan incorporates the Bhakra-Nangal project, completed in the early '60s, to bring water and electricity to six of the region's states. Two of the diversion tunnels will be used for irrigation, three as penstocks for the powerplant which will have an initial installed capacity of 240 Mw, four units of 60 Mw each, with a provision for two additional 60-Mw units at a later stage. The first generating unit is expected to go on line in October, 1977.
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 199:4

TITLE: Sayan's record powerhouse will spur Siberian development
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; DAMS; PLANNING; POWER RANGE 1-10 GW; USSR; EUROPE; POWER PLANTS; 130000* - Hydro Energy
DESCRIPTION: A description is given of the continuing construction of Russia's Sayan Dam on the Yenisey River gorge. The dam will be 804 feet, will produce 6,400 MW, and it is slated for completion in 1983. (PMC)
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 199:3

TITLE: Influence of temperature on the vibration of hydrogenerator stator windings
AUTHORS: Alekseeva, L I; Kislitskii, B V
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FREQUENCY DEPENDENCE; STATORS; TEMPERATURE EFFECTS; TESTING; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Temperature has no significant influence on the vibration state of the stator windings of hydrogenerators with various winding designs and types of insulation. It is sufficient to perform experimental studies of the vibration state of the stator winding for any arbitrary thermal state of the stator. It appears favorable to use the natural thermal state of the stator. Objective evaluation of the design variant, as well as evaluation of the dynamics of the stator winding vibration state in the process of generator operation is possible only on the basis of study of the amplitude-frequency curves.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 6:7; Other Information: Translated from Elektr. Stn.; No. 7, 52-55(Jul 1977)

TITLE: Hydrogenerator stator core maintenance in accord with the results of instrument monitoring of the joints
AUTHORS: Vodeneev, N F; Kislitskii, B V; Kalina, M F; Mel'nikov, G P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; MAINTENANCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; JOINTS; MONITORING; STATORS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The use of instrument monitoring of hydrogenerator stator joints prevents undetected impairment of the state of this zone and permits planning of timely maintenance operations at the moment a critical state arises. The proposed complex of maintenance-repair measures reliable restoration of the tightness of core section joints and the system for attachment of the core to the stator housing without exceeding the planned maintenance time.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 6:7; Other Information: Translated from Elektr. Stn.; No. 7, 25-27(Jul 1977)

TITLE: Vibration characteristics of the stator winding of a VGSVF-940/235-30 hydrogenerator
AUTHORS: Biryuleva, T B; Kremenchugskii, M G; Nadtochii, V M; Polynskii, A S; Feodoridi, P I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FREQUENCY DEPENDENCE; STABILITY; STATORS; TESTING; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The design of the stator winding front part baskets on the advance model VGSVF-940/235-30 hydrogenerators provides a sufficiently low winding vibration level at the rated current load and may be recommended for series production generators of this type. For accumulation of information on the stability of the stator winding fastening system during prolonged operation it is favorable to monitor the vibration of the advance model generator once per year. The monitoring should be performed from the statistical parameters of the vibration state of the stator winding during a steady-state three-phase short circuit at the rated stator current with obligatory measurement of the amplitude-frequency curves of the front arch oscillations.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 6:7; Other Information: Translated from Elektr. Stn.; No. 7, 49-51(Jul 1977)

TITLE: Peru extends Andean river project
AUTHORS: Wolfenzon, A; Simonetta, M; Maravi, C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PLANNING; PERU; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; CLIMATES; CONSTRUCTION; DAMS; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; ENGINEERING; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; GEOLOGICAL SURVEYS; MANPOWER; POWER GENERATION; RIVERS; TRANSPORT; WATER RESOURCES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; LATIN AMERICA; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SOUTH AMERICA; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 520500 - Environment, Aquatic- Site Resource & Use Studies- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Exploitation of Peru's water resources began 35 years ago with plans to develop the Rio Mantaro tributary of the Amazon. Subsequent surveys in the 1950's showed the river to have a different flow than had been mapped. A second bend in the river allowed two development sites. The Coporacion del Mantaro (CORMAN) became the country's first government-corporation for developing power. The first power was delivered in 1973 to the Lima area. Extension of the project is under construction and will be operating in 1979. Construction of a second power station begins in 1977. The project has involved the Italian firm Impregilo-GIE and the Swiss firm Electrowatt Engineering Services Ltd. The project has had to proceed against a harsh climate, a virtually impassable terrain that makes transportation and access difficult, and rock slides, all of which created hazards and required innovative engineering. Besides power, the project succeeded in establishing communications and transportation links on the Atlantic side of the Andes, developed an infrastructure, and opened up new opportunities for developing Peru's resources. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 14:7

TITLE: Behavior of auxiliary intake of Ramganga Dam at low levels
AUTHORS: Mohan, H; Sharma, H D; Varshney, D V; Tiagi, S S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INTAKE STRUCTURES; DAMAGE; AIR; FLOW RATE; FLUID FLOW; INDIA; PENSTOCKS; WATER; ASIA; FLUIDS; GASES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PIPES; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: In June, 1975, when the auxiliary intake of Ramganga Dam was being run, its hemispherical trash-rack was lifted up, displaced from its seat, and subsequently sucked into the tunnel. Model studies were conducted to investigate the causes of the trash-rack displacement and of the auxiliary intake behavior at low reservoir levels. The studies indicated that the release of air-water spouts resulting from escape of locked air in the tunnel through the intake shaft at a reservoir level of El.970.46-ft could have lifted up and displaced the hemispherical trash-rack. In order to avoid air entry into the tunnel, a regulation curve for HB valve operation has been suggested to prevent recurrence of such a phenomenon in the future.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Hydraul. Div., Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 103:HY7
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Hydraul. Div., Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States)

TITLE: South Africa's largest hydro scheme nears completion
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; PLANNING; SOUTH AFRICA; WATER RESOURCES; CAPACITY; DAMS; DESIGN; DIMENSIONS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; ENGINEERING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; MARKET; POWER DEMAND; PUMPED STORAGE; SPECIFICATIONS; TURBINES; AFRICA; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY STORAGE; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; STORAGE; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The Electricity Supply Commission (ESCOM) of South Africa relies primarily on coal-fired power plants, but is now looking for ways to exploit hydroelectric power on its two major rivers. The Orange River Project combines power generation, flood control, irrigation and urban and industrial water supplies. Plants on the Orange River and Cabora Bassa represents conventional hydroelectric plants, while future plans are to explore the potential of two pumped-storage projects that could take advantage of the Drakensberg Mountains and the area of the Western Cape. A review of the planning and construction phases of the Orange River Project includes specifications for each of its components, now producing a total of 540 MW. ESCOM's 12% growth rate is attributed to the bulk supplies to customers in urban areas, industry and mining operations. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 14:7

TITLE: California's aqueduct offers peaking power to Los Angeles
SUBJECT: 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; SPECIFICATIONS; CALIFORNIA; DAMS; DESIGN; ENERGY FACILITIES; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; POWER GENERATION; PUBLIC UTILITIES; PUMPS; TURBINES; WATER RESERVOIRS; WATER RESOURCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; TURBOMACHINERY; USA; WESTERN REGION; 250300* - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989); 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 520500 - Environment, Aquatic- Site Resource & Use Studies- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The half-completed Castaic hydroelectric project in California combines an innovative system for generating environmentally clean power from energy recovered when water is pumped over the mountains. The system is designed to provide a peak energy source that doesn't interfere with the water supply. Interconnections with other power plants are expected to insure cheap pumping energy. The project, located on the California aquaduct at Pyramid Lake and Castaic Lake on either side of the Tehachapi Mountains, is managed by three utility companies. An abnormally dry climate has prevented the system from operating as planned. Specifications of the project design include construction details, earthquake precautions, and a description of the pumps, turbines, and generators. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 14:7

TITLE: Australia approaches limit of hydro power development
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; AUSTRALIA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PLANNING; CONSTRUCTION; DAMS; ECONOMICS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; FORECASTING; IRRIGATION; POWER GENERATION; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; WATER RESOURCES; AUSTRALASIA; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: Australia, in spite of a low dry country with limited hydroelectric potential, is planning several projects that could provide between 22 and 91% of the 1972 power output, the amount depending on Australia's economic climate. The World Energy Conference projects a gross theoretical capability of 53.6 trillion watt hours (TWH) per year, but economic, geographical, and environmental constraints will reduce the probable capability to 22.5 TWH. Significant hydroelectric potential remains in Tasmania and Queensland, with peak load potential in the northwest and west. A scheme now under development includes several dams and pumped storage facilities. The Tallowa Dam and the Kangaroo Valley-Fitzroy Complex construction are described. Details of these and other facilities include their projected power output and irrigation potential. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 14:7

TITLE: Method for dynamic testing of dams
AUTHORS: Ostrom, D K; Kelly, T A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; TESTING; CONCRETES; DAMPING; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; SEISMIC EFFECTS; STABILITY; BUILDING MATERIALS; MATERIALS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The Popper Test is an effective test that is easy to conduct and can be used to help determine the dynamic response characteristics of small to moderately large concrete dams. The Popper Test method is particularly suited in single-arch and multiple-arch concrete strength dams. This test method combines the versatility, ease, and low cost of ambient testing with the data quality advantages of active testing. Fundamental mode data (mode, shape, frequency, and damping) can be extracted visually in the field with proper filtering of the transducer signal. Detailed higher mode information must be obtained by analytical techniques or more specialized field equipment.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Power Div., Proc. Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 103:PO1
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Power Div., Proc. Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States)

TITLE: Hydro power plans back up Nigeria's oil developments
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 32 ENERGY CONSERVATION, CONSUMPTION, AND UTILIZATION; 58 GEOSCIENCES; NIGERIA; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; AGRICULTURE; ARID LANDS; CROPS; DAMS; ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT; FLOOD CONTROL; HYDROLOGY; IRRIGATION; NIGER RIVER; POWER GENERATION; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; RIVERS; AFRICA; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; ENGINEERING; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 320301 - Energy Conservation, Consumption, & Utilization- Industrial & Agricultural Processes- Energy Sources; 530100 - Environmental-Social Aspects of Energy Technologies- Social & Economic Studies- (-1989); 580100 - Geology & Hydrology- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The Niger River and its tributaries offer a potential renewable energy source to supplement Nigeria's oil and gas production. The country's gentle gradient requires containment of the two distinct floods (the sediment-free winter Black Flood and the silt-laden fall White Flood) to be limited to low dams, but also allows large storage reservoirs. Upstream hydro plants operate in Guinea and Upper Volta primarily to generate power, while Nigeria and Mali need multi-propose projects for flood control and irrigation as well as power. Reservoirs to provide irrigation for two or three crops each year could develop a food surplus and a stable agricultural industry. Nigeria's largest project is Kanji, which will have an 836-MW capacity in 1978 and includes navigational locks and reservoirs. A series of low dams and locks on the Niger is needed to cover rapids, reefs, rock outcroppings, and sand banks and allow barge traffic on a regulated flow of water. The National Electric Power Authority (NEPA) plans six more projects which, combined with Nigeria's oil and gas reserves, will provide substantial electric power. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 14:7

TITLE: Three-plant complex adds to Austria's peaking capacity
SUBJECT: 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; AUSTRIA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; PUMPS; SPECIFICATIONS; CAPACITY; CONSTRUCTION; DESIGN; DIMENSIONS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; ENGINEERING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LAKES; PERFORMANCE; POWER GENERATION; RIVERS; WATER RESOURCES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; EUROPE; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 250300* - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989); 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Three power plants that span a 1358-meter head range will add 877 megawatts to the power network of southern Austria. The Malta River will be blocked by the 200-meter high Koelbrein dam, which will store 200 million cubic meters of water in its reservoir. The water will travel through a short tunnel to the Galgenbichl power station, where water can be discharged into a small reservoir to be pumped back to Koelnbrein or through an 18-meter tunnel through the mountains to the Rottau power plant, which has a compensating basin to hold water for the Moellbruecke power station. May 1978 is projected for completion of the project. Between Koelmbrein and Rottau is the Goesskar reservoir, which receives water by aqueducts from neighboring streams and may be the site for a fourth power plant that would use an existing lake for a pumped storage project. Outstanding features of the complex include the height of the Koelnbrein dam, the design of Rottau pumps units, and the option of bypassing the Galgenbichl power station. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 14:7

TITLE: Hydrostatic bearing lubrication during hydrounit start-up and shutdown
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; LUBRICATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; BEARINGS; CALCULATION METHODS; LUBRICATING OILS; ROTORS; START-UP; LUBRICANTS; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: In order to create an oil film in a step bearing before start-up raising of the rotor on the brakes and oil feed under pressure from a pump are equally applicable. Each of these methods has its positive and negative sides. While the operation of raising the rotor on the brakes before start-up is difficult to automate, oil feed under pressure requires grooves on the babbitt surface of the segments, which during normal operation distort the graph of the hydrodynamic pressure, decreasing the thickness of the lubricant film. Formulas given permit determination of the thickness of the start-up lubrication film, the oil feed and the location of the center of the groove for oil feed for concrete operating conditions and bearing designs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 6:5; Other Information: Translated from Elektr. Stn.; No. 5, 37-42(May 1977)

TITLE: High-head pumped storage cools its nuclear partner
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 22 GENERAL STUDIES OF NUCLEAR REACTORS; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS; COOLING PONDS; THERMAL EFFLUENTS; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; WATER RESERVOIRS; CONSTRUCTION; THERMAL POLLUTION; DAMS; DESIGN; ECONOMICS; ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY; POLLUTION REGULATIONS; SURFACE WATERS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NUCLEAR FACILITIES; POLLUTION; PONDS; POWER PLANTS; REGULATIONS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 130000* - Hydro Energy; 250300 - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989); 220500 - Nuclear Reactor Technology- Environmental Aspects; 520400 - Environment, Aquatic- Thermal Effluents Monitoring & Transport- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The design, construction, and thermal control of the pumped storage water reservoir at Columbia S.C., which will serve as a power source for 480 MW Fairfield hydroelectric plant and as a cooling pond for the nearby 900 MW V.C, Summer nuclear power plant are discussed. In order to meet EPA thermal pollution standards, heated effluents from the nuclear plant must not increase the upper reservoir ambient water temperature more than 3/sup 0/F to a limit of a 90/sup 0/F monthly average. (LCL)
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 198:17

TITLE: African HVDC system world's largest. [533 kV, 1440 km transmission line]
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HVDC SYSTEMS; DESIGN; ECONOMICS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER TRANSMISSION; AFRICA; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; CONTROL SYSTEMS; DAMS; PERFORMANCE; POWER TRANSMISSION LINES; THYRISTORS; UNDERGROUND; DC SYSTEMS; LEVELS; POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES; 200302* - Power Transmission & Distribution- DC Systems- (1989-); 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Africa now has an HVDC transmission system whose design is unique in some respects. It operates at the highest dc voltage ever utilized, stretches across a longer distance than any other dc line, and will ultimately deliver more power than any similar project yet anticipated. The HVDC line 1,440 km long, transmits the bulk of the output of the Cabora Bassa hydro complex now being developed on the Zambezi River in Mozambique. There, an underground powerplant has been constructed that will generate 2,000 MW when its final stage of development is completed in early 1979. This figure can later be doubled by construction of a sister powerplant at the same dam. In the near future, nearly all the Cabora Bassa output will be exported to the Republic of South Africa.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. World; (United States); Journal Volume: 187:8

TITLE: Polymerization of concrete fights cavitation
AUTHORS: Murray, M A; Asce, A M; Schultheis, V F
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; CONCRETES; REPAIR; DAMS; CAVITATION; MAINTENANCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; EROSION; POLYMERIZATION; BUILDING MATERIALS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; MATERIALS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 360604 - Materials- Corrosion, Erosion, & Degradation; 360401 - Polymers & Plastics- Preparation & Fabrication- (-1987)
DESCRIPTION: At Dworshak Dam on the north fork of the Clearwater River in Idaho, cavitation gutted the concrete of the spillway outlets and stilling basin. The owner, the Corps of Engineers, has pioneered a solution to this maintenance problem: replace the missing concrete, then when it's dry, soak a liquid plastic into the concrete's pores and harden it by applying heat. The polymerization procedure is described.
RELATION: Journal Name: Civ. Eng. (N.Y.); (United States); Journal Volume: 47:4

TITLE: Egyptians eye 50-mile, sea-level channel cut with A-bombs
SUBJECT: 45 MILITARY TECHNOLOGY, WEAPONRY, AND NATIONAL DEFENSE; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; INLAND WATERWAYS; NUCLEAR EXCAVATION; NUCLEAR EXPLOSIONS; USES; ECONOMICS; EGYPTIAN ARAB REPUBLIC; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PLANNING; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; SAFETY; SITE SELECTION; AFRICA; EXCAVATION; EXPLOSIONS; POWER PLANTS; 450200* - Military Technology, Weaponry, & National Defense- Nuclear Explosions & Explosives; 130000 - Hydro Energy
DESCRIPTION: The feasibility, economics, safety, and test ban aspects of using nuclear explosives to excavate a 50 mi-long channel between the Mediterranean Sea and the Qattra depression in Egypt is discussed. The Qattra depression, approximately 400 ft. below sea level, could then be used to develop a hydropower complex with a 1200 MW conventional hydroplant using channel flow and a 5800 MW pumped storage peak power plant. (LCL)
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 198:9

TITLE: West drought perils power for summer
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; AVAILABILITY; BEHAVIOR; BLACKOUTS; BONNEVILLE POWER ADMINISTRATION; CALIFORNIA; CHARGES; CLIMATES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY CONSERVATION; ENERGY SHORTAGES; FORECASTING; OREGON; POWER DEMAND; POWER GENERATION; WASHINGTON; WEATHER; ENERGY SOURCES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Mandatory electricity curtailment and higher power prices may be required on the West Coast as a result of the worst drought conditions since 1926. Some utilities have cut back operations in the hope that summer rains will allow them to avoid rationing. Northwest suppliers like Bonneville Power Administration (BPA) are preparing for next winter when power demand peaks in an area that is highly dependent on hydroelectric power. Curtailment plans, which must be determined by state governments, will put most of the burden on comfort and convenience use rather than industry in order to preserve jobs. BPA does not plan to export power outside its system. California, which normally buys power from BPA will have to use high-cost thermal power and pass on fuel adjustment charges to customers. Some observers feel the Nuclear Regulatory Commission is under pressure to approve earthquake standards for the Diablo Canyon plant, but the plant will not contribute power for several months after its approval. Strategies for meeting the immediate crisis include shutting off customers with interruptible power, voluntary reductions, and, as a last resort, rolling blackouts. Some California utilities expect to be able to meet demand unless the drought continues through the summer. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy User News; (United States); Journal Volume: 2:8

TITLE: Prolonged asymmetrical operation of hydrogenerators
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TURBOGENERATORS; STATORS; HEATING; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; PERFORMANCE TESTING; COOLING; OPERATION; PERFORMANCE; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; WATER; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POWER PLANTS; TESTING; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Full-scale studies of asymmetrical operation were made on two high utilization 500 MW hydrogenerators, i.e., G1 has a single-layer winding and compound insulation and G2 has a two-layer winding and thermoreactive insulation. In order to obtain the necessary information on the influence of an inversely synchronous field on each of these generators special sensors were installed: thermocouples on the cores and the damper cage jumpers between the poles and on the steel of the pole socket, and Rogovskii bands on all the damper cores. On the active steel, on the front parts of the winding and on the structural members of the unit vibration sensors were installed for measuring the vibration in the tangential, radial and vertical directions. In addition, the vibration of the active steel was measured by a vibration probe at eight points of each of the six joints of the active steel core in the tangential and radial directions. Data on heating and vibration were recorded in varying test and load conditions. The results showed that for both turbines the greatest pole heating was recorded on the surface of the pole shoe, and that, at I/sub 2//I/sub r/ = 0.08 to 0.09, the 100 Hz vibrations of the core and the front parts are within the limits of the vibration displacements on generators in prolonged operation. I/sub 2//I/sub r/, or ratio of negative sequence current to the rated current expresses the asymmetry of the generator load. The data obtained show the allowability of asymmetry of I/sub 2//I/sub r/ = 0.1 to 0.12 for generators with a single-layer winding and the allowability of I/sub 2//I/sub r/ = 0.08 to 0.09 for generators with a two-layer winding. Thus, the generators tested with direct water cooling of the stator windings allow prolonged asymmetrical load at I/sub 2//I/sub r/ greater than or equal to 8 percent. This makes it possible to transmit 350 to 400 MW through two phases of a large unit. This has been supported by full-scale tests.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 6:2; Other Information: Translated from Elektr. Stn.; 6: No. 2, 50-55(Feb 1977)

TITLE: Tensometric diagnosis of the state of hydrogenerator stator joints
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TURBOGENERATORS; STATORS; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; PERFORMANCE TESTING; CONFIGURATION; OPERATION; PERFORMANCE; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; POWER PLANTS; TESTING; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The main cause of high-frequency (100 Hz) vibration of hydrogenerator stator cores is degradation of the stator section joints in the process of operation. The operation of hydrogenerators at significant stator vibration levels leads to serious damage to individual structural parts. This necessitates monitoring of the condition of the joints. Gaps in the stator joints on an operating generator were measured with special tensometers in order to establish quantitative relationships between the gap size and the generator condition parameters which influence the gap size. It was determined that the size of the gap in hydrogenerator stator section joints is directly related to the temperature difference between the active steel and the stator housing shelves, and that there is a quantitative relationship between the size of the joint gap, the thermal state of the stator, and the voltage on the hydrogenerator leads which permits determination of the allowable gap in stator section joints.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sov. Power Eng. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 6:2; Other Information: Translated from Elektr. Stn.; 6: No. 2, 44-49(Feb 1977)

TITLE: Crawler cranes erect thin arch, saving canyon walls from harm
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; DESIGN; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COLORADO; COST; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; ROCKY MOUNTAIN REGION; USA; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The design and construction of the 323 ft high thin arch-type Crystal Dam on the Gunnison River in Colorado are described. This dam is one of 3 which regulate flow to the Curecanti hydroelectric power plant. The use of large crawler cranes on a trestle platform for pouring concrete prevented damage to the canyon walls and resulted in savings of both time and money during the construction. (LCL)
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 198:4

TITLE: Western water: coming crisis. [Survey of problem and proposals for solution]
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; WATER RESOURCES; AVAILABILITY; AGRICULTURE; BEHAVIOR; CLIMATES; COMPETITION; DEMAND FACTORS; DISTRIBUTION; ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; FRESH WATER; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; MANAGEMENT; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; USES; WATER POLLUTION; WATER QUALITY; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POLLUTION; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; WATER; 290300* - Energy Planning & Policy- Environment, Health, & Safety; 290400 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Resources; 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 530100 - Environmental-Social Aspects of Energy Technologies- Social & Economic Studies- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Western states faces a choice of either living with serious water constraints or augmenting the natural water supply. Competing demands on the dwindling supply of water result in a confrontation of man and nature in which human demands for water are exceeding renewability. Population growth in the Sunbelt, agricultural irrigation, energy development, industry, Indian water rights, and environmental protection laws are all vying for more water than reservoirs and wells can hold. Continued dry weather has added to the problem of sinking groundwater level and increased salinity of rivers and ground water. Development of the West reflected the settlers' perception of it as oases of settlement clustered around water supplies, both natural and artificial. Although irrigation systems had been developed by the Indians, the first serious efforts to conquer the desert followed the Reclamation Act of 1902 and the development of technology capable of rechanneling and harnessing water. Public policies governing water supply developed unevenly and were of unequal benefit. Water management programs alone can do no more than delay the need to develop new sources of water. Proposals for augmentation include costly inter-basin transfers from the Columbia, Mississippi, Alaskan and Canadian Rivers. Other possibilities include weather modification, desalination, conservation, more efficient use, and an end to Federal subsidies for irrigation so that agricultural efforts will shift to more suitable areas. 19 references. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Ed. Res. Rep. (Wash., D.C.); (United States); Journal Volume: 1:2

TITLE: Small hydro: where do we go from here
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; PLANNING; AVAILABILITY; COST; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; DAMS; DESIGN; ECONOMICS; ENGINEERING; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; EQUIPMENT; LAND USE; MANAGEMENT; MARKET; MODIFICATIONS; PERSONNEL; PUBLIC UTILITIES; SITE SELECTION; WATER RESERVOIRS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SURFACE WATERS; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 130601 - Hydro Energy- Land Use & Aesthetics- (-1991 )
DESCRIPTION: In spite of the high capital investment and long lead time required for conventional large-scale hydroelectric projects, new interest has developed in such nonfuel energy sources as small hydro plants of 5,000 kW or less. There is the possibility in New England alone of tapping 2,600 existing dams that lack generating facilities. Environmental damage from either small-scale power plants or reservoirs would be minimal. Comparisons of new hydroelectric costs with alternative fuels show hydro to be in a poor competitive position at 1976 prices, but rising fuel prices and uncertainties over supplies can reasonably be expected to give hydro the advantage. Possibilities for cost reductions are more favorable in power plant equipment than in the dam or reservoir construction. New concepts include unmanned stations, the application of available equipment design, fail-safe design, and standardized design. An assured Federally coordinated market is needed before industry will initiate this kind of approach. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Public Power; (United States); Journal Volume: 35:4

TITLE: Water power: potential and problems
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 16 TIDAL AND WAVE POWER; 14 SOLAR ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; AVAILABILITY; OCEAN THERMAL ENERGY CONVERSION; TIDAL POWER; DAMS; GLOBAL ASPECTS; LAND REQUIREMENTS; POWER GENERATION; WATER RESOURCES; CONVERSION; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY CONVERSION; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; SOLAR ENERGY CONVERSION; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 160000 - Tidal & Wave Power; 140100 - Solar Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: It is possible to double the amount of electricity produced by falling water in the next two decades if the US is willing to underwrite the costs and if the public is willing to inundate at least as much real estate as has already been converted to reservoirs. However, there is some doubt as to whether citizens will want to see further loss of large tracts of land. An alternative to the large hydro systems now in use is a revitalization of the thousands of small hydroelectric facilities built during the last century. There are an estimated 48,000 such dams that might be put back to work generating electricity. It is estimated that these dams, if power-generating turbines were placed on them, would produce seven times more energy than the Administration anticipates from solar heating in 1985 and almost the same amount of electricity produced by all nuclear plants in operation today. The tides could yield the energy equivalent of 560 billion kWh/year, i.e., 14% of 1969's world electricity consumption. A third major source for water power is harnessing the energy contained in the action of waves. Recent estimates have placed wave power potentials from 2700 to 89.3 million gigawatts; wave power in the year 2000 could be supplying 10% of the world's energy needs. (MCW)
RELATION: Journal Name: People and Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:4

TITLE: In lieu of dams
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY CONSERVATION; WATER RESOURCES; PLANNING; CHARGES; DAMS; FLOODS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; DISASTERS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; RESOURCES; 290300* - Energy Planning & Policy- Environment, Health, & Safety; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Nonstructural solutions to flood problems are: water pricing; water conservation and proper management; scenic rivers; energy conservation prior to building more hydropower dams; and priority to refurbishing railroads instead of constructing new barge canals. Options to dams, canals, and stream channelization for flood control, navigation, recreation, and water supply are discussed. Many alternatives could be undertaken by USACE without legislation. (9 photos, 1 table)
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Spectrum; (United States); Journal Volume: 9:4

TITLE: Nova Scotia seeks to cut oil bill for power generation. [Hydroelectric power]
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; NOVA SCOTIA; POWER GENERATION; AVAILABILITY; DESIGN; ECONOMICS; ENERGY DEMAND; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; UNDERGROUND; CANADA; LEVELS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: A new hydroelectric plant will relieve Nova Scotia of some of its dependence on high-priced oil. Although the project has been under study since the 1950s, it was not thought to be economically feasible until oil prices began to rise. The new plant at Wreck Cove will add 200 megawatts for a peak power reserve with very little environmental impact on surrounding tourist and fishing areas. The power plant will be underground and will discharge directly into the sea. Instead of a high dam, a series of four lakes is being enlarged and linked by tunnels and canals to feed into the power plant. Work has progressed smoothly at the four reservoirs, which are being enlarged by rock- or earth-fill dams. From the final surge lake, there is a 344.5-meter vertical drop to the powerhouse. Tunnel construction has encountered delays because of unstable sediments that required modifications in excavating technique. The power cavern is ready for the turbines and generators to be installed. Remote control will tie the plant into the Maritime grid system. Details on the construction status and specifications for sections of the system are included. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 14:1

TITLE: Economic load scheduling of cascaded river systems by lambda method
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; POWER SYSTEMS; LOAD MANAGEMENT; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; COOLING; FLOW RATE; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPTIMIZATION; POWER GENERATION; RIVERS; MANAGEMENT; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130000* - Hydro Energy; 200101 - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Cooling & Heat Transfer Equipment & Systems
DESCRIPTION: The method used most widely for daily economic load dispatching of a hydrothermal system is the so-called lambda method which is characterized by two principal parameters lambda and ..gamma... However, this method is not as effective for the cascaded river system. A method is proposed for determining the value of parameter lambda so as to satisfy the coordination equation for hydrothermal systems when reservoir-type hydroplants are operating or the coordination equation for a thermal system when the hydroplants are out of service. Features of the proposed method are as follows: the commitment (start-and-stop) of a hydroplant is taken into account; the initial value of lambda is determined and corrected by a new method; the direct lambda method is proposed for economic load scheduling of cascaded river systems; the relation between the two parameters lambda and ..gamma.. is clarified; the reason is made clear for poor convergence of iterative calculation for economic load scheduling of hydrothermal systems; and a new method is proposed for preventing reservoir overflow and for operating the regulating reservoir. The proposed program is useful not only for daily operation but also for development planning of a cascaded river system.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. Eng. Jpn. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 97:2; Other Information: Translated from Denki Gakkai Ronbunshi, B; 97: No 3, 119-126(Mar 1977)

TITLE: HYDRO-SOL: a forward looking energy model for currently hydro sufficient provinces and states. [Integrated hydro- and solar power system]
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 14 SOLAR ENERGY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; SOLAR POWER PLANTS; CAPACITY; ECONOMICS; ELECTRICITY; ENERGY DEPENDENCE; ENERGY MODELS; ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS; ENERGY SUPPLIES; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; LOAD MANAGEMENT; POWER GENERATION; SOLAR ENERGY CONVERSION; CONVERSION; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY CONVERSION; ENERGY SOURCES; MANAGEMENT; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 140700 - Solar Thermal Power Systems; 130000 - Hydro Energy
DESCRIPTION: HYDRO-SOL, an integrated hydroelectric and solar power system, offers a model for using water power and solar conversion to augment local energy self-sufficiency while more research is conducted to make nuclear energy safer. The model takes advantage of the current capability for efficiently converting solar energy to electrical energy and allowing hydro power to be stored. Examples are drawn of how systems can benefit by using solar power to supply electricity to the power grid during periods of high demand, while the continued storage of water in reservoirs and lakes adds no cost to the system. States and provinces that already have energy self-sufficiency can benefit most from this kind of power-augmentation system. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Environ. Sci. Health, Part A; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:8
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Environ. Sci. Health, Part A; (United States)

TITLE: Dambuilder fights rugged site that's a dream for designers
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CALIFORNIA; CONCRETES; EXCAVATION; GEOLOGIC DEPOSITS; BUILDING MATERIALS; MATERIALS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: Details in the construction of a 625 ft-high earthfill dam in the Stanislaus River canyon are described. (LCL)
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 197:24

TITLE: Corps to build giant hydro scheme with Alaskan cash. [Two dams will generate 6,100 MW on upper Susitna River]
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ALASKA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; FINANCING; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; POWER PLANTS; USA; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: A complex financing scheme engineered in the closing hours of the 94th Congress and a behind-the-scenes arrangement last week have opened the doors for a $1.5-billion hydroelectric project. The scheme would be financed by state revenue bonds and operated by the Alaskan Power Authority, but built by the Corps of Engineers. The project, planned as a two-dam hydroelectric scheme on the upper Susitna River, north of Anchorage, would produce a maximum of 6,100 MW. Commonly called the Devil Canyon project, it would consist of an 810-ft-high earthfill dam at Watana and a 610-ft-high thin arch concrete dam downstream at Devil Canyon. As currently planned, Watana would be built first, and Devil Canyon would follow four years later. Power production could begin as early as 1986.
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 197:23

TITLE: Cableways, fancy formwork speed concreting on tall arch

SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 03 NATURAL GAS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ENERGY CONSERVATION; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; ENERGY POLICY AND CONSERVATION ACT; IMPLEMENTATION; ENERGY POLICY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; LICENSING; NATURAL GAS; PLANNING; RECOMMENDATIONS; REGULATIONS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; FLUIDS; FOSSIL FUELS; FUEL GAS; FUELS; GAS FUELS; GASES; LAWS; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 293000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Policy, Legislation, & Regulation; 031000 - Natural Gas- Legislation & Regulations; 130400 - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations
