TITLE: Effects of dams on Pacific salmon and steelhead trout
SUBJECT: 63 RADIATION, THERMAL, AND OTHER ENVIRON. POLLUTANT EFFECTS ON LIVING ORGS. AND BIOL. MAT.; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; BEHAVIOR; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; JUVENILES; MIGRATION; MORTALITY; SALMON; TEMPERATURE EFFECTS; TROUT; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; FISHES; POWER PLANTS; VERTEBRATES; 560205* - Thermal Effects- Vertebrates- (-1987); 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The construction of dams has had more impact on the survival of salmon than any of the other activities of man. Because of the necessity for providing safe passage over the physical obstructions of dams, fishways were provided to permit adult fish to swim over the dams to continue their upstream migration. The large scale of fishway construction required more information on fish behavior and abilities, therefore a special laboratory for fishery-engineering research was constructed in which the reactions of anadromous fish were measured. Experiments provided data on the spatial requirements of salmon on fishways, on rates of movement of ascending fish, and on the effect of fishway slope and length on fish performance. Mortality rates for juvenile fish have been estimated at 15 percent loss per dam, thus studies were undertaken to develop practical methods of protecting young migrants at dams. Dams created other environmental stresses such as delays in migration, temperature changes, and ''nitrogen supersaturation.'' To avoid the cumulative hazards of a long series of dams, a system is being developed to collect and transport young migrants to the estuary. (CAJ)
RELATION: Journal Name: Mar. Fish. Rev.; (United States); Journal Volume: 38:11

TITLE: Ban Chao Nen scheme gives economic boost to NW Thailand
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; THAILAND; GEOLOGY; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; ASIA; POWER PLANTS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: A major hydroelectric scheme in northwest Thailand is the first of several that could be developed on the Quae Yai River. Not only will it relieve demand for fossil fuel which would otherwise have to be imported, but it will also provide irrigation and social benefits through a well ordered resettlement scheme for families displaced by the creation of a reservoir.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 13:11

TITLE: Northwest industry faces loss of hydro
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; BONNEVILLE POWER ADMINISTRATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SHORTAGES; REGIONAL ANALYSIS; ECONOMICS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; FORECASTING; FOSSIL-FUEL POWER PLANTS; INDUSTRY; LEGISLATION; NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS; PLANNING; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NUCLEAR FACILITIES; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 296000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Industries dependent on the 30 hydroelectric projects of the Bonneville Power Administration (BPA) have been warned that power supplies may run short in the 1980s. A population increase in the area is redirecting power to residential and commercial uses and creating a demand for more jobs. Even BPA's preference customers, 120 utilities and federal agencies, have been warned that future growth needs can not be guaranteed. The aluminum industry, which was attracted to the area by cheap power, will be hit especially hard. The industry has initiated a request that Congress allow BPA to buy thermal power from both private and public sources to supplement hydroelectric power. A joint public and private effort is developing to begin regional planning for power mixing, which would also aid some of the fast growing utilities supplying power for irrigation. Major advantages would be lower costs for older utilities and reduced capital requirements for new facilities. After political approval is won, the BPA must still resolve the environmental barriers to introducing fossil-fuel or nuclear thermal plants to the region. With nuclear initiatives in Washington and Oregon, conservation and tax incentives will also have to be explored. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy User News; (United States); Journal Volume: 1:5

TITLE: Experimental investigation of hydrodynamic damping during bending oscillations of blade profiles in water flow
AUTHORS: Kaminer, A A; Kavitskii, B M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; TURBINE BLADES; HYDRODYNAMICS; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; DAMPING; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; GRAPHS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; OSCILLATIONS; TESTING; DATA; DATA FORMS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; FLUID MECHANICS; INFORMATION; MACHINERY; MECHANICS; NUMERICAL DATA; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The vibration reliability of hydroturbine blades operating in water flow conditions largely determines their ability to dissipate energy during oscillations. Important factors are hydrodynamic damping, which can exceed the structural damping by several orders of magnitude and the energy dissipation in the blade material. Experimental investigations with wide and independent variations in the dimensionless parameters governing the oscillatory processes were conducted to determine the damping in bending oscillations of blade profiles in water flow. The flow angle of attack and geometrical parameters of the lattice remained unchanged. The experiment was performed on the GD-1 facility at the Academy of Sciences of the Ukrainian SSR. The experimental procedure is described. Results show that the hydrodynamic damping of profile oscillations does depend on the profile solidity. Analysis of the data shows that the variation in hydrodynamic damping due to variation in profile solidity does not depend on the Strouhal number, but is determined only by variation in the relative profile thickness: one reason for reduction in the hydrodynamic damping with increase in profile solidity is that a more solid profile is less sensitive to variation of angle of attack.
RESEARCH_ORG: Inst. of Strength of Materials, Kiev, Ukrainian SSR
RELATION: Journal Name: Strength Mater. (USSR) (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 8:1; Other Information: Translated from Probl. Prochnosti; 8: No. 1, 27-29(Jan 1976)

TITLE: World's largest hydro sets exceed their design performance
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PERFORMANCE; CONSTRUCTION; DAMS; DESIGN; EQUIPMENT; OPERATION; SPECIFICATIONS; TURBINES; POWER PLANTS; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 200104 - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Components
DESCRIPTION: This winter, the first three units at the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation's Grand Coulee Third Powerhouse will be in service--over 1800 MW of peaking energy from the world's most powerful water turbines yet. The first unit has been in service now for one year. In that time its performance has fully justified the design and the extraordinary methods of construction that were forced on the contractors by the sheer size of the units and the remoteness of the site in eastern Washington state. The first unit took only 10 days to reach full rated output and later achieved 820 MW (1.1 million hp.) gross output on a higher operating head. In this article a look is taken at the way in which these machines were designed and erected.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 13:9

TITLE: Nelson River offers long-term hydro base for Manitoba
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; CANADA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; PLANNING; CONSTRUCTION; ENERGY SUPPLIES; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; FORECASTING; MANITOBA; REGULATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 296001 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Manitoba possesses abundant hydro power potential which, when fully developed, will provide the province with sufficient energy into the 1990's. The Nelson River will be the focus of this development; its steady volume of flow coupled with a gradient of approximately 214 meters over a distance of 660 kilometers and its relative accessibility to the populated South make it one of the most desirable remaining sources of hydroelectric power in North America. However, there are serious environmental obstacles to overcome where the river is being developed. The potential generation of 14 stations planned for the Nelson River, two of which--Kelsey and Kettle--are now complete, is 8270 MW, but to achieve this level of output requires diversion of the Churchill River and regulation of Lake Winnipeg.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 13:9

TITLE: La Grande hydroelectric complex
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PLANNING; CONSTRUCTION; DAMS; EHV AC SYSTEMS; POWER TRANSMISSION LINES; WATER RESERVOIRS; AC SYSTEMS; POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 200301 - Power Transmission & Distribution- AC Systems, EHV & UHV- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The James Bay Hydroelectric Project, presently under construction in northern Quebec, is one of the world's largest energy developments. Four major powerhouses are planned that will produce 10,000 MW. There are six reservoirs with 147 earth and rockfill dams containing 203.5 million cu yd of material and extending 60 mi in total length. Water from two other rivers will be diverted into this network on the La Grande River to augment the already enormous potential of this watershed. The electricity will be carried by 735-kV transmission lines. Construction is scheduled over a 12-year period.
RELATION: Journal Name: Civ. Eng. (N.Y.); (United States); Journal Volume: 46:9

TITLE: Idikki gives economic boost to South India
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INDIA; CONCRETES; DESIGN; ECONOMICS; ASIA; BUILDING MATERIALS; MATERIALS; POWER PLANTS; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: The Idikki project, now half completed is a complex of three gigantic dams, impounding a single reservoir, a head tunnel almost 2 km long, and an underground power house. The project is 120 km inland from the old sea port of Cochin and is located in South Western Ghats in Kerala State in South India. The project comprises three dams which combine to impound a reservoir of 2.28 billion m/sup 3/ capacity. The dam across the Periyar River at the Idikki gorge is a thin-walled double curvature parabolic arch 167 m high with a crest length of 360 m, a thickness of 7.5 m at top and 24 m at the base, covering a total volume of 466,000 m/sup 3/ of concrete. It is the first arch dam of its type in India and is the country's secondest highest dam. The second dam is built on the Cheruthoni River and is a conventional gravity structure 136 m high. The third dam at Kulamavu is located at the headwaters of the reservoir. Work has begun on the erection of 220-kV single-circuit inter-state transmission lines from Idikki to Mysora, a distance of 366 km, to be completed in June 1977. (MCW)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 13:8

TITLE: Could hydraulic rams increase our hydro power potential
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 16 TIDAL AND WAVE POWER; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PLANNING; PUMPS; TIDAL POWER PLANTS; WAVE POWER; POWER GENERATION; CANADA; CONTROL; DAMS; DESIGN; ECONOMICS; EFFICIENCY; HYDRAULICS; LEVELS; OPTIMIZATION; PUMPED STORAGE; STORAGE; ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY STORAGE; FLUID MECHANICS; MECHANICS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 299003 - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation- Other- (-1989); 160700 - Tidal Power Plants; 160800 - Tidal & Wave Power- Wave Energy Converters; 130000 - Hydro Energy
DESCRIPTION: Much energy is going to waste on many rivers throughout the world due to the fact that development of the power would not be economical or practicable because of the non-availability of an adequate head for conventional turbine-generators. However, the head might be quite adequate for a hydraulic ram installation if in fact a suitable ram mechanism can be developed. The output from the rams might be arranged to flow directly to a surge tank which in turn would supply conventional generating sets, or a storage feature might be introduced, depending on circumstances. In most cases run-of-river sites would be developed through the use of the tunnel system, in which a tunnel would by-pass a rapids or fast water section of river. As a component of a tidal power system, the ability of the hydraulic ram to operate efficiently under very low heads makes it appear very attractive as a means of providing a supply of water to prolong the periods during which the turbines would have an adequate head for their operation. Wave energy, too could be exploited with the aid of a ram. For instance, by means of an array of check gates, high and low-level pools might be established within a suitable enclosure or caisson, with hydraulic rams arranged to be operated by the available flow from the high to the low pool, the rams delivering water to a surge tank from which, in turn, conventional turbine-generators would operate. (MCW)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 13:7

TITLE: Water utility hydroelectric power development. [Simultaneous water pipeline pressure control and hydroelectric power generation using pipeline flow thru 1 to 23 MW turbogenerators]
AUTHORS: Lauten, J H; Balcerzak, R W
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; WATER RESOURCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ECONOMICS; LEGAL ASPECTS; PRESSURE CONTROL; ENERGY CONSERVATION; FLUID FLOW; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; PIPELINES; POWER GENERATION; TRANSPORT; TURBOGENERATORS; WATER RESERVOIRS; CONTROL; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SURFACE WATERS; USA; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The Colorado River and California aqueducts require large amounts of power to lift the water over intervening mountains. Replacing pressure reducing valves with power generation facilities, at current oil prices, is economically attractive, but regulatory problems need to be solved, and package generation facilities need to be designed.
RESEARCH_ORG: Metropolitan Water District of Southern California, Los Angeles
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Am. Water Works Assoc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 68
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Am. Water Works Assoc.; (United States)

TITLE: Tight coordination of hydro projects offers real savings
AUTHORS: Johnson, Jr, R C; Mayo, H Jr
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; PLANNING; COMMUNICATIONS; COST; DESIGN; ECONOMICS; EQUIPMENT; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; LICENSING; POWER GENERATION; POWER SUPPLIES; PRODUCTION; RELIABILITY; SIZE; ELECTRONIC EQUIPMENT; POWER PLANTS; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The pattern in hydroelectric projects has evolved from annual purchase and installation of small units of 50 to 400 hp to installation of six major projects in sizes up to 1-million hp. The latter require hundreds of drawings, sophisticated design work, laboratory testing, lead times of casting or forging, and governmental approval, all adding up to a very time-consuming process. The changing nature of these projects require tight coordination for economical construction. It requires close coordination of the purchaser, general contractor, and manufacturer of major equipment. This in-depth coordination demands close contact and good communications. After a discussion of the many factors involved in scheduling and costing and benefits from coordination, the construction scheduling of Grand Coulee is described as a good example. (MCW)
RELATION: Journal Name: Power (N.Y.); (United States); Journal Volume: 120:6

TITLE: Yugoslav pumped storage plant poses design challenge to Japanese supplier
SUBJECT: 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; YUGOSLAVIA; CONSTRUCTION; DEFORMATION; EFFICIENCY; STRESS ANALYSIS; TURBOGENERATORS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; EUROPE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 250300* - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989); 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: When it comes into service in 1978, Yugoslavia will boast the world's highest head pumped storage scheme. The 630-MW Bajina Basta plant will have two 315-MW Francis-type reversible pump-turbines operating under a head range in excess of 600 m--a good 50 m higher than at any plant now operating. As is generally acknowledged, the runner of a high-head pump-turbine is relatively flat because of low specific speed, and there is much friction loss; consequently, it is difficult to produce a high-efficiency, pump-turbine. However, improving the runner blade shape, modifying the runner sealing from a conventional single seal to a multiple seal, and making other changes resulting from introduction of an automated design method for the runner have enabled Toshiba to produce a high-efficiency design. Improved cavitation characteristics have eliminated secondary flow at the runner inlet and unstable areas have been removed. Research on construction and intensity equal to the high head or the high pressure is required. In order to accomplish this, a computer-based finite element method has been developed and is now in regular use. Using this method, it is easy to illustrate the stress and deformation analysis made on the casing, stay ring, scroll case, and the head cover. (MCW)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 13:5

TITLE: Juctan avoids pumping energy loss with third reservoir
SUBJECT: 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; PLANNING; SWEDEN; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; DAMS; DESIGN; ECONOMICS; EFFICIENCY; ENERGY LOSSES; OFF-PEAK ENERGY STORAGE; POWER GENERATION; WATER RESERVOIRS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY STORAGE; EUROPE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SCANDINAVIA; STORAGE; SURFACE WATERS; 250300* - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989); 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: The majority of the large rivers in northern Sweden have now been exploited. On their tributaries there are, however, heads which have not been developed and lakes which are employed only for the annual regulation of the main river. The head of 145 m between Storjuktan and the confluence of the Juktan with the Ume River has not been exploited at all, while the 85 m head above this point as far as Storuman has been completely harnessed by plants. The mean water flow in the Juktan is 30 m/sup 3//s which, by storage in Storjuktan, is concentrated in the winter months. By diversion through a tunnel to Storuman, about 85 m of the unexploited head in the Juktan could be utilized in the three existing power plants. The head of 60 m between Storjuktan and Storuman could at the same time be exploited in a power station. The study proved that such a diversion could be advantageously combined with a pumped-storage plant. The Juktan plant will not add to the total production of energy but will require no energy. The head for generation is, in fact, so much higher than the pumping head that this compensates for the energy losses normally inherent in a pure pumped storage plant. The Juktan project thus means that approximately one third of the River Juktan's previously unexploited energy resources, before its confluence with the Ume River, will provide a valuable peak power of 335 MW. The remaining two-thirds will add 160 GWh to the annual energy production. (MCW)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 13:4

TITLE: Diversion of water through Northfield Mt. Pumped Storage Project
SUBJECT: 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; WATER RESERVOIRS; DESIGN; MANAGEMENT; MASSACHUSETTS; WATER RESOURCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NORTH ATLANTIC REGION; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; 250300* - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989); 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Provisions were made at the Northfield Mountain Pumped Storage Project for the diversion of 26 billion gal or 79,800 acre-ft (98,800,000 m/sup 2/) of water per year from the Connecticut River to the Quabbin Reservoir. The outlet works including gates, fish screens, stop logs, metering devices, and transmitting and recording devices were provided by Northeast Utilities. During periods of flood flow in the Connecticut River, excess flow will be pumped into reserve space in the upper reservoir by use of the main pump-turbine units and this will then be permitted to run through the diversion works which include the outlet works and the proposed aqueduct to the Quabbin Reservoir. Northeast Utilities is cooperating with the Commonwealth of Massachusetts in the proposed development of this source of water supply. This diversion project utilizing a pumped storage hydroelectric power project to augment a municipal water supply is unique and important.
RESEARCH_ORG: Stone and Webster Engrg. Corp., Boston
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Water Resour. Plann. Manage. Div., Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 102:WR1
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Water Resour. Plann. Manage. Div., Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States)

TITLE: Operations models for Central Valley Project
AUTHORS: Becker, L; Yeh, W W.G.; Fults, D; Sparks, D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; WATER RESERVOIRS; WATER RESOURCES; MANAGEMENT; AUTOMATION; CALIFORNIA; COMPUTERS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPTIMIZATION; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: System optimizing procedures are being developed for on-line use in the operation of the Central Valley Project (CVP), a complex multiple objective water resource system, in California. The project is subject to requirements and interagency agreements. A practical optimization method must address not only these requirements but also the continuing needs of day-to-day operation, and the necessity for interposing the project managers in monitoring and final decision roles. The basic technical difficulty with an optimizing algorithm for a complex water resource system is the dimensionality which can easily run into the tens of thousands of decision variables and constraints. The method being developed for the project provides the necessary decomposition and involves the project managers, assisted by an integrated group of multiple policies based on interconnected monthly, daily, and hourly models, using iterated linear programming-dynamic programming techniques.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Water Resour. Plann. Manage. Div., Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 102:WR1
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Water Resour. Plann. Manage. Div., Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States)

TITLE: Practical monthly optimum operations model
AUTHORS: Fults, D M; Hancock, L F; Logan, G R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; WATER RESERVOIRS; OPERATION; WATER RESOURCES; MANAGEMENT; COMPUTER CODES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SYSTEMS ANALYSIS; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: A mathematical model is developed for the Central Valley Project. The model produces a 12-month operating policy. The model is programmed in FORTRAN IV for processing on a CDC CYBER 74 computer. Project operations managers use the model as a decision-advising tool. This model will be coupled with a daily strategy mode. A four-dimensional incremental dynamic programming algorithm is developed to optimize the operation of the four-reservoir system. The objective of the model is to maximize energy generation within the limits of firm water and power contracts, mandatory releases, and flood control. A unique technique given the acronym RecIP for recomputed initial policy is developed to compute the initial operating policy that is optimized. The RecIP technique is an iterative process using the results of the incremental dynamic programming algorithm to compute a new initial policy to satisfy the required end of operational period target storages desired by the user.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Water Resour. Plann. Manage. Div., Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 102:WR1
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Water Resour. Plann. Manage. Div., Am. Soc. Civ. Eng.; (United States)

TITLE: China opts for small-scale energy techniques. [Micro hydro plants, small coal mines, methane from organic wastes]
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 09 BIOMASS FUELS; CHINA; ENERGY SUPPLIES; COAL MINING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; METHANE; BIOMASS; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; ECONOMICS; ENGINEERING; FUEL GAS; GASIFICATION; INDUSTRY; MANAGEMENT; PRODUCTION; ALKANES; ASIA; CRYOGENIC FLUIDS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; FLUIDS; FUELS; GAS FUELS; GASES; HYDROCARBONS; MINING; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 292000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Supply, Demand & Forecasting; 012000 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- Mining; 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 090122 - Hydrocarbon Fuels- Preparation from Wastes or Biomass- (1976-1989)
DESCRIPTION: China, the largest of the developing countries, has adopted the intermediate technology approach to provide its basic energy supply. The dictum of the Chinese economy since the later 1950s has been not only developing large modern enterprises but also small projects in the rural areas. The advantages of the intermediate approach lie in an extensive use of plentiful and cheap labor instead of expensive machinery, maximum usage of local resources and materials instead of costly imports, considerable capital savings, and easier and wider penetration of essential technologies throughout the rural areas. Small-scale developments in energy industries have been predominantly concentrated in three areas: coal mining, hydroelectricity production, and biogas generation. The advantages and shortcomings of each industry are described. The first attempts at large-scale introduction of biogas generation have been undertaken in India since the early 1960s where the total number of Gobar gas plants is to reach about 25,000 by the end of the current Five-Year Plan in 1977-78, but Chinese developments are more extensive. In the southern provinces of Szechwan alone, 30,000 units were completed by the end of 1973, with 410,000 containers completed by mid-1975. (MCW)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 13:2

TITLE: Hydraulic drill speeds construction at Swiss pumped storage site
SUBJECT: 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; ROCK DRILLING; EQUIPMENT; SWITZERLAND; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; HYDRAULICS; OPERATION; DRILLING; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; EUROPE; FLUID MECHANICS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MECHANICS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 250300* - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989); 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Three tunneling projects in the southeast of Switzerland provide a practical demonstration of the claims made for a new hydraulic rock drilling equipment launched on the international market by Atlas Copco at the end of 1973. Faster penetration rates--up to 50 percent better than can be obtained in similar rock conditions with conventional pneumatic drills--less noise, and a cleaner working environment for the drill crews are the benefits for these early customers in the mountains. The pumped storage project at Grimsel, over 2300 m above sea level, adds pumped storage capacity between two catchment reservoirs supplying an earlier, seasonal pumped storage plant, Grimsel 1. Grimsel 2 is being built in two stages, each of 300 MW capacity in separate underground power plants--2 East and 2 West. The first to be built is Grimsel 2 East, which will have four Escher Wyss, horizontal Francis turbines with separate, single-stage storage pumps. Individual ratings are 75 MW for each turbine with a head range of 370 to 400 m and a flow rate of 90 m/sup 3//s. Each pump is rated 82.5 MW with a head range from 400 to 420 m and a flow of 78 m/sup 3//s.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 13:2

TITLE: Effect of hydraulic works on the parasite fauna of the Dnieper River
AUTHORS: Markevich, A P; Iskov, M P; Koval, V P; Chernogorenko, M I
SUBJECT: 63 RADIATION, THERMAL, AND OTHER ENVIRON. POLLUTANT EFFECTS ON LIVING ORGS. AND BIOL. MAT.; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 59 BASIC BIOLOGICAL SCIENCES; AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS; PARASITES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; WATER RESERVOIRS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; ABUNDANCE; DAMS; DISTRIBUTION; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; HOST; HYDROLOGY; RIVERS; USSR; WATER CHEMISTRY; WATER CURRENTS; WATER POLLUTION; CURRENTS; ECOSYSTEMS; EUROPE; POLLUTION; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 560204* - Thermal Effects- Invertebrates- (-1987); 520100 - Environment, Aquatic- Basic Studies- (-1989); 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 550000 - Biomedical Sciences, Basic Studies
DESCRIPTION: The reservoirs of the Dnieper River were investigated for parasite fauna and compared to the waters they replaced. The reservoirs formed new biological communities characteristic of lakes and streams with a slow current. The distribution of the parasites depended on a suitable host plus a number of environmental factors. The most important of these were currrent, temperature, water level, morphometry, development of aquatic vegetation, species diversity, abundance, biomass, distribution of zooplankton and zoobenthos, species composition of fishes, amphibians, wading birds, waterfowl, and mammals and extent of pollution by organic and inorganic matter. The considerable fluctuations of water level markedly affect the abundance of parasites. Changes in hydrology and hydrochemistry from river to reservoir conditions had an enormous effect on fauna including parasites. Abundance and species diversity varied between the individual reservoirs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrobiol. J. (U.S.S.R.) (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 2

TITLE: Observations on gas bubble disease among wild adult Columbia River fishes
AUTHORS: Bouck, G R; Chapman, G A; Schneider, Jr, P W; Stevens, D G
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; COLUMBIA RIVER; SUPERSATURATION; FISHES; GAS BUBBLE DISEASE; ADULTS; AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; EYES; NITROGEN; OXYGEN; POWER PLANTS; SALMON; WATER POLLUTION; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; BODY; CRYOGENIC FLUIDS; DISEASES; ECOSYSTEMS; ELEMENTS; FLUIDS; NONMETALS; ORGANS; POLLUTION; RIVERS; SATURATION; SENSE ORGANS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; VERTEBRATES; 520100* - Environment, Aquatic- Basic Studies- (-1989); 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects

TITLE: Smith Mountain--Leesville project: a case history
SUBJECT: 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; FISHES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LIMNOLOGY; PRODUCTIVITY; TURBINES; VIRGINIA; WATER RESERVOIRS; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; CENTRAL REGION; ECOSYSTEMS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; TURBOMACHINERY; USA; VERTEBRATES; 250300* - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989); 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The Smith Mountain Pump Storage Project consists of two reservoirs in tandem on the Roanoke and Blackwater Rivers approximately 64 km southeast of Roanoke, Virginia. The reservoirs have provided sites for evaluating the impact of pump storage operation on primary productivity, fisheries, and water quality. Due to the location of the dam and the dendritic nature of the basin, the effect of recycling to alleviate detrimental water quality effects caused by thermal stratification were minimal. Moreover, as might be expected, the quality of water found in the upper reservoir depends upon the quality of water being recycled from the lower impoundment. Recycling appears to enhance primary productivity rates, at least in the vicinity of the dam. Pump storage operation does not appear to detract from the fishery in either reservoir. Although comprehensive studies are still needed in many areas, the results of all studies to date indicate a net beneficial effect of pump storage operation on environmental quality. (auth)
RESEARCH_ORG: Virginia Polytechnic and State Univ., Blacksburg
RELATION: Journal Name: Trans. Am. Fish. Soc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 105:1

TITLE: Pumped storage: its significance as an energy source and some biological ramifications
AUTHORS: Hauck, F R; Edson, Q A
SUBJECT: 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; FISHES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LAKE MICHIGAN; PLANNING; RIVERS; TURBINES; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; ECOSYSTEMS; GREAT LAKES; LAKES; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; TURBOMACHINERY; VERTEBRATES; 250300* - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989); 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Pumped storage hydroelectric projects provide an economic way of meeting peak energy needs in electric power systems. Types and locations of pumped storage projects and their basic engineering and operations are described together with the biological impacts common as well as unique to this form of power generation. The rapid increase in the number of pumped storage projects during the last 16 years and projected future construction indicate a serious need for expanded studies to provide for better design features and reduced environmental damage. Biological studies underway and those needed are described and discussed. (auth)
RELATION: Journal Name: Trans. Am. Fish. Soc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 105:1

TITLE: Muddy run pumped storage project: a case history
SUBJECT: 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; ADULTS; AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; EGGS; FISHES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LARVAE; LIMNOLOGY; PENNSYLVANIA; PONDS; RIVERS; TURBINES; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; CENTRAL REGION; ECOSYSTEMS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; TURBOMACHINERY; USA; VERTEBRATES; 250300* - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989); 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The ecology of Conowingo Pond (the lower pond) and the Muddy Run Pumped Storage Pond (the upper pond) on the lower Susquehanna River in southeastern Pennsylvania was studied to determine the effects of operation of the Muddy Run Pumped Storage Station. Nearly all the species of fish present in the lower pond are now found in the upper pond. Extensive sampling in the two ponds indicates no detrimental effects of the station operation on the fishes and fisheries of Conowingo Pond. The creation of the 398.9-hectare upper impoundment serves as an area where biomass of fishes pumped up from Conowingo Pond can be increased and exploited by anglers. Wide fluctuations (up to 15 m in a weekly cycle of operation) in water level limit the reproduction of nest-building fishes in the upper pond. About 6.5 times as many fish larvae were pumped up into the upper pond as left during generation. No reliable quantitative estimates could be obtained on the percentage mortality of fishes passing through the pump-turbines. The mortality of fishes associated with the operation of the pumped storage station appears to be negligible. It is concluded that screens are not needed for the protection of fish at the Muddy Run Station. Even if a satisfactory type of screen could be installed substantial mortality due to ''gilling'' of fishes would occur. Sampling problems unique to the pumped storage project are discussed. (auth)
RELATION: Journal Name: Trans. Am. Fish. Soc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 105:1

TITLE: Energy storage
AUTHORS: Kalhammer, F R; Schneider, T R
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 08 HYDROGEN; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ENERGY CONSERVATION; ENERGY STORAGE; ECONOMICS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; REVIEWS; USES; COMPRESSED AIR; COST; EFFICIENCY; ELECTRIC BATTERIES; FLYWHEELS; FOSSIL FUELS; HEAT STORAGE; HYDROGEN STORAGE; PUMPED STORAGE; STORAGE; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS; AIR; DOCUMENT TYPES; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; ELECTROCHEMICAL CELLS; ELECTROMAGNETS; ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS; EQUIPMENT; FLUIDS; FUELS; GASES; MAGNETS; SUPERCONDUCTING DEVICES; 290700* - Energy Planning & Policy- Transport & Storage; 250000 - Energy Storage; 080200 - Hydrogen- Storage, Transport & Handling; 130000 - Hydro Energy; 250902 - Energy Storage- Batteries- Performance & Testing; 250300 - Energy Storage- Pumped Hydro- (-1989); 250500 - Energy Storage- Flywheels; 250600 - Energy Storage- Thermal; 250100 - Energy Storage- Magnetic
DESCRIPTION: The energy-conservation aspects and environmental benefits of large-scale energy-storage systems are reviewed and discussed. Uses of energy storage in power generation, transportation, and in commercial, residential, and industrial buildings are described. Methods and technology for storing mechanical, thermal, chemical, and electromagnetic energy are enumerated. These include pumped hydro, compressed air, flywheels, heat storage, batteries, hydrogen energy storage systems, and superconducting magnetic energy storage. The efficiency and cost of each system are tabulated. It is concluded that improved energy storage systems will play an important role in future energy systems. 137 references. (LCL)
RELATION: Journal Name: Annu. Rev. Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 1

TITLE: Metabolism of the Russian sturgeon (Acipenser guldenstadti) from around the Volgograd Power Station Dam
SUBJECT: 59 BASIC BIOLOGICAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FISHES; METABOLISM; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; DAMS; GLYCOGEN; GONADS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LIVER; MUSCLES; OOCYTES; PROTEINS; REPRODUCTION; RIVERS; SPERMATOZOA; SURFACE WATERS; USSR; VOLGA RIVER; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; BODY; CARBOHYDRATES; DIGESTIVE SYSTEM; EUROPE; GAMETES; GERM CELLS; GLANDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANS; POLYSACCHARIDES; POWER PLANTS; SACCHARIDES; STREAMS; VERTEBRATES; 550500* - Metabolism; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: An account is given of the dynamics of the content of protein, nonprotein nitrogen, lipid, glycogen, phosphorus (total, inorganic and ATP) and dry matter in the muscles, liver and gonads of Russian sturgeon (Acipenser guldenstadti) spawners during the lengthy period (8 to 9 months) spent around the Volgograd power station dam. This whole period is typified by intensive metabolism, as a result of which the content of body-building and energy-providing substances is reduced in the muscles and liver and increased in the maturing oocytes and spermatozoa. Males and females differ appreciably both in the level of the content of the substances investigated in the muscles, liver and gonads, and in the dynamics of accumulation and expenditure.
RESEARCH_ORG: State Research Inst. for Lake and River Fisheries, Volgograd
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Ichthyol. (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 15:3

TITLE: Hydroelectric power: a non-renewable resource
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; RIVERS; SEDIMENTS; WATER RESOURCES; ECOSYSTEMS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The only group of influential engineers with a vested interest in renewable energy resources is that of dam-builders. A number of marginal hydroelectric projects have been resuscitated since the energy crisis. To an engineer with the beaver syndrome, an undammed river must represent a wasted resource. Downstream consequences of dams, including loss of sediment, adverse effects on aquatic organisms, and salt intrusion in extreme cases, are explained.
RELATION: Journal Name: Technol. Rev.; (United States); Journal Volume: 76:7

TITLE: USSR stations will harness two mountain born rivers
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 03 NATURAL GAS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PLANNING; USSR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; EHV AC SYSTEMS; AC SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; EUROPE; POWER; POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 030300 - Natural Gas- Drilling, Production, & Processing
DESCRIPTION: The Republic of Tadzhikistan plans 13 hydro stations, several of which are now under construction, along the Vakhsh and Pyandzh to meet the demands of agriculture amd new industry. Plans include a 750-kV line. The U.S.S.R. has plans for exploiting the hydroelectric potential of streams originating in the Pamir Mountains and flowing through the Republic of Tadzhikistan. The Vakhsh, one of Tadzhikistan's principal rivers, begins at an elevation of 11,800 ft. above sea level. It has a potential of 23.2 MW per mile, being unequalled even by the rivers of eastern Siberia. Plans for the Vakhsh call for construction of five hydro stations with a total generating capacity of 7,800 MW. Even larger will be eight hydro stations on the Pyandzh, which forms the boundary between Tadzhikistan and Afghanistan. Their total power is expected to be 16,000 MW, for which 500 kV, later 750-kV, lines will be required.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. World; (United States); Journal Volume: 167

TITLE: EHV transmission in the USSR power grid
AUTHORS: Lebedev, B P; Rokotyan, S S
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 21 SPECIFIC NUCLEAR REACTORS AND ASSOCIATED PLANTS; EHV AC SYSTEMS; OPERATION; USSR; POWER GENERATION; POWER TRANSMISSION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; AC SYSTEMS; EUROPE; NUCLEAR FACILITIES; POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; 200301* - Power Transmission & Distribution- AC Systems, EHV & UHV- (-1989); 200100 - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Power Plants & Power Generation; 130000 - Hydro Energy; 210000 - Nuclear Power Plants
DESCRIPTION: In 1965, 507 billion kWh of electricity was produced in the Soviet Union, and the total generating capacity of its power stations reached 114,000 MW. The total length of transmission lines, with voltages of 350 kV and higher, ran to 312,000 km. The capacity of the European power interconnections of the U.S.S.R. exceeded 68,000 MW in March 1966. The control of the power industry is centralized under the Ministry of Power and Electrification of the U.S.S.R. Ninety-four percent of its electric energy is generated at power stations that are part of interconnected systems. Thermal stations predominate; their generating capacity accounts for 77% of the total installed generation. Hydroelectric plants represent 22% of the total capacity and 18% of the total output. About one percent of the total power production is from nuclear plants. Thirty-six percent of the thermal plants are equipped to transmit heat energy as well as electric power.
